site_title: Google aims to put Android in everything you do
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Google aims to put Android in everything you do

Published

Sun, Jun 29, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SAN FRANCISCO] Google Inc is on a mission to make its Android mobile software ubiquitous.

In a series of announcements last week at its annual developer conference, Google unveiled a new version of the software for handsets and tablets and showed it in use in smartwatches, cars and a new television service.

That puts Android not only into gadgets that people carry with them wherever they go, but also increasingly into their living rooms, onto their bodies and in how they transport themselves.

Google wants to provide a "seamless experience across all these connected devices", Android chief Sundar Pichai said. "We're making everything contextually aware. We want to know when you're at home, with your kids."

The Web search giant is expanding Android as an underlying software foundation to become a digital gatekeeper to consumers. The more that Google can connect devices, vehicles and other items with its software, the more likely it is that consumers will stick with the company for all their needs.

Rivals like Apple and Amazon are also pushing to tie more services and devices together. Earlier this month, Apple showed how its iOS software for the iPad and iPhone and its Mac operating system are increasingly working together, with a customer able to answer a call to an iPhone on his or her iMac. Apple is also looking to get into smartwatches to broaden its product ecosystem.

Amazon has introduced Fire Phone, a smartphone that is closely connected to the Web retailer's online store and library of movies plus other content.

Google is looking to add new features as well, including 3-D technologies for mobile phones and tablets. The effort, called Project Tango, will be included in a device from LG Electronics next year, Johnny Lee, technical project lead for the group at Google, said at last week's conference.

The technologies can help users easily render 3-D images of a home and also offer new opportunities for games and other applications, he said.

"With Apple already in the TV and car space and rumoured to be attacking wearables, Google doesn't want developers to have any excuse to choose Apple's ecosystem over Android," Carl Howe, an analyst with the Yankee Group, said. "Therefore, Google wants to ensure that it is in all those places too."

Smartphones based on Android, which Google gives to hardware manufacturers for free, made up 78 per cent of the global industry in 2013, up from 66 per cent in 2012, according to Gartner Inc. The No 2 player was Apple's iPhone, which had 16 per cent, down from 19 per cent.

The new version of Android, dubbed L, will let them easily implement features such as animations and will include more privacy tools, executives said. It also has a feature that lets people disable their smartphones if they get stolen.

"We have been working very hard," Mr Pichai said, adding that Android now has more than one billion active users. "This is one of the most comprehensive releases we have done."

That inclusive approach extended into a battery of new gadgets and areas where Android will play. Google announced new smartwatches at the event, with one from LG Electronics that had apps loaded onto it and that is available through Google's Play online store. Some of the watches have capabilities that enable it to be used as a remote control for other devices. - Bloomberg

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Click with event-planning

Event-planning for anything from a wedding, an exhibition or a staged gig is now a breeze online. BT Weekend susses out the go-to sites that take the legwork - and guesswork - out of planning for that big day

Published

Fri, Jun 27, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Venuerific

www.venuerific.com/sg

Tasked with booking your company's annual corporate dinner? Finding the right event space for that often can be a painfully tedious process of back and forths as you get on the phone, scour the internet or trek through town to view options.

31-year-old Ricardo Sentosa wants to make things easier so last year, he launched a website called Venuerific, which lists over 200 available-for-rent event spaces around Singapore. These includes restaurants, pubs, convention halls, rooftops and even yachts. Think of it as an Airbnb for restaurants.

Through the website, consumers can check a space's maximum capacity, amenities, location and even request for a quote to see if the estimated price displayed is within their budget.

Prices of the venues depend on factors such as time of day and duration, but in general, people can expect to pay a minimum of about $3,000 to rent a section of a bar or cafe for a few hours or at least $1,000 for a yacht for five hours. "The idea came to me early last year, when I realised that the 'sharing economy' was real," says Mr Sentosa, who holds a degree in accounting and finance.

"A huge tectonic shift was under way, and it would disrupt traditional notions of consumption and ownership. It was around that time that Airbnb, one of the pioneers in the space, was beginning to see significant traction.

"That's when it hit me - if Airbnb allowed people to monetise their living spaces, then what about other spaces that could be used for other purposes? People could discover unique spaces for their events, and venue owners can turn their under-utilised capacity into gold - it's win-win," he adds.

Since its launch in September last year, Venuerific has grown to now even offer spaces for rent in Hong Kong and Malaysia. Most of the events booked through their website so far tend to be corporate events such as product launches or office parties, but there have also been birthdays and wedding events.

As for venue types, what he hopes for in the future is to have more unique private spaces listed on the website such as wine galleries, vacation homes or even private condominiums. But for now, most of their energy is focused on trying to get the word out there that there's a more convenient way to book an event space.

"In the long-term, our aim is to create a flexible and wide-reaching ecosystem which would touch on every aspect of the events value chain. Part of that strategy will also be to work with other startups in the same space to create an integrated platform. That way, we can be a one-stop event-planning solution. At least, that's my dream," says Mr Sentosa.

0.5ha Tuas industrial site triggered for sale

Committed bid price not less than $3,527,300

Mindy Tan

Published

Mon, Jun 30, 2014 · 10:00 PM

A 0.5 hectare industrial land parcel at Tuas South Street 7 has been triggered from the reserve list with an application of a committed bid price of not less than $3,527,300.

This translates to about $65.5 per square foot (psf) for the 5,000 square metre site which has a maximum permissible gross plot ratio of 1.0. Plot 44 has a tenure of 20 years and 10 months, and is zoned for Business-2 development.

Ong Kah Seng, director at R'ST Research, said that he expects the site to attract between five and 10 bids, and the top bid to be in the range of $85 to $110 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr).

"It is quite within expectations that this site is triggered for sale in 2014 as it is an optimal size for medium-scale industrialists," said Mr Ong. "Also, there's limited sites around 0.5 ha available in the H2 2014 Industrial Government Land Sales Programme (IGLS) for sale."

Nicholas Mak, executive director, research and consultancy at SLP International, said that he expects the site to receive a top bid of between $66 and $75 psf ppr.

"The subject site has been removed from the reserve list of the IGLS programme for H2 2014 which will take effect from July 1. Thus, the party who applied for the subject site to be released for tender probably really wanted to acquire this land parcel."

Mr Mak said that he expects the site - which is rectangular in shape with dual frontages - to attract between five and eight bidders.

According to Mr Ong, the site is ideal for a low-rise single-user factory.

"(This site is ideal) particularly for industrialists who engage in fairly labour-intensive and pollutive activities given that the space allocated for such use is set to diminish as Singapore moves toward high-tech and value-added industrial activities," he noted.

The public tender for the land parcel is scheduled for end-July with a tender period of six weeks.

site_title: Board alert for the Personal Data Protection Act
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Board alert for the Personal Data Protection Act

Singapore companies should implement measures to comply with their obligations under the new law, writes YEOH OON JIN

Published

Sun, Jun 29, 2014 · 10:00 PM

PARLIAMENT passed the Singapore Personal Data Protection Act (PDPA) in October 2012. This new law primes the consumer to be more aware of his rights over his personal data collected by companies, and how it can be used in any business-to-consumer relationship.

The first phase of the PDPA came into effect on Jan 2 this year with the Do-Not-Call Registry. Each company should already have in place a system to ensure that individuals who have listed themselves on the registry are not contacted for marketing activities through phone, SMS and fax unless explicit consent has been obtained from the individuals.

The remaining PDPA rules which govern the collection, use and disclosure of personal data will soon become effective on Wednesday.

Complying with the PDPA

Compliance with the new law should be taken seriously. Besides damage to a company's reputation, any substantiated complaint can attract a fine of up to $1 million or imprisonment.

Accordingly, all Singapore companies should implement measures to comply with their obligations under the new act. Compliance includes implementing effective measures for access and correction requests, obtaining consent for the collection, use and disclosure of personal data and ensuring that the personal data collected is accurate and complete.

Significantly, whenever and wherever data is transferred outside Singapore, the onus is on the company to ensure that the recipient provides a comparable level of data protection as that afforded to the individual in Singapore under the PDPA.

Companies also need to appoint a Data Protection Officer to establish, implement, communicate and enforce the company's data protection policies and practices. This includes the important process of receiving and managing complaints. Contact details of the company's Data Protection Officer as well as the company's policies and practices must also be publicly available on request.

What should concern the board?

The board needs to exercise its supervisory powers over management to ensure that it has used reasonable efforts to implement a robust compliance framework for the PDPA and the Do-Not-Call Registry requirements. Developing a stringent framework should serve as a reliable defence against any data protection complaints against the company.

As a minimum, the board should assess whether the specific statutory obligations set out in the PDPA, including the Do-Not-Call Registry requirements, are met. These include having measures for specific collection, retention and destruction of personal data, the training of employees on data protection matters, and the regular monitoring, reporting and auditing of data protection processes and controls.

Compliance with the PDPA is not just a one-time effort, but an on-going process as the quantity of personal data collected and used will certainly increase.

Future developments

The Asia-Pacific region has seen the most rapid development in privacy laws in recent years. In addition to Singapore, both Malaysia and the Philippines recently adopted new data protection regulations. Other countries such as Hong Kong, Australia and New Zealand are tightening existing privacy rules and increasing the penalties for non-compliance and/or data breaches.

However, for the most part, data privacy rules in the Asia Pacific are less stringent than European Union (EU) standards. The EU is currently considering extending its reach extra-territorially, so that companies processing data of EU citizens will have to comply with the EU's data protection laws, regardless of where those companies are incorporated.

The importance of a Singapore company implementing a robust PDPA-compliant framework cannot be over-emphasised. Not only is such a framework essential in providing customers and employees with peace of mind that the personal data in the possession and control of the company remains secure, but it also provides the company with the ability to comply with the PDPA and any international data protection laws that may impact the company in the future.

The writer is a member of the Governing Council of the Singapore Institute of Directors

site_title: Cross over to Suzuki
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Cross over to Suzuki

Suzuki returns to the small SUV segment with the S-Cross compact crossover. By Samuel Ee

Published

Fri, Jun 27, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE Suzuki brand doesn't always produce a winner but occasionally, it does manage to roll out a small but clever car. Take, for example, the Wagon R and Swift - a minivan and hatchback respectively - which amply demonstrate the marque's expertise in efficient packaging.

The Japanese manufacturer has also enjoyed success with the small SUV, like the Jimny and first-generation Vitara. Its latest model, the S-Cross, marks a return to that segment although the model doesn't really look like an SUV nor appear as diminutive.

Suzuki calls the S-Cross a compact crossover. With its inoffensive styling and car-like handling, this COE Category A car looks and drives more like a tall hatchback.

Made in Hungary and aimed primarily at the European market, it has a 1.6-litre naturally aspirated four-cylinder engine to either drive the front wheels or both axles. The four-wheel-drive version, called the Suzuki S-Cross 4WD, features proprietary All-Grip 4WD technology for all-weather, all-terrain performance.

It offers four driving modes - Auto mode, which is mainly front-wheel-drive to maximise fuel efficiency but switches to all-wheel-drive when slip is detected; Sport, where engine and transmission response are heightened and when more torque is distributed to the rear wheels for improved cornering performance; Snow mode, to enhance traction on snowy or slippery surfaces for optimum stability; and Lock mode, which modifies the ESP electronic stability program and distributes torque to help extricate the car out of snow, mud or sand.

In normal conditions, the S-Cross behaves just like a Japanese hatchback would except that it feels European, with well-weighted controls and a nice meaty steering.

Maximum torque of 151 Nm is not much but the relatively low kerb weight (about 1,200 kg) and seven-step continuously variable transmission with steering wheel-mounted shift paddles make it a smooth drive. Progress is more than adequate, while engine noise levels are acceptable for this class of car.

The equipment level is high, with seven airbags, cruise control, auto headlamps, climate control and Bluetooth telephony. A double sliding panoramic sunroof, said to be the world's first, is an option and allows for a very large opening.

At 4.3 metres long and 1.58 metres tall, with a wheelbase of 2,600 mm, the interior is sufficiently spacious. Because the rear occupants sit upright, head and legroom are good. Boot size is also generous, with 60:40 split rear seats to extend the cargo area and a privacy cover that allows access to the boot from within the cabin.

The Suzuki brand has maintained a low profile here in recent times. But the S-Cross should help it to revive interest again.

site_title: Dutch to face stern test from spirited Mexico
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Dutch to face stern test from spirited Mexico

Published

Fri, Jun 27, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE Netherlands has topped Group B with three convincing victories and has sent a very strong signal of their title ambitions. An average of 3.3 goals per game provides ample evidence of their offensive strength in quick counter-attacks, accurate final passes and decisive finishing.

Arjen Robben's mazy runs and clinical finishing offer exciting options to their offensive forays. In-form Robin van Persie seems to revel in his captaincy role with three goals to his credit. Substitutions made during the final group match against Chile bear evidence of the depth at the bench and the uncanny ability of Louis van Gaal to make impactful changes. Their vulnerability on the left side of the defensive third will be tested when faced with stiffer competition. Coping with the publicity and high expectations will be crucial to their progress in this tournament. In Van Gaal, the Dutch has one of the best tutors of uncompromising team discipline and cohesion. His knowledge of the game and ability to manage the egos of the great talent under his watch will be telling.

Mexico's progress in the tournament has been impressive too. Unbeaten with two wins and a draw, they have shown excellent organisation in defence and attack. Adopting a 5-3-2 formation with clear emphasis on defensive discipline and allowing the wing backs to provide timely options for playmaker Andres Guardado and the lively attacking duo of Giovani dos Santos and Oribe Peralta have worked well.

In a commendable 0-0 draw with Brazil, they showed their defensive strength in numbers to thwart several Brazilian attempts at goal. Excellent goalkeeping by Guillermo Ochoa denied the prolific Neymar on at least two occasions. Ochoa will have to be at his best once again. Skipper Rafael Marquez and his men will be tested in set-pieces, penetrating runs from Robben and swift crosses into the six-yard box. Maintaining full concentration will be crucial to their success. The defensive slip that resulted in Croatia securing a consolation goal in their last outing is an example of Mexico's lapse in concentration.

Mexico's turnaround on the back of a rocky qualifying campaign owes much to Coach Miguel Herrera inspirational leadership. He has motivated and transformed a tentative team into a confident and disciplined side. He is able to bring out the best from his players.

Netherlands will face a very stern test from a spirited Mexican side with the ability to test the title credentials of the Dutch. However, the offensive prowess of Robben may just provide the moment of brilliance to secure a narrow victory for the Dutch.

site_title: NUS price index for private homes up 0.8% in May
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

NUS price index for private homes up 0.8% in May

Increase marks first gain for Overall SRPI after 9 consecutive months of declines

Kalpana Rashiwala

Published

Mon, Jun 30, 2014 · 10:00 PM

NATIONAL University of Singapore's (NUS) price indices for completed non-landed private homes rose month on month in May, after straight declines for several months. Its latest flash estimate shows that the Overall Singapore Residential Price Index (SRPI) rose 0.8 per cent in May from the revised value for April - after slipping one per cent in April over the previous month.

The increase marked the first gain for the index after nine consecutive months of declines between August 2013 and April this year. May's flash estimate is down 6.3 per cent from the recent peak in July 2013. Year on year, the May index value is down 6 per cent.

Commenting on the month-on-month appreciation based on the May flash estimate, associate professor Lum Sau Kim of the university's Department of Real Estate said the May indices were "perhaps boosted in part by the more active sales in the primary market during May".

"Going forward, the lower activity that is often the case in June may result in a small dip in the indices.

"Our general view based on the evidence thus far suggests that the market seems to be moderating slowly, with price levels that are still high due to the strength of holding power of many participants. The effects of newly completing supply have yet to kick in to induce larger price corrections for completed non-landed private homes," she added.

SLP International executive director Nicholas Mak too predicted that the Overall SRPI may contract in June. "Buying demand would be weaker in June due to the school holidays and the World Cup drawing the attention of market participants away from the real estate market," he said.

Savills Singapore research head Alan Cheong said that amid current anaemic transaction volumes, data interpretation becomes tricky. Illustrating his point, he said that raw caveats information from the URA Realis system shows the overall average transacted resale price for non-landed private homes fell 6.2 per cent year on year in May 2014. However, if one were to do a finer split by regions and size, the picture changes.

"For example, take URA's Core Central Region (CCR), which most observers are very negative about. In May, the average transacted resale price for units 70 sq metres and below, actually went up 6.9 per cent year-on-year. It is only for units larger than 70 square metres (753.47 sq ft) that recorded a 5.4 per cent price decline.

"The same price behaviour is exhibited for the Rest of Central Region and Outside Central Region."

In the face of the total debt servicing ratio (TDSR) framework introduced in June last year, developers have been building smaller units to achieve aggressive per square foot prices. "The resale market takes its cue from the primary market, ie, resale prices for completed units fare better for smaller units than bigger units," he added.

"Here, we are simply using raw data without subjecting it to more sophisticated data management tools. With developers dynamically reacting to policies like the TDSR framework, today, they are likely to build on average smaller units than they had launched as recently as a year ago. If the policies get tweaked, they will react accordingly. There is no foolproof way for any index to capture the entire dynamics of the market," said Mr Cheong.

NUS's flash estimates yesterday showed the SRPI for Central Region (excluding small units of up to 506 sq ft) rose 0.7 per cent month on month in May, after easing 0.1 per cent in April. The latest May flash estimate reflects a 7.5 per cent year-on-year drop.

Central Region is defined as districts 1-4 (including the financial district and Sentosa Cove) and the traditional prime districts 9, 10 and 11 by the university's Institute of Real Estate Studies, which minted the SRPI series tracking prices of completed private apartments and condos (excluding executive condos).

The sub-index for Non-Central Region, again excluding small units, rose 0.8 per cent in May after sliding 1.9 per cent in April. The May figure translates to a 5 per cent year-on-year drop.

Prices of small apartments and condo units (up to 506 sq ft) islandwide climbed 0.8 per cent in May - against April's one per cent decrease. Year-on-year, the drop is 3.1 per cent. This is the smallest decrease of the four indices.

site_title: Delivery of big liftboat lifts Triyards' record
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Delivery of big liftboat lifts Triyards' record

450-ft self-elevating unit handed over to a unit of Ezion Hldgs

Anita Gabriel

Published

Mon, Jun 30, 2014 · 10:00 PM

SOME 20 months and US$90 million later, Singapore's mainboard-listed Triyards Holdings has handed over the 450-foot lattice-legged self-elevating unit (SEU), one of the world's largest liftboats, to a unit of Ezion Holdings.

On several levels, it marks a crucial point for Triyards, the fabrication arm of parent Ezra Holdings, which built the state-of-the-art vessel known as BH450 at Saigon Shipyard, one of two yards it owns in Vietnam apart from a third it owns in Houston, Texas.

For one thing, it rachets up Triyards' status in the SEU space, where it already enjoys a tidy niche and leading position in South-east Asia.

"We are climbing up the complexity chain in terms of fabrication and engineering. The value proposition of Triyard is not in our balance sheet but in our track record," said Triyards chief executive Chan Eng Yew in an interview with The Business Times.

In a landscape fixated with scale and depth, this proprietary-designed workboat is impressive with a vast open deck which can carry up to 250 passengers and three lattice legs that allow it to operate in deeper waters of up to 105 metres and can withstand harsher wind, wave and currents.

In business speak, it widens the net for Triyards - a firm with a market value of just over $180 million - to capture more clients, predominantly in the oil and gas space. That way, the timing is spot on too.

Liftboats are breaking out of their traditional oil and gas market in the Gulf of Mexico where they are most preferred for shallow-water jobs due to their lower down time and stable elevated work platform, and are gaining a foothold among key operators in other parts of the world.

According to Mr Chan, they are becoming popular in West Africa, the Middle East and South-east Asia, the latter two regions being key markets where Triyards is hoping to expand its presence.

Industry data further sweetens the expectation over a big room for growth. According to a Macquarie Research report last year, the ratio of SEUs to platforms in North America works out to some one to 14 (based on 240 SEUs and 3,257 platforms) whereas in South-east Asia, the Middle East and West Africa, it stands at one to 60 (54 SEUs and 3,266 platforms).

In short, the market potential in non-traditional markets is huge - some 179 SEUs huge, to be precise.

"This discrepancy is another thing we are excited about as it would take a lot of SEUs to rebalance the ratio," said Mr Chan.

The self-propelled SEU - they are also known as liftboats or service rigs which are used to support offshore activities, for example, maintenance of oil and gas well platforms - is the seventh unit that Triyards has delivered since 2007.

For the firm's captains, it is no less significant. The delivery of this vessel marks a rainbow moment for Triyards' long-time former boss Wong Bheet Huan, who stepped down in February from the helm to assume a less active but more advisory role as part of a "semi-retirement" plan. The job to build the sophisticated SEU was bagged during his leadership.

It also sets in motion what Mr Chan himself refers to as his key mandate at the firm since he took over the helm five months ago - to go out there, woo clients and make good on the investments that have been ploughed to fully develop the yards.

The facility in Houston, which makes cranes, winches and other equipment, is gradually being turned into a distribution spot while a bulk of the fabrication is done in Vietnam - both for its cheap labour and material costs and its strategic proximity to active shipbuilding markets of China and South-east Asia.

That's a clever move. According to Mr Chan, the firm has enjoyed hefty cost savings of up to 40 per cent by simply doing that.

To further lift fortunes, Triyards has gone into ship repair, another move that has been fruitful. The firm's order book as at August last year stood at US$217 million.

site_title: Economists expecting 'market-moving' week
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Economists expecting 'market-moving' week

Key reports to be released include jobs, pending home sales, carmakers sales, among others

Published

Sun, Jun 29, 2014 · 10:00 PM

LAST week, major US stock indices lost a little ground, but they could easily set new record highs this week as long as economic data is neither too hot nor too cold.

After a slow start to the summer, this promises to be a "market-moving week", said economists at brokerage Nomura Securities, in a research note. The June jobs report on Thursday will cap a four-day week into which it feels like "four weeks" worth of data has been compressed. Other key reports include pending home sales, the Institute for Supply Management's surveys of both the services and manufacturing sectors and sales reports from major US car manufacturers.

Strategists say that the data has taken on a new urgency now that the extent of the first-quarter slowdown has become clear. Last week, the Commerce Department reported that the economy contracted by 2.9 per cent - a quarterly production rate that would be considered bad, even in a recession.

"The final number suggests this was more than just a weather-induced slowdown (even) exports were down," said Quincy Krosby, investment strategist at Prudential Financial. "There's still lingering questions as to the underlying strength of the economy. So the market wants to know "is this economy really growing?"

The economy almost certainly rebounded in the second quarter to around 3 per cent, according to most analyses. For stocks to maintain or build on their already relatively rich valuations, the data will need to corroborate with those analyses.

Any signs in the jobs, services or manufacturing data that the economy did not maintain the 3 per cent pace this month will naturally put a dent in the major stock indices, stoking fears that the first-quarter slowdown was not an anomaly. This is intuitive: a slower than expected growth rate means slower than expected corporate profits and that's clearly bad for stocks. On Wall Street, that's called "bad news is bad news". This week, however, could be one of those occasions when "good news is bad news".

As illustrated in the minutes from its most recent meeting, the Federal Reserve is already looking beyond the end of its gradual unwinding of stimulus, or "tapering", which is due to finish by December. The Fed is now debating when to begin raising interest rates, and, in this context, traders will recoil from data that shows hotter-than-expected growth.

Should the economic data this week surpass economist expectations by too wide a margin, should new jobs this month be far above the 218,000 forecast by economists, for example, stocks could sell off because of how it affects the Fed's rate-hike timetable. The unemployment rate is already out of the danger zone as far as the Fed is concerned.

A pick-up in hiring, which would be consistent with the weekly jobless claims reports, would hint at a relatively tight jobs market in some sectors. When it's easy to find another job, employers have to offer pay raises to hang onto workers. That causes wage inflation, which will quickly translate into price inflation. "Investors have bid up financial assets, buoyed by expectations that global monetary policy will stay easy for a long time," said analysts at brokerage Barclays, in a note to clients.

If imminent rate hikes are priced into the markets in the next few months, stock and bond investors would "find it difficult to repeat second-quarter returns," the analysts added.

Prices for some goods are already rising largely because of wars affecting some of the globe's most productive oilfields and cornfields.

Iraq, the world's third largest oil producer, remains on the brink of civil war, and any further escalation would likely push oil prices through their 2008 record highs. Ukraine, one of the world's biggest grain producers, is at a similar impasse. Food and energy prices will soon hit levels that will crimp consumers' discretionary spending.

Home prices are also rising. While shares of banks, builders and hardware stores have benefited from the recent increase in home prices for now, some analysts fear the housing market could be a victim of its own success. Demand for houses drove up the price, but now high prices may weigh down demand.

After receiving some blame for the last bubbles in housing and oil, the Fed could soon react if prices keep rising. Federal Reserve Bank of St Louis president James Bullard has repeatedly warned that the central bank could raise rates as soon as the first quarter next year

Traders could have a "Goldilocks" week with data that comes in "just right". Like the Three Bears, however, the Fed will eventually spoil the party.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

West Coast port labour talks running out of time

Published

Sun, Jun 29, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[LOS ANGELES] With peak shipping season approaching, US retailers are anxiously monitoring labour negotiations affecting 20,000 workers at West Coast ports that handle more than 40 per cent of goods shipped in ocean containers.

The six-year contract between dockworkers and the employers who operate port terminal and shipping lines expires on July 1 at 5 pm PDT (0000 GMT). It covers workers at 29 ports from California to Washington state, including major hubs in Los Angeles/Long Beach and Seattle/Tacoma.

Representatives for the workers and their employers said they expect container cargo to continue moving until an agreement is reached, but retailers and other business that depend on the ports are still haunted by a costly 2002 shutdown.

"Folks are nervous about what's going to happen once the contract expires," Jonathan Gold, vice-president of supply chain and customs policy for the National Retail Federation, said on Friday. During the months of July through September retailers such as Wal-Mart Stores Inc and Target Corp receive ocean shipments of goods sold during their critical back-to-school and holiday shopping seasons, Mr Gold said.

Labour negotiations at West Coast ports typically extend beyond the contract expiration date. This round of talks could stretch into mid-July, said Wade Gates, spokesman for the Pacific Maritime Association, which represents the port employers. PMA is "not expecting any" work interruptions, he said.

"The negotiators will keep negotiating, the workers will keep working," said Craig Merrilees, spokesman for the International Longshore and Warehouse Union, which represents most of the affected workers.

A breakdown in negotiations resulted in a 10-day lockout at West Coast ports in 2002. That stoppage was estimated to have cost the US economy US$1 billion a day, said Mr Gold, and disrupted supply chains for six months.

The National Association of Manufacturers and NRF estimated in a recent report that a 10-day work stoppage at West Coast ports would cost the US economy US$2.1 billion per day and result in the loss of 169,000 jobs.

Key issues in the talks include rising healthcare costs and the use of outside contract labour. - Reuters

site_title: Audemars Piguet makes major foray into art
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Audemars Piguet makes major foray into art

The luxury brand is set to commission artists for future Art Basels, reports HELMI YUSOF

Published

Thu, Jun 26, 2014 · 10:00 PM

LUXURY watch brand Audemars Piguet is the latest company to sink its teeth into the contemporary art scene. At its Art Basel VIP booth designed by hotshot designer Mathieu Lehanneur, the 141-year-old watch brand launched the new Audemars Piguet Art Commission, which will support the creation of one major artwork annually by an emerging or mid-career artist.

Chief marketing officer Tim Sayler said: "There are many parallels, links and connections between the world of watchmaking and the world of art. We want to inspire art collectors with our renowned watches ... But looking at it from the other perspective, we also want to be inspired by artists, to have a stimulus, to understand how they think."

Source of inspiration

Though the artist will be given free rein to create an artwork of any medium, the company is interested in candidates who look to complex mechanics, technology and science as their source of inspiration.

For its part, Audemars Piguet will help connect artists to state-of-the-art technology, top craft practitioners, scientific thinkers, research centres or design experts to conceptualise and execute their work.

Working with guest curator Marc-Olivier Whaler, the artist will unveil the artwork next year which will be displayed at all three Art Basel fairs: Art Basel Hong Kong, Art Basel, and Art Basel Miami Beach.

Though the watch company began partnering the art fair last year, this is the first time it has embarked on a major art commission of this nature.

Mr Sayler explained: "Our brand has proved many times in history that it is bold and innovative in terms of its watchmaking technology and design ... so we're familiar with the avant garde."

Watchmakers Jules Louis Audemars and Edward Auguste Piguet founded the company in 1875.

And in 1892, they revolutionised watchmaking with the minute repeater, a complex horological feature that allows a watch to tell the time with sound and music.

Other groundbreaking inventions followed, including the full calendar with which the watch can indicate the day of the week, date, month and moon phases; and the dual time function, which lets you keep track of time in two time zones.

In 1972, the company made the bold choice of launching the world's first luxury sports watch in steel called the Royal Oak, which has been a bestseller for it ever since.

Among watch collectors, the brand bears a mark of prestige, precision and exclusivity among watch collectors. For one thing, only 35,000 pieces were handmade last year - a very small number compared to other luxury watch brands that sell more than 500,000 pieces a year.

At Le Brassus, a village in the Vallee de Joux in Switzerland where the brand was born, the media was invited to the Audemars Piguet Museum. Here, there is a vault with precious handwritten records of every watch the company has ever sold. The neatly inscribed details include the model number, the name of the buyer and the country from which he or she came.

Singaporean buyers

Then something amusing happened: museum director Sebastian Vivas opened a book containing the data entries of recent years. And nearly every page shown indicated some four to eight buyers out of the 35 or so listed as being Singaporeans.

"There's Singapore... Singapore... Singapore," said Mr Vivas with a proud smile as he moved his finger down the page.

The museum showcases 250 watches dating back more than a century, but that will increase to as many as 500 when the museum builds a radical new extension that's shaped like a spiral and partly submerged underground.

Its avant garde design, coupled with the company's growing support of contemporary art, all suggest attempts by the company to recast its image as a cutting-edge global brand.

Mr Sayler added: "We think of Audemars Piguet watches as cultural objects that are steeped in history, innovation and creativity - and that's what Art Basel and art mean to us too."

site_title: SingTel's relationship with OTT players complicated
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

SingTel's relationship with OTT players complicated

Telco now cautious on digital acquisitions, two years after announcing ambitions for the space

Published

Thu, Jun 26, 2014 · 10:00 PM

SINGTEL might start treating the providers of platforms like Viber and WhatsApp more like friends than foes - but this doesn't mean its wariness of its freewheeling counterparts has evaporated.

In the group's annual report for the year ended March 31, 2014, which was released yesterday, group chief executive officer Chua Sock Koong said SingTel wants to become the "preferred network partner", both to over-the-top (OTT) players like Viber and WhatsApp as well as the consumers of such services.

SingTel is "exploring various business models" to this end, she said.

As OTT apps like Whats- App and Facebook ride on operators' networks for free, eat into voice calls and erode SMS volumes, telcos have veered between seeing such apps as freeloading rivals or as novel opportunities to monetise data.

Even as SingTel appears to have taken the latter path through its tie-ups with WhatsApp and Facebook, the wariness is still there; group chairman Simon Israel noted in the annual report that OTT companies now offer a myriad of online services and mobile applications that "threaten telcos' traditional revenue streams from voice, SMS, TV and data services".

Ms Chua reminded investors, also in the annual report, that OTT players still need telcos' networks, and that "the underlying connectivity provided by telcos remains the glue that binds OTT providers to their customers".

Referring to the competition that still runs between telcos and OTT players, she said: "As a telco, we have unique assets and capabilities to make our digital services better than many of the OTT players. Many customers prefer to do business with brands they know and trust."

At the same time, however, a note of caution has crept into the group's view on digital acquisitions, two years after it announced its ambitions for the space.

Ms Chua said: ". . . we note that valuations of Internet companies are at record-high levels, and we will remain disciplined about how we acquire new capabilities to build these digital businesses."

SingTel made some big-ticket digital purchases through its digital ad firm Amobee this month, scooping up ad-technology firms Adconion for US$209 million excluding debt, and Kontera for US$150 million.

These deals came out of the S$2 billion kitty SingTel earmarked last year for digital acquisitions running into 2016. Since then, about a quarter of this war chest has been spent.

On the remuneration front, SingTel's annual report said that for FY2014, its group CEO's pay package blipped up a notch after falling 5.8 per cent in FY2013. Ms Chua earned about $4.71 million in total cash and benefits in FY2014, up 2.2 per cent from $4.61 million in FY2013.

The bulk of the increase came from the variable bonus component of her pay package, which rose $100,000 to $2.98 million. The variable bonus comprises a performance bonus and a value-sharing bonus, with the latter tied to the economic profit performance of the group.

Ms Chua's fixed remuneration remained unchanged year-on-year at about $1.65 million.

The slight overall increase was not enough to bump up her pay package to FY2012 levels, when she took home $4.89 million in total cash and benefits.

Where share awards were concerned, she did better year-on-year, having been awarded 102,097 restricted shares and 1,422,663 performance shares for FY2014, up from 98,060 and 1,418,169 in FY2013 respectively.

site_title: Carving their own niche
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Carving their own niche

A leading role in a big brand name restaurant may seem like every F&B staffer's dream, but three food and beverage personalities tell Debbie Yong why they decided to ditch safe havens to go solo

Published

Fri, Jun 27, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Paul Longworth

Rhubarb le Restaurant

3 Duxton Hill

Opens in Aug

WHEN the time came for him to leave Au Petit Salut to strike out on his own, Paul Longworth picked an unusual partner: his boss.

In August, Mr Longworth, 37, will open Rhubarb, a restaurant on Duxton Road with former colleague Jerome Desfonds and Au Petit Salut owner, Alice Low-Ang.

Mr Desfonds was the restaurant manager at Au Petit Salut, while Mr Longworth was its executive chef. Both men left the restaurant earlier this month. According to Mr Longworth, the three parties will "go in three ways" on the new restaurant, which will operate independently of The Salut Group. Besides its fine-dining flagship, the Salut Group also owns French bistro Chez Petit Salut in Holland Village. It closed its second Chez outlet in the Marina Bay Financial Centre last week.

The plan to run a more intimate venture was something Mr Longworth and Mr Desfonds have been germinating since December last year, says the former. "Au Petit Salut is a big restaurant. We've often thought that if we put the same amount of effort as we did at Au Petit Salut into a smaller venture, we could take the food and the whole experience of dining a whole lot further," he elaborates.

Au Petit Salut seats 100 in a standalone colonial black-and-white building in Dempsey, while Rhubarb's two-storey shophouse space will seat 30 on the ground floor, and 16 in the private-dining room upstairs.

Doing the groundwork

"But, we didn't have any financial backers then, just an idea," he says. Fortuitously, APS's owner Alice Low-Ang was also looking to open a smaller outlet, so the three started talking. "You have to be careful who you go into business with. The restaurant industry is not one that is quick to make a profit. With her experience and business knowledge, we believe Alice is the perfect partner for this," he says.

On why he didn't just stay on and open Rhubarb as an outlet within the group, Mr Longworth says: "Au Petit Salut is what it is, it's been like this for a long time. We wanted to start something from scratch, a platform on which I can really stamp my identity."

Which chef, after all, doesn't dream of opening his own restaurant one day?

"I never rushed my career. I never took a job for its money. One needs to be patient and work his way up - but this was always the goal, from Day One," he elaborates. "Even as a junior cook, I always had my eye on the next section: when I was working on the prep station, I would look at the fish section, then when I got there, I wanted to get onto the meat section."

After starting in London's iconic Blueprint Cafe, Mr Longworth built his career on a string of French restaurants such as French brasserie Racine and one Michelin-star Club Gascon before moving to Singapore in 2009. Here, he was the opening head chef of restaurant and wine retail store Oenotheque by Wine Universe at Millenia Walk before moving over to helm Au Petit Salut three years ago. Mr Desfonds, on the other hand, has worked at Michelin star restaurants in Norway, Ireland, Belgium and France and was the restaurant manager at Nicolas le Restaurant before heading the service team at Au Petit Salut for the last three years. Having both lived in Singapore for five years now, Mr Longworth believes that he and Mr Desfonds now "have a good base to do it ourselves".

"You need to understand the local demographics, suppliers, staff, culture and pricing and how you're going to get staff and customers before plunging into a new restaurant," he says.

For instance, instead of building a fully open kitchen with counter seats as current dining trends prescribe, "which makes conversation difficult for groups of more than two", only the kitchen "pass" will be kept open and visible from every table in the restaurant, says Mr Longworth. The pass is where the food presentation is checked and finalised by the kitchen before it is handed over to the service staff. It is usually manned by the head chef.

And though Rhubarb's menu will bear hints of Mr Longworth's classical French training and his love of fruit, he says of his ultimately category-defying cuisine: "We don't care what the trend is, whether Spanish or Peruvian food is in right now. We don't want to follow trends blindly and be left outdated after they have come and gone."

Expect, thus, a small but carefully curated menu that changes as often as possible to give him carte blanche for experimentation. Lunch sets will start at $42 for three courses, while a la carte options will cost from $15 to $30 for starters and $30 to $36 for mains, and degustation menus of $128 and $138 per person. A "very small selection" of Au Petit Salut favourites will be brought over, such as his signature pigeon leg and breast served with rhubarb and rose puree and nut-encrusted grapes a la Aussignac (the latter named in honour of his mentor Pascal Aussignac), and a duck confit served with pumpkin, vanilla and honey-roasted pears.

Black tiles and stainless steel in the kitchen complemented by earthy stone and copper fittings, carpeted floors and rhubarb-hued accents in the dining area will give the half-a-million-dollar outfit a fittingly luxe feel.

"Ultimately, it's not about being your own boss, but having the freedom to do what you love, then you don't need to find security in anyone or any restaurant group," he says.

"You see so many egos in chefs because they are being backed by large groups. But there's no ego for me in doing this. We work hard to produce a product that hopefully people will be willing to spend their hard-earned money to buy.

"That, for me, is all the compliment I need."

site_title: Asian art powers on in Basel
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Asian art powers on in Basel

Art Basel, the world's biggest art fair, saw greater prominence of Asian art and collectors. By HELMI YUSOF

Published

Thu, Jun 26, 2014 · 10:00 PM

GALLERISTS described the unexpected throngs of Asian art collectors at this year's Art Basel art fair in words that parallel a military invasion.

"They came in large numbers on the first day... and it meant really good business for us," said Theresa Liang, director of Long March Space.

"We have Chinese collectors who follow us to every art fair. We'd see them at Art Basel Hong Kong, and then a month later at Art Basel in Basel, and some of them at Art Basel Miami," noted Rene Meile, co-director of Galerie Urs Meile, a Swiss-based gallery with a branch in Beijing.

Art Basel, the world's biggest art fair brand, has three editions: Art Basel Hong Kong in May (though it's moving to March from next year), Art Basel in June, and Art Basel Miami Beach in December.

Most prized artworks

But Art Basel, the original 45-year-old Swiss fair, remains the biggest and most prestigious, with VIP collectors literally elbowing each other on opening day to get their hands on the world's most prized artworks. This year, some 284 galleries from 34 countries were selling US$4 billion worth of art, according to an estimate by insurer AXA Art. Audemars Piguet and UBS, among others, are the fair's partners.

By the first day, a Jeff Koons sculpture of an inflatable dolphin had sold for US$5 million and a Damien Hirst installation of pharmaceutical drugs titled Nothing Is A Problem For Me went for nearly US$6 million. An Andy Warhol self-portrait was snapped up for US$32 million within the first 15 minutes - possibly the most expensive sale at the fair.

The Singapore Tyler Print Institute (STPI), the only Singapore and South-east Asian gallery selected to show in Art Basel, sold a large painting by Thai artist Rirkrit Tiravanija for US$80,000, as well as four mid-sized works by him for US$14,000 each - all on the first day.

STPI's director Emi Eu said: "We met collectors from Central and South America who are huge fans of his art. It's amazing to imagine his work finding a home in that part of the world. I wish we had brought more of his works here, because we ended up selling everything of his." STPI also brought the works of Singapore artist Heman Chong which garnered strong interest among collectors.

Tokyo gallery Take Ninagawa sold its entire booth of works by Shinro Ohtake. And Gallery Side 2, another Tokyo gallery, also sold its entire lot of Fumito Urabe's works.

Indeed, the tills for Asian works were ringing more frequently than it had ever done before in Basel. Even though there were only 21 Asian galleries this year compared to last year's 31, the shortfall was made up for by Western galleries showing Asian artworks - some for the first time. Germany's Galerie Lohrl, for instance, dedicated its entire booth to the sculptures of Japan's Katsura Funakoshi. And Switzerland's Galerie Tschudi showed the photographs of Su-Mei Tse in the hope of attracting more Asian collectors - even though Tse is a half-Chinese and half-English artist born and raised in Luxembourg and is really European.

Major London gallery Victoria Miro placed Yayoi Kusama sculptures and paintings at its entrance, with Sarah Sze's works on the inside. New York's Sean Kelly Gallery and London's Marian Goodman Gallery put a Mariko Mori sculpture and a Yang Fudong photograph respectively at choice locations in their booths to attract the Asian crowd.

"Let's just say everyone's realised for some time the important role Asian collectors play in the market. Putting Asian artworks outside our stands makes perfect sense ... so we can reel them in," said a gallerist, who chose to remain anonymous.

But Long March Space's Ms Liang said it's not just the Asian collectors who are interested in buying Asian artworks. "We're seeing the transition among international collectors too. At first, they were drawn to Asian art because of the wonderful things that were happening the Asian art market ... But we are slowly riding out of that period. More collectors are now looking at Asian art because they actually think the art is good.

"For Asian galleries like us, who have been taking part in art fairs and promoting their artists on the international circuit for years, this is what we've been hoping for all along."

Just last month, Asian art collectors hit the headlines for making up a sizeable portion of buyers at Sotheby's and Christie's auctions in New York. Collectors from Hong Kong, China and South Korea, among others, were seen bidding up the Monets, Picassos and Renoirs. At Sotheby's evening sale, Asian money accounted for US$63.9 million worth of sales, which is almost a third of the US$218 million total sales.

As David Mugrabi, son of the famous art collector Jose Mugrabi who is said to own 800 Warhols, joked: "Most collectors start off buying art from their own country, and then they start to look at art from other countries too ... When it comes to buying art, the hardest part is buying the first one. Once you get started, it's downhill from there."

Defying commerce

To counter the strongly commercial tone of the fair - which some, especially artists, regard with consternation - Art Basel has always worked hard at creating non-commercial, cultural activities surrounding the fair.

Leading the charge this year was 14 Rooms, a special exhibition featuring the world's most famous performance artists, including Yoko Ono, Marina Abramovic and Tino Sehgal. In 14 rooms, each measuring 15m by 5m, human performers became the artworks, meticulously carrying out the instructions given by the artists.

The choice of performance art is critical: performance art is often regarded as the least commercial among art forms, because a collector cannot "own" a performer, so to speak. Typically, the only things for an art collector to buy are the official photographs, instruction manuals for the performers, or other documents.

But in 14 Rooms, all visitors (with few exceptions) were barred from taking pictures, making the experience purely ephemeral and phenomenal - and, hence, hard to commodify.

In Sehgal's room, a male and female performer spoke aloud one word at a time to create complete sentences. But the game took on an unexpectedly competitive and hilarious edge as either party could support or subvert the meaning and direction of the sentence with the addition of one word - such as a "not" or "maybe". The title of this simple but acerbic work? This Is Competition.

Meanwhile, Ono's room opened to a sign that said: "Touch." Upon entering, one plunged into complete darkness with other visitors. One felt one's way along the walls, bumping into strangers, giggling, apologising, and relying on every other sense other than sight, to find the way out.

In Chinese artist Xu Zhen's room, a living and breathing performer stayed motionless in mid-fall, inviting onlookers to contemplate the laws of gravity. Meanwhile, in English artist Ed Atkins' room, a man had a constant argument with a talking 3D computer image over who is more "human" and useful to society - the man or the intelligent computer generated image (CGI). Now, if the man and his competing CGI were to look at Art Basel's strategy, with its delicate balance of commerce and art, they might realise it's possible to find a win-win solution.

site_title: Womenomics is mere talk in Japanese society
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Womenomics is mere talk in Japanese society

Published

Fri, Jun 27, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Tokyo

THE buzzword "womenomics" coined by Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe to describe one element of his "Abenomics" policies may have a sexy ring to it, but unfortunately for him, what it has done is draw attention to the sexist nature of male-dominated Japanese society.

He says that he wishes to make Japan a more woman-friendly society, but this high-sounding sentiment is at odds with the reality of how women are treated at the workplace in Japan, as was made glaringly obvious recently.

The Foreign Correspondents Club of Japan (FCCJ) in Tokyo this week hosted a press conference by Tokyo Metropolitan Assembly member Ayaka Shiomura, who is at the centre of a furore over sexist remarks flung at her by male members when she dared question the city's policies towards helping young mothers to continue working.

A male member of this prefectural parliament of Tokyo reportedly shouted at her: "You're the one who should get married as soon as possible!"

Another taunted her with a question about whether she was able to have children, prompting raucous laughter among the male councillors. Ms Shiomura was reduced to tears by this bullying, which went viral through 20,000 tweets; 35,000 people signed an online petition calling for the offenders to be punished.

Only one among several members of Mr Abe's ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) thought to have been responsible for the heckling, Akihiro Suzuki, has so far come forward to apologise.

Seiko Noda, who chairs the LDP's general council, is urging Mr Abe to appoint more women to his Cabinet; perhaps only in the glare of national television would these women be safer from insults than are their sisters in the metropolitan assemblies, she said.

But discrimination and harassment against women is not limited to government institutions, and risks driving young women to jobs overseas - just when Japan needs them most.

I was reminded of this when I moderated a luncheon speech this week at the FCCJ for Keiko Tashiro, who, in 2009, became the first woman to be appointed a board director of securities house Daiwa - quite an achievement for a "mere" woman.

It was no coincidence that she was hired by Daiwa - one of the more progressive Japanese firms when it comes to such issues - in 1986, the year a new equal-opportunity law took effect in Japan.

One of only a tiny minority of female graduates to find executive employment in Japan's financial industry at the time, she said that she felt very uncomfortable in a male-dominated environment. She escaped it by pursuing an MBA degree at Stanford and then working in Singapore and London for Daiwa.

Her appointment to Daiwa's board was followed in 2011 by that of Junko Nakagawa as chief financial officer of Daiwa's larger rival Nomura Securities, although Ms Nakagawa has since stepped down from the position. But these exceptions only prove the rule that high-level female executive appointments are rare in Japan.

How does all this sit with womenomics?

The truth is that Mr Abe appears to be rather more concerned with finding a solution to Japan's demographic problems than he does with gender equality.

The nation's population is shrinking and the workforce along with it. Only one thing surpasses misogyny in Japan - the dislike of foreigners or gaijin. This makes large-scale immigration taboo.

So Mr Abe wants to maximise the use of women in the workforce. His New Economic Strategy unveiled this week proposes raising the proportion of women in corporate management from just 7.5 per cent now to 30 per cent by 2020.

But will this solve Japan's problems at anything other than a numerical level? No, said Ms Tashiro, who now works in the US for Daiwa. She said: "It's not just about numbers; it's about diversity."

Others have argued along similar lines, saying that a better mix among genders, ages and races from diverse backgrounds would give more stability - along with economic viability - to Japanese business and society in the long run.

Meanwhile, critics say that Mr Abe's drive to get more women into the workplace is at odds with his desire to see Japanese women produce more babies in order to arrest the nation's declining population and stabilise it at around 100 million.

Ms Tashiro argued that the reverse is true: women are more likely to work if they have access to good child-care facilities.

But male-chauvinist Japanese men obviously believe that a woman's place is in the home - and that she should stay there.

site_title: Great Eastern and shareholders unfazed by CEO's resignation
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Great Eastern and shareholders unfazed by CEO's resignation

Published

Fri, Jun 27, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

GREAT Eastern Holdings chairman Norman Ip's predecessor had had five months before she had to find a new chief executive.

Mr Ip has no such luxury. Less than three months into his appointment, current chief executive Chris Wei announced on Thursday that he will be joining rival Aviva plc.

But what are unfortunate events to an insurance company? Great Eastern yesterday told The Business Times that, despite the leadership changes, the business remains on track and in steady hands.

Its spokesman Tan Seck Geok said: "It is business as usual for us at Great Eastern. Our core business fundamentals remain sound and we are well-placed to build on our good business momentum, helmed by Mr Norman Ip who is no stranger to Great Eastern and has been on the board since 2010.

"We have in place a strong and dedicated management team in the countries where we operate who are committed to serving our customers and markets with the best insurance services and financial products."

Mr Ip will assume an executive role until a replacement is found. He became chairman in April after his predecessor Fang Ai Lian chose not to seek re-election.

Ms Tan said candidates must be familiar with the industry and share Great Eastern's core values.

Mr Wei, who will be Aviva's Asia chairman and chief executive of global life insurance, said he left for personal reasons and to spend more time with his family in Hong Kong. His last day at Great Eastern is Sept 30.

Under Mr Wei's leadership, Great Eastern was named Life Insurance Company of the Year in 2011 and 2013 by the Asia Insurance Industry Awards.

In the stock market yesterday, investors took the resignation news in their stride. Great Eastern shares slipped marginally by 0.6 per cent, or 14 cents, to close at $22.06 on Friday.

Major shareholder OCBC Bank, which holds about 87 per cent of Great Eastern's shares, declined comment.

site_title: Here to prove she's no 'one-hit wonder'
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Here to prove she's no 'one-hit wonder'

Published

Thu, Jun 26, 2014 · 10:00 PM

WHEN German-born artist Stefanie Hauger took home US$35,000 after winning the 2013 UOB Painting of the Year title for Singapore and South-east Asia, the art world buzzed with criticism about the judges' decision.

Since Hauger had started her career as a full-time artist only in 2011, some questioned whether her winning work, Space Odyssey, deserved to win over the works of more prominent artists, such as Indonesian painter Suroso Isur.

But now, just months after the award was announced in November, Hauger is putting on her maiden solo exhibition,New Horizons.

The exhibition features two series of her work - "Mandala", which includes Space Odyssey, and "Moments". The two represent what Hauger calls the "yin and yang" of her art, and are on display at the UOB Art Gallery until Aug 1.

While the "Mandala" series was created by pouring paint and rotating the canvas to create unpredictable swirls of colour, the "Moments" series is more deliberate, and required the artist to drag and scrape paint across the canvas.

Through this exhibition, Hauger hopes to be able to show people that she is in fact a serious artist.

"When I won the prize, I was a very young artist, and everybody knows that. And that was a moment when I said: 'Okay, for now to be taken seriously I have to produce a body of work which is substantial and shows I can do other things.' I'm not a one-hit wonder," she says.

And Hauger is just the first Painting of the Year artist who will be exhibiting at the 108 square-metre newly refurbished UOB Art Gallery.

The space, which was originally set aside to display pieces from UOB's own art collection, will now be reserved for Painting of the Year alumni to showcase their works. This was announced at a closed-door session on Wednesday, when UOB also unveiled details of this year's competition.

One major change is that the entry period has been doubled from the original two months, lasting from now until Oct 12. Aside from that, the competition will remain the same as last year, after the new categories for emerging and established artists were introduced.

When asked what she would be looking out for in this year's winner, one of the judges, Bridget Tan, says she hopes to see relevance and emotion.

"I think the first thing to say is in general at any one time there is no single standard as to what would be a winning work," says Ms Tan, who is the director of the Institute of Southeast Asian Arts at the Nanyang Academy of Fine Arts.

"It's always a consensus of the moment and that is largely determined by the profiles of the individual judges. But what I would look for would be something that is of its time. . . And I think emotion is important too. One of the things we overlook in contemporary art is the emotional aspect. These two things are important," she says.

New Horizons' runs at the UOB Art Gallery at the lobby of UOB Plaza One from Monday to Friday, 9am to 6.30pm, and on Saturday, 9am to 2pm. Admission is free

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

IPS Securex making Catalist debut

Published

Fri, Jun 27, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

THE trading of shares of IPS Securex Holdings Limited, a provider of security products and integrated security solutions, starts on Monday after all its placement units were subscribed.

IPS Securex launched its initial public offering (IPO) with a placement of 12 million new shares at $0.35 each, in conjunction with its proposed listing on the Catalist board of the Singapore Exchange.

As at the close of the IPO at noon on Thursday, all the 12 million placement shares were validly subscribed, raising gross proceeds of $4.2 million and net proceeds of approximately $2.7 million. The 12 million placement shares represent 16 per cent of the enlarged share capital of 75 million shares of IPS Securex.

At $0.35 per share, the placement is priced at a price earnings ratio of 13 times based on the group's historical earnings per share of 2.7 cents for the financial year ended June 30, 2013, and pre-placement share capital of 63 million shares.

Commenting on the IPO, Kelvin Lim, executive director and chief executive officer of IPS Securex, said: "We hope our listing on Catalist will not only enhance the public image of our group locally and overseas, and open up more business opportunities, but will also help to attract and retain talent."

The group said that over the last 14 years, its business in Singapore and the region has been driven by its ability to be a one-stop security solutions provider. Mr Lim added that the company is well-positioned to expand its business both in Singapore and Asia-Pacific, "where demand for security products and solutions has risen since the events of 9-11".

United Overseas Bank is the sponsor, issue manager and placement agent of the IPO.

Speculation continues as Aspial CEO ups LCD stake

Published

Thu, Jun 26, 2014 · 10:00 PM

ASPIAL Corporation chief executive Koh Wee Seng has continued to buy shares in LCD Global Investments at prices above the 17 cents a share buyout offer from Lum Chang's Raymond and David Lum - fuelling further market talk of a counter-bid.

On Wednesday, Mr Koh bought 100,000 shares at 28.5 cents, raising his total stake in the company to 15.24 per cent. Since last month, he has gradually built up his stake in LCD - which owns, develops and manages hotels and resorts globally - by buying shares on the open market for as much as 30 cents a share.

Mr Koh's purchases - at prices significantly higher than the 17 cents a share the Lum brothers offered shareholders in April - have sparked market chatter that he may make a competing offer, or is attempting to push the offerors to raise their bid price.

LCD's independent financial adviser had said that the offer was fair when viewed in relation to historical market share prices, but "not so compelling" in light of LCD's net asset value of 27.2 cents per share.

The offer, whose closing date was earlier extended to June 23, has been extended again to July 11. As at June 23, the offerors received valid acceptances representing 3.86 per cent of LCD's issued share capital.

Mr David Lum is the senior executive director of LCD and managing director of listed construction and property company Lum Chang Holdings, while his brother Raymond is Lum Chang's executive chairman. Including valid acceptances, they and parties acting in concert with them controlled a total of 35.98 per cent of LCD's issued share capital, as at June 23.

Mr Koh's Aspial has a property arm, residential real estate developer World Class Land, and Mr Koh himself also holds a 10.3 per cent stake in property and construction group TA Corp, according to its 2013 annual report.

LCD's share price closed flat at 29 cents yesterday.

site_title: Downside risks cloud S'pore growth
content:
Downside risks cloud S'pore growth

Surprise 2.5% fall seen in May factory output

Published

Thu, Jun 26, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] The Republic's economic growth now faces downside risks for Q2 and 2014 after the manufacturing sector slipped into contraction mode last month, for the first time since June last year.

Surprised by the dismal performance, private-sector economists now say that full-year GDP growth will fall short of earlier forecasts - and will, in all likelihood, be lower than 2013's 3.9 per cent expansion.

Contrary to expectations, factory output declined 2.5 per cent in May year-on-year (sharply down from April's upwardly-revised 5.3 per cent increase), pulled lower by drops in both the electronics and biomedical manufacturing clusters.

Economists polled by Bloomberg before the Singapore Economic Development Board (EDB) released the numbers yesterday had been expecting industrial production to rise by 2.4 per cent; only two of the 23 economists surveyed had anticipated May's contraction in factory output.

Excluding the volatile biomedical sector - which contracted 9.2 per cent last month on lower production of active pharmaceutical ingredients - output would still have fallen, albeit by a smaller 0.5 per cent.

The electronics cluster, which retains the largest weight of 33.4 per cent on the industrial production index, proved the biggest drag on manufacturing output. Electronics production fell 7.5 per cent year-on-year in May; the semiconductors, computer peripherals, and data storage segments fell 6.4 per cent, 11.8 per cent, and 29.2 per cent respectively.

Output of all other clusters rose, except general manufacturing industries which fell 1.1 per cent.

EDB said that after adjusting for seasonal factors, industrial production contracted 5.7 per cent month-on-month in May - far larger than forecasters' expectations of a 0.6 per cent decline. Excluding biomedical manufacturing, output would have increased 0.4 per cent.

Economists were expecting the hit to electronics production, given EDB's April report which stated that a "one-off" and "firm-specific factor" will cause a "decline . . . in year-on-year growth for the rest of the year" in the semiconductors segment.

But while economists have been forewarned of the contraction in semiconductor output, they are still trying to figure out the magnitude of the impact - especially since EDB has continued to decline to share the name of the company, the specific reasons for the output fall, and the nature of the company's operations, citing company confidentiality reasons.

"Add to that the volatility of the biomedical cluster - sure susah lah," said CIMB economist Song Seng Wun, using a Malay term to describe the challenging situation. Indeed, the pull-back in biomedical manufacturing - which posted double-digit expansions in February, March

and April - resulted in a "double-whammy" effect on overall factory output, and caught most off-guard.

The latest data has turned economists more pessimistic about Singapore's growth prospects not just for Q2, but for 2014 as a whole.

UOB economist Francis Tan has revised his full-year industrial production forecast down to 3.5 per cent from 5 per cent previously; his Q2 GDP growth forecast of 4 per cent could also "potentially be downgraded" to 3.1 per cent. The government is expected to release its advance Q2 GDP estimates by mid-July.

While Mr Tan and ANZ economist Daniel Wilson are waiting "a few more months" to get a clearer picture of electronics' (and therefore manufacturing's) performance, they agree that 2014 GDP growth will likely come under last year's 3.9 per cent expansion.

CIMB's Mr Song has tempered his initial expectations of 4.3 per cent economic growth to 3.8 per cent; Citi economist Kit Wei Zheng sees "small downside risks" to his 3.5 per cent forecast for 2014, although growth above 3 per cent remains "possible" in his view.

Several economists also flagged the increasing downside risk to the long-awaited export-led recovery in the second half of this year. Mr Song said that this is especially "with the return of geopolitical risks from the unfolding civil war in Iraq, (which has been) pushing up oil prices and pushing down consumer confidence".

Still, other economists such as Barclays's Leong Wai Ho and OCBC's Selena Ling remain sanguine about the manufacturing sector here; the former "continues to see room for a recovery in (the electronics) sector as the US investment cycle gathers steam".

Added Ms Ling: "This marks a breather in Q2 manufacturing growth momentum, but should not detract from the steady but stable GDP growth trajectory expected for Singapore for the year as a whole."

site_title: More global IPOs expected in second half
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

More global IPOs expected in second half

Published

Thu, Jun 26, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE steady appetite for global initial public offerings (IPOs) is expected to continue in the second half of the year, despite heightened investor caution.

This follows economic recovery in many markets as equity indices remain buoyant and volatility is on a downward trend, according to EY Global IPO Trends: 2014 Q2 released yesterday.

The report said that a significant uptick of IPOs in the second half of the year is expected to come from the financial, real estate, technology and consumer products and services sectors.

Maria Pinelli, EY's global vice-chair of strategic growth markets, said: "With a solid pipeline of IPO-ready businesses across a broad range of geographic markets and from multiple sectors, there is no shortage of supply."

But she noted that this will "increase the pressure on pricing as investors will be wary of meeting over-optimistic valuations".

In the first half of 2014, there were 588 deals raising around US$117.7 billion, an increase of 60 per cent and 67 per cent respectively on the same period in 2013 and the highest amount of capital raised in the first half since 2007.

In the second quarter, there were 333 IPOs raising US$70.7 billion, a 30.6 per cent increase on the previous quarter and a rise of 62.4 per cent compared to the same quarter last year, by deal numbers.

There was a fall in first-day returns but IPO stocks in the second quarter are still outperforming the broader equity markets in many places.

The report stated that activity in the first six months was spread broadly across sectors, with health care the most active at 103 IPOs, more than double the volume from the same period in 2013.

Technology IPOs doubled in number (78 IPOs), while energy raised the most capital through IPOs in the first six months of 2014 (US$17.6 billion).

Asia-Pacific led with the most deals by volume - exchanges saw more IPOs in the first half of 2014 than any other region, with 217 deals raising US$33.7 billion, an increase of 64 per cent and 45 per cent, respectively on the first half of last year.

Four of the 20 largest IPOs in the first six months were on Asian exchanges - three from Hong Kong and one from Tokyo.

While activity slowed in the second quarter compared to the first, Max Loh, EY's Asean and Singapore managing partner, noted that a slew of Chinese companies are expected to list this year, and that it sets the stage "for considerable, albeit constrained, IPO activity in the second half of the year".

Among the top 10 issuers in Asia in the second quarter this year were Singapore-listed PACC Offshore Services Holdings Ltd and Thailand-listed Kaset Thai International Sugar Corp pcl.

Indonesia and Thailand were among the top 10 exchanges by deals in Q2 2014 with eight and seven deals, respectively.

Still, Mr Loh pointed out that the IPO transactions will "need to have the right growth story and be priced right to attract investors".

The report said that Europe saw 162 IPOs raising US$44.5 billion in 2014 so far - an increase of 131 per cent in deal numbers and 351 per cent in capital raised compared to the same period a year ago and the best since 2007, with London leading the region.

In the United States, for the first time in more than 10 years, the second quarter of 2014 was the third consecutive quarter with more than 70 IPOs on its exchanges, marking a stand-out first half of the year, said the report.
