site_title: Music to the ears of the Pioneer Generation
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Music to the ears of the Pioneer Generation

Published

Thu, Jun 26, 2014 · 10:00 PM

IT just got better to be part of the Pioneer Generation as the Philharmonic Youth Winds will be presenting a special concert just for them; and what better way to celebrate it than through the music of their generation.

But Songs Our Parents Love is also poised to be a "win-win" show for everybody as not only do the older audience members get to enjoy an unforgettable show; the younger ones will also get a chance to learn about the music their parents and grandparents listened to when they were younger.

Adrian Cheong, president of The Philharmonic Winds, says that the event is a gift from the Philharmonic Youth Winds performers, as most of them received the opportunity to learn and play music due to the support and encouragement from their parents.

He notes that some of their concerts are considered too heavy or serious for parents to enjoy, though they still attend to support their kids, so they decided to go with a different and lighter programme this time round. Familiar pop oldies such as hits from The Carpenters and tunes from classic Hong Kong television series such as The Bund are just some of the tunes that can be heard at Songs Our Parents Love.

The concert also features collaborations with homegrown talents Lindy Chia and George Chan, who will be performing in Mandarin, Hokkien and Cantonese.

Deciding on the songs was no walk in the park though conductor Adrian Chiang says that the hardest thing for him and arranger Ong Jiin Joo was deciding what should go into the programme.

"We have all listened to our parents' music when we were young," he says, "While we may not have understood many of the songs then, listening to them now gives us a stronger sense of nostalgia, and helps us understand why our parents loved them."

To pick the songs, they decided to get advice from the target audience as well as turning to their parents and other older relatives for recommendations and stories.

"Some of the pieces, like Ballade Pour Adeline Matsuri and Music Box Dancer, convinced my mother to race against her peers to have her son learn the piano," recalls Ong. The memories related to the music, however, are not confined to the pioneer generation. "One of the pieces, Country Roads, was a must-sing during my primary school scout camping trips," he adds.

The audience can also rest assured that most of the pieces are symphonic interpretations that are close to the originals. "We want to showcase the versatility of the wind band sound, but at the same time, we wanted the audience to recognise the music as they heard it 30 to 40 years ago," says Ong.

'Songs Our Parents Love' will be held this Sunday at the Esplanade Concert Hall, at 5pm. Tickets range from $15 for individual tickets to $40 for a package of four. For more information, log on to

www.esplanadesingapore.com

The prequel festival to the Singapore International Festival Of Arts (Sifa), OPEN, or Open Participate Enrich Negotiate, aims to change Singapore's cultural landscape by encouraging audience ownership of ideas, issues and themes. site_title: World Cup may decide Brazil's next leader
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

World Cup may decide Brazil's next leader

Published

Thu, Jun 26, 2014 · 10:00 PM

FOR Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff, the ongoing Fifa World Cup in her country is more than just a football tournament. Should the month-long event run its course without any major hiccups, and should the host nation eventually go on to lift the famous trophy on July 13, these twin successes could well make the difference in whether Ms Rousseff gets re-elected later this year. Last week, the 66-year-old, the first female president in Brazil's history, was officially endorsed by the governing Workers Party to run for a second four-year term in October. While she has promised to boost social policies and invest more heavily in housing, education and public health, Ms Rousseff still faces a barrage of criticism over the billions of dollars that Brazil has spent on this year's World Cup and the Olympic Games to be held in Rio de Janeiro in 2016.

There is still much unhappiness surrounding the organisation of the World Cup, with protesters demanding answers as to how the budget swelled to reach US$11 billion. More than a million people took to the streets last year during the Confederations Cup, a World Cup warm-up event, to argue that the money could have been better spent on improving public services. In the weeks leading up to the tournament, there were more strikes and violent protests. The discontent comes at a time when Brazil's once red-hot economy has slowed down significantly - gross domestic product is expected to grow by just 1.6 per cent in 2014. Ms Rousseff, however, has resolutely maintained that all the investments made in areas such as transport and infrastructure will continue to benefit Brazilians long after the tournament is over.

When the World Cup eventually kicked off on June 12, Ms Rousseff, who was present for the opening ceremony and the first match between Brazil and Croatia, was greeted with boos every time her image was flashed on the big TV screens around the stadium. But for all the criticism hurled at her, it is telling that she still leads her rivals ahead of the Oct 5 election. One poll conducted last week found that 39 per cent of voters support her candidacy, against just 20 per cent for her main opponent Aecio Neves. If no single candidate gets more than 50 per cent of the votes, there will be a run-off on Oct 26.

With Brazil doing well in the World Cup so far - the team went undefeated in the group stage and cruised into the second round - the protest movement has lost some steam of late. While there are still crowds gathering in various cities, the numbers are dwindling. The upcoming election is a crucial one, with the Workers Party facing its biggest electoral challenge since former president Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva came to power back in 2002. Ms Rousseff knows exactly what's at stake. Even with her seemingly comfortable lead in the polls, a trouble-free World Cup, capped off by a Brazil triumph, would mean much less ammunition for her opponents.

site_title: Hello again, Yellow Brick Road
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Hello again, Yellow Brick Road

Dylan Tan

Published

Thu, Jun 26, 2014 · 10:00 PM

A MASTERPIECE is sometimes created when one least expects it - Elton John's seminal 1973 album, Goodbye Yellow Brick Road, is an example. Originally meant to be recorded in Jamaica until political unrest forced the session to be moved to France where it was made in just two weeks, it has become a milestone record for the pop singer and his most commercially successful ever, with over 30 million copies sold worldwide.

Boasting a handful of John's classics including the title track, Saturday Night's Alright for Fighting, Candle in the Wind and Bennie and the Jets, the 17-track double-album has recently been reissued in various editions including a multi-disc deluxe box set to mark its 40th anniversary.

Overseeing it all is Peter Asher, himself a huge pop-star in the sixties and one-half of the folk group Peter and Gordon, before moving to work behind-the-scenes in the music industry as a label head and record producer.

Over the phone from Los Angeles, he states that the intention of the re-release was not to make a classic album sound better.

"Instead I saw it as an opportunity to re-approach the songs everybody already knew and love," clarifies Asher. "But at the same time it was also very intimidating. I said to Elton: 'I don't want anyone to think that I could improve upon anything you, Bernie (Taupin, the lyricist who is John's regular songwriting partner) and Gus Dudgeon (Goodbye Yellow Brick Road's original producer) have created all those years ago.'"

He adds that even with modern recording and remixing technology, there was no way to catch a better drum sound than what Dudgeon had already captured on tape four decades ago - "I used all the brilliant new stuff but that doesn't necessarily make things better because there were amazingly good records made back then by completely different methods."

The goal of the anniversary edition, instead, was to present the songs again in such a way that it reminds the listeners of the pure songwriting genius beneath the critically acclaimed album with rarities like unreleased demos and alternate mixes - including an acoustic version of Candle in the Wind - giving fans the opportunity to listen to Goodbye Yellow Brick Road like it was new.

A bonus disc features nine contemporary music acts like Ed Sheeran, Imelda May and Fall Out Boy covering classic tracks like Saturday Night's Alright for Fighting and Bennie and the Jets. It's likely to draw a new generation of fans to discover for themselves the influence Goodbye Yellow Brick Road had on the history of pop music.

Asher reveals glam rockers Muse was one of the acts he would have liked to cover the album's epic 11-minute-plus opener, Funeral For A Friend/Love Lies Bleeding, if not for a conflict in their touring schedule. But he thinks nothing of the missed opportunity because he is already looking ahead to the record's golden jubilee in a decade's time. "There are still eight songs remaining and a lot of great people left to do them!" he laughs.

site_title: Asiana crash crew 'unfamiliar with auto-throttle'
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Asiana crash crew 'unfamiliar with auto-throttle'

Investigators tell of pilots' deficient training, confusion

Published

Thu, Jun 26, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[WASHINGTON] The crew members of an Asiana Airlines flight that crashed their Boeing 777 against the sea wall at San Francisco International Airport last July had missed multiple cues that they had done something wrong in the seconds before the crash, according to investigators.

But their training was deficient, and they shared widespread confusion about how to use a crucial system, the auto-throttle, according to comments at a meeting held by the National Transportation Safety Board the Tuesday to establish the cause of the crash.

"The flight crew over-relied on automated systems that they did not fully understand," said Christopher Hart, the acting chairman of the board. Crew members unknowingly disabled the auto-throttle, which they thought would keep them from flying too slowly, because they gave multiple instructions to the autopilot during the approach and failed to follow airline procedures in the sequence of instructions and in saying aloud what they were doing.

And despite the fact that the pilot in command had raised the nose to a highly abnormal attitude to slow his too-rapid descent - a cue that the plane was too slow - none of the three pilots in the cockpit reacted until it was too late.

The chief of the safety board's operations group, Capt Roger Cox, said that the pilot "needed more active coaching".

"He showed poor awareness of altitude and airspeed," Capt Cox said. But in the other seat, where the co-pilot usually sits, was a second captain, who was training the pilot in charge, he said. The flight was his first as a solo trainer, and he did not intervene. The crew was counting on the auto-throttle to keep the big plane's speed in a safe range, investigators said.

But Robert Sumwalt, a member of the safety board and a former airline pilot, said that many airline pilots and even some instructors did not understand when the auto-throttle would work and when it would not.

Three young women among the 291 passengers were killed; one of them was left for dead by firefighters and inadvertently run over by two emergency vehicles, according to the investigators.

While more than 80 per cent of the passengers escaped with minor or no injuries, all four of the flight attendants in the rear galley were pulled from the plane when the tail broke off; two more were trapped by emergency slide rafts that inflated because the force of the impact damaged their trigger mechanisms.

Safety board investigators had spotted within the first few hours the factor that they eventually identified as the immediate cause of the crash: The crew had used the autopilot in a way that disabled the automatic throttle, which none of the three pilots in the cockpit realised. And all three, apparently relying on the automatic system, had stopped paying attention to their airspeed.

The airline, however, tried to broaden the issue and cast some of the responsibility on Boeing's cockpit design.

The highly automated cockpit gave an alarm when the speed fell too low, but it gave the warning a few seconds too late to be useful. And the fact that the auto-throttle could be disengaged so quietly amounted to a trap for an unwary crew, the airline said.

The crash raised broader questions about whether crews were over-relying on automation, to the detriment of safety. And investigators said that some of the automation could be improved, to give warnings in a more timely way.

Another broader issue is jet lag. The plane was landing in midday in San Francisco, but it was 3.30 am in South Korea, perhaps reducing the crew's attention to detail.

The Asiana crash was the first fatal passenger airline accident in the US in more than four years.

The board is also looking into a host of smaller safety problems, and certainly the system still shows evidence of unsafe actions. In January, a Southwest Airlines 737 landed 737 at the wrong airport. Such mistakes raise the threat of a collision with other aircraft, among other problems. - NYT

Fri, Jun 27, 2014 · 10:00 PM

AirClick.co

www.airclick.co

AT the end of last year, Christopher Chong found himself in an unusual situation - having just exited from his successful company Groupon Singapore with his co-founders for a reported $24 million, he was unemployed and faced with the possibility of early retirement.

"But I loved working, so an early retirement was never an option," says the 25-year-old with a chuckle. Instead, within a few months of "soul-searching", he found himself itching to dive back into the startup industry with a brand new venture.

"An idea came to me when I needed to make more money while I was unemployed and tried looking for freelance photography jobs," says Mr Chong. "I realised the industry is so hard to get into as a newcomer, because it's intensely competitive and hard to get noticed, unless you have a reputation."

So that's when he came up with the idea for AirClick.co - a website that allows freelance creative professionals such as photographers and videographers to post their portfolios for potential clients to browse through via a uniform platform. Consumers can find details such as per-hour rates for each photographer, package prices for specific events such as weddings and birthday parties, or even the specific equipment that the photographer carries.

He adds: "I had talked to a few friends who had nightmarish experiences as customers trying to find the right photographer for weddings, and I soon realised that if I could connect the dots and make it easier for professionals to find more jobs across a wider network, as well as for customers to have a more convenient way of finding the right photographer, I just might have a business."

To put a profile up on AirClick is free, because Mr Chong only makes money by charging a commission whenever transactions are completed; and just like the Airbnb model, transactions are finalised only 14 days after the actual event to help protect the customer.

Prices are determined by each individual photographer and currently ranges from about $75 to more than $250 per hour. Over 30 available hands are available for hire since the website was launched earlier this month - and this number is gradually increasing.

Says Mr Chong: "We are trying to change an industry which has seen very little innovation over the last 10 years in terms of finding new customers.

Traditional classifieds and forums are inefficient, time-consuming and laborious, so I see myself soon having to pick up the phone and manually call from a directory of professionals to convert them one by one."

And while he grows the database of photographers, he also promises to grow the community of potential clients as well, by putting his life's savings into various marketing channels. "One of the many things I share in common with other creative professionals is this belief - what good is a beautiful image, artwork, video or website if you don't have an audience to show it to? I want to be able to give them that audience," he adds.

SUBSCRIBERS

Global Invacom licks its chops as its peers retire

Satellite equipment maker prices London IPO at 19.75p

Published

Thu, Jun 26, 2014 · 10:00 PM

ELDERLY satellite entrepreneurs of the world: Global Invacom Group might have a retirement package for you.

The ground-based satellite equipment specialist is embarking on an acquisition campaign to capture its industry's demographic quirk, and is in the final stages of securing a secondary listing in London to fill its war chest.

In essence, the pioneers who started businesses in making broadcast-satellite components and services are no longer young, said Global Invacom chief executive Tony Taylor, 51.

He told reporters yesterday, shortly after obtaining shareholder approval for a secondary listing on the London AIM market: "There is a fabulous opportunity in our industry right now for a selective acquisitions strategy.

"Our industry started in the late 1970s and early '80s. There are a lot of small businesses - no dominant players in this business, we're one of the larger guys - and a lot of the people who started this industry and who are still in business are in their early 60s or late 60s and have no exit plan, no retirement plan.

"And it's our goal to be their retirement plan by acquiring the businesses that will grow our business in the right areas."

The AIM initial public offering was priced just shy of the mid-range of early indications yesterday. Global Invacom will raise US$15 million by issuing 44.6 million new shares at 19.75 pence (42 Singapore cents) apiece after talking the deal at 35-60 Singapore cents.

Mr Taylor expects the listing to take place within the next couple of weeks.

The IPO price is a 16 per cent discount to yesterday's closing stock price of 50 cents.

Based on Global Invacom's 2013 net earnings of US$8 million and its May 26 issued share capital of 231.8 million shares, the listing will dilute earnings per share from 3.46 US cents to 2.91 US cents.

The company gained listed status in Singapore in 2012 through a reverse takeover deal with the Radiance Group. Recalling that the Radiance backdoor listing was "tremendously difficult", Mr Taylor said the marketing for the London IPO was considerably easier and drew strong interest from institutional investors.

He said: "Technology probably isn't the flavour of the month in Singapore, but it is in London. They've kind of had a renaissance in technology and so, right now, that's the best place to raise money."

Global Invacom plans to use US$7.6 million of the proceeds for expansion, and the rest for working capital and listing expenses.

Mr Taylor said Global Invacom is looking at 36 potential acquisition targets, with about five "hot" candidates that could become reality soon.

He expects acquisitions to be the main focus for the next 1-2 years, after which the company may consider formalising a dividend policy.

Dish manufacturing in the United States and anything along the supply chain in South America and India are the current acquisition priorities, he added.

Mr Taylor is upbeat about an industry that he described as "growing like gangbusters". The company swung into profitability last year, with an US$8 million net profit from US$116 million of revenue; it paid a dividend and expects to do so again this year.

"There's nobody in our space that's more than US$150 million, US$170 million of sales a year," he said. "By acquisition and organic growth, we're going to be pretty close to that this year, and I can see how we can exceed that easily. So we will become the leading player within the next few years."

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Japan firm plans 100b yen boost to hotel ventures

Rising inbound tourism, government hospitality targets prompt Hulic's move

Published

Thu, Jun 26, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[TOKYO] Hulic Co is seeking to invest as much as 100 billion yen (S$1.2 billion) over the next five years in hotels in Japan amid rising inbound tourism in the country.

Hulic, the second-best performer among Japanese real estate firms in the past two years, is looking to acquire properties for hotel development, said Noritaka Takahashi, general manager of the real estate planning department at the Tokyo-based company.

The developer, which spun off from Mizuho Bank, owns buildings that house the bank's branches and may redevelop them in key locations into hotels, he said.

The hospitality business is becoming one of Japan's fastest-growing industries as the government targets inbound tourists to reach 20 million by 2020, when Tokyo hosts the Olympic Games.

Foreign visitors to the country in April rose to a record high, gaining 33 per cent to 1.2 million from a year earlier, according to an estimate by the Japan National Tourism Organization.

"We have identified some opportunities in the tourism market and we recognised our strength lies in the lodging business," said Mr Takahashi.

Consumption by inbound tourists rose 31 per cent to 1.4 trillion yen in 2013, while spending by domestic travellers gained 4 per cent to 20.6 trillion yen, according to the Japan Tourism Agency.

Hulic was created after Mizuho Bank, formerly known as Fuji Bank, spun off its real estate business in 1957, the company said on its website.

About 40 per cent of leasing revenue that the developer generates is from Mizuho, while the bank and its subsidiaries own a 6.5 per cent stake in the developer.

Hulic has invested about 15 billion to 20 billion yen in three hotels in Tokyo and the neighbouring Yokohama area since 2010, according to the company. The developer plans to add about 10 to 13 hotels to its portfolio, Mr Takahashi said.

Occupancy rates for city hotels across Japan rose for a second year to 75 per cent in 2013, according to the Japan Tourism Agency. Tokyo hotels had an occupancy rate of 83 per cent during the July to September period last year, according to the agency.

Shares of Hulic have more than tripled in the past two years, making the company the best performer among the 45 members that make up the Topix Real Estate Index after Sun Frontier Fudosan.

The stock closed 2 per cent higher at 1,384 yen in Tokyo, trimming its year-to-date decline to 11 per cent, compared with the 14 per cent drop by the industry measure. - Bloomberg

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Hyflux enters sale and lease-back deal for global HQ

Angela Tan

Published

Thu, Jun 26, 2014 · 10:00 PM

BARELY two years since Hyflux unveiled its new global headquarters in July 2012, the water specialist yesterday said that it will sell Hyflux Innovation Centre to Ascendas Real Estate Investment Trust (A-Reit) for $170 million in cash and lease it back for 15 years in a move to unlock capital to fund growth.

The sale and lease-back deal - entered with HSBC Institutional Trust Services (Singapore) Limited in its capacity as A-Reit's trustee - will reap a divestment gain of $84 million for Hyflux, which retains the naming rights for the property as its largest tenant.

Hyflux will lease back 50 per cent of the gross floor area of 43,434 sq m for 15 years. All third-party tenants - which include NEC and American Express - will be assigned to A-Reit. The 10-

storey building at Kallang Industrial Estate will have an occupancy rate of 83.9 per cent. Hyflux will provide rental support for the remaining vacant space for three years.

Hyflux plans to use the proceeds to buy new technology and investments in research and development; expand and automate its membrane manufacturing operations in Tuas Hub; and fund its infrastructure project tenders.

"The sale and lease-back transaction is part of our capital recycling strategy to enhance the efficiency of our balance sheet and to redeploy capital for strategic investments. Hyflux Innovation Centre will continue to be the nerve centre of our global operations, and we intend to remain at Hyflux Innovation Centre for the long term," Hyflux executive chairman and group CEO, Olivia Lum, said.

Buyer A-Reit will pay JTC an upfront land premium of $21.2 million for the remaining land lease of the first 30-year term on the assignment of the land lease. The property is a JTC estate, with lease expiring in December 2068.

A-Reit expects the purchase to generate a net property income yield of about 6.98 per cent, post acquisition costs, in the first year. The annualised pro-forma financial effect of the acquisition on distribution per unit would be around 0.118 cent per unit for the financial year ended March 31, 2014, assuming that A-Reit had bought and operated the property for the whole of fiscal 2014. It also assumes that the purchase was funded by 60 per cent equity and 40 per cent debt.

An A-Reit spokesman told BT that the acquisition will be funded by existing debt facilities and will push A-Reit's gearing up 1.5 percentage points to 31.5 per cent.

The property, sitting on a 17,374 sq m site, was earlier valued at $197 million, inclusive of land premium payable, by DTZ Debenham Tie Leung (SEA) Pte Ltd.

Following the purchase, A-Reit's weighted average lease term to expiry is expected to increase from 3.85 years to 3.96 years. Analysts are comfortable with A-Reit's acquisition and gearing as it solidifies its position within the industrial Reit space. It will own a total of 103 properties in Singapore and two business park properties in China. A-Reit was trading around $2.30 a share yesterday.

The sale is Hyflux's second divestment in recent months. It had sold its 49 per cent interest in Marmon Hyflux Investments Pte Ltd for about $8.5 million in March.

Analysts say that the $84 million divestment gain will significantly boost Hyflux's bottom line, and add nine cents to Hyflux's share price valuation. Hyflux was trading around $1.20 a share yesterday.

But they warn that Hyflux's core operations remain weak this year due to a lack of projects and new wins. Without disposal gains, analysts say that Hyflux may incur a net loss of about $5 million.

site_title: Sentosa condos feel the blues
content:
Sentosa condos feel the blues

Published

Fri, Jun 27, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

ABOUT two in five Sentosa condominium units have resold at a loss in the past year, symptomatic of the plight of luxury homes here, as financing restrictions put off buyers, industry watchers say.

Since May last year, 31 units have changed hands at six Sentosa projects: Marina Collection, Seascape, The Azure, The Berth, The Coast and The Oceanfront, according to data compiled by STProperty.sg from URA Realis.

The profitability findings is in line with data gathered by HSR Research which shows resale prices at the plush Sentosa district falling 25 per cent to about $1,800 psf in the first five months of this year, compared to around $2,400 psf over the Jan-May 2013 period.

That said, the price movements tend to be volatile, given the single-digit number of transactions each month. There were just five transactions altogether this year, and none in the months of February, March and May.

Of the 31 transactions in the past year, profitability analysis could not be done for seven because caveats, which include information on purchase prices, were not lodged for the units. Profitability is calculated by subtracting purchase prices from selling prices. Of the remaining 24 transactions, 10 resold at a loss.

Among the loss-making transactions, four were units at The Berth, the debut project at the Cove which was launched in 2004 and completed in 2006. Three units made losses at The Oceanfront, two at the Coast, and one at the Azure.

Two in particular made seven-digit losses. A 2,982 sq ft unit at The Oceanfront sold for $5.65 million ($1,895 psf) in November last year, after it was purchased in April 2008 for $7.2 million ($2,415 psf) - a $1.55 million loss.

Another 2,820 sq ft unit at The Coast sold for $4.8 million ($1,702 psf) in January this year, two years after it was purchased at $6 million ($2,128 psf). This was a $1.2 million loss.

SLP International executive director Nicholas Mak suggests that this could be due to owners struggling to find tenants for their units amid the weak leasing market. Some may also not be able to secure high enough rental rates to service their loans. (Most Sentosa homes are bought not for own occupation, but as investment.) "So they may find it a better option to just liquidate," he said, adding that the location is also not the most convenient for expats to commute to the mainland for work.

Another industry watcher added that buyers who bought units at $2,100 psf and above appear to have "overpaid". Those who profited from their resale deals mostly bought in at lower psf prices; a handful even got their units at $800, $900-plus psf back in 2006.

Meanwhile, several Sentosa Cove units are also up for sale at auction houses here. A 2,777-sq-ft unit at Turquoise condo, put up for sale by a lender at a Colliers' auction this week, yielded no bids, despite having reduced its opening price to $4 million from its previous $5 million.

Two Sentosa homes are up for auction by DTZ, both by lenders, one at Turquoise and another at Marina Collection. Another four are for sale by private treaty (akin to private negotiations) by JLL - two at Turquoise and two at Marina Collection.

Typically, banks repossess homes and put them up for auction as part of a repayment structure when delinquent mortgagors (borrowers) are unable to find buyers and dispose of their properties themselves.

JLL's head of auction and sales, Mok Sze Sze, said: "The owners of the two Turquoise units bought them at $7 million each, which is quite difficult to match in the current market.

"Auctioning is a good method to garner all interested parties in a room to competitively bid. Potentially, the owner can also expect to get the optimum price because it's a competitive method of sale."

Meanwhile, some Sentosa condos such as Cape Royale and The Residences at W have made strategic decisions to lease out their unlaunched units instead, given current soft condo prices on the Cove.

Roaring sales in the waterfront enclave back in 2006-2008 were hit by the financial crisis and had hardly recovered when the private housing market succumbed to successive rounds of cooling measures from 2009. The way Mr Mak sees it: "For property prices anywhere, what goes up will also come down."

site_title: Queries on penny stocks: should SGX be more selective?
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Queries on penny stocks: should SGX be more selective?

Published

Wed, Jun 25, 2014 · 10:00 PM

GIVEN that penny stock punting now forms the bulk of daily activity and that the low absolute prices of these counters mean that large percentage movements will be commonplace, should the Singapore Exchange (SGX) maybe exercise greater discretion in its queries and issuing of "Trade With Caution" (TWC) notices?

It's a question which some retail brokers have been asking and it's certainly valid since too many queries and TWCs would lessen their effectiveness.

Also of concern is that if queries and TWCs really fulfil their intended role as warning signals, then an overload of such signals could cut short a nascent revival in pennies - much to the dismay of retail brokers already reeling from a drastic fall in income.

Consider, for example, that SGX yesterday asked China Yongsheng for reasons behind the activity in its shares after the counter rose from 2.5 to as high as 2.7 cents.

In percentage terms this was 8 per cent, which is arguably large enough to be described as unusual - if, for example, a much higher-priced blue chip like, say, Jardine Matheson was to rise by the same percentage, this would mean a US$4.80 jump to US$64.80 - undoubtedly worthy of closer regulatory scrutiny.

Closer examination, however, shows that it was not the price movement that got SGX's attention but instead the volume - more than 13 million shares were traded compared with zero on Tuesday and 473,000 on Monday. This is a very significant change, so perhaps a query was justified.

Price and volume both played a part in the case of Sinotel Technologies, which was queried on Monday when its shares rose from 5.4 to 6.5 cents, a gain of 1.1 cents or 20 per cent.

Again, the absolute price is small but the percentage quantum was magnified by the low starting price. Turnover was 1.4 million shares - not high if viewed in isolation but certainly unusual when compared to the previous week's daily average of 32,000. Like Sinotel, a query was arguably warranted.

The problem is that ever since liquidity started draining out of the local market - and most other emerging markets - following the US Federal Reserve's declaration in May last year to gradually taper its money printing, daily activity on the SGX has shifted heavily towards penny stocks.

There was a lull between October and around April this year when confidence was shaken by a crash brought on by official investigations into the trading of a few penny stocks, but over the past six to seven weeks, penny interest has made a tentative comeback, possibly because liquidity in blue chips has dried up.

In addition, an increasing number of retail brokers, having seen their income drop sharply over the past year because of a withdrawal of retail interest, have turned to trading penny stocks to supplement their bottom lines.

According to some remisiers, this means coming to work every day, switching on trading terminals and jumping aboard whichever penny stocks happen to be among the day's most actives, regardless of what these might be or if the companies concerned have any fundamentals or announcements to justify the trading.

Since proprietary desks and dealers rarely hold large overnight positions, this means what is in vogue today can be almost totally forgotten tomorrow - volume in Sinotel, for example, may have been 1.4 million on Monday, but it dropped sharply to 113,000 on Tuesday and only 79,000 were done yesterday.

It is important to note that not all large penny percentage gains draw queries. Scintronix yesterday gained as much as 100 per cent when it rose from 0.1 to an intra-day high of 0.2 cent and Advance SCT gained as much as 50 per cent by advancing 0.1 cent to 0.3 cent. Both were quite rightly not queried by the exchange.

This suggests that SGX does indeed exercise some judgement when deciding what to query. The question then is whether it should go further and factor in sentiment, prevailing conditions and the likelihood that dealers indulging in speculative rotational plays could be responsible for the sudden interest in some stocks, rather than just rely on percentage gains and/or drastic volume spikes.

Rakuten 'to buy big stake in AirAsia's Japan venture'

Published

Thu, Jun 26, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[TOKYO] Japan's biggest online retailer Rakuten Inc plans to buy a major stake in a Japanese budget airline to be established by Malaysia's AirAsia Bhd, in a renewed bid to tap one of Asia's most lucrative air markets, Japanese media reported.

A foray into the airline business could help the acquisitive Japanese company controlled by Japan's fourth-richest man, Hiroshi Mikitani, boost its online travel site that is already one of the nation's largest.

A similar strategy was pioneered two decades ago by travel company H.I.S, when it set up Skymark Airlines, which has since become Japan's leading discount carrier.

For AirAsia, owned by one of Malaysia's wealthiest people, Tony Fernandes, it would be another attempt to expand to Japan after last year pulling out of a joint airline venture with Japan's biggest carrier ANA Holdings Inc. The venture, launched in 2011, failed to woo travellers.

"Rakuten certainly makes sense. They can use Rakuten's platform and they can also carry e-commerce goods," said K Ajith, an analyst at brokerage UOB Kay Hian in Singapore "For AirAsia, it's pretty clear that they won't face much interference in terms of how to run the airline."

Mr Fernandes declined to comment when asked if AirAsia was planning a venture with Rakuten. The Japanese company in a statement said it had nothing to announce at present.

Mr Fernandes and Mr Mikitani will announce the deal on July 1 in Tokyo, the Nikkei business newspaper said. Both men share a passion for sports, with Mr Mikitani's company owning baseball team Rakuten Eagles and Mr Fernandes the major shareholder in British football club Queens Park Rangers.

Shares in Rakuten rose 2.9 per cent yesterday, outperforming a 0.2 per cent rise in the broader Tokyo market.

ANA blamed AirAsia's first flop on poor marketing and a user-unfriendly website, agreeing a year ago to buy its third of the company. It later rebranded the discount airline, based at Tokyo's Narita Airport, as Vanilla Air.

Under Japanese law, a local airline joint venture cannot be more than 33.3 per cent owned by a foreign firm.

At the time, AirAsia's Mr Fernandes said he looked forward to returning to the Japanese market. His new Japanese carrier will be based at Chubu airport in central Japan, media reports said.

Doing so, would give AirAsia access to landing rights unavailable at crowded airports serving Japan's capital.

AirAsia's return would ratchet up competition among Japan's discount carriers. They have struggled to overcome ANA and Japan Airlines, which dominate domestic routes.

The size of Rakuten's stake in the company was unclear, business magazine Toyo Keizai said on its website, but added that both AirAsia and Rakuten may invest up to a third each, leaving the rest to several Japanese companies. It did not cite any sources.

An airline stake buy would be the fifth acquisition by Rakuten this year, adding to more than 100 investments since 2000. Its most recent in February was the US$905 million purchase of Viber, a mobile messaging and call service. - Reuters

site_title: Celebrating Singapore's best visual artists
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Celebrating Singapore's best visual artists

The upcoming Singapore Eye volume will showcase 75 of the Republic's top contemporary artists, reports HELMI YUSOF

Published

Thu, Jun 26, 2014 · 10:00 PM

EACH book is about 400 pages long, measures 24cm by 24cm, and weighs at least two kg - and that's the paperback version, mind you, not the hardcover one.

But for South Korea, Malaysia, Indonesia and Hong Kong, the Eye books have become useful basic guides to their contemporary arts scenes.

With their full-colour pages and comprehensive lists of artists, the books offer a friendly crash course for anyone unfamiliar with the visual arts in those countries.

Next year, Singapore will get to enjoy the same with the publication of Singapore Eye, which will feature 75 of its best contemporary artists.

Each artist will have a four-page picture spread of their works with brief explanations about their artistic practices.

Exhibition of works

Accompanying the book's release is an exhibition of artworks by 25 artists shortlisted from the 75.

The exhibition is supported by Prudential Corporation Asia and will open at the ArtScience Museum of Marina Bay Sands on Jan 17, 2015, to coincide with Art Stage and Singapore Art Week, as well as the country's 50th anniversary.

Behind the effort is Parallel Contemporary Art, a non-profit organisation led by European husband-and-wife philanthropists David and Serenella Ciclitira.

Avid art-collectors, they chanced on the idea of starting the Eye series after visiting South Korea and enjoying its art - then finding no books in English to guide them through the scene. So they looked for prominent local curators, partnered Italian publishing company Skira and started releasing these comprehensive pictorial surveys, beginning with Korean Eye in 2010, followed by Indonesian Eye in 2012, Hong Kong Eye in 2013, and Malaysian Eye earlier this year.

To be sure, these books are not without controversy.

At the launch of Malaysian Eye earlier this year, there were heated debates on the side among artists over why certain names were selected for the book and others dropped.

But Mr Ciclitira insists that the selection process is impartial.

He says: "What we always do is invite every single gallery in the country to submit the portfolio of works of all their local contemporary artists. And, from there, the panel selects 75 to be featured in the book ... In fact, what's wonderful about our selection process is that we are completely unaware of the politics of the local scene, so we don't play favourites. The selection is done purely on the basis of the submitted portfolios."

Local inflections

The panel consists of his wife Serenella; Niru Ratnam, the Global Eye Programme director; Nigel Hurst, Saatchi Gallery CEO; and Johnson Chang Tsong-Zung, founder and director of Hanart Gallery.

Mr Ratnam explains: "Speaking very personally, what I look for in contemporary art are the nuances that are inflective of local concerns. Even though the artist might speak the universal language of contemporary art, what sets his or her practice apart from that of artists of other countries are those local inflections. That's exciting to me."

site_title: Hard-hitting double bill
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Hard-hitting double bill

Published

Thu, Jun 26, 2014 · 10:00 PM

WHAT happens when a country decides that there's no more land for its old people?

In Cultural Medallion winner and playwright Han Lao Da's Floathouse 1001 - his futuristic tale of a group of unhappy people who are unfairly treated - the play sees Singapore placing old people in pods that are set adrift at sea.

When they die, the pods sink to the ocean floor. But naturally, as in any dystopian tale, there are a few rebels - and three elderly folk in the pods take things into their own hands before they are driven half-mad being cooped up in the enclosed space.

The Chinese play was first staged at Jubilee Hall in 1995, but now gets to be played to a wider audience with Jeremy Tiang's translation into English. New theatre company Pinball Collective first did a reading of the translated play, and will soon be staging it at The Arts House.

"As theatre in translation becomes more prominent in our multi-lingual society, we feel that work of this nature will grow in importance as it helps create bridges across communities," notes Tiang, who has translated five books and a few plays from Chinese.

Another of his translations will be staged in this double bill. Floating Bones is Quah Sy Ren's Dragon Bone, which is a dream play filled with a collage of memories and impressions. Through the fragmentary images, the play questions the senses and to what or whom one is loyal.

The two important plays, which haven't been restaged in more than a decade, make their English-language debuts that will reach out to a wider audience.

For Floathouse 1001 especially, Han's dystopian future envisioned more than 20 years ago has a current resonance, what with the issue of overcrowding and the ageing population of Singapore.

Bringing the plays to stage will be director Elina Lim, who brings many years of experience of backstage management to the productions.

It's the fourth play she's directed since Bedok Reservoir, the first Pinball Collective production three years ago.

The two plays are dark, she says, but there are also beautiful and funny moments. "I was initially concerned that both plays would be too dark, but I was really impressed at how much self-discovery and lightness these two pieces had," says the degree holder in theatre production from Melbourne's Victorian College of the Arts.

Working on a translated play, Lim says that she discussed it with the playwrights to get a better idea of what they intended. "And then we reshaped the script a bit more. When it's a translated play, our concern is whether we bring across what the writer intended, and how accurate we are in portraying the play," she adds.

It helps that Lim does read Mandarin but her directorial process was to devise the play with the actors: Lim Kay Siu, Bridget Lachica, Zachary Ibrahim, Bevin Ng and Elizabeth Sergeant Tan.

"We'd discuss the ideologies behind the play and the emotional journeys of the characters, but we have to let the play come to its own conclusion. I'd say the plays are evolving during rehearsals and we sometimes come up with something that's more befitting emotionally," she shares.

The plays will also be more physical in nature, says Lim, with two persons in the production who don't have speaking parts but only do movement.

On influences, Lim says she's a huge fan of how London-based Shunt Collective interacts with the audience, and American dance theatre company Pilobolus.

Locally, she includes the Fingerplayers (for their visual effects) and The Necessary Stage (for their ability to capture the intimate moments and devising plays), while her interest in theatre was sparked in secondary school by drama mentor Jeremiah Choy.

She moved to directing after a six-month backstage stint with The Lion King, she explains. "It was apparent to me that the learning curve had stopped for me then, and I didn't want to stay on a show that had reached the height of its development. That's why I started working freelance and set up my own theatre company."

Lim draws from her years of backstage management, and being the sounding board for directors and dramaturgs. "Very often, I was their right-hand person and giving them feedback which has refined my decision-making, in that respect," she muses.

Floating Bones will be an interesting production to see how she's going to direct two abstract, conceptual plays but with hard-hitting messages.

'Floating Bones', a double bill, will show at various times, from July 4-6 at Play Den, The Arts House. Tickets from $18 are available from The Arts House,

site_title: As many twists and turns off-page as on-page
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

As many twists and turns off-page as on-page

Readers gain when booksellers slug it out, report LESLIE KAUFMAN and ELIZABETH A HARRIS

Published

Thu, Jun 26, 2014 · 10:00 PM

LIKE any mystery novel expected to be a summer blockbuster, Robert Galbraith's The Silkworm, released last Thursday, features shadowy subtext and crafty machinations - but in this book's case, the manoeuvrings are both on and off the page.

That's because Galbraith is not a run-of-the-mill thriller writer but the pseudonym for JK Rowling, creator of the Harry Potter series, and the publisher is Little, Brown and Co, a division of Hachette Book Group, which is locked in battle with Amazon, the giant online retailer.

Amazon, which controls roughly a third of the US book market, has been discouraging sales of Hachette books in an effort to make the publisher agree to terms on a new contract for its e-books.

As part of the stand-off, Amazon has removed pre-order buttons for several Hachette titles, including The Silkworm. While Amazon's hardball tactics have been a nightmare for Hachette and its affected authors, other booksellers have smelled opportunity.

Big hit

With The Silkworm expected to be a big hit - the first Galbraith book, The Cuckoo's Calling, was a No 1 New York Times best-seller - retailers from independent bookstores to giant box chains are looking to exploit the dispute to win back customers who may be frustrated by Amazon's lack of inventory. (An Amazon spokeswoman said that it started selling The Silkworm last Thursday, although it is unclear whether it will have it in stock or there will be shipping delays, as there have been with other Hachette books.)

Wal-Mart, especially, is looking to capitalise. In the past few weeks, the retailer has augmented its promotional strategy to give The Silkworm an additional boost. This week, Wal-Mart-sponsored advertisements started appearing on Facebook, promoting heavily discounted books - most visibly The Silkworm - at Wal-Mart. And a few weeks ago, the company sent an e-mail to millions of customers promoting certain Hachette titles. It also displayed those books on its home page, and The Silkworm was featured.

"We just want to continue to let customers and readers know that they can find Silkworm and other Hachette titles at Wal-Mart," said Jaeme Laczkowski, a Wal-Mart spokeswoman.

On the other end of the bookselling spectrum, Third Place Books in Seattle has been giving 20 per cent off the US$28 list price to customers who pre-order the book from them and has promised to hand-deliver.

Other major booksellers are also eagerly awaiting the arrival of The Silkworm. At Books-A-Million, for example, some Hachette titles are available for up to 40 per cent off, and The Silkworm will be featured prominently at the front of the store for a discount of up to 30 per cent.

This week, the home page of the iTunes book section has featured a list of e-books available for pre-order for an unusually low price of US$9.99 or less, all of which are Hachette titles, including The Silkworm.

Hudson Booksellers, the ubiquitous airport bookstore, has created a Hachette page on its website that includes titles for 30 and 40 per cent off - along with a red downloadable sticker that reads "I Didn't Buy it on Amazon". That sticker was first shown on Stephen Colbert's show earlier this month and is also available for download on his website. (Colbert is a Hachette author.)

Promotional push

Barnes & Noble has not adjusted its marketing plan for The Silkworm over the past few weeks - its executives said that they had always planned to give it a full-throated promotional push. Its efforts appear to be paying off.

Last Thursday, the book was ranked No 1 among hardcover titles on the company's website.

"We've partnered with Hachette and supported JK Rowling from the very beginning," Mary Amicucci, vice-president of adult trade books at Barnes & Noble, said in an e-mail. "We know Silkworm is going to be one of our biggest books of the summer, and have put forth our full marketing assets."

Similarly, Little, Brown, - the publisher of The Silkworm - had ambitious marketing plans in place before the fight with Amazon broke out.

Heather Fain, a marketing executive at Little, Brown, noted that while the inability to pre-order from Amazon could have hurt the book's sales, it also received a big publicity boost from all the attention that it has received because of the dispute. - NYT

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Frasers Hospitality Trust IPO units at 88 cts each

Acquisition pipeline provides potential for its asset portfolio to swell

Published

Mon, Jun 30, 2014 · 10:00 PM

FRASERS Hospitality Trust (FHT), which will start trading on the Singapore Exchange this month, could be making another acquisition as early as in the next 15 to 18 months.

Besides an initial portfolio of 12 hospitality assets worth $1.67 billion, it has the right of first refusal (ROFR) to acquire 18 other assets from its sponsor Frasers Centrepoint Limited (FCL) and the latter's major shareholder TCC Group.

This acquisition pipeline through ROFRs alone could more than double FHT's portfolio from the current 2,770 hotel rooms and serviced residences units.

"There could be a couple of assets to be ready in the next 15 to 18 months," Eu Chin Fen, chief executive of the Reit manager, told reporters.

"When the time is right, we definitely will be talking to the sponsor and trying to negotiate a deal to inject the assets at a reasonable price," she added.

FHT will have access to acquisition opportunities in all income-accretive hospitality assets of FCL and TCC Group's assets outside of Thailand.

It expects a distribution yield of 6.9 per cent for the forecast period from April 1 to Sept 30, 2014, and 7 per cent for the projection year ending Sept 30, 2015.

FHT started its roadshow last week for its initial public offering (IPO), which opens today and closes on July 10. Trading of FHT securities will begin on July 14.

It is offering 185.1 million stapled securities at 88 cents each, comprising a placement tranche of 139.6 million stapled securities (which is already more than 21 times subscribed) and a public tranche of 45.5 million stapled securities.

Another 232.9 million stapled securities will be issued to cornerstone investors including Tong Jinquan, founder of Shanghai-based developer Summit Group; DBS Bank; Malaysia's Fortress Capital Asset Management; Metro Holdings; and Gordon Tang, non-executive director of SingHaiyi Group.

Some $367.9 million is expected to be raised from the IPO and cornerstone investors.

At listing, FHT will also have a gross debt of about $729 million, comprising $613 million in term loans, $29 million in Japanese yen bonds, $37 million in senior bonds securitised by Westin Kuala Lumpur, and $50 million from a revolving credit facility.

This translates to an initial gearing ratio of 41.7 per cent. Ms Eu said the

Reit-manager will be comfortable with a long-term gearing ratio of 40 per cent.

FHT could have a maximum gearing limit of 60 per cent given its credit rating. Moody's last week assigned a provisional Baa2 to FHT with "stable" outlook.

Moody's noted that FHT has a good revenue mix that allows it to enjoy potential upside from the more cyclical hotels segment and have income stability from serviced residences. Most of its assets are located in prime city areas with good connectivity, allowing FHT to attract a good spread of leisure and corporate travellers.

But FHT "is constrained by its small asset size relative to its peers", initial high leverage and exposure to the underlying credit profile of its sponsors FCL and TCC Group, said Moody's analyst Jacintha Poh.

FHT's master lease arrangements for its properties make up half of the total expected rent per annum, according to its prospectus.

Ms Eu said that the Reit manager will work with the operators on initiatives to raise revenue, find new revenue sources and improve operating margins.

Post-listing, FHT is committing $26 million to renovate and add new rooms in one of its hotel assets, InterContinental Singapore. Several properties in the initial portfolio have already undergone massive renovations pre-listing. "This means that the Reit, going forward, will stand to benefit," Ms Eu said.

SUBSCRIBERS

CitySpring in JV to develop and lease data centre

Published

Mon, Jun 30, 2014 · 10:00 PM

CITYSPRING Infrastructure Trust is forming a joint venture with architectural and engineering firm Shimizu Corporation to develop and lease a data centre, as it seeks to deepen its presence in telecommunications infrastructure.

The joint venture, in which its wholly owned subsidiary CityDC Pte Ltd will hold a 51 per cent stake, will design and build a data centre building and install all plant, mechanical and electrical equipment.

When the development works are completed and the data centre is ready for use, the joint venture will then lease the building to 1-Net, which is wholly owned by MediaCorp Pte Ltd.

Explaining the reason for the joint venture, City-Spring said that demand for data centre space has been growing more quickly than supply. "The data centre industry, both worldwide and in Singapore, has been growing steadily over the recent years as a result of growing Internet penetration into the consumer and corporate market," said

CitySpring in its announcement.

Data centre space was near full utilisation rate at 92 per cent last year, and demand growth had outstripped supply growth by 3 per cent on average each year between 2010 and last year, it added. "CitySpring intends to develop and acquire a portfolio of data centres in Singapore and the Asia-Pacific if and when suitable opportunities arise."

A data centre building houses IT and telecommunication systems, and typically provides back-up power sources, strict building ambience controls and security configuration, among others.

The facility that the joint venture is to build will have four floors for data centre halls, and one floor for office and ancillary space.

The joint venture firm will also acquire an 8,538-sq m property that is subdivided from a Housing and Development Board (HDB) property at 2 Marsiling Lane. This has a leasehold interest of about 20 years; it intends to acquire a further lease of 10 years from HDB.

The total cost for the transaction will come up to about $130 million, which will be funded equally by equity financing and long-term debt financing. City-Spring said it will fund its proportion of the investment from internal cash reserves.

CitySpring is 37.4 per cent owned by Temasek Holdings. 1-Net is also an indirect wholly owned Temasek subsidiary.

CitySpring will be seeking the approval of its unitholders at an extraordinary meeting, with Temasek and its associates abstaining from voting.

The counter closed 0.5 cent lower at 47.5 cents yesterday, before the announcement.

site_title: Challenging task weaning employers off group plans
content:
Challenging task weaning employers off group plans

Nisha Ramchandani

Published

Fri, Jun 27, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

THE MediShield Life Review Committee has called on the government to consider improving corporate tax incentives or providing grants to firms willing to switch to portable medical benefits that ride on MediShield Life for their employees.

But the committee is aware that the transition towards portable medical benefits will be a challenging one, given that the benefits under the group hospitalisation and surgical insurance plans offered by employers are seen as more attractive.

"These plans tend to offer higher perceived value to employees and at relatively lower costs for employers, especially if they have a younger and healthier employee profile," said the report.

Under a portable medical insurance scheme, a firm makes contributions to an employee's Medisave account. So the employee uses those funds to buy MediShield Life or an Integrated Shield Plan (IP); this reduces what would otherwise be duplication of coverage between the employer's medical benefits and MediShield Life. Portable coverage is also a boon for employees as they continue to be insured even if they switch jobs or retire - which is not the case with employer benefits.

The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC), responding to the committee's report, believes that portability is the way to go: "We hope to get more companies on board the Portable Medical Benefits Scheme (PMBS) as a possible way of reducing (potential duplication of medical insurance benefits). Employers should consider taking up portable medical benefits that ride on MediShield Life or provide additional Medisave contributions to help their workers pay for MediShield Life or IP premiums."

But this will be a hard sell with businesses, some of which regard their individual medical benefits as a way to attract and retain talent, said Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce & Industry president Thomas Chua.

PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) Singapore partner Woo Shea Leen said the take-up rate of PMBS is low despite tax incentives being available because companies prefer the more cost-effective option of a group plan; switching to portable insurance will cost more at a time when employers are seeking to control expenses.

But the Singapore National Employers Federation (SNEF) said the committee's recommendations for a standard IP - enabling risk-loaded policies for IP insurers and stronger incentives from the government to entice firms to restructure their medical benefits - represent a "major breakthrough" in encouraging the transition to portable medical benefits.

"For employers, their medical costs would be more predictable and, for workers, they would be able to get better coverage when they are in between jobs and after retirement," SNEF said, adding that government incentives to make the switch would be crucial.

Still, a key step will be made next year, with the CPF employer contribution rate rising one percentage point, and the increase to be funnelled towards the employee's Medisave account. A one-year employment credit scheme, under which employers will receive an offset of 0.5 percentage point of wages, will cushion the heavier burden for firms in the first year.

Meanwhile, REACH has set up a microsite to collect views on the MediShield Life recommendations. This microsite is at

www.reach.gov.sg/medishieldlife

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Outgoing chairman who transformed SBF

Published

Fri, Jun 27, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

"NO matter what we have done, we can always do more", Tony Chew says, when asked to reflect on what he has achieved during his six years as chairman of Singapore's apex business chamber, the Singapore Business Federation (SBF).

The prominent businessman - who is, among several things, executive chairman of Asia Resource Corporation and an independent director at Keppel Corporation - stepped down yesterday, after three consecutive terms. He has been with the federation for all of its 12 years, the first six as a council member and the rest as its chairman.

While he chooses to remain modest about his contributions, SBF has achieved much under his leadership.

Among various things, it has forged stronger ties with Singapore's trade associations and chambers; boosted its membership; put in place a strong management team; found a permanent base; helped its members venture to numerous countries; established a committee dedicated to looking after the concerns of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) - which now has a voice even in the Singapore Budget; and launched a foundation that encourages the business community to give back to society.

Mr Chew brought much of his own experience to bear, but he is quick to attribute SBF's success to others.

"I've been fortunate that I have the support and help of so many people, or much of what was achieved might not have been possible.

"So, having friends is very important," he quipped.

Such friendship and the loyalty of SBF members was won by much hard work - not least the numerous initiatives undertaken by the federation in recent years.

SBF's activities, which include overseas business missions for its members to Asia, Africa and Central and Eastern Europe, have grown from 50 events in its inaugural year to 550 in 2013, attracting some 74,500 participants.

Notable initiatives include the SBF-led SME Committee (SMEC), formed in 2011. The SMEC has gone a long way in advocating the causes of SMEs - bringing their issues and concerns to the attention of the government, so much so that the Ministry of Finance now asks the SMEC for its input on the Budget. In 2013, the ministry included 33 of the recommendations put forth by the SMEC for that year's Budget.

In addition to about 100 members serving on the SMEC, Mr Chew said many others also provide their time, resources and experience to other initiatives undertaken by SBF.

He talks about how, for example, five SBF members decided to each donate $1 million to get the NTU-SBF Centre for African Studies started, so that it could be a useful resource for companies thinking of setting up in Africa.

"And they're not just contributing money; they also serve on the steering committee," he pointed out.

"We also have many members, who are successful businessmen, offering to mentor our SMEs and our young business leaders. Some of the most active mentors include Boustead Singapore's chairman and group CEO Wong Fong Fui."

And there's Philip Ng, CEO of Far East Organisation, who gifted SBF 22,000 square feet of prime office space on Robinson Road, and named it SBF Centre, so that the federation would have a permanent home.

"The reason he did so is that he felt the team (at SBF) was making a difference and he wanted to support SBF. On top of it all, he also gave $10 million to seed the SBF Foundation," Mr Chew said.

The SBF Foundation, launched this year, is dear to Mr Chew's heart. It is funded by donations and set up as a separate entity from the federation.

"The Foundation can go beyond what SBF was originally established for. It can look at creating jobs, creating a conducive as well as a competitive business environment. It looks at how we can encourage businesses to look at helping low-wage workers by upskilling them, training them and so on. And it can also provide opportunities for older workers as well as female workers.

"This is what we have managed to develop and inculcate: this sense of giving back, of helping others, and not just of competing with each other. This is important, going forward. We hope we can influence young business leaders to do the same in the future," Mr Chew says.

site_title: The mobile race in developing markets
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

The mobile race in developing markets

Vserv's CEO tells VICTORIA HO where the key in cashless payments lies

Published

Sun, Jun 29, 2014 · 10:00 PM

SOFTWARE makers and advertisers must figure out how to better work with mobile carriers, or they will lose out fast in emerging markets, warned Dippak Khurana, chief executive and co-founder of mobile platform and solutions vendor Vserv.

Mobile usage in developing markets continues to surge, though cashless payment modes are still slow to catch up in many parts of the world. And the latter is blocking software makers and advertisers from making inroads into these markets, according to Mr Khurana.

He told BizIT that because of low credit card penetration rates, most users rely on their pre-paid carrier wallets to transact with mobile apps, or with other users. This stops them from using the central Google Android wallet, or Apple App Store account, and as a workaround, many developers end up selling content through their own app stores instead of going the mainstream route.

For developers, Mr Khurana said they need to support carrier wallets in order to remove the friction from payment, or users will avoid paying for their content.

And for advertisers, he said this leakage from traditional streams is harder to capture and track, making it tougher to figure out where users are spending their money in the region.

Online reports claim there are about 20 million credit cards and 330 million debit cards circulating in India, which means a penetration rate of just about 30 per cent of the country's 1.2 billion people.

A survey last year by Jana, a mobile advertising platform, revealed similar penetration rate - average 32 per cent - in emerging markets in Asia, South America and Africa.

Vserv is an Indian-based mobile advertising network which acts as a middleman between advertisers and app makers. It makes its money through advertisers who pay for the network to carry ad impressions. Developers incorporate Vserv's ads within their apps.

Vserv also works with mobile operators to allow them to push ads to end-users, and it has a service allowing operators to offer their own e-wallets for in-app payment. Most of its clients are in India, the Middle East, Africa and South America.

Companies from developed markets don't understand the differences in behaviour in these locations, Mr Khurana said. They often thought mobile phones to be the "second screen" in emerging markets - what users would look at when not on their desktops. This puts the mobile phone as second priority.

But Mr Khurana said in emerging markets, where many are coming to the Internet via the phone first, mobiles are first screens. "The proportion of time spent outside the phone, like on the desktop, can be little to zero. They spend their time on the mobile, then television and PCs as a distant third."

For these markets, the proportion of ad expenditure on the mobile compared with other platforms should shift to reflect this behaviour, he said.

Mr Khurana said e-commerce platforms should also tweak their products to provide a full experience on the mobile as well, because people are using their phones as the "first" screen.

Mobile advertising platforms have been introducing services to cater to the largely pre-paid user base in emerging markets. In January, Vserv unveiled an ad format called SmartRewards that tops up users' prepaid accounts in exchange for clicking on ads, or downloading sponsored apps.

In March, Boston-based Jana released a similar service called Marketplace. This allows advertisers to send mobile ads to users' devices, and users who watch the videos get their mobile accounts credited.

Jana launched this service with a 30-day campaign with Unilever.

Mr Khurana said mobile advertising is much younger as a medium compared with traditional channels, having been around for just the past four to five years. Advertisers are still experimenting with how best to reach out to users.

Since 2010, when Vserv was started, the addressable user base in emerging markets has grown about five times. Vserv's own reach has tripled in the past 12 months, from 131 million to 421 million, according to Mr Khurana.

And the potential for emerging markets continues to grow.

India has about 160 million users with data phones, South-east Asia has 120 million, there are 150 million in South American countries such as Mexico and Brazil, and 60 million or so more in the Middle East and Africa. "If you fast forward another 24 months, roughly 60 per cent of the global data-consuming users will come from these markets," Mr Khurana said.

Vserv has a staff of 200, mostly based in Mumbai. It has raised about US$6.7 million to date, and is looking to raise another round for its next phase of growth.

site_title: Thank you for the passion, Brasil!
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Thank you for the passion, Brasil!

Published

Mon, Jun 30, 2014 · 10:00 PM

I WRITE this from Rio International Airport after an amazing 12 days of football, fun and food (meat, to be more specific) on a father-son adventure at the World Cup.

Our trip spanned three cities (Rio, Sao Paolo and Belo Horizante), five games and the key tourist attractions.

As an England fan it was always going to be important to approach this trip with a broader sense of adventure so our enjoyment has been detached from any football expectation - an attitude I feel most of my countrymen shared out here - and evidenced by our fans singing "England's Going Home" to the tune of Football's Coming Home in a pointless third group game we attended in Belo against Costa Rica.

The response from the Costa Ricans? A chorus of "Eliminado!" You don't have to be a linguist to translate that one and you'd think they'd let us have our self-deprecating fun without rubbing it in!

However, what struck my son Daniel and me across the entire trip is that this country truly has an equal, if not higher, claim than anywhere else to be the home of football. At all five games we attended, there were as many Brazilian shirts evident as the teams on the field. At hospitals (flash bout of flu in Sao Paolo!), at airport gates, screens on taxi dashboards (major safety hazard), in bars, restaurants and even on the beach you couldn't escape the games and while the image of protests go out around the world, the feeling here is that the passion and enthusiasm for the game are above anywhere else we've ever experienced.

At the Maracana, we watched a live feed of the last 16 games and a talented Chile side take the home team to a penalty shootout, and were relieved when the home team scraped through for two reasons. Firstly, we knew elimination of the host nation might radically change the party mood at our upcoming final match pitting a James Rodriguez-inspired Colombia against a Suarez-less Uruguay. Secondly, and selfishly, we wanted the Brazilians to be in the tournament as long as we were here. It's that vital to the continued party atmosphere!

And so as I sit here at the airport in front of yet another screen watching Mexico play Holland before boarding, my over-riding thought is this: England went home too early, I am coming home to Singapore to renewed awkward viewing times but football has, in fact, already come home. Putting aside the politics and appropriate use of funds, Brazil deserves the World Cup and the world football community couldn't ask for a more passionate, informed and engaging host!

Thank you Brasil for an amazing 12 days !

The writer is Group CEO, Courts Asia Ltd

Alpha Bank to securitise 1b euros of loans: sources

Published

Mon, Jun 30, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[ATHENS] Greece's Alpha Bank plans to securitise about one billion euros (S$1.7 billion) of shipping loans this summer in one of the first European asset-backed deals in this industry for years, a banker with Alpha Bank and another finance industry source said.

Europe's asset-backed market has not recovered from the financial crisis, but the European Central Bank and the Bank of England have both said that they want to revive it to provide money for credit-starved businesses and help to revitalise the region's economy.

Sources told Reuters last Friday that Alpha Bank expects to raise about 500 million euros in the transaction, which basically bundles together a series of individual shipping loans.

One source familiar with the deal said that the transaction would be mainly arranged by US bank Citi. Citi declined to comment. "We are working on a plan to securitise about one billion euros worth of shipping portfolio loans, aiming to conclude the deal in the summer," the senior Alpha banker said separately, declining to be named. "The securitisation will get us funding of about 500 million euros. The bonds will have a five-year maturity and will be privately placed," the banker added.

The Alpha banker said that the money raised would help the bank funnel the liquidity into new loans and support the Greek economy's recovery.

The deal also represents part of efforts by industry players to seek other ways to raise money to plug a multi-billion dollar funding gap caused by several European banks exiting the shipping sector or scaling back exposure in response to tougher regulations after the financial crisis. - Reuters

site_title: Euro5 diesel to be available at Johor's BHP kiosks
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Euro5 diesel to be available at Johor's BHP kiosks

It enables vehicles to meet S'pore's emission standards

Published

Thu, Jun 26, 2014 · 10:00 PM

SINGAPORE appears to have done Malaysian motorists a favour by insisting on higher smoke-emission standards for diesel-powered vehicles.

Cleaner, higher-grade Euro Standard 5 (Euro5) diesel will become available at some of BHP's stations in Johor, enabling Malaysian lorries and commercial vehicles to top up their tanks there before entering Singapore, and so meet the Republic's more stringent emission standards.

Singapore's National Environment Agency's new regulation requires all diesel vehicles to meet the smoke-opacity standard of 40 Hartridge Smoke Units (HSU) or less - 10 units lower than before.

Malaysia Automotive Institute (MAI) chief executive Madani Sahari told reporters in Cyberjaya yesterday that having 15 to 20 out of BHP's 40-plus petrol stations in the southern state carrying Euro5 diesel might be just the catalyst for the Malaysian government to speed up the introduction of higher-grade diesel nation-wide.

He also expressed hope that other fuel companies would follow BHP's lead and import Euro5 diesel, which has less sulphur and is more environment-friendly.

The Euro5 diesel to be sold by BHP in Johor in two to three weeks will enjoy the same subsidy given to Euro2, the current diesel standard in Malaysia; motorists wishing to buy Euro5 pay only about 10 sen (four Singapore cents) more for each litre. (Diesel is now sold at RM2 a litre.)

Malaysia has dragged its feet on the implementation of Euro4 and is way behind its neighbours; Thailand is already on Euro4 and Singapore, Euro5.

If Singapore's implementing the HSU40 ruling gives impetus for the Malaysian government to switch up to a cleaner diesel, it would be a happy development for MAI and car companies in Malaysia, which have long called for cleaner fuel; local motorists have also found themselves locked out of the chance to own the latest vehicle models, which have not been imported into Malaysia because they need higher-grade fuels.

Another positive effect of the Singapore policy across the Causeway is that companies such as Mercedes Benz and BMW would be more encouraged to make investments in energy-efficient vehicle manufacturing, and so qualify for government incentives.

In his update on MAI, the International Trade Ministry's policy-forming agency for the automotive sector, Mr Madani said that lorries entering Singapore would, in the interim, use newer vehicles that meet the HSU40 standard. This is possible if a filter is used.

Between 3,000 and 4,000 Malaysia-registered lorries enter and leave Singapore daily, transporting goods and produce. They each have two fuel tanks, which makes it possible for them to drive from Penang on Euro2, and fill up in Johor with Euro5.

The HSU40 standard was to have kicked in on Jan 1 this year, but a six-month reprieve was given to diesel-powered vehicle owners to meet the new standard.

Johor Lorry Operators Association president Anthony Tan Boon Fiong had previously noted that Euro4 was to have been implemented in 2011, but has now been pushed back to 2018, when Petronas' new refinery in Pengerang in Johor is expected to be operational. Owners of lorry fleets have had little incentive to buy new lorries with better engines, with Euro2 remaining the standard.

Half of Malaysia's diesel is refined locally by Petronas and Shell, and the other half, imported.
