site_title: Philippines looks to upgrade its call centres
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Philippines looks to upgrade its call centres

There is a strong push in the country to keep its contact centres competitive, reports VICTORIA HO

Published

Sun, Jun 22, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] With 60 per cent of the Philippines' outsourcing industry in call centres, businesses there are looking for a way to upgrade what contact centres can offer.

Speaking to BizIT on the sidelines of the CommunicAsia conference last week, president and CEO of the IT & Business Process Association of the Philippines (IBPAP), Jose Mari P Mercado, said that the country's call centre industry is a pillar of its outsourcing industry, and there is a strong push within to keep it competitive.

There were an estimated 900,000 call centre workers in the Philippines in 2013, and this pool is expected to grow to 1.3 million by 2016. By the end of this year, there will be about a million call centre workers in the Philippines, he said.

The overall outsourcing industry brought in US$15.5 billion to the Philippines last year, and this is on track to hit US$25 billion in 2016, he added.

To compete with other countries, call centres are racing to upgrade its staff so that they don't get caught up with the race to the bottom of the price list.

The centres are equipping staff with technical training, so they can handle support calls for IT services.

More are also trained with business diplomas and degrees, said Mr Mercado. "Ten years ago, the call centres here did basic customer service and provided stuff like directory lookup. Today, they do higher level technical support, and the centres hire people with Cisco certifications, they hire sales people, and people who can handle insurance and finance work," he said.

And the IBPAP has its eye on the next technology frontier already. He said that big data and analytics are hot areas of focus for many customer-facing call centres, and being able to offer sophisticated customer relationship service can provide a huge edge for a call centre.

A worker adept at handling customer relationship management (CRM) software can see in front of him the profile of a customer on the other line. This can help save time so that the service staff doesn't have to ask unnecessary questions about what the customer's set up is, and by running analytics on the spot on the customer's buying history, a skilled worker can even introduce the customer more products down the line based on what he might need, Mr Mercado explained.

"Just that personal touch, without asking those questions. People calling in feel good, like their (service provider) knows them personally. That's where the future of the call centre is going," he said.

In April, The Associated Chambers of Commerce and Industry of India (Assocham) revealed that India is losing 70 per cent of its domestic outsourcing business to the Philippines, particularly to call centres.

The trade association said that workers in the Philippines have the edge over the majority of Indian workers in terms of education and their command of the English language.

The cost of that business is estimated at USS$30 billion in foreign exchange earnings, said Assocham.

Patricia M Abejo, director of ICT industry development and cyberservices at the Information and Communications Technology Office, from the Philippines Department of Science and Technology, said that the government body is trying to create more awareness of these skills, and of training in the rural areas of the country.

About 70 per cent of the Philippines' potential labour pool is estimated to be outside Metro Manila, in its provinces and fringes.

Rather than encourage people to move to bigger cities, the government is hoping to facilitate better remote workers who can work either from home, or central Internet facilities that are available in provinces, said Ms Abejo.

She pointed out that more than 50 per cent of the people on global remote working site Elance.com, for example, are from the Philippines. "There are 155,000 Filipinos on Elance," she said.

According to figures from Internet World Statistics, the number of Internet users in the Philippines grew to 41 million in 2013, up from 33 million the year prior. It has a mobile penetration rate of 111 per cent, and two-thirds of mobile users have smartphones.

site_title: S'pore to take a hit if Iraq crisis worsens
content:
S'pore to take a hit if Iraq crisis worsens

Inflation, growth outlook in the country will be affected if situation does not improve

Published

Sun, Jun 22, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Singapore's inflation and growth outlook will take a hit if the crisis in Iraq - which has shown no signs of abating - escalates further.

So say economists, who are keeping a close watch on the unfolding events in Iraq, where a Sunni Islamist extremist group has taken wide swathes of territory in the northern and central regions.

If the violence spills over into the country's key oil-producing Southern area, analysts warn that a sharp jump in oil prices would mean a feed-through effect on imported inflation here, and a further knock-on effect on economic growth.

"It's not the base case, but if there's a major military intervention in the Middle East affecting the South of Iraq and involving Iran as well, things will get really bad," said Maybank head of FX research Saktiandi Supaat.

According to Bloomberg, Iraq accounts for 3.6 per cent of the world's oil production; Iran controls 4.1 per cent. UOB economist Francis Tan told BT: "The first line of impact will be an immediate uptick in inflation. On the business side, transport costs will rise with petrol prices. The transport and storage sector will see a big hit first, and that will affect the wholesale and retail trade segment. Households will also see higher electricity tariffs, and they could scale back on consumption."

Added Mr Supaat: "There could be a reduction in production and even exports. All this would eventually impact consumption and our growth trajectory . . . There's also the risk that (the events in Iraq) will affect sentiment. It's a double-whammy of things that may affect Singapore's GDP."

Several economists highlighted that all this would only serve to exacerbate rising business costs here - which would in turn weigh on growth.

Barclays economist Leong Wai Ho estimates that if oil prices hit US$130 per barrel, Singapore's current account balance would drop by 0.7 percentage points. Bank of America Merrill Lynch's (BAML's) Chua Hak Bin thinks that a 10 per cent increase in oil prices would lower Singapore's GDP growth by 15 basis points, and increase the consumer price index by 10 basis points.

Still, Credit Suisse economist Michael Wan thinks that elevated oil prices will only have a knock-on impact on core inflation "at the margin".

"The first round of (risk to inflation) still comes from the tight labour market. The underlying issue is not so much oil prices, but more the structural moderation in labour supply."

At the same time, unlike countries such as India and Indonesia - whose fuel subsidies and price controls would exacerbate already-swelling current account deficits - economists say that Singapore is better protected against the impact of higher oil prices.

"Although Singapore would also experience a big impact given the external reliance of its economy, its large current account surplus should insulate it from a balance of payments shock," noted Mr Leong.

While Singapore may not be as badly affected as its neighbours if the situation in Iraq worsens, economists are still staying alert to any second-degree impact that could occur, should the region suffer. After all, as a large net importer of oil, Asia is vulnerable to steep price increases.

But Dr Chua also believes that Asia is "generally in a stronger position to weather an oil price shock this year" compared to last September when the Syria crisis erupted, citing improving current account deficit positions and moderating external debt ratios.

Still, economists like Mr Supaat, Mr Leong, and Dr Chua were keen to stress that things are still "manageable as of now".

"We're not being affected in a big way yet because things haven't escalated. Right now, it's still far too early to conclude that (the instability in Iraq) is going to have a big hit on growth," said BAML's Dr Chua.

Added Barclays's Mr Leong: "All of what we are saying is just simple analysis. A regime change in Iraq is the risk scenario, because it will mean prolonged disruption. But it also takes quite a bit of geopolitical risk to push this into a persistent price increase - it doesn't take into account the Saudis stepping in to supply more, or governments supplying more from their own strategic petroleum reserves. So there are mitigating factors."

site_title: Vincent Tan to list MOL Global on Nasdaq in October
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Vincent Tan to list MOL Global on Nasdaq in October

Published

Mon, Jun 23, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[KUALA LUMPUR] Tycoon Vincent Tan is listing MOL Global Pte Ltd on Nasdaq in the US in October and expects the company to be worth US$3 billion in five years.

MOL, which bought social networking site Friendster Inc in 2009 for US$26.4 million, expects a market capitalisation of U$1 billion upon listing.

"Potentially, MOL can be a very big company. If you look at the market capitalisation of Internet companies, they are huge. China's Alibaba is worth almost US$300 billion, while Tencent, which owns WeChat, is around US$150 billion.

"Our target of US$3 billion may be a small fraction of that, but I do believe it can grow. We started the company with just RM2 million in 1999 and have invested RM150 million so far to expand.

"Today, we have presence in 14 countries and are expanding in Latin America, the Middle East and Africa," he told Malaysia's Business Timesrecently.

The company, which owns MOL AccessPortal Bhd, a global online payment service provider, is also targeting growth in Europe, although cautiously.

MOL's major profit contributor is MOLPoints, which is an all-in-one online currency for games, content and services.

The company is 73 per cent owned by Mr Tan, Malaysia's 10th richest man with a net worth of US$1.3 billion, and his family.

Group chief executive officer and co-founder Ganesh Kumar Bangah and the Sultan of Johor own 12 per cent and 15 per cent of the company, respectively.

MOL will be the first South-east Asian company to carry out an initial public offering (IPO) in the US in more than four years. The IPO will raise US$300 million, and one-third will be utilised for working capital purposes, Mr Tan said. "The balance of around US$200 million will be returned back to me and my family as we dilute our shares for the listing."

Mr Tan said that after listing MOL, he and his family will own less than 50 per cent of the company, the Malaysian daily said. The stakes held by the Sultan of Johor and Mr Ganesh will be cut to 14 and 10 per cent, respectively, he said.

Mr Tan recently listed convenience store operator 7-Eleven Malaysia Holdings Bhd in a US$250 million IPO. He is also exploring Welsh soccer team Cardiff City's listing on Singapore's small-cap Catalist exchange as well as that of lottery company Sports Toto and mobile phone operator U-Mobile.

site_title: Sacrificing sleep for the sheer thrill
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Sacrificing sleep for the sheer thrill

And the best is yet to come in this already exciting World Cup

Published

Sun, Jun 22, 2014 · 10:00 PM

WHEREVER I've gone these last 10 days, many people have asked me the same question: "Just how do you do it?"

"It" being staying up each night to catch most of the World Cup football matches - which kick off at the rather unforgiving times of midnight, 3am and 6am, Singapore time - and still being able to put in a full shift of work the next day.

My response is simple: have a power nap instead of a power lunch; invest in a good gourmet coffee-maker; and, above all, love The Beautiful Game enough.

The World Cup comes around only once every four years, and after the drab affair in South Africa back in 2010, the ongoing fiesta in Brazil has been nothing but exhilarating so far.

Catching the midnight match has been easy enough, but the 3am game is the tricky one. Just what do you do during the 75-minute lull between the two games? Sleep, and you're more than likely to wake up only long after the sun has risen.

But those who have sacrificed their 40 winks to witness the action unfurling some 12,000km away in 12 Brazilian cities have been rewarded handsomely.

It helps that most of the 3am kickoffs have been absolute crackers. Just yesterday morning, Germany and Ghana battled to a scintillating 2-2 draw, with the unfancied African side even threatening to snatch the win right at the death against the European powerhouse.

The previous day in that time slot, France and Switzerland served up a surprising seven-goal thriller, while last week we witnessed Chile stun the world by eliminating defending champions Spain.

Uruguay sent England home early as well after a two-goal masterclass by the talented Luis Suarez. Why, there was even a goalless draw that had everyone glued to the telly as Mexico fended off hosts Brazil for 90 minutes, thanks to a heroic performance by goalkeeper Guillermo Ochoa.

There's something magical about this World Cup that is able to draw people out of bed to their living room sofa in the middle of the night. Thousands of people islandwide have also swarmed to nearby community centres or a McDonald's outlet to make sure they don't miss out.

They all know that each of the 64 games has the potential to deliver something special - yes, even the likes of Costa Rica, Croatia, Ecuador and Colombia, all of whom have exceeded all expectations by playing attractive football and scoring exquisite goals along the way.

With all this, it's easy to forget that the tournament is still at the group stage. It's probably safe to say that the best is yet to come, with the knockout rounds coming up this weekend.

That's when we'll likely see some games needing 30 minutes of extra time or even the dreaded penalty shootout to decide the winner.

By the time this column sees print, I would have just landed in Washington, DC on a work trip. I hope my schedule will allow me to sneak in a match or two, since they would start at the much saner times of noon and 4pm - perfect for watching the action during lunch at the hotel or at one of the many watering holes in the area.

It almost makes me want to start saving up now so that I can fly to Russia for the next World Cup in 2018, when most of the games will start in the late afternoon and around dinner time.

Come to think of it, that doesn't sound like too bad an idea, actually. Sure, that trip won't be too kind on my wallet - but my well-rested body would certainly thank me later on.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality on acquisition spree to grow Europe portfolio
content:
Frasers Hospitality on acquisition spree to grow Europe portfolio

It hopes to move fast to set up private equity fund

Published

Mon, Jun 23, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Frasers Hospitality is on a buying spree to grow its portfolio, even as it is injecting six serviced residences into a hospitality Reit to be listed next month.

It hopes to set up a private equity fund focused on acquiring assets in Europe, where yields are currently the highest among its existing markets.

Another wholly owned unit of Frasers Centrepoint Limited (FCL), Frasers Hospitality Global Limited (FHGL), is also gunning for more acquisitions - not just in serviced residences, but also in hotels, resorts and, down the road, retirement villages.

Choe Peng Sum, the chief executive of both Frasers Hospitality and FHGL, told The Business Times that Frasers Hospitality needs to move fast on the private equity fund.

"We don't have a date yet but suffice to say, we are working hard at it. We hope it will be within this year or next year - not too late because the window is closing on us. Other funds are going in as well," he said in an exclusive interview.

"We see Europe as a potential growth area. Almost three four years ago, the prices were ridiculously high. The same properties we are seeing right now have dropped quite a bit in prices. The yield now makes sense," he added. "That does not mean that later on, we will not set up other equity funds that could be China-centric or Asia-centric."

Frasers Hospitality is building a "hotel residence" in Frankfurt and rebranding an existing hotel in Barcelona under its "Capri by Frasers" brand - a hybrid concept that combines the full range of hotel facilities with the flexibility and conveniences of full serviced residences.

It is undertaking due diligence in Germany's Berlin and Hamburg as well as in Italy, in view of a huge demand for hotel residences in Europe.

Mr Choe noted that there is a surge in the number of companies relocating younger single executives, whom he referred to as "the road warriors", rather than senior executives with families, given shrinking corporate budgets. This is contributing to Capri's popularity, though it just started 11/2 years ago.

The firm has five brands: Fraser Place, Fraser Suites, Fraser Residence, Capri by Fraser and Modena, which is currently focused on China.

Given the parent FCL's plan to beef up its investment properties, FHGL was set up last October with a broader mandate to venture beyond serviced residences.

FHGL could go after greenfield projects, brownfield or half-fitted projects, conversions of office buildings into hospitality assets, or operating hospitality assets.

For a start, FHGL made an A$100 million (S$117.5 million) acquisition of an office building in Brisbane's CBD last year and is converting it into Capri Brisbane. A lacklustre office market and a shortage of hotel supply in Australia has presented such an opportunity for the change in use of office buildings.

Elsewhere, FHGL snapped up the five-star hotel Sofitel Sydney Wentworth for A$202.7 million last month.

Mr Choe noted that Australia remained a "safe market that could stand the test of time" despite recent softness in the mining, oil and gas industries, key pillars of its economy.

Frasers Hospitality's properties in Sydney, Melbourne and Perth are almost full-house now; it still has "some breathing space" before a major industry supply comes onstream. A report this year by Deloitte noted that hotel occupancies in Australia could push further into record territory.

Mr Choe said there are also many heritage buildings in Europe that can be renovated and transformed into hotels or serviced residences.

FHGL will "incubate these assets" and eventually inject them into the hospitality Reit, Frasers Hospitality Trust (FHT), which just lodged its prospectus yesterday. FHT's initial $1.66 billion portfolio consists of six serviced residences from FCL and six hotels from FCL's major shareholder TCC Group.

Mr Choe said Frasers Hospitality remains on track to double its assets to 30,000 rooms in five years. "We would like to add a piece of the jigsaw puzzle that we don't have - that is, the USA," he added. "We are looking aggressively to see how we can enter the market."

site_title: Collectors get shirty over sweaty World Cup souvenirs
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Collectors get shirty over sweaty World Cup souvenirs

Published

Sun, Jun 22, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SAO PAULO] It may seem like a strange gift to give someone, but a sweaty shirt exchanged with an opponent at the end of a World Cup game has become both a mark of sporting respect and a valuable collector's item.

But a lot of the garments exchanged are never given pride of place in the recipient's home, and many will end up stuffed into plastic bags and stored in garages and attics until the player's career is over and he needs to sell them to raise some money.

When they do so, there are avid collectors all over the world who will pay top dollar for historic match-worn garments. "A shirt or boots worn by a player whose goal wins a pivotal game, such as Luis Suarez against England, or during a moment of pure genius, like Tim Cahill against the Netherlands, would be highly sought-after," Irish collector Barry Rojack told Reuters.

Mr Rojack has acquired several classic pieces of Ireland's World Cup history. Many are unwashed and still have grass stains on them.

Among them is a shirt issued to Ray Houghton for the famous 1-0 victory over Italy in 1994 in which he scored the winning goal and Damien Duff's top from the 2002 World Cup round of 16 when Ireland lost to Spain on penalties in 2002.

Duff swapped it with new Barcelona manager Luis Enrique, who gave it to Rojack.

As to the value of a garment worn in a World Cup, Mr Rojack said that it can be hard to estimate, adding: "Generally you can't properly ascribe a long-term value to a World Cup shirt until the tournament is over. For instance, Suarez's shirt from the England game is worth a lot today, but in a month's time that could go up or down depending on what happens in the rest of the tournament."

Such items are neither easy nor cheap to get hold of, even for experienced collectors. "Roughly speaking, a good World Cup shirt might set you back anything from 400 euros (S$679) to 1,000 or 2,000 euros. That assumes you can get one, and are satisfied the provenance is good."

For collectors, the biggest problem in the market is establishing that what they are being offered is the genuine article, and not a forgery. "Sourcing shirts is not easy. The best way is through the player, their agent or family, or through an administrator within the relevant football association," said Mr Rojack.

The collector added that online auctions can be a good resource, but that "there are an awful lot of fakes available online".

"Generally, the shirts players wear are significantly different to ones you buy in the shops," the 35-year-old said. "It goes from things like larger sponsor's and player's names and numbers to less obvious things like the type of material used, the country of manufacture, the embroidery used on badges."

"One common fake you see is a replica shirt which has been 'dressed up' to look like a match shirt," he said, adding that he pores over photographs and match videos to establish the authenticity of prospective purchases before buying. "Think about a classic Renaissance painting - not only is it possible to fake them, many genuine paintings have been incorrectly ascribed as fakes and vice versa," he said. "So trust and research can only reduce risk, not eliminate it." - Reuters

Wearnes auto unit likely to get 4 bids

Bidders said to be Swire Pacific, M'sian car distributor, OUE, Al-Futtaim Group

Published

Mon, Jun 23, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE four parties eyeing the Wearnes group's automotive business are likely to submit their bids this week.

The interested bidders are said to be Swire Pacific, OUE, a Malaysian car distributor and Al-Futtaim Group.

The last party only threw its hat into the ring recently but is seen to be the one most able to pay United Engineers' asking price.

UE, which bought Wearnes for a total of almost $1 billion last May, is understood to be seeking as much as $450 million for the automotive division, which represents 12 brands in six Asian countries. The amount includes the stocks, infrastructure and land that are held by Wearnes Automotive.

But despite the valuable property and prestigious franchises in its stable - among them Bugatti, Bentley, McLaren, Range Rover and BMW - the bidders are said to be more comfortable with a price tag of about 30 per cent less than the asking price.

This is because at $450 million, the price-earnings ratio is close to 20, or higher than an automotive player like Jardine Cycle & Carriage, which has a P/E ratio of 13 to 14 and is not only a retailer but also a distributor and assembler of vehicles.

Still, any one of the four bidders could be willing to meet the price, depending on how well they believe the Wearnes purchase fits in with their current business.

Swire Pacific, which owns Cathay Pacific Airways, has a company distributing various makes in its home base, Hong Kong, as well as in China and Taiwan. It recently became a Volkswagen dealer in Malaysia and is said to be keen on expanding in the South-east Asian region.

OUE is a hotel and property company whose executive chairman Stephen Riady plans to leave the motor operation to a successful Singapore car distributor while he focuses on Wearnes' various property holdings here.

The Malaysian car group is big in China as a distributor of a make of high-end sports car but is interested in acquiring more brands to expand its reach.

As for Al-Futtaim, the United Arab Emirates conglomerate which owns the Robinsons department store also has a major automotive business dealing with Japanese brands.

"The parties are interested and have been poring over the financials but the price remains a sticking point because of the relatively low and uncertain returns from the business," said a source. "As you know, the whole market is down. So it looks like it will be left to the one with the most cash to swoop it up."

site_title: Mmmm 4
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Mmmm 4

The turbocharged BMW M4 Coupe comes with a higher fun factor. By Samuel Ee

Published

Fri, Jun 20, 2014 · 10:00 PM

ONE look at the BMW M4 and it could be mistaken for a dressed-up 4 Series Coupe. But examine this latest evolution of the M3 Coupe more closely and you will notice it is an almost totally different car. The new nameplates for the 3 Series Sedan and 4 Series Coupe models have resulted in the M3 Sedan and M4 Coupe. But given that the M division modifies virtually every bit of the car, the link between the respective models is small.

For a start, only two body parts of the M4 have been carried over from the 4 Series - the doors and windows. Everything else is different, from the aluminium bonnet and front fenders, to the carbon fibre roof and boot lid, which has a subtle integrated ducktail spoiler.

This intense focus on shedding weight - the 1,500 kg M4 is 80 kg less than its predecessor - is done to enhance agility and controllability.

For example, lightweight aluminium is used extensively for the front suspension, while the new rear five-link set-up has forged aluminium.

The drive shaft is carbon fibre, and so is the new U-shaped front strut brace, which attaches the axle subframe to the body. At the back, the rear axle subframe is connected to the bodyshell motorsport-style without the use of elastic rubber elements for greater rigidity and hence directional stability.

The front is two cylinders lighter now because the previous naturally aspirated 4.0-litre V8 has been replaced by a brand new 3.0-litre turbo inline six-cylinder unit - the first time this compact high-performance model has employed forced induction. More interestingly, maximum torque jumps nearly 40 per cent to 550 Nm.

This means the M4 has a newfound lightness with the two small mono-scroll turbos producing lag-free response. Floor the accelerator and the high-revving straight six responds immediately with a brand new sound. It grunts at lower speeds and rasps loudly further up the rev range, accompanied by an angry exhaust growl when the electronically controlled exhaust flaps are opened to minimise back pressure.

The engine's lightweight magnesium dry oil sump is also taken from motorsport. Its suction pump ensures oil is effectively supplied under high-G cornering on the track.

On the road, the body control is impressive. The M4 is rock solid at high speed and extremely planted in sweeping bends. The fat rim of the beautifully stitched leather steering wheel is wonderfully reassuring, as is the Active M differential, an electronically controlled limited-slip rear differential to prevent wheelspin in tight corners and increase traction.

Together with the optional carbon ceramic brakes (a first for the M3/4), the weight transfer under heavy braking is less and the fun factor is much higher. Where the V8 M3 Coupe may have been noseheavy for amateur drivers going into a fast corner, the front end now feels more obedient.

Three modes - Comfort, Sport and Sport Plus - can be separately chosen for the engine, steering and suspension. The seven-speed M DCT double clutch transmission which connects the engine to the rear wheels also offers three levels of gear shift speeds. Together, their variability produces two extremes of driving experiences - from quiet and languid, to focused and more aggressive - and everything else in between.

With these capabilities, this fifth-generation M car has become even tighter and sharper. In M3 Sedan or M4 Coupe form, the 2,812 mm wheelbase is identical and so are front and rear tracks, although the M3 Sedan is taller. But what's nice is that both can be used just as easily on the road during the week and on the circuit over the weekend.

Comforting, stodgy fare

Published

Fri, Jun 20, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Gastrosmiths

103 Beach Road

www.gastrosmiths.com

Opens mid-July

TIP to restaurant owners: always be nice to your customers, for you never know when one of them might turn out to be a future business partner.

Such was the case with Gastrosmiths, a joint venture between Dillon Ng and Heng Tong Jin. Mr Ng used to run The Humble Loaf, a 10-seater bakery and sandwich counter in Katong Shopping Centre, which Mr Heng, a stockbroker, patronised weekly. When Mr Ng's handmade sandwiches in flavours such as short rib with gruyere and pulled pork with kimchi pears started drawing in constant queues, the two men - who had become friends over Mr Heng's eight months of patronage - decided to team up to open a larger outfit.

Mr Ng shut The Humble Loaf in April and will open five-times-as-large Gastrosmiths in a tenanted space within the Marrison Hotel in Bugis next month. There, the At-Sunrice GlobalChef Academy-trained Mr Ng will serve up more substantial European comfort fare with Asian accents, such as an Asian risotto made with Japanese rice and monkfish stew, a Marmite-laced porridge topped with mushrooms and poached eggs, and grilled cod with ee fu noodles dipped in vinegar. Lunch sets go for $15 to $20 while average spend per person for dinner should range from $25 to $35.

Besides having seats for 40 - including al fresco - Gastrosmiths will also have a retail kiosk a few paces away. On-the-go office workers can take away sandwiches and Highlander-roasted signature blend of Arabica coffee for lunch, or drive by to pick up homemade cakes and pies on their way home.

There's ample parking space along adjacent Tan Quee Lan Street, so linger around for a while to watch Mr Ng and his team whip up homemade confectionery in their open concept pastry kitchen.

"Because everything is individually handcrafted here, no two items will look alike," adds Mr Ng.

content:

EU regulators expect battle with shipping firms over new pollutant law

Published

Sun, Jun 22, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[LONDON] Northern European regulators will face a battle with many shipping companies over new EU rules aimed at cutting pollution from ship fuels as some owners are likely to find it cheaper to pay fines than to comply.

Ships are typically powered by heavy fuel oil or bunker oil, both of which produce harmful pollutants such as sulphur dioxide which can cause respiratory and heart problems.

Such fuels contain 2.5-3 per cent sulphur on average, which is up to 3,000 times the sulphur content of road fuel in Europe, according to marine campaigners Seas at Risk.

Under EU rules from Jan 1, 2015, all ships operating in the North Sea, Baltic Sea and English Channel will have to use a fuel with a maximum sulphur content of 0.1 per cent.

Ship owners can comply by changing fuels, such as to low-sulphur marine gasoil, which can cost four times as much as high-sulphur bunker fuel.

Or they can use bunker fuel and fit a "scrubber", a technology that filters out pollutant gases before they are released into the atmosphere.

This costs as much as three million euros (S$5 million) for a small vessel - often more than the value of the ship itself - and as much as 12 million euros for a larger ship, and it could take up to two years for every ship to be fitted.

Another option is to use liquefied natural gas (LNG), but ships would need expensive retrofitting, and there is not yet a reliable supply chain in place for LNG. "Neither of these options (scrubbers and LNG) can easily be deployed by January 2015," the International Energy Agency said last week.

Many shipping firms have complained about the costs of meeting the regulation, saying that it will damage competitiveness and lead to job losses.

All ships worldwide, however, will be subject to a limit of 0.5 per cent sulphur content in fuels by 2020 under rules by the International Maritime Organization, which are still subject to a feasibility review.

Maersk Line, the world's biggest ship container group, said that switching to low-sulphur fuel under the EU rules will cost it an extra US$200 million a year. P&O Ferries' fuel bill will rise by £30 million (S$63.8 million) a year, which it said it would pass onto customers.

"On longer routes, fares will need to rise more than on shorter ones to cover the greater increase in fuel costs," P&O Ferries chief executive Helen Debbie wrote in a letter to staff, which was seen by Reuters.

There is also the risk that some firms will find it cheaper to pay fines for not complying with the limits than pay upfront capital costs to change fuels or fit technology.

"The potential for not following the regulations is there, because you can save a lot of money. It is so significant that over time, companies in compliance may not even be able to compete with companies who are not in compliance," said Mads Stensen, global adviser on sustainability at Maersk Line.

Britain-based ferry group Red Funnel has been using low-sulphur fuel for 18 years, however, and a spokeswoman said that the company has maintained its competitiveness through efficiency improvements.

Apart from the costs, there is also a lack of clarity about how enforcement will work. Each EU member state is responsible for deciding its own methods of enforcement including penalties, according to the European Commission. - Reuters

Three-Minute Digest

Published

Sun, Jun 22, 2014 · 10:00 PM

S'pore to take a hit if Iraq crisis worsens

SINGAPORE'S inflation and growth outlook will take a hit if the crisis in Iraq escalates further. If the violence spills over into the country's key oil-producing southern area, analysts warn that a sharp jump in oil prices would mean a feed-through effect on imported inflation here, and a further knock-on effect on economic growth.

Equity barely raises a whimper in first half

CAPITAL markets here were rather inequitable to equity investment bankers in the first half of 2014. While their debt colleagues were overwhelmed with deals, equity fund raising saw a drop amid a volatile, quiet secondary market and low interest rates. The rest of the year, however, could see a pick-up.

WongP sets up Myanmar unit, builds Asean presence

WITH Asean set to be an investment destination of choice for local and multinational companies alike, Singapore law firm WongPartnership wants to make sure it's well-positioned to take advantage of the work that's coming this way. The firm is setting up an office in Yangon, Myanmar.

JLL eyes more residential business in region

GLOBAL property consulting firm JLL is not letting up on its efforts to grow its residential services in South-east Asia, where it just opened an office in Malaysia through an acquisition.

Profitability can wait, says QT Vascular CEO

THE chief executive of loss-making QT Vascular says that the inflatable catheter maker plans to boost sales before shifting its focus to positive earnings.

Pawnshops cash in on business from gamblers

PAWNBROKERS are proliferating across Singapore as gamblers seeking short-term loans add to demand for quick cash from people struggling to make ends meet.

US stock market rally seen continuing

FEDERAL Reserve chief Janet Yellen signalled that rational exuberance is just fine. That, at least, is how some of America's largest money managers interpreted her comments last Wednesday suggesting interest rates will remain low through 2016. It reinforced their views that easy money means the US stockmarket rally has further to run despite notching a series of record highs this year.

Abe to unveil New Growth Strategy this week

JAPANESE Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is due to unveil his New Growth Strategy on Friday amid growing awareness that it is not going to set financial markets alight.

Warning about buying shares in Chinese Internet firms

BUYING stock in online giant Alibaba or other Chinese Internet companies that bypass Beijing's restrictions on foreign ownership could be a big risk for investors, a US government panel warns.

Maker looks to S-E A for YouTube audience

THE exploding number of viewers hungry for online video in South-east Asia is an unstoppable force, said Rene Rechtman, Maker Studios' international president. The video company is pushing into Asia, opening a Singapore office as its South-east Asian hub. Hong Kong is likely next, and Australia too, say reports.

site_title: BNP close to US$9b settlement over violation of US sanctions
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

BNP close to US$9b settlement over violation of US sanctions

Bank could also be banned temporarily from handling transactions in US dollars

Published

Mon, Jun 23, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[WASHINGTON] BNP Paribas is close to an agreement to plead guilty and pay US$8 billion to US$9 billion to settle allegations that it violated US sanctions, according to a person familiar with the negotiations.

The French bank intentionally hid transactions amounting to about US$30 billion that violated US sanctions against countries including Iran and Sudan, said the person, who asked not to be identified because the discussions are confidential. BNP Paribas will probably plead guilty early next month to a criminal charge of conspiring to violate the International Emergency Economic Powers Act, the person said.

Terms of a settlement aren't final, although the two sides have reached a broad agreement in principle, said the person.

Leslie Caldwell, head of the US Justice Department's criminal division, and bank officials spoke on Friday about the potential resolution, the person said.

Cesaltine Gregorio, a BNP Paribas spokeswoman in New York, declined to comment. Brian Fallon, a Justice Department spokesman, didn't immediately return an e-mail message seeking comment after business hours.

The Wall Street Journal reported the broad settlement terms earlier. BNP Paribas would be temporarily banned from handling transactions in US dollars, probably for a matter of months, and would announce departures of more than 30 employees, many of whom already have left, the newspaper said.

The settlement would make BNP Paribas the second major European bank to plead guilty in the US this year. Last month, Credit Suisse Group agreed to pay US$2.6 billion, the largest penalty in an offshore tax case, after using secret Swiss accounts to help Americans hide money from the Internal Revenue Service. Its main banking unit pleaded guilty to a criminal charge.

Investigators in the US had sought at least US$10 billion to resolve the probe of BNP Paribas, people familiar with the discussions have said.

US authorities first learned about possible wrongdoing by BNP Paribas around 2007, when an informant contacted the Manhattan District Attorney's office. The bank conducted its own investigation and about a year later came forward with its findings, people familiar with the matter have said.

HSBC Holdings agreed to pay US$1.9 billion in 2012 to resolve a sanctions-violation and money-laundering investigation, while it avoided a guilty plea by admitting wrongdoing as part of its accord. That had been the largest settlement for doing business with sanctioned countries.

US prosecutors argued that a more severe penalty against BNP Paribas was justified because the misconduct was more egregious and the bank didn't fully cooperate with the investigation, a person with knowledge of the matter has said. - Bloomberg

Box in talks to raise US$100m after it delays IPO

Published

Sun, Jun 22, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[NEW YORK] Box Inc, the cloud-storage provider that filed for an initial public offering (IPO) earlier this year, is in talks to raise about US$100 million at a valuation of at least US$2 billion, according to people familiar with the matter.

The Los Altos, California-based startup is holding discussions with investors including TPG Capital after delaying its IPO, said the people, amid a bumpy ride for technology companies in the stock market earlier this year. Raising new funds offers more flexibility for companies in the timing of when they go public. Box's talks are at an early stage and the terms of the financing may change, said the people.

"Our plan continues to be to go public when it makes the most sense for Box and the market," Ashley Mayer, a spokeswoman for Box, said on Friday. "As always, investing in our customers, technology, and future growth remains our top priority."

The talks with TPG were reported on Friday by The Wall Street Journal.

Box, led by CEO Aaron Levie, filed to raise US$250 million in an IPO on March 24, using that figure as a placeholder without giving the number of shares or price. Box was valued at US$2 billion in its last funding round in December.

Box is competing with fast-growing startups such as Dropbox Inc, as well as Microsoft Corp, Google Inc, Apple Inc and Amazon.com Inc. They're all vying for users as consumers and employees shift from personal computers to iPads and smartphones. - Bloomberg

site_title: JLL eyes more residential business in region
content:
JLL eyes more residential business in region

It just opened a new office in Malaysia through acquisition

Published

Sun, Jun 22, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Global property consulting firm JLL, which is traditionally strong in office leasing and investment sales, is not letting up on its efforts to grow its residential services in South-east Asia, where it just opened a new office in Malaysia through an acquisition - the firm now wants to expand the pool of buyers in this region and bring in more products for these investors to capitalise on rising Asian affluence and investment appetite for real estate.

"At the moment, Asian investors in the global residential market are concentrated in Singapore, Kuala Lumpur, Hong Kong, Taiwan, China, Beijing and Shanghai. Our goal is to expand the base of buyers into cities like Jakarta and Bangkok," JLL managing director for Singapore and South-east Asia, Christopher Fossick, said in an exclusive interview.

"We would also like to expand into some Indian cities and Chinese cities."

According to Mr Fossick, investors prefer proximity and familiarity when choosing where to put their money, which is why many have invested in more transparent and mature markets such as London.

"In 2013, we started selling Tokyo properties. I think 2014 onwards, we will see more products from America, from New York and San Francisco, and more properties from Australia - Sydney and Melbourne in particular," he said.

JLL's capacity to serve its clients in the region was boosted when it opened a new office in Malaysia following a 49 per cent stake acquisition in YY Property Solutions Sdn Bhd this month. The Kuala Lumpur-based transaction and advisory firm has since been rebranded as JLL Malaysia.

Mr Fossick explained that the acquisition was "opportunistic" in nature to capitalise on the relaxation by Malaysian government on the cap for foreign equity in real estate.

"This is not due to a change in market outlook or opportunities in Malaysia," he said. "We are not taking short-term views. We think that Malaysia is a country that will continue to grow and provide opportunities."

JLL is hoping to double the team there from the current staff strength of 40 over the next two years. The team will focus on office leasing in Kuala Lumpur and investment sales. It will also look at providing residential sales services in the capital city.

Elsewhere in the region, Jakarta and Manila are the other hot spots, Mr Fossick said. Manila is growing as a business process outsourcing (BPO) centre and there is demand for residential upgrading. The demand for mid-priced affordable apartments in Jakarta from Indonesians is also picking up.

As for Singapore, which remains JLL's largest South-east Asian market, the residential market is becoming more challenging. But leasing demand for office space in both centralised and decentralised locations is supported by steady corporate growth and a balanced supply, Mr Fossick said.

There will be limited new office supply in the central business district until 2016 onwards when Marina One, the mixed-development in Marina South, Guoco Tower in Tanjong Pagar and mixed-use Project Jewel in Changi will come onstream.

Mr Fossick has been working in Asia for 25 years since he joined CBRE's Singapore and Asia office leasing teams and later became president and CEO of CBRE Japan, before joining JLL in Singapore in 2006 in his current role.

JLL has made a string of acquisitions here in the past few years. In 2011, it acquired DST International Property Services, which markets projects in Asia-Pacific, the US and the UK and in 2012, bought Credo Real Estate, which specialises in collective sales. Last year, JLL acquired boutique firm Halcyon Real Estate to beef up its strength in project residential leasing.

The success of these acquisitions came in the form of a 50 per cent jump in profits in Singapore. Strong market performances in Jakarta and Manila also aided a 33 per cent profit growth in South-east Asia.

"2013 had an exceptional growth that is hard to repeat," Mr Fossick said.

site_title: US revamping Boeing missile defence contract
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

US revamping Boeing missile defence contract

Restructuring drive spurred by multiple test failures, harsh independent review

Published

Sun, Jun 22, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[WASHINGTON] The Pentagon is restructuring a US$3.48 billion contract with Boeing Co for management of the troubled US homeland missile defence programme, said two sources familiar with the situation.

The system, which faced a critical test yesterday, has failed to hit a dummy missile in five of eight tests since the Bush administration rushed to deploy the system in 2004 to counter growing threats by North Korea. It has not hit a target since 2008.

Another miss could put the brakes on plans by the US Missile Defense Agency (MDA) to spend billions of dollars to improve the Boeing-led Ground-based Midcourse Defense system (GMD), and add 14 more interceptors to the 30 already in the ground in Alaska and California.

US defence officials, lawmakers and outside experts agree the GMD programme - projected to cost US$41 billion - must be changed, even if yesterday's test succeeds.

Under discussion is additional funding for maintaining interceptors and improving their reliability, more testing of components and the entire system, and upgrades to improve the system's ability to tell actual missiles from decoys. There will also be different fee structures to provide Boeing with incentives for improvements in quality rather than cost-cutting.

Officials at Boeing, the Pentagon and MDA declined comment on the contractual changes under discussion.

The programme, long a political football for US lawmakers, remains the only US defence against long-range missiles that could carry chemical, biological or nuclear warheads.

Supporters say the system is making progress under Navy Vice-Admiral James Syring, who took over in November 2012 from Army Lieutenant-General Patrick O'Reilly.

But the multiple test failures and a harsh review by an independent group commissioned last year by MDA have spurred a drive to restructure a seven-year Boeing contract that began in 2011, and the initial contract it has held since 2001, according to sources briefed on the review. The aim is beef up the system's quality and reliability.

That review has not been released, even to Congress, and details are being closely held.

Led by former military officials, the review blasted MDA's move away from a rigorous "systems engineering" approach and more frequent testing that would have boosted reliability and quality, and could have helped avert last July's test failure, according to the sources familiar with the situation.

Pentagon acquisition chief Frank Kendall in February said "a lot of bad engineering" was found while investigating the July test failure and two previous ones in 2010.

The Senate Armed Services Committee in its fiscal 2015 budget added US$30 million in funding for reliability and maintenance improvements to the GMD programme, saying it was aware that the independent review had revealed deficits in that area. Congress will finalise the budget plans later this year.

One source familiar with the programme said he was "shocked" to see the lack of attention to reliability, risk management and ensuring precise production practices. He said the contract with Boeing was structured poorly, providing the company with greater fees for cutting costs than improving quality and reliability.

Riki Ellison, who heads the non-profit Missile Defense Advocacy Alliance, said GMD's problems were due to "misguided" decisions around 2009 to scale back testing, reduce funding and cancel work on a new kill vehicle, the part of the system that hits an enemy missile. The moves were part of the Obama administration's early efforts to reduce tensions with Russia and focus more on regional defence, he said.

One senior US official said Pentagon leaders are confident that Vice-Admiral Syring is taking the steps needed to put the programme on track, and put appropriate incentives in place for Boeing.

The defence and aerospace company, which had already earned over US$18 billion on the GMD programme since 2001, beat out a combined Lockheed Martin Corp and Raytheon Co team to continue managing the programme when MDA opened the programme to competition in 2011. Boeing is teamed up with Northrop Grumman Corp on the new contract.

The company is hoping to resume deliveries of replacement interceptors, which were halted by MDA after a test failure in July 2013. That failure occurred when a Raytheon kill vehicle failed to separate from the third stage of the rocket and thus missed its target.

Vice-Admiral Syring last week told a Senate hearing that MDA had identified the cause of that failure, and would fix all 30 interceptors before year end. Deliveries would resume if the test succeeded, he said. He said Boeing's incentive fees had been docked after the test failures, but gave no details.

Another test failure would likely put a hold on 14 additional interceptors the Pentagon plans to order, putting US$1.05 billion in potential orders on the line for Boeing. - Reuters

site_title: Maker looks to S-E A for YouTube audience
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Maker looks to S-E A for YouTube audience

It believes the region will be its biggest viewership market by 2016, reports VICTORIA HO

Published

Sun, Jun 22, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] The exploding number of viewers hungry for online video in South-east Asia is an "unstoppable" force, said Rene Rechtman, Maker Studios' international president.

Mr Rechtman was explaining the video company's push into Asia, during a recent visit to Singapore.

Maker is a multi-channel network on YouTube, where it works with an extensive network of third-party content creators who put up videos on their own channels online. Maker's Los Angeles-based staff create their own content, but most of the company's revenue comes from its creator network.

In March this year, Disney announced that it had offered US$500 million in cash and stocks for the company, plus an additional US$450 million performance bonus.

Riding on this high, Maker embarked on global expansion proper in May, opening a Singapore office as its South-east Asian hub. Hong Kong is likely next, and Australia too, according to reports.

Mr Rechtman joined the company half a year ago, coming over from AOL to oversee the company's international growth plans.

He said: "We have 720 million views monthly right now in South-east Asia. In a year, that'll be three or four times that volume."

And the number of Asian eyeballs will only continue to grow, he said. The growth of Asian audiences, as mobile Internet devices continue to spread in the region, will "hit the traditional value chain" of passive TV "even harder than what we've seen so far".

"We believe this region will be our biggest in the next 18 months," he said.

The idea of the mobile as the "second screen" is often erroneous in Asia's emerging markets, where it is the "first screen", instead. People are preferring to consume personal entertainment on tablets and mobile phones, and TVs are being relegated to just the consumption of live events, said Mr Rechtman.

He said that the volume of video consumed here is 70 per cent done through mobile phones - the highest proportion globally. In comparison, the average audience outside of South-east Asia watches about 40 per cent of online video on their phones.

An estimated 60 per cent of Maker's viewership comes from outside of the United States, say reports.

According to online sources, Maker's 50,000 channels attract approximately 5.5 million page views a month, making the network one of YouTube's largest.

YouTube videos typically earn between US$1 and US$3 per thousand views, and successful videos within Maker's network roll into the tens of millions of views. Maker takes about 16 per cent of the ad revenue, with YouTube owner Google taking 45 per cent, and the content creator takes the rest.

Many of the YouTube creators that stand out in Maker's roster are individuals, often with basic setups and who produce content from home.

Mr Rechtman said these creators are appealing to audiences because of their authenticity. Likening them to reality TV shows, he said mass audiences started to feel fatigued with regard to reality TV because they could tell how staged the programmes were. "When you follow one of our YouTube stars, they feel like they're your friends, in the way they look and the way they speak."

Over in Asia, the amount of talent is also growing, he said. "When we first started working in the region about two to three years ago, there were so few video creators. Now, it's booming."

Because of the growing pool of audiences watching video online, it's natural that advertisers are following them to the platform, he added.

"All I hear from big advertisers is, 'How do I stay relevant to people under 34?' Traditional brands are worried about not appealing to young people," he said.

site_title: Profitability can wait, let's boost sales first
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Profitability can wait, let's boost sales first

QT Vascular CEO urges patience as he picks up more patients. By KENNETH LIM

Published

Sun, Jun 22, 2014 · 10:00 PM

QT Vascular

Follow

CAN profitability ever be bad for a company? Yes, if it comes at the expense of long-term sustainability, according to Eitan Konstantino, chief executive of loss-making QT Vascular.

But Mr Konstantino has a plan. He reckons that the inflatable catheter maker just has to double its sales before shifting its focus to positive earnings.

Recent approval to sell a key product in an underserved segment should give a boost to achieving that goal, but in the meantime growing sales and investing in research will remain the priority, Mr Konstantino said.

For some investors, QT Vascular's latest quarterly headline results may not have seemed impressive.

First-quarter net loss attributable to shareholders widened significantly to US$9.2 million in the three months to March 31, dwarfing the year-ago loss of US$4.1 million. But part of that loss came from a US$2.4 million non-cash fair value loss on financial instruments, while listing-related professional fees added US$2.1 million to administrative costs.

Mr Konstantino is concerned that those numbers could turn off investors in Singapore, which have not historically had a lot of experience with early-stage medical device companies.

"We saw mixed feedback from the market on our Q1 results," he said. "Some people were very happy with the increase in revenue, some people were not so happy because we still had losses from Q1. And my message is, the most important right now, in the next year and a half to two, is to grow, grow, grow, grow, grow."

For a company like QT Vascular, profitability can wait until the company's products, many of which are still in development, have established a stronger beachhead, the CEO said.

"You know, start-up companies are a little bit different, because for mature companies, their focus is naturally profitability and bottom line," Mr Konstantino said.

"For start-ups, the focus is growth. How fast they can grow, how much penetration, how much business you can take from others? . . . Later on, when you get to a different critical mass, you can turn to profitability.

"It's important to signal to the market this is by choice. Because you can decide to turn profitable earlier, but what you really want to do is increase revenue and reinvest in R&D to be on the cutting edge of technology. And we believe that by doing that, we will provide the best return to our shareholders."

That is why Mr Konstantino is proud of QT Vascular's latest topline numbers. Sales of its Chocolate PTA Balloon Catheter jumped during the quarter, helping revenue to grow by more than 41/2 times, to US$2.8 million during the quarter as the company stepped up sales efforts for the surgical treatment of narrowed arteries.

If QT Vascular can keep up those sales, they would imply annualised revenue of US$12 million for the year. Mr Konstantino said he was reluctant to focus on achieving profitability until yearly sales hit US$30 million to US$35 million.

Mr Konstantino is hoping to get to that threshold a little faster now that QT Vascular has just obtained approval from the United States to market its catheter as a treatment for coronary heart disease.

Mr Konstantino believes that the approval will allow QT Vascular to capture two important trends.

The first is a gradual shift away from implants such as stents amid concerns about complications that can arise whenever a foreign object is left inside the body. The balloon catheter, which is typically extracted once it has done its job of expanding a narrowed artery, satisfies that preference.

The coronary treatment field is also relatively mature with high approval hurdles, and medical device makers have looked elsewhere for lower-hanging fruit.

"First, it's a much larger market and, second, it's a market that did not observe enough innovation in the past, probably 10 years other than iterations of stents. So in a way it's a more mature market with less players and less competition on the physician's time in the catheterisation lab," Mr Konstantino said.

CIMB analyst Gary Ng is a believer in Mr Konstantino's thesis.

In a recent note, Mr Ng called the coronary application a "game changer" for QT Vascular that would give the company access to a market worth about US$8 billion worldwide. The analyst expects QT Vascular to be profitable in 2015.

"QT Vascular's product adoption globally and exclusive partnerships with reputable distributors will propel revenue," Mr Ng wrote. "Pipeline creations and staggered approvals are keys to transforming this early-stage incubator into a serious contender in the global vascular market, which should lead to maiden profits in FY15."

Mr Konstantino said QT Vascular plans to market the coronary product on its own initially before looking for larger distribution partners if the product takes off quickly.

In the meantime, QT Vascular continues to maintain a pipeline of development products. The company this year plans to seek European approval for a drug-coated version of its non-coronary catheter. It is also developing a non-metallic version of the catheter that could potentially halve the cost of its product and make it more attractive for hospitals to use.

QT Vascular's initial public offering in May raised S$55 million, and it has given the company a comfortable capital cushion as it continues to grow its business, Mr Konstantino said.

"We think we are well capitalised," he said. "We don't see that we are going back to the market soon for any of the items that were listed in the use of proceeds. Now, if we decide to do inorganic growth or acquisitions or partnerships, that's a different story. But for our bread and butter, for our day-to-day, we have more than what we need."

site_title: Turning heads
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Turning heads

London's Royal Ascot trots out the most fashionable blooms, berets and wide brims but closer to home, local milliners show styles with a distinct Asian accent that go beyond equestrian pursuits. By May Yip

Published

Fri, Jun 20, 2014 · 10:00 PM

BLAME it yet again on Kate Middleton, the relatable trendsetter who doesn't so much as break fashion rules as quietly puts her own spin on classic favourites. Thanks to the Duchess of Cambridge, headwear has become stylish statement-makers rather than traditional accessories, fit only for royalty.

"Demand for hats has grown after the Royal Wedding," observes homegrown milliner Mandy Pan, who picked up the craft after coming across the works of Jane Taylor, the go-to milliner for the Duchess. "Many people think that you can only wear a hat to special occasions but that's nonsense. You can wear a hat anywhere. It just depends on the hat design."

Apart from major horse-racing events such as the annual Singapore Airlines International Cup, during which eye-catching hats are usually donned, an increasing number of women are sporting loud toppers for themed parties, company dinner-and-dances, and weddings. In fact, there are at least four locally based hat-makers who craft the accessories by hand - despite the less-than-mainstream appeal of headgear here.

"I am getting more and more customers who are placing custom orders for hats to wear to special occasions such as weddings in exotic locations," says Chee Sau Fen, who has worked for more than 15 years in the visual arts and events industries before starting her hat label Heads of State Millinery three years ago. "Other customers are fashion leaders who usually grab our first prototypes in every collection and keep close tabs on the 'works-in-progress' photos from our sewing table which we post on our Instagram feed and our Facebook page."

The self-taught designer creates hats by sewing upcycled materials such as men's ties or abaca, a handloomed fabric that can be shaped by folds and stitches, rather than traditional hat-making methods of applying heat, moulds, glues, stiffening chemical sprays and wires to shape designs.

Ms Pan, on the other hand, picked up her more classic hat-making skills from Rose Cory, a one-time Royal Milliner in the UK. "I have lived in Australia for eight years and worked in the tourism sector. Very often, I was invited to horse-racing events such as the Spring Racing Carnival," recalls Ms Pan, who stitches and creates all the trimmings on her hats by hand.

"This was to be my first exposure to race hats and I started buying and wearing them. And when I saw (British milliner) Philip Treacy's gravity-defying hats in magazines, I was intrigued and started searching for hat pictures online."

While outre, intricately-crafted hats might be experiencing a fashion moment only now, homegrown hat-makers have been developing a love of pillboxes, fedoras and fascinators for years.

Another local milliner, Kristine Hakim, kickstarted her obsession with stylish hats while exploring a passion for vintage fashion. "A couple of years ago, I was very much inspired mainly by burlesque artist Dita Von Teese and the iconic Marlene Dietrich, and I started dressing up in vintage styles," says the owner of Mandarin Gallery boutique Eskpade, who picked up her hat-making skills from British milliners and books. "Then, I was asked to make some headpieces for magazine shoots when I was in Indonesia and I realised that I really enjoyed it, and hence decided to pick up the craft professionally."

For now, millinery training is still only available abroad. Ms Hakim suggests enrolling in colleges in London, while Ms Pan notes that Australian hat-makers are more innovative than their British counterparts at the moment and recommends courses with established milliners from the continent. And, as Ms Hakim adds: "If one is passionate enough, one could learn from books, the Internet and mere observation."

But the easiest way to satiate a love of headpieces is to simply incorporate them into one's wardrobe. Unlike toting a bag of the moment or tottering around in the season's trendiest shoes, however, wearing a hat does require a sartorial eye. "Asians tend to have wider faces, so the most flattering way to wear a hat is to tilt it to the side," advises Ms Hakim. "This will create a slightly elongated line, adding height and visually slim down the face."

Unlike mass-produced hats available off the rack from high street stores, such handcrafted designs don't come cheap, with prices starting from $200 for a simple design. The hefty price tags, however, are justified by the amount of skill and effort that go into the creation of the head-turning pieces.

Ms Pan, for example, requires at least three weeks' notice for a custom order and mainly attracts customers through word of mouth rather than other forms of publicity, since she could not keep up with a larger volume of orders. When selecting a hat, pay attention to the piece's fine details to determine its quality and craftsmanship, adds Ms Chee, who started her company after winning a creative enterprise business pitching competition by Asia On The Edge, a regional ideas incubator.

"Stitches should be invisible except when they are decorative," adds Ms Chee, whose hats are also sold at multi-label boutiques such as The Society of Black Sheep at Marina Bay Sands. "There is a sense of lively spontaneity in how the trims are attached. Nothing feels like it is sewn down rigidly. There is lightness and grace where lines and edges flow and float, defying gravity."

But local ladies are still apprehensive about wearing hats. "When you wear a hat, the head and face becomes the focal point and you get lots of attention," she says.

site_title: Buying rebounds; selling plunges
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Buying rebounds; selling plunges

Published

Sun, Jun 22, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE buying rebounded while the selling among directors plunged, based on filings on Singapore Exchange in the third week of June. Buyers outweighed sellers with 16 companies that recorded 30 purchases worth $5.6 million versus seven firms with 10 disposals worth $4.4 million. The buy figures were up from the previous week's 13 companies, 22 purchases and $890,000. The sales, on the other hand, were sharply down from the previous week's 13 firms, 28 disposals and $16.3 million.

While the buying by directors rose last week, buyback activity was flat with eight companies that posted 23 repurchases worth $8.6 million. The figures were consistent with the previous week's nine firms, 23 trades and $9.2 million. Buybacks were recorded in Nam Cheong and GP Industries and insider buys in MegaChem Limited, Sing Holdings, LantroVision Singapore and Libra Group. Meanwhile, there were rare director purchases in United Industrial Corporation and Hu An Cable Holdings last week.

Nam Cheong

Shipbuilder and vessel-chartering services provider Nam Cheong Limited picked up where it left off in May with 3.5 million shares purchased on June 16 at 38.5 cents each. The group previously bought two million shares on May 23 at 38 cents each. The repurchases since May are the company's first buybacks since the stock was listed in 1999. The trades were made on the back of the rise in the share price since April 2013 from 24 cents. The counter is also sharply up since December 2011 from 11 cents. Investors should note that CEO Leong Seng Keat purchased an initial 10 million shares (direct interest) from August to October 2013 at an average of 27 cents each. The shares bought represented 0.48 per cent of the issued capital. He also has deemed interest of 80.834 million shares or 3.84 per cent. The counter closed at 38.5 cents on Friday.

GP Industries

Consumer electronic products manufacturer GP Industries resumed buying back after the stock rebounded by 13 per cent from 44 cents on May 12 with 458,000 shares purchased from June 19 to 20 at an average of 50.5 cents each. The group previously acquired 240,000 shares from April 15 to 17 at an average of 48.1 cents each. Prior to the repurchases this quarter, the company acquired 11.15 million shares from January to October 2013 at 43 cents to 52 cents each or an average of 50.3 cents each and 10.9 million shares from August 2010 to January 2011 at 44 cents to 60 cents each or an average of 56.5 cents each. The counter closed at 51 cents on Friday.

MegaChem

Executive chairman, managing director and co-founder Sidney Chew Choon Tee resumed buying shares of specialty chemical solutions provider MegaChem Limited at a higher price with 39,000 shares purchased on June 18 at 32 cents each. The trade increased his direct holdings to 45.961 million shares or 34.48 per cent of the issued capital. He also has deemed interest of 434,296 shares or 0.33 per cent. The acquisition was made after the stock rebounded by 10 per cent from 29 cents on May 28. He previously acquired 50,000 shares on May 5 at 30 cents each and 130,000 shares from March 4 to April 14 at 30 cents each. Prior to his purchases since March, Mr Chew acquired 317,000 shares from April to October 2013 at an average of 29.2 cents each and 35,000 shares from October to December 2012 at an average of 26.7 cents each. Prior to his purchases since 2012, the chairman acquired 415,000 shares from May 2009 to May 2011 at an average of 20.3 cents each and 1.22 million shares from May 2004 to October 2008 at an average of 20.8 cents each.

Also positive this quarter is executive director Tan Bock Chia with 3,000 shares purchased on May 28 at 29 cents each, which boosted his direct stake to 22.905 million shares or 17.18 per cent. He previously acquired 100,000 shares on April 10 at 28 cents each. Prior to his purchases this year, the director acquired 454,000 shares from June to July 2013 at an average of 29.3 cents each and 830,000 shares from November 2004 to September 2007 at an average of 19.3 cents each. The counter closed at 31.5 cents on Friday.

Sing Holdings

CEO Lee Sze Hao picked up where he left off in residential, commercial and industrial properties developer and investor Sing Holdings in May with 130,000 shares purchased on June 18 at 38 cents each. The trade increased his direct holdings to 9.070 million shares or 2.26 per cent of the issued capital. He also has deemed interest of 139.074 million shares or 34.68 per cent. He previously acquired 1.02 million shares from May 19 to 29 at an average of 37.7 cents each. The purchases in the past two months were made on the back of the drop in the share price since June 2013 from 51 cents. Prior to his purchases since May, the CEO acquired 1.82 million shares in February 2013 at an average of 44.4 cents each, 2.04 million shares from March to June 2012 at an average of 33.1 cents each and 3.9 million shares from December 2009 to October 2011 at an average of 32.2 cents each. The counter closed at 38 cents on Friday.

LantroVision Singapore

Non-executive director Yeo Jiew Yew resumed buying shares of IT infrastructure cabling services provider LantroVision Singapore Limited at a sharply higher price with one million shares purchased on June 18 at 56.5 cents each. The trade increased his direct holdings by 5 per cent to 20.168 million shares or 7.48 per cent of the issued capital. The acquisition was made after the stock rose by 66 per cent from his acquisition price in January. He previously acquired 266,000 shares from Jan 14 to 15 at 34 cents each. Prior to his trades this year, Mr Yeo acquired 915,000 shares in September 2013 at an average of 34.4 cents each, 13,000 shares in January 2013 at 26 cents each and 2.467 million shares from October to December 2012 at an average of 25 cents each. The counter closed at 56 cents on Friday.

Libra Group

Executive chairman Chu Sau Ben picked up where he left off in mechanical and electrical engineering (M&E) services provider Libra Group in April with 2.09 million shares purchased from June 16 to 17 at an average of 8.5 cents each. The trades increased his direct holdings to 50.899 million shares or 51.04 per cent of the issued capital. He also has deemed interest of 8.320 million shares or 8.34 per cent. The acquisitions were made on the back of the 15 per cent drop in the share price since April 10 from 10 cents. He previously acquired 5.3 million shares from April 4 to 9 at an average of 8.5 cents each. The purchases since April are the chairman's first on-market trades since the stock was listed in November 2011. The chairman's acquisition price was sharply lower than the IPO price of 20.5 cents. Also positive this year is CFO Chua Siong Kiat with an initial 150,000 shares purchased on March 26 and a further 189,000 shares on April 4 at an average of 8.4 cents each. The shares bought represented 0.34 per cent of the issued capital. Those are his first on-market trades since he joined the Board in July 2013. The corporate shareholder sentiment is not entirely positive this year as Lee Kay Choon ceased to be a substantial shareholder on April 9 following the sale of one million shares at nine cents each, which lowered his direct stake by 17 per cent to 4.900 million shares or 4.91 per cent. The counter closed at 8.6 cents on Friday.

United Industrial Corporation

Director Gwee Lian Kheng recorded his first on-market trades in property developer and information technology, development management and consultancy services provider United Industrial Corporation since his appointment to the board in 1999 with an initial 70,000 shares purchased from June 18 to 19 at an average of $3.36 each. The shares bought represented 0.01 per cent of the issued capital. The purchases were made on the back of the 16 per cent rise in the share price since February from $2.90. The counter is also sharply up since June 2012 from $2.46. The stock closed at $3.24 on Friday.

Hu An Cable Holdings

Executive chairman & CEO Dai Zhi Xiang recorded his first on-market trade in wire and cables manufacturer Hu An Cable Holdings since September 2011 with 6.1 million shares purchased on June 19 at 8.2 cents each. This increased his direct holdings by 6 per cent to 107.489 million shares or 10.62 per cent of the issued capital. He also has deemed interest of 70.666 million shares or 6.99 per cent. The acquisition was made on the back of the 38 per cent drop in the share price since January from 13.2 cents. The counter is also sharply down since January 2012 from 18.1 cents. He previously acquired 1.4 million shares in September 2011 at 25 cents each and 600,000 shares in March 2011 at 34 cents each.

The sentiment is not entirely positive this year as non-executive deputy chairman Yeung Wai Wing unloaded 16 million shares on Jan 3 at 13.1 cents each, which lowered his direct stake by 49 per cent to 16.507 million shares or 1.63 per cent. He also has deemed interest of 15.210 million shares or 1.5 per cent. He previously sold 7.5 million shares in February 2012 at 17 cents each. The counter closed at eight cents on Friday.
