SUBSCRIBERS

Putting East European art in the spotlight

Next month's Art Apart Fair will showcase Russian, Ukrainian and Serbian artworks, reports HELMI YUSOF

Published

Thu, Jun 19, 2014 · 10:00 PM

RUSSIAN art will take centrestage at the fourth edition of Art Apart Fair when it returns next month to the Parkroyal on Pickering.

According to founder Rosalind Lim, the last edition of Art Apart in January - timed to coincide with Art Stage and the Singapore Art Week - saw strong sales of Russian art among local and expatriate buyers.

Hence, she is devoting a quarter of the hotel rooms she's booked for the fair this time to Russian, Ukrainian and Serbian artworks from five Eastern European galleries. The remaining hotel rooms will feature art from Singapore and other countries including Korea, Taiwan, Japan and the Philippines.

Ms Lim, 63, says: "Russia, as we all know, has a long and important history of arts and culture. Its artists combine intellect, technical skills and emotions to produce their art . . . When we saw more than 15 Eastern European works, priced between $6,000 and $18,000, snapped up at the last fair, we realised that this was the direction we want to take for this edition."

For the opening night on July 18, visitors will be treated to classical Russian music played on the piano by mother-daughter team Iryna and Kfeniia Vokhmyanina, accompanied by soprano Anna Ivanenko belting Russian romances - a type of Russian music popular in early 1900s.

Russian canapes and champagne will be provided by Buyan, the Russian restaurant and caviar bar on Duxton Hill. And Russian artist Tatiana Lysak-Polischyk, who has painted the portraits of her country's celebrities, will be on hand to sketch your portrait.

Started in January last year, Art Apart is Singapore's first and only hotel art fair, modelled after a popular concept that originated in New York in the 1990s. The organiser typically books an entire floor of rooms in a hotel for a period of time and leases them out to galleries.

Hundreds of artworks for sale are then displayed on the walls, beds, tables and even toilets. For foreign gallerists on a budget, the rooms double as a place to sleep at night - an advantage ordinary art fairs don't offer. Since Art Apart's debut, two other organisers have attempted to start their own hotel fairs - but both failed to take off.

Art Apart has received criticism for featuring less established artists compared to premier art fairs, and for attracting a lower footfall. Its 3,500 visitorship number is much smaller than Art Stage's 45,700 and Affordable Art Fair's 13,300 in their last respective fairs.

But Ms Lim and her team have taken it on the chin and soldiered on. And from Oct 16 to 19, Art Apart will debut its London edition at Singapore hotelier Loh Lik Peng's Town Hall Hotel in Bethnal Green in London. It plans to show more than 1,500 artworks in approximately three dozen rooms at Mr Loh's 95-room boutique hotel. The dates are timed to coincide with London's biggest art fair, Frieze.

Ms Lim says: "An art fair takes time to gain traction, increase visitorship and strengthen its gallery credentials. So while the criticisms made about us in the past were certainly legitimate, we're taking it in our stride."

The galleries taking part in the fair here next month include Singapore's Utterly Art and Barnadas Huang Gallery, Craft 21 from Korea and Berlin- based Russian gallery Gaze.

Gallery 11.12, a Moscow gallery with a branch here on Armenian Street, will also be taking part in the fair for the first time. Founder Elvira Sharova says: "Gallery 11.12 has been operating in Singapore since 2012. We're quite familiar with the tastes of the buyers here, so we'll be bringing works we think the Singapore audience will enjoy very much."

site_title: Lack of online services a deal breaker for HNWIs
content:
Lack of online services a deal breaker for HNWIs

Those below 40 view online access as important: report

Published

Thu, Jun 19, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] An analysis of the world's wealthy had this message for wealth managers here: If the services you provide are not integrated across all communication channels, including digital ones, your client is very likely to leave you for another firm.

This is especially true among the wealthy in the emerging markets of Latin America and the Asia-Pacific ex Japan region. They are looking for an "integrated channel experience". This means a client should be able to start an activity on one channel, like on the phone or in a face-to-face meeting, and finish it on another channel, like email, website, mobile apps, social media or videos.

In addition, there is a growing importance of digital services that cuts across all wealth levels. Those aged below 40 are especially likely to view digital services as important.

"The younger high net worth individuals (HNWIs) made their own fortune through digital means themselves, so they would expect from wealth management firms the same 24/7 access they are giving to their own clients," said Claire Sauvanaud, vice-president and senior account executive for Capgemini Asia Pacific.

Stefan Mueller, managing director and head of investments and products at the Royal Bank of Canada's (RBC) wealth management business in Asia, said that the industry faces a "make or break" situation.

"The winners make it convenient to share knowledge and interact with clients," he said.

RBC Wealth Management and Capgemini Financial Services released World Wealth Report 2014 yesterday, a comprehensive look at the world's HNWIs - those with investable assets of more than US$1 million, excluding their primary residence. More than 4,500 HNWIs across 23 major markets were interviewed for the report.

The report found that nearly two-thirds of HNWIs expect to manage most or all of their wealth relationships digitally in five years' time. The same proportion would consider leaving their current firm if they cannot get an integrated wealth management experience across different channels.

In Latin America and the Asia-Pacific excluding Japan, over 80 per cent of HNWIs said that they will consider moving to another firm if this kind of integrated experience is not provided. This compares to around 60 per cent in Europe and North America.

"Social media and video tools are important notably in Asia. In Asia you have two very concentrated financial centres, Hong Kong and Singapore, yet HNWIs are spread across the whole region," said Mrs Sauvanaud.

HNWIs want digital capabilities to keep them informed and to enable transactions, the report said. Where engaging the firm for advice is concerned, however, they prefer being there in person and through the phone.

Wealth managers have been investing heavily in the digital space from last year. Early this year, DBS Bank said that it will invest $15 million over three years in Watson, a cloud-based service of tech giant IBM that can process large amounts of information. The bank plans to use Watson to help its relationship managers recommend products to clients.

site_title: Parody that can be tedious at times
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Parody that can be tedious at times

Published

Thu, Jun 19, 2014 · 10:00 PM

"IT'S always worse the second time around," says Deputy Chief Hardy (Nick Offerman), the police captain who reassigns cops Morton Schmidt (Jonah Hill) and Greg Jenko (Channing Tatum) to the undercover cops-in-schools programme called 22 Jump Street - and it's hard to disagree with him.

The twist in this breezy, irreverent summer comedy and numerically superior sequel to 21 Jump Street (2012) is that the filmmakers readily subscribe to that philosophy as well, taking every opportunity (starting with the title) to poke fun at themselves while ensuring that the audience is always in on the joke. Still, there's something annoying about a movie that is a little too smug about its self-mocking tone.

The odd-couple cop pairing - Schmidt is nerdy and socially inept while Jenko is a jock who seriously lacks brain power - is something that audiences never seem to tire of (see Exhibit A: the Lethal Weapon series) but 22 Jump Street takes it to another level (and I don't just mean going from high school to college).

These guys are the most unlikely-looking students since Bluto in Animal House (1978) but, of course, there's no age limit when it comes to juvenile male behaviour: Schmidt and Jenko simply shrug off their ridiculously age-inappropriate presence on campus and move along to the next wink-wink scene, typically surrounded by hordes of bikini-clad babes.

The storyline in the first film called for the pair to bust the supplier of a synthetic drug. This time, after failing to capture a dealer named Ghost (Peter Stormare), they find themselves back in school posing as university students, sent by Jump Street team boss Captain Dickson (Ice Cube) to seek out the dealer who supplied a killer drug to one of the students.

The flimsy plot takes a jab at just about every cliché known to American college culture. Along the way, the relationship between Schmidt and Jenko shifts from the bromance-driven dynamic in the original movie to a possible break-up, thanks to third-party interference. Jenko connects on and off the field with the school's star quarterback Zook (Wyatt Russell), and they soon become the new power couple on campus and hurting Schmidt's feelings in the process.

Schmidt pouts but also spends time impressing attractive art student Maya (Amber Stevens) with his poetry-slamming prowess and getting cosy in her dorm room.

Maya's roommate Mercedes (Jillian Bell) is a reluctant witness to their romantic encounters and her deadpan dissing of Schmidt accounts for some of the film's funnier moments - along with the hilarious end credits sequence where an endless variety of Jump Street sequels is presented.

Directed by Phil Lord and Christopher Miller - a filmmaking power couple in their own right in both animated (Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs, The Lego Movie) and live-action comedy genres - 22 Jump Street presses just about every parody button you can imagine. The results are funny at times and tedious at others.

Still, this movie will appeal to the audience that matters most: males in the 18-to-25-year-old bracket - and all the other bros who act like they still belong there.

Rating:

C+

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Kopitiam v2.0

Chequered tablecloths, craft beers, ramen burgers and affordable French food dished out by a young modernist chef. Debbie Yong looks at a coffeeshop in Bukit Merah that's defying convention

Published

Fri, Jun 20, 2014 · 10:00 PM

IMMANUEL Tee never saw himself working in a coffeeshop.

To most young chefs in Singapore, the 27-year-old chef's resume is the stuff of envy. He got his culinary diploma from At-Sunrice, spent several years working for Andre Chiang at Jaan and Restaurant Andre and now-defunct Guy Savoy in the Marina Bay Sands before clinching a stage at two Michelin-star Pastorale in Belgium.

At just 25, he was promoted to the head chef position at modernist restaurant Keystone in the heart of the Central Business District. But it all came to a sudden halt last year when Keystone shuttered for good following a rental hike. Mr Tee was left jobless.

He scoured the market for investors to start his own restaurant, but when talks with potential partners didn't pan out and he couldn't cough up the more than $300,000 typically needed to fund a restaurant, he dug into his savings to go it alone in the most unlikely of places - a Bukit Merah coffeeshop.

But it wasn't just any old coffeeshop. Call it Kopitiam version 2.0 if you will: all of the 170-seater's tables are covered with blue and white chequered tablecloths. In place of traditional hawker fare, stalls dish out German pork knuckles, French beef bourguignon and grilled Cajun prawns that are more commonly seen on restaurant menus. You can wash them down with craft beers instead of the usual Tiger or Heineken, and the best part? Nothing costs over $20.

The coffeeshop even has a name: Salut, which is French for "hi" but also intended as "a salute to the customers for giving us a chance and the tenants for coming up with such original, tasty food," says Chua Kiat Tat, who runs the coffeeshop on behalf of his father. His family acquired the entire space two years ago after nine other landlords before them had failed to make it profitable, he says.

"We're surrounded by so many coffeeshops with famous stalls in them, so we were forced by circumstances to differentiate ourselves," he says of the decision to position the coffeeshop as a low-cost startup platform for local food entrepreneurs. Rents vary according to stall size, but average $4,000 per month. "By keeping rents low, tenants won't have to stinge on the quality of their ingredients so we can bring restaurant-standard food to customers at an affordable rate. It's a win-win for diners, tenants and us as coffeeshop operators."

Vibrant synergy

Mr Chua's family runs German stall Stew Kuche, and the other six units are tenanted out to a seafood stall, a dessert shop, a healthy juice stall and the latest three additions, noodle stall Mian, fried chicken specialists Two Wings and Mr Tee's Immanuel French Kitchen.

Additional conveniences such as a centralised payment system and joint events such as an Oktoberfest buffet are still being worked out. The long-term goal is to grow with existing tenants to duplicate the set-up in other coffeeshops around Singapore, hopefully as early as next year, says Mr Chua. For Mian's Karen Cheng, the good tenant mix and vibrant synergy among them was what attracted her to the space when scouring for a brick-and-mortar base for her food truck, The Travelling Cow.

Two Wings' Jeremy Loh originally eyed a stall at a neighbouring coffeeshop, but an unplanned meal at Salut convinced him to sign up on the spot. "It was packed with young people who looked like they didn't mind spending more, it was like nowhere else I'd been to," says Mr Loh.

But for a concept like this to work, careful management is needed, he reckons. "There must be no competition between stalls," he says, adding that he considered - but was dissuaded from - selling fried fish fingers items to avoid cannibalising neighbouring seafood stall Seasalt's business, for instance.

It wouldn't work in any neighbourhood either, say tenants. The Bukit Merah venue works because of its proximity to office towers and high-density condominiums in the area. Western and Asian expatriates fill the space at lunch, while families heading to nearby Ikea and Queensway Shopping Centre stream in on weekends. Tenants are also banking on the under-construction Park Hotel Alexandra just a few paces away to bring in more traffic.

The sweaty hard slog aside, Mr Tee believes that a coffeeshop makes for a more conducive training ground for young chefs. "In a restaurant, chefs can hide all day in the kitchen, but in a coffeeshop stall, you have to face your customers daily. You have to swallow your pride and take in their comments, good or bad."

Says the soft-spoken, amicable young chef, who hopes to open further stalls under the Immanuel brand: "It will always be my dream to be in fine dining, but it's tough to do it in Singapore. One has to be realistic."

site_title: Docudrama to introduce Georgette Chen to more Singaporeans
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Docudrama to introduce Georgette Chen to more Singaporeans

Published

Thu, Jun 19, 2014 · 10:00 PM

HOW much do you know about Georgette Chen - apart from the fact that she was one of Singapore's most prominent female artists of the 20th century, and one of the forerunners in Singapore art alongside people like Cheong Soo Pieng, Chen Wen Hsi and Liu Kang? Or that she received a Cultural Medallion for visual arts in 1982?

A new three-part documentary titled The Worlds of Georgette Chen will delve deep into her life and be broadcast in April next year.

This docudrama is commissioned by the National Gallery Singapore, and produced by Channel NewsAsia.

Chong Siak Ching, chief executive officer of National Gallery Singapore, says the idea came about when the gallery noticed a lack of available materials on local pioneer artists such as Georgette Chen - which it felt would be worth highlighting to the public.

She says: "Georgette Chen was an extraordinary woman who lived through extraordinary times, and we believe her life would inspire many people - from young Singaporeans who do not know of her to our pioneer generation who may have experienced the Singapore that she eventually found her home in."

Since the artist's works will be displayed at the DBS Singapore Gallery at the National Gallery when it opens next year, it seemed appropriate to make the docudrama.

The Worlds of Georgette Chen will be set in three different periods: the French period from 1927 to 1933; the Chinese/Hong Kong period from 1934 to 1948; and the Penang/Singapore period from 1950 to 1980.

Says Channel NewsAsia managing director Debra Soon: "Georgette's life story is a rich tale of passion for art, set against the backdrop of tumultuous world events and a uniquely cosmopolitan lifestyle of a rich and powerful ethnic Chinese family. The story is more than just the artist herself, but a revelation of the social milieu that she lived in at the time."

According to Ms Soon, research for the show started earlier this year, when her staff gathered archival materials like letters written by and to the artist, and interviewed Chen's close friends, students and relatives.

"There are high expectations, and we have only a year to complete this," she says. "There will be production timeline pressures but, more importantly, our own pressure - of ensuring the integrity of the story, keeping it accurate, entertaining and inspiring, which will be key to the success of the series."

Making this production has proven to be daunting. Ms Soon points out that not all of the artist's life has been properly documented, and many of the people whom she knew personally have either passed on or declined to participate.

This makes it a little tougher for local actress Rui En, who will be portraying the artist in the docudrama, because every piece of documentation is crucial to help her get into the mind of the artist.

"There are no surviving interviews or footage of her speaking on camera. In other words, there may still be a certain level of imagination required to flesh this character out. Understanding her history and background has been instrumental to comprehending her," she says.

Ultimately, that's the main aim of this docudrama: to introduce this artist to more Singaporeans and make her more relatable via a modern and mainstream platform.

Says Ms Soon: "Georgette was an extremely cultured and talented artist . . . she bloomed beautifully despite living through the ravages of war, a bad marriage and the pain of her lifelong arthritis. Although she was born with a silver spoon in her mouth, she was respected for her humility and diligence. She's a truly remarkable, inspiring role model for the women of today."

site_title: NY luxury condos boast Eden-like gardens
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

NY luxury condos boast Eden-like gardens

Some projects are so exclusive they are off-limits even to the residents

Published

Thu, Jun 19, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[NEW YORK] Deborah Nevins is one of the most sought-after landscape designers in the world. She has seeded and sodded estates for the likes of David Geffen, Stavros Niarchos and Rupert Murdoch, and her haute habitats dot townhouse backyards and pre-war rooftops from Greenwich Village to Park Avenue.

For her latest project, she is turning what would otherwise be a barren air shaft inside a new Tribeca loft building, the Sterling Mason, into a lush 1,000-square-foot courtyard. Hawthorn trees telegraph the seasons, from rich white blossoms to lush green leaves, red berries and spindly branches. Ivy creeps along the ground, framing a sculptural stream.

"It should be a remarkably peaceful space," said Dan McInerney, a vice-president for Taconic Investment Partners, which is building the 32-unit Sterling Mason.

To keep that peace, this most inviting oasis will be off-limits, and not just to the general public. Even residents of the building, where apartments are going for up to US$23 million, will be allowed to enjoy it only from the ground floor lobby and library or their bedroom windows upstairs.

In the concrete jungle, one of the rarest amenities is actual foliage. In-building laundry, even yoga rooms and bike storage, are more common than a lawn, let alone one designed by one of the premier horticulturalists in the business. But at a growing number of upmarket buildings, the ultimate luxury offering is a miniature Gramercy Park, one so exclusive that no one but the gardener gets a key.

No need to stop and smell the roses, developers and designers say.

"Just catching a glimpse of greenery in the city can bring a sense of calm," Ms Nevins said. "I never have time to go to Central Park, but just walking out my door on 73rd Street and seeing it there makes all the difference."

The Schumacher, a historic watch factory on Bleecker Street in Nolita that is being converted, had an original light well from 1883, when natural light was the only way to do the intricate manufacturing. With 21 condos for US$4 million to US$25 million, buyers could hardly be expected to look out onto an empty concrete shaft, like the denizens of some nearby tenement. Worse yet would be if it became a party venue.

"This is a serene space - the last thing we want is barbecue and cigarette smoke," said Rory Stillman, president of Stillman Development, the building's developer.

Mr Stillman hired the renowned landscape designer Ken Smith. "We didn't want big trees, because it would block too much light, but we still wanted to create a sense of privacy," Mr Stillman said. "We decided to bring the Hanging Gardens of Babylon to Manhattan."

Ivy covers the walls - inspired by a stay Mr Stillman had at the Hotel Plaza Athénée in Paris - and climbs along cables stretching from a base of crushed marble up to the roof six storeys above, looking like alien tendrils. Further complementing the space will be a pair of sculptures by Jeff Koons belonging to the collector Alberto Mugrabi. He bought a pair of triplex units for US$20.7 million and was so taken by the garden he wanted to contribute to it.

The newer residential gardens are largely an outgrowth of the current, post-bubble market, where financing has been scarce, leading to smaller boutique projects with larger units aimed at the wealthy. When apartments stop being cramped, there is less need to leave it for a get-together on the terrace or courtyard. Plus, if the owner wants to escape to nature, odds are good they already have a retreat or two somewhere.

"Even if you have a place out east, upstate, the Riviera, a yacht, it's still nice to wake up in nature," Mr Stillman said.

Technology has also advanced to the point where these spaces require almost no maintenance, especially if they are off-limits, which eliminates the need for shovelling and raking - seasonal pruning will do. Ample sunshine can be a problem, though, as well as layout.

"You're designing on two planes, for people in the lobby and the common areas looking out on the garden, but also from above," Mr Smith said.

SK Development is tilling two look-but-don't-touch gardens. Where others are manicured, the Reade Chambers in Tribeca has one as wild looking as the High Line. At 10 Bond St in NoHo, a sunken light well for the gym and retail space was turned into an oversize vitrine planted with a single 18-foot Saucer magnolia tree to enliven the space. "We wanted to make the basement more than a basement," said Scott Shnay, the principal of SK Development.

While still uncommon in the city, this latest crop of gardens is a bit of a throwback, to an earlier gilded era. Grand turn-of-the-century apartment buildings such as the Apthorp, the Dakota and Riverhouse all featured small, inaccessible gardens within their entrance courtyards.

Since this golden age, most installations have been corporate ones, such as Isamu Noguchi's Zen garden at Chase Manhattan Plaza downtown and a stand of birch trees at The New York Times building, though the goal is the same - a pleasant view and lots of light. The current apartment appellation owes a debt as well to the Museum of Modern Art, where Mr Smith, the Schumacher designer, created a massive installation of plastic plants and fake rocks on the museum's roof after its 2003 expansion. It is meant to enhance the view from residences in neighbouring buildings.

Even as New Yorkers are getting back to nature at urban farms, waterfront parks and green roofs, apartments boasting these Edenic refuges and their forbidden fruit may actually be the truest expression of gardening.

"It really is a garden in the most traditional sense," which is a simulation of nature, said Denise Hoffman-Brandt, director of the landscape architecture programme at City College. "It's all about the artifice." - NYT

site_title: Empire State goes for hot and hip with in-house gym
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Empire State goes for hot and hip with in-house gym

Iconic building hopes to shed its dowdy image as just a tourist landmark

Published

Thu, Jun 19, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[NEW YORK] Workers inside the Empire State Building may soon be able to imagine testing their weightlifting prowess or other muscle-building regimens against the mythical feats of King Kong, who once scaled this building's facade.

This summer, a 15,000-square-foot fitness centre for tenants and their employees will open in the concourse of the building, part of an effort to reinvent the 83-year-old tower as a modern day urban campus.

The gym, with white, undulating tile walls and dark wood finishes, can accommodate the building's roughly 10,000 workers. Executives who don't want to work out with the rank-and-file will have access to a private gym suite.

Other changes to the art deco landmark are also meant to appeal to a high-end market. Empire State Realty Trust, which owns and operates the building, is also adding a conference centre on the 67th floor and a 100-seat white-tablecloth restaurant on the lobby level, with private dining below. The restaurant, State Bar & Grill, wants to cater to a business clientele, rather than the millions of tourists who visit the observatory every year (about 4.3 million in 2013).

"Whatever your work hours are, you can come in, get your coffee at Starbucks, go to your modern, efficient work space and break for a workout," said Thomas P Durels, chief of property operations and leasing for Empire State Realty Trust, which became a listed company last year.

The recent improvements tap into a trend in office design to create a more inviting work environment. Technology companies in particular have gained a reputation for providing enticing amenities such as free meals, yoga and Foosball. The philosophy is to give workers another incentive to stay longer. Detractors contend that installing a gym would not necessarily improve workers' happiness, particularly in a neighbourhood where gyms are plentiful.

Restaurants serving the health-conscious and chic bars pouring after-work drinks remain sparse in this part of midtown Manhattan. Although the Empire State Building has a Starbucks, a Chipotle, a Heartland Brewery, a deli and an AT&T store, workers expressed disappointment that one of the largest office buildings in the world doesn't offer sufficient retailing for the people who work in it. The new restaurant is intended to help address that concern.

The building has long struggled with its identity. The iconic tower might be the most recognisable on the New York City skyline, but for decades its offices didn't share in the glory. When the tower opened in 1931, during the Great Depression, it failed to attract enough tenants (the 2.6 million-square-foot building earned an unfortunate nickname, the Empty State Building).

For decades, a hodgepodge of nondescript tenants leased tiny spaces. Vast floors were subdivided into small, dreary offices with drop ceilings, shag carpeting and fluorescent lighting.

So in 2006, Malkin Holdings, the company handling day-to-day operations at the time, began a US$550 million modernisation endeavor to restore the marble lobby and reproduce the damaged mural on the ceiling, gut vacant floors, upgrade the building's technology and overhaul the mechanical systems. The new amenities are the latest stage of the project, which includes updating the 68 passenger lifts.

"The Empire State Building is a brand that's been abused, but it's a brand," said Anthony E Malkin, chief executive of Empire State Realty Trust. "What is the brand of the Empire State Building? Back in 2006, my answer was: We're going to make it hot, we're going to make it hip."

Dozens of small tenants have been replaced with a few big names with stylish, modern offices, like the social networking site LinkedIn. In April, the international fragrance manufacturer Coty expanded to five floors. The stock photography company Shutterstock moved into two floors in January, paying in the mid-US$50s per square foot, according to Paul Ippolito, the broker for Newmark Grubb Knight Frank who represented Shutterstock.

"In the past few years, it's really turned a corner," said John Tauranac, author of "The Empire State Building: The Making of a Landmark."

Rents have soared. In 2006, the average rent was US$26.50 a square foot. Today, asking rent ranges from the mid-US$50s to the low-US$60s per square foot, according to Durels.

By comparison, the average asking rent for office space in Midtown South was US$56.31 in the first quarter of the year, according to a report by Newmark Grubb Knight Frank.

Shutterstock's new space is an airy, open office with exposed beams, hanging Edison bulbs and two outdoor terraces. A wide internal staircase leads employees from the 21st floor down to the 20th, which has a cafeteria, yoga studio, library and game room (a second game room on the 21st floor has an Alice in Wonderland theme).

"It's a beautiful building," said Tracy J Kim, a vice-president for human resources at Shutterstock. "It's a great location."

Doormen clad in burgundy uniforms that match the marble greet every person who enters the building. Signs direct tourists to the Fifth Avenue entrance, leaving the 33rd and 34th street lobbies exclusively for office workers.

"The last thing an office worker wants to see is a dad in a tank top with three screaming children," said Mr Malkin, whose grandfather, Lawrence A Wien, bought the Empire State Building in 1961 with Harry Helmsley.

Despite the investment, a dowdy reputation can be hard to shed, and some prospective tenants are reluctant to visit the building for a tour. Even some current employees perceive it as an unappealing tourist magnet.

"It's not in the Fashion District and it's not cool downtown," said Sarah Levine, who works in the building as a senior technical designer at Li & Fung, the consumer goods giant.

Some tenants are welcoming the changes. Jacques Catafago, a lawyer, began leasing space in 1990. He pays US$32 a square foot for a 4,900-square-foot space on the 48th floor. But his rent will soon rise to about US$52 a square foot.

Given the building improvements, Mr Catafago didn't balk at the new bill. Instead, he is looking forward to the gym. "I'll lose 20 pounds (9kg)," he predicted. - NYT

site_title: Le Noir's back, with thrills galore
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Le Noir's back, with thrills galore

Lee U-Wen

Published

Thu, Jun 19, 2014 · 10:00 PM

IMAGINE a pair of giant spinning wheels rotating high above the stage, with two men running inside and even on top of them like deranged hamsters. Without any safety harness, these Colombian acrobats jump, sprint and even skip rope as the wheels go faster and faster.

Without spoiling the surprise of the rest of this quite amazing Wheel of Death segment that is the grand finale of the circus spectacle Le Noir, let's just say it's likely to leave the audience squirming on the edge of their seats as they fear for the performers' lives.

See it for yourself since the show is back in Singapore at the Mastercard Theatres at Marina Bay Sands (MBS), the same venue where it entertained more than 18,000 people for nearly a month last year.

If you caught Le Noir during its inaugural run, you might notice that the majority of the acts this time around are similar, although some boast new performers with new moves and tricks in their repertoire.

Among the 20-strong cast are contortionists, dancers, musicians and a comedian, many of whom used to work for Cirque du Soleil.

The best thing: there's not a bad seat in the house when it comes to this show because Base Entertainment Asia (the company responsible for bringing Le Noir back to these shores) has once again transformed the theatre at MBS into a circus-like arena.

There's a custom-built circular stage where spectators get to enjoy a full 360-degree view of the action as it unfolds right before them.

There isn't much of a storyline during the two-hour show, but the performances are unique and visually stunning in their own way to keep the audience sufficiently engrossed.

Also, it's not just the "death-defying" acts that are worth catching - our favourite was a "fairly simple" one where a guy with a mohawk spins a large metal frame in the air with remarkable ease.

And, like most circus shows, those in the front rows might get more than what they paid for when they are asked to take part in a trick or two. (Ladies: beware a smooth-talking Frenchman who is seeking a date for a romantic picnic and won't take "no" for an answer.)

The clever use of colourful strobe lights and fast-paced music help add to the intensity of Le Noir. Seeing is truly believing, in this case.

Le Noir - The Intimate Side of Cirque is running at MasterCard Theatres, Marina Bay Sands, at 7.30pm on Tuesdays to Fridays; 3pm and 7.30pm on Saturdays; 1pm and 5.30pm on Sundays, until June 29. Tickets from $70 are available at

sistic.com.sg

I Reit Global plans US$300m Singapore IPO

Published

Thu, Jun 19, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] I Reit Global Management, backed by office buildings in Germany, is preparing an initial public offering (IPO) in Singapore that may raise about US$300 million, sources with knowledge of the matter said.

The property trust has received listing approval from the Singapore Exchange and is testing investor demand for the sale, the sources said, asking not to be named as the process is private.

Shanghai Summit Property Development, led by Chinese real estate tycoon Tong Jinquan, may buy more than half of the IPO, they said. Calls to Shanghai Summit's main office went unanswered.

Real estate investment trusts (Reits) and business trusts were the biggest fundraisers in Singapore's IPO market in the past year, according to data compiled by Bloomberg. The FTSE Straits Times Real Estate Investment Trust Index, comprising 32 trusts, has risen 6.6 per cent this year while the benchmark Straits Times Index has advanced 3.6 per cent.

Frasers Hospitality Trust plans to offer a dividend yield of 7 per cent for the 2015 financial year when it starts selling units in its IPO next week, sources said yesterday. OUE Commercial Real Estate Investment Trust raised US$274 million from a Singapore IPO in January, data compiled by Bloomberg show.

Mr Tong bought more than half the stock in Viva Industrial Trust's US$294 million offering in October. He also invested in Perennial China Retail Trust's Singapore IPO in 2011, and sold his stake almost a year later for an undisclosed price. - Bloomberg

site_title: Nostalgic paintings wow collectors
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Nostalgic paintings wow collectors

Helmi Yusof

Published

Thu, Jun 19, 2014 · 10:00 PM

EVEN before the opening of his first solo show at OCBC Art Space last Friday, painter Hilmi Johandi has sold five of the eight paintings being displayed at the bank's Chulia Street head office lobby.

The artist, who graduated last year from Lasalle College of the Arts, has been gaining good notices for his evocative, sepia-tinted paintings that hark back to an earlier Singapore. And collectors have been quick to snap up the works priced from $3,400 to $4,800.

Indeed, three paintings were bought by The Watch Fund co-founder Dominic Khoo alone, who says: "The paintings make you stop and look at them carefully. They remind me of the kind of photographs I used to take myself, the kind that rewards slow looking."

For this exhibition titled Dusk to Dawn, Hilmi used numerous photographic images of Singapore taken from the 1950s and 1960s as starting points. These were complemented with stills from P Ramlee films, which he grew up watching.

Hilmi juxtaposes the images and paints them in a diaphonous, scumbled way so the images appear soft and half-faded, as if they are set to vanish into thin air. The resulting images are arresting, enigmatic and tinged with elusive memories.

Hilmi, 27, says he is obsessed with the black-and-white cinema of yore, especially classic films by directors Yasujiro Ozu, Alfred Hitchcock and Ramlee. "I'm always looking back into the past to make sense of the present. It's as if there's a mystery to be unlocked and uncovered - and the only way to do it is to examine the images of the past," he says.

One of his stronger works, titled The Waltz, splits the canvas into two parts. On the right are three men wearing sarongs and sitting cross-legged on the floor (a scene taken from Ramlee's Bujang Lapok comedy) with a rural background behind them. On the left are four modern-dressed women seated at a table, with a dancehall in the background.

"I specifically wanted to use images of the 1950s and 1960s because this was the decade of rapid modernisation and transformation. Many of the images show the transition of Singaporeans from living in kampongs to high-rise buildings, from wearing traditional Asian clothing to so-called modern Western dress."

Another notable work is City Dwellers, which depicts a partial Stamford Raffles statue, a group of girls studying Chua Mia Tee's iconic 1950 painting National Language Class and random crowds against the background of low-rise flats.

"Everything changed so much, so quickly, for Singapore during those two decades. Blink and your environment is gone. In a way, these images represent the rapid changes of Singapore throughout all the decades," he says.

Dusk to Dawn, presented by OCBC and Galerie Steph, is on until June 27 at the OCBC Art Space at the lobby of OCBC Centre Branch, 65 Chulia Street. You may view the works during the bank's operating hours from Monday to Saturday

site_title: A fresh perspective of Chinatown
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

A fresh perspective of Chinatown

Published

Thu, Jun 19, 2014 · 10:00 PM

ARTIST Tung Yue Nang is perhaps best remembered for his series of Peranakan chinaware - a plate or a bowl, viewed from the top and with intricately representative details, framed in strict lines and a solidly red cloth.

One can't think of any other artist who has put such a strong stamp on still life painting in Singapore like he has since 1997.

After a hiatus of about eight years since his last exhibition, Tung now returns with an almost completely opposite series of works. From his intimate and Buddhist philosophy-infused view of the Peranakan table, Tung has switched his gaze and trained his brush on the lines and life of Chinatown. From the soft colours of nyonya-ware, he's now gone monochromatic in Silence, the title of this exhibition of some 30 ink-on-rice-paper paintings featuring Chinatown and Singapore River.

"There comes a time when artists need to take a break and step away," he says of his long hiatus, when he travelled extensively in South-east Asia for the last eight years. "I also took up photography because I bought a digital camera, so I wanted to develop and spend time with this new medium, and discover more of myself," elaborates the 55-year-old.

The first place he visited when he embarked on his new hobby was Angkor Wat, where he joined a photographic group. He extended his visit after the eight-day trip, and stayed on in a village.

Since then, his method of travel was to immerse himself in the local community and experience the pace of life and culture in countries like Cambodia, Vietnam and Thailand. "I took about three million photos in the last five years!" he enthuses.

He would spend just under a month in a country simply because that's how long Singaporeans can stay without a visa. "And I'd stay in the same village, living simply with the people and trying to understand their way of life. If you stay longer, that's when they involve you more in their lives," he adds.

Besides documenting their lives and collecting material for future work, Tung also took pictures for them. "I realised that these villagers didn't have photographs of themselves. To get a photo taken, they'd have to go all the way to town to get a studio shot, whereas I could do it easily for them."

"At first I thought I liked to shoot scenery, but I realised that I preferred photographing people, and it made it easier as well to communicate and interact with them."

When he finally returned to painting in Singapore, he found a fresh wave of inspiration from Chinatown - which he first painted 12 years ago.

"While that series was done in colour, my current one is in black and white. I feel that the single colour cuts out the unnecessary distractions from the painting."

He has some childhood memories of Chinatown, coupled with impressions of the place from his parents - first-generation immigrants from China - and memories of visits to his godmother who lived in the area.

"It's not where I grew up but I've bits and pieces of it in my mind, and now, with new immigrants from China, there are other different layers of scenes overlapping one another in my mind," he elaborates.

For the past two years, Tung painted on site, from 7am until the afternoon or evening - spending four and up to 12 hours a day soaking in the atmosphere and making a point to observe the changes in the day.

"I had to go there in the early morning because in some locations, once businesses started operating, I couldn't sit in front of their stores to paint. But I liked staying there for long periods - sometimes starting at 5am - to absorb the mood," he says.

In painting Chinatown, Tung joins a long list of artists who've tackled the subject. "What I've done is not to just focus on the architecture but to distil my own feelings about Chinatown and the blend of old and the new, and try to convey that in my paintings," he adds.

That explains the (incongruous) title, Silence, for drawings that capture the hustle and bustle of Chinatown. Tung would not rush to finish a painting, taking as long he liked to just get a sense of the scene. "Sometimes even in four hours, you're just scratching the surface. Painting to me is almost like meditation - I try to concentrate until things slow down around me, and I find the real meaning of what I'm trying to paint," he adds.

Tung was 17 when he started taking lessons from his sifu - Shi Xang Tuo and Ng Eng Teng - in a variety of Chinese artistic mediums, ranging from calligraphy, Chinese painting, engraving, ceramics and sculpture. He was a graphic designer until he became a full-time artist.

It's interesting that his latest series is based on something so close to home rather than on his travels in South-east Asia over the years - he talks fondly of the simple pleasures of life, of being with nature and joining the children playing in the river and sharing from one portion of rice.

Spending so much time painting the scenes of Chinatown, he became a familiar face there, he says. "There'd be an uncle who'd offer me coffee, and one time I paid for an old lady's drink when we were having lunch at the same table. The next day, she bought me a drink in return. So it's through these interactions that I slowly eased back into life in Singapore," he shares.

Sure, life is fast in Singapore but one can still find that peaceful spot in its midst. Now, it's up to art aficionados to see if they can discern the painter's inner core through his work - which is what Tung strived to capture through his rendering of Singapore's iconic locations.

Silence, which will be shown at Cape of Good Hope Art Gallery, features 97cm x 97cm pieces priced at $10,000 each. The exhibition is from June 21 until 30. The gallery at the Old Hill Street Police Station, 140 Hill Street #01-06, is open from 11am to 7pm daily. Tel: (65) 6733 3822.

site_title: Are shorter industrial leases a problem?
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Are shorter industrial leases a problem?

Hard to obtain loans and resell, but it ousts speculators

Published

Thu, Jun 19, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] The government's move to shorten industrial land tenures to help industrialists better manage costs is all well and good. Going by simple comparisons, it has even worked. Land prices have indeed fallen for plots rolled out from July 2012 whose leases have been halved to 20-30 years, from a maximum of 60 years previously.

Let's take two examples of plots situated close to each other that were sold before and after the 30-year lease cap was implemented. In March 2011, an Ubi Ave 4 site with a 60-year lease attracted the highest tender of $72.2 million, or $2,333 per square metre per plot ratio (psm ppr). Two years later, another site in the vicinity sold for $16.2 million, or $1,851 psm ppr. That's a 21 per cent price drop. Both sites were zoned Business-1.

Another example: a 58-year lease Serangoon North Ave 4 industrial site received a winning bid of $47.1 million, or $2,332 psm ppr, in March last year. Eight months after that, a nearby site at Ave 5 sold for $27 million, or $1,439 psm ppr - a stunning 38 per cent price drop.

The available like-for-like comparables are few and far between and thus are not conclusive, but the signs are pointing to the effectiveness of shorter tenures in reducing land prices. Not exactly in half in tandem with the tenures, however, since land values decline in a curve, not linearly, to their tenures. By analysts' calculations, cutting a lease from 60 to 30 years should theoretically lower its value by 25 per cent.

And yet, like squeezing a five-year university education into three, everything just becomes more intense over the shorter duration.

If we were to divide the quantum over the tenure to obtain the cost per year, purchase and construction costs, spread over a shorter period, would have risen instead. For the Ubi sites, the land prices would have jumped from $39 to $62 psm ppr per year, while the costs of the Serangoon North sites would have risen from $40 to $48 psm ppr per year.

Spreading the loan over a shorter tenure also results in higher monthly mortgages, which can reduce the company's liquidity and cash flow, said Mervyn Koh, head of Business Banking, Singapore, UOB Group. Some banks, such as DBS, require a lease period of at least 10 years at the end of the term loan, further shrinking the repayment period.

Alan Cheong, Savills Singapore research head, said: "Leverage plays an important role in the determination of asset values. . . Shorter tenures do not reduce the cash outlay of an end user who has a mortgage on the asset, because the loan tenure will correspondingly be shortened to account for the shorter lease. This can negate the price decline." The shorter tenures also make reselling the property more difficult. If the first owner already struggles to obtain financing for the purchase, imagine the hurdle a second buyer would face. Besides, not much demand exists for a property with a mere few years of the lease remaining in the resale market.

The shorter tenures also mean that the property's asset value will depreciate very quickly (in quantum terms per year). A 20-year lease site, after three years of construction and five years of minimum occupation, will have only 12 years left on its lease - not very much time for an investor to recoup his investment. But these shortcomings of shorter-tenure properties may precisely be what the government is aiming for: to make industrial property unattractive to speculators and investors so as to weed them out from the buyer pool.

Interest was diverted to this segment, especially for strata-titled industrial properties, from the residential sector after supply glut risks and government interventions started weighing down on the latter from 2011. The appeal of the industrial property segment was sweetened by its high rental yields and lower capital required.

R'ST Research director Ong Kah Seng said: "The main purpose of the government's slashing of leases is to clarify that industrial land is not for speculation. The government is hoping to dim their investment potential by reducing their long-term returns. Ousting specu-vestors will help keep prices and rents of industrial space more stable, with less mom-and-pop entry and more genuine ownership."

And the government has been very consistent in its stance with every cooling measure it has introduced.

The upshot for industrialists is that it will become increasingly easier for them to buy and own their own property for more stability in business costs, free from market fluctuations and landlords' rental hikes.

The property becomes less an asset for paper gain, and more a long-term rental guarantee.

site_title: Creating enormous bronze apples for Farrer Park hotel
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Creating enormous bronze apples for Farrer Park hotel

CHEAH UI-HOON goes behind the scenes of a monumental sculpture-in-the-making

Published

Thu, Jun 19, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THERE are Buddha figurines everywhere, in various stages of being made including a gigantic one where the lower half of the body is touching the roof of the foundry warehouse. In the midst of heads and limbs lying about waiting to be soldered together, two giant apples are in the final stage of completion.

Dust of all kinds - metal, ceramic and fine sand - swirls in the air as work at the bronze foundry is in full swing. In a hot but windy afternoon, the workers assigned to artist Kumari Nahappan's apple sculptures are polishing and smoothening the surface (a process called "chasing"), filling up and welding tiny holes to create a flawless finish. Kumari - in face mask and gloves - is closely overseeing the work to make sure it's done correctly.

Ever so quietly, in her characteristically gentle style, Kumari is putting the pressure on the Thai workers of Asia Fine Art (AFA) as the deadline to deliver the apples draws nearer. "They are very good in what they do, but this sculpture is also very different from the work they normally do, so I have to be here to supervise every step because it's more difficult and much more costly to correct something gone wrong," she explains. In two weeks, the monumental sculptures will be shipped from the foundry in Ayuthya, Thailand, to Singapore.

The giant apples will be gracing the entrance to the first five-star hotel in Farrer Park - One Farrer Hotel & Spa - and the adjoining Farrer Park Hospital, both of which are housed in a multi-use complex, Connexion.

The monumental sculptures are the very first art commission that One Farrer Park Company made, says Richard Helfer, member of the company's board and chairman of One Farrer Pte Ltd who is driving the company's art collection.

"We knew that we wanted to work with Kumari, but we left it to her to propose the idea," he explains. After months of discussion and thought, Kumari proposed the apples, which was a departure from her iconic tropical fruit such as peppers and nutmegs.

"In this case, I thought that there'd be much more acceptance for the apples - which I'd named Apollo and Artemis - given the nature of the buildings," she says.

The green "apple of life" was named after Artemis, the Greek goddess known for her affiliation for the wild and the pursuit of lifestyle, while the red apple is named after her twin, Apollo, who's the god of medicine and healing.

"I think the colours will be quite iconic because that's what people will remember as well, which helps makes that visual connection," says Dr Helfer.

The colour inspiration will come from Red Washington and Granny Smith apples. AFA's workers are experimenting with the shades now, using acid and fire to prepare the bronze surface before dabbing pigment on it so that the metal is able to hold the colour. The apples aren't going to be painted but given the right patina, which is an art in itself, explains Kumari.

It's not every day that she gets commissioned for her monumental sculptures, and in fact, Kumari can undertake only one or two such time-consuming projects like this in one year.

Her giant peppers burst onto Singapore's sculpture scene about a decade ago, and since then, her iconic works have made a monumental mark on the landscape - there is the bronze chilli-pepper, Pedas Pedas (2006) commissioned by the National Museum of Singapore, while her giant Saga (2007) can be seen at Changi Airport and the Nutmeg (2009) outside ION Orchard. Pembungaan (2011) is another monumental bronze mural of over 45m in length at OUE Bayfront.

"I couldn't do more than two projects like this a year," she says, and a first-hand look at the arduous process of making bronze sculptures helps one understand why. Besides the lengthy process, the complexity is further scaled up with monumental sculptures.

For a small sculpture using the lost wax method, the artist makes the mould, after which a negative wax imprint is made of it. Then it has to be dipped in several layers of ceramic glue, then fine sand and coarse sand (to retain its structure) over the course of a few days to a week. When everything has dried fully, melted bronze is poured into the moulds, cooled, and then the ceramic structure around it is broken, after which the bronze object has to be treated and given its final finish. All this takes weeks, much more so when it's a new, one-off creation.

For Kumari's gigantic works, the sculpture is made in parts and then later soldered together. Because they're so large, the parts are put into a sand mould rather than a ceramic mould. "And because it's made with a sand mould, the surface is much less perfect than when it's made with a ceramic mould," she explains.

But she's worked with this foundry since 2002 because of the high quality of the bronze it uses (it is imported from Australia) and its willingness to work on her pieces, she says, as well as the high standards maintained.

The foundry's main income is from the Buddhist statues and also statues of Thai kings, present and past. "So you can understand that they are working out of the norm when they have to work on my sculptures," she notes.

But Kumari's works also perk up the workers' otherwise quite predictable routine, pushes the limit of their expertise, and her ideas are inspiring, says Thawan Muengchang, the owner of AFA, beaming at us as he pops by to chat. "She really has unusual and good ideas . . . we like working with her," he adds in halting English. He has assigned a few staff who speak English well enough to work with Kumari.

The foundry also works with other artists. Sometimes, however, commissions can fall through - we were shown a huge sculpture, almost three meters tall, of a muscular man standing on top of a globe. Instead of piecing the almost-finished work together though, workers were taking it apart as the order was cancelled at the last minute.

It's heart-breaking to see all the man hours go down the drain, and even if the bronze can be melted down to be used again, its quality is compromised.

At least, though, there's the foundry's satisfaction of knowing that Kumari's sculptures will get to their final destination in Singapore - where they'll stand as a testimony to one artist's concept and a foundry's craftsmanship.

site_title: Fed sees slower growth for year despite rebound
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Fed sees slower growth for year despite rebound

It also keeps to plan to taper its stimulus campaign

Published

Thu, Jun 19, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[WASHINGTON] The Federal Reserve said on Wednesday that economic growth had rebounded after a nasty winter even as it slashed its economic forecast for this year to reflect the unexpected contraction during the early months of the year.

In a show of confidence that the winter was an aberration, the Fed also continued to retreat from its economic stimulus campaign. As expected, it announced that it would reduce its monthly bond purchases by US$10 billion to US$35 billion beginning next month, and that it still expects to stop expanding its holdings later this year.

"Growth in economic activity has rebounded in recent months," the Fed said in a statement after a two-day meeting of its policymaking committee. It said that labour markets, household spending and business investment all were improving.

The committee's decision was unanimous.

In predictions published on Wednesday, Fed officials estimated that the economy would expand 2.1 to 2.3 per cent this year, down from a March forecast for growth of 2.8 to 3 per cent. It is the seventh straight year that the Fed's initial optimism has been eroded by disappointing data.

But officials maintained relatively optimistic forecasts for 2015 and 2016, predicting growth next year would exceed 3 per cent for the first time since the recession.

At the same time, officials predicted that the unemployment rate would decline more quickly than they had expected in March, also part of a continuing pattern. They predicted the rate would end the year between 6 per cent and 6.1 per cent. The decline is primarily a result of a shrinking work force rather than job growth.

Fed officials also remained sanguine about inflation, making only small changes to their predictions that inflation will remain at or below 2 per cent through 2016.

There was also little change in the expectations of Fed officials about the timing of an initial rate increase. Twelve of the 16 participants expected a first increase in 2015; half thought the rate would be at or below one per cent at the end of the year.

About a year has passed since Fed officials gave the first signal that they would begin to wind down the Fed's stimulus campaign. After buying US$85 billion in bonds each month last year, the Fed has steadily reduced the volume of its monthly purchases; it plans to buy US$45 billion in June, and to end the purchases later this year.

The economic contraction during the first quarter of this year has not shifted the Fed's plans because officials regard it as a hiccup rather than a change in the economic weather. They have pointed to evidence of stronger growth this spring.

Some private-sector economists agree. James Paulsen, chief investment strategist at Wells Capital Management, says that he sees signs of gathering momentum, including increased lending by banks and borrowing by consumers.

"The real stimulus comes when the free market starts to stimulate, and that is happening now," Mr Paulsen said. "This is now the most stimulative moment at any time in the recovery," he added, as money changes hands more quickly.

But faster growth may bring its own challenges. The Fed's chairwoman, Janet Yellen, has argued that inflation is not likely to rise as long as millions of people remain unable to find work, allowing the Fed to continue its stimulus campaign.

Other economists, however, predict that inflation will begin to rise more quickly because many people without jobs have been marginalised, and are no longer being treated by employers as effective competitors for available jobs. - NYT

site_title: Two former staff of Darco unit sentenced to jail
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Two former staff of Darco unit sentenced to jail

Taipei court found ex-GM guilty of fraud, CBT; former admin manager guilty of fraud

Published

Thu, Jun 19, 2014 · 10:00 PM

DARCO Water Technologies, a mainboard-listed provider of water and wastewater system solutions, yesterday announced that two former employees of a subsidiary have been sentenced to jail by Taiwan's Taipei District Court.

Darco said "this update has no material financial impact on the group".

On Wednesday, former Darco Engineering (Taiwan) (DET) general manager Chen Kuai was found guilty of criminal breach of trust and embezzlement and was sentenced to a total of six years' imprisonment. The company's former administration manager, Nina Chiu, was found guilty of embezzlement and was sentenced to a jail term of three years and eight months.

"Third parties facilitators and conspirators had been dealt with separately," added Darco in its statement.

In May last year, the two former employees had been formally charged by Taipei's District Prosecutors Office for alleged fraud, breach of trust and misappropriating company funds, while 16 other suppliers were charged with alleged complicity.

Darco had first expressed its concerns about the way in which DET's accounts had been managed to the Singapore Exchange in March 2010.

Said Thye Kim Meng, chief executive officer of Darco: "At Darco, we view cases involving fraud and embezzlement very seriously. We will spare no efforts in taking action against perpetrators of these acts.

"The judgment by the Taipei District Court represents positive news for our shareholders and clients who have kept their faith with us over the years."

He added that in the past year, the group has further strengthened its accounting and internal control functions, citing the appointments of Darco's new group financial controller and group chief financial officer.

"Going forward, we will continue to uphold the highest standards of financial integrity, and be vigilant in the prevention and detection of potential fraud," added Mr Thye.

Darco is listed on the Singapore Exchange mainboard. Its principal activities include the area of engineered water systems. This involves the design, fabrication, installation and commissioning of water purification and wastewater treatment systems.

Darco shares last changed hands at 3.7 cents each.

site_title: Prime cuts for the gym-bound
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Prime cuts for the gym-bound

Published

Fri, Jun 20, 2014 · 10:00 PM

The Daily Cut

B1-31 One Raffles Place

Hours: 11am to 9pm daily

www.thedailycut.sg

Opens July 9

JONATHAN Yang is his own best customer, and the former public relations professional-turned-restaurateur isn't shy to admit it.

"A lot of the things I do either solve a problem or address my own needs, preferably both," he laughs. The California-born Singaporean, after all, started his San Francisco Mission-style burrito bar Muchachos a year ago to satisfy a craving for his childhood comfort food.

His second venture, The Daily Cut, which opens in two weeks, was likewise created from what he saw as the dearth of decent health food joints here.

"I work out in the gym three to four times a week, and after each session, I want to feed my body a high-protein, nutritious meal that is tasty and also clean, but it is impossible to find anything," he explains. "It's a pain to have to cook it myself, or I have to tell the servers to hold the gravy, the fries and the coleslaw if I eat out. It takes too much effort."

He believes that he isn't the only one in the fitness-obsessed working class in Singapore who is inconvenienced. "There are a good amount of people out there who want to consume a higher protein diet, but Asian meals tend to be very carbohydrate-heavy. High-protein local options also tend to be battered and deep-fried. The Daily Cut is my answer for people who want to eat healthier but for whom the idea of choking down a salad is repulsive," he says.

Unlike salad bar chains where you often have to pay $12 to $15 for a bowl of greens with a just few slivers of meat, The Daily Cut will be protein-centric, says Mr Yang. Its name is a subtle play on words as the process of "cutting" in bodybuilding vocabulary refers to a dieting phase focused on gaining muscle mass while shedding fat.

At The Daily Cut, you custom create a "meat box" by first choosing a base protein from options such as salmon, turkey, beef steak, chicken thigh or tofu, and then picking Subway counter-style from complex carbohydrate sides such as sweet potato, brown rice and whole wheat pasta. You complete the box by supplementing it with healthy toppings such as walnuts, almonds, sous-vide-cooked eggs or fresh avocado and mozzarella.

Meat boxes come in three sizes depending on their protein content: regular-sized boxes come with one protein option, large ones with two, or go the whole hog with "the beast"-sized servings of your choice of three proteins. No heavy marinades or gravy-coated servings here; all the meats are lightly grilled or roasted and each portion - beef steaks weigh in at 180gm to 220gm, chicken thighs or breast meat at 220gm to 280gm - will be sliced in front of you when you order, "so people see exactly what they are paying for," explains Mr Yang.

Like with Muchachos, Mr Yang is expecting a largely take-away crowd at the 660 square foot, 24-seat eatery in the heart of Raffles Place. It helps too, that there are at least 12 commercial gyms within a kilometre radius around the joint, he observes. "If no one is doing something like this yet, why shouldn't I be the first one?"

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Genting S'pore's Korea casino plan stalls

Ground-breaking ceremony in Jeju Island postponed

Published

Thu, Jun 19, 2014 · 10:00 PM

GENTING Singapore's plans to build a casino in South Korea have been stalled, Channel NewsAsia (CNA) reported yesterday evening, citing a statement from the mainboard-listed casino operator.

Instead of going ahead with initial plans for a ground-breaking ceremony in Jeju Island on June 24, the company has decided to reschedule the event.

The postponement is to "allow the company the opportunity to brief the newly-elected governor of Jeju and his team on the casino's development plans and its contribution to Jeju Island", according to CNA.

The news also said that a separate e-mail was sent to notify guests of the change; Genting Singapore had said that Resorts World Jeju was expected to break ground in Q3 this year, and slated to open in stages three years from now.

Genting Singapore had first announced in February that it had partnered a Chinese property developer, Landing International Development, to build and operate a US$2.2 billion integrated resort on Jeju island.

The 2.3 million square metre property is expected to be Genting's flagship Korean casino venture and Jeju island's largest tourism resort to date. It will have luxury hotels, a shopping mall, a theme park, villas and apartments, casinos and other leisure and entertainment facilities.

With Genting Singapore's recent sterling Q1 results, some analysts have been recommending a buy on the stock, as they expect the Jeju project in South Korea and a potential bid win in Japan next year to boost the share price.

Genting Singapore shares closed trading yesterday unchanged at $1.33.

site_title: World Cup tourists might bring in parasites
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

World Cup tourists might bring in parasites

350 new plant parasites could be brought into Brazil, say agriculture watchdogs

Published

Thu, Jun 19, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[RIO DE JANEIRO] Agriculture watchdogs in Brazil fear foreigners arriving for the World Cup could bring up to 350 new plant parasites into the country.

American tourists pose the biggest threat, since the US has 225 agricultural parasites that do not currently exist in Brazil, said the National Plant Defense Association (Andef), an agro-industry umbrella group.

Italian fans, who could bring in up to 126 new parasites, and French fans, who could bring in up to 120, are also making farmers nervous.

A recent study found foreign parasites are more and more frequent in Brazil, such as the cotton bollworm, or Helicoverpa armigera, which arrived from Australia late last year.

Major sports events raise the risk of invasions of foreign species, said Andef.

During the 2008 Beijing Olympics, 35 new parasites arrived in China.

The Brazilian authorities have moved to crack down on unwanted pests by keeping a tight control on imports.

On June 9 they impounded 39 kilogrammes of the Uruguayan national team's dulce de leche, a caramel-like confection made from milk that is a national favourite in Uruguay.

The team lacked the necessary document from the authorities, said a spokesman for the federal agriculture regulators' union.

Andef said that the most exposed of Brazil's 12 host cities was Recife in the north-east, a region known for its sugar cane, cotton and cocoa farms.

With matches featuring Ivory Coast, Croatia, Italy, Costa Rica, Japan, Mexico, Germany and the US, Recife could be invaded by no less than 323 new parasites.

About 600,000 tourists are expected to attend the World Cup. The US leads the pack with 187,000, followed by Germany with 57,000 and Argentina with 56,000. - AFP

site_title: SingPost speeds up transformation efforts
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

SingPost speeds up transformation efforts

Angela Tan

Published

Thu, Jun 19, 2014 · 10:00 PM

SingPost

Follow

SINGPOST said yesterday that it has been speeding up its transformation efforts in view of the global decline in its traditional mail business.

"SingPost has been accelerating its transformation efforts over the past few years, and continues to pursue opportunities, both organic and via M&As, to drive growth in Singapore and the regional markets," it said.

It said this as part of a response to a Singapore Exchange (SGX) query on Wednesday on the unusual price and volume movements of its shares.

SingPost said that it knew of no other information not previously announced that would have explained the trading activity.

SGX has in response issued a "trade with caution" on the stock.

SingPost separately revealed yesterday that it has won the 15th World Mail Award 2014 for e-commerce.

Wolfgang Baier, SingPost chief executive officer, attributed the award to the company's ability to reinvent its postal business.

"Letter mail volume continues to decline rapidly here in Singapore and globally. Last year, our domestic mail volume fell 1.3 per cent, marking the second consecutive year of declines. Escalating operating costs compound our challenges. To make up for declining volumes and higher costs, we had to transform and develop a second wing."

Dr Baier said that at the same time, the changing landscape saw an explosive growth in e-commerce globally with the e-commerce logistics market in the Asia-Pacific expected to hit US$175 billion by 2016.

He added that this presented a huge opportunity for SingPost to grow its second wing, and added that the company responded quickly to develop a revolutionary new set of e-commerce models.

SingPost has been in the limelight after Alibaba Group Holding, China's biggest e-commerce company, agreed to buy a 10 per cent stake in the company to develop its logistics in South-east Asia.

Alibaba had said that it would spend $312.5 million to acquire about 220 million new and existing SingPost shares and that the two companies would enter talks for an e-commerce logistics venture.

Recently, CIMB hosted SingPost chief financial officer (CFO) Ng Hin Lee and deputy CFO Daniel Phua at its 4th Annual Asia Pacific Conference. CIMB said in a note later that Alibaba's decision to partner SingPost rather than other regional logistics providers reaffirms the company's leading position in e-commerce logistics. It has also identified Indonesia as a key market in South-east Asia.

"SingPost offers an attractive dividend yield of 4 per cent while also providing potential earnings upside from the collaboration with Alibaba and M&A activity," analysts Jessalynn Chen and Kenneth Ng said.

"We maintain our add rating and DCF-based target price of $1.86," they added.

SingPost shares closed trading yesterday at $1.745, down two cents.

site_title: Fab Four return on mono vinyl format
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Fab Four return on mono vinyl format

Dylan Tan

Published

Thu, Jun 19, 2014 · 10:00 PM

A GOOD thing never gets old and fans of The Beatles can prepare to hear the Fab Four exactly like the way they first heard the group in the 60s, when a new collection is released in September.

Targeted at audiophiles and Beatles purists, the set will feature the band's nine UK albums (except Let It Be and Abbey Road, which were only mixed in stereo), the American-compiled Magical Mystery Tour, and the Mono Masters collection of non-album tracks in full mono glory on 180-gramme vinyl LPs, complete with faithfully replicated artwork.

Freshly mastered from the original analogue tapes, each album will be available individually or as a lavish, limited edition 14-LP box set which comes with a 108-page hardbound book.

The Beatles in Mono collection was originally issued on CD in 2009 together with the stereo mixes - imaginatively titled The Beatles in Stereo - which went on to get the vinyl treatment in 2012. However, unlike the stereo LPs from two years ago which were directly pressed from the CD masters - a move that had fans and audiophiles up in arms - the new set will not involve any sort of digital manipulation or technology.

Instead, they will be mastered exclusively for vinyl from quarter-inch master tapes at Abbey Road Studios by Grammy-winning engineer Sean Magee and mastering supervisor Steve Berkowitz, who employed the same techniques used in the 1960s and used detailed transfer notes made by the original cutting engineers.

The pair also worked in the same room at Abbey Road where most of The Beatles' albums were initially cut and dedicated the first weeks to concentrated listening and comparing the master tapes with first pressings of the mono records made in the 1960s. After that, a Studer A80 machine was used to play back the precious tapes from which a new vinyl master was cut on a 1980s-era VMS80 lathe.

The exhaustive exercise is detailed in the box set's exclusive 12-inch by 12-inch hardbound book featuring new essays and a detailed history of the mastering process by award-winning radio producer-author Kevin Howlett. It also contains many rare studio photos of the band, archived documents, and articles and advertisements sourced from 1960s publications to advertise the LPs.

For decades, the group's producer George Martin and the mop-topped quartet themselves have explicitly stated the best way to enjoy their music is to listen to it in mono - the predominant audio format before the introduction of stereo. In fact, up until 1968, every Beatles album was issued in both mono and stereo mixes for fans to decide between the two.

'The Beatles in Mono' is out on Sept 8 through Universal Music and available for pre-order now at

www.thebeatles.com

site_title: Art for under $3,000 at pop-up show
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Art for under $3,000 at pop-up show

Helmi Yusof

Published

Thu, Jun 19, 2014 · 10:00 PM

FOR former advertising executive Hoong Yun Peng, her new career as the organiser of pop-up art shows is a long time coming. Today marks the opening of Fun Art, the first of what she hopes to be a series of pop-up exhibitions featuring works by young artists which are priced affordably. For the inaugural show at Goodman Arts Centre, nearly all the works by eight artists from Singapore, China and Indonesia are priced below $3,000, with 75 per cent of the works priced below $2,000.

Ms Hoong has dreamt of a career in art since her 20s. Now 40, Ms Hoong quit her position as a group account director in Ogilvy Beijing a year ago to start Fun Art, which puns on the Chinese word "fan" to refer to a tasteful and stylish appearance.

If the inaugural show does well, Ms Hoong wants to stage a pop-up show every three months at different locations and featuring different artists.

She says: "When I was working in Ogilvy Beijing, I spent my free time going to art exhibitions in Beijing's top art schools. I got to know some of the promising students and worked with them to bring their works to Singapore. As it is, a few of them are already in some demand, so I had to work hard to have their pieces appear in this show and in future shows."

Four of the featured artists are from China, three from Singapore and one is Indonesian. Most of them are below 30 years old.

Ms Hoong says: "I want to create a more intimate environment for getting to know art, a place where you can stop and chat with the artists, four of whom will be present at the show. It is, in a sense, to counter the busy and crowded art fair scenario of art buying."

Because it's her first show, Ms Hoong is keeping it small with 24 works on display. But she hopes the next show will be a bigger one.

Among the interesting artists is China's Zhao Shuhong, a 29-year-old printmaking graduate from the Tianjin Academy of Fine Arts. His eye-catching Deconstruction series depicts detailed mini-universes of machinery inhabited by bug-like minions. The lithographs are available in editions of 20 and priced at $1,800 with frame.

Among the Singaporean artists is Allison Low, a graduate of University of New South Wales College of Fine Arts, whose dark and unsettling images depict young children engaging in less than wholesome games.

Fun Art opens today and runs until Sunday at The Gallery at Goodman Arts Centre, 90 Goodman Road, Block B, #01-08, from 10am to 9pm
