SUBSCRIBERS

Geo Energy to buy stake in coal-rich firm

Published

Thu, Jun 19, 2014 · 10:00 PM

INDONESIAN coal mining firm Geo Energy Resources plans to buy a stake in a company with mining licences for two coal concessions in South Kalimantan, in a move which could boost its coal production dramatically.

The transaction will cost it a consideration of US$55 million and add at least 30 million tonnes to Geo Energy's current 11.1 million tonnes of reserves in its concession in East Kalimantan.

The company on Wednesday agreed conditionally to buy a stake in Singapore-incorporated Borneo International Resources Pte Ltd from an Indonesian named Lenny Limanto and his British Virgin Islands-incorporated investment holding company.

Borneo International Resources has, in turn, agreed to subscribe to new shares in PT Era Tiga Putra at one million rupiah per new share; via the latter's subsidiary, it agreed to subscribe to new shares in PT Sungai Danau Jaya.

Upon completion, the subsidiary, PT Karunia Mitra Berkat, will own 93.3 per cent of Sungai Danau Jaya, which has no business operations besides holding two mining licences.

The first licence, which expires on March 8 next year, is for a 194.9 hectare area in Angsana in the regency of Tanah Bumbu; the second, which expires on May 22, 2022, is for an adjacent area of 41.2 hectares.

The proposed acquisition is in line with Geo Energy's business strategy to expand its business operations and raise production levels, the company said.

The agreement is conditional on the approval of Geo Energy's board and shareholders, an independent technical report being prepared and issued, and getting the necessary regulatory approvals, among other terms.

Geo Energy will carry out the relevant due diligence on the companies; if anything is not to its satisfaction, it will be able to end the agreement without paying any termination fee.

The acquisition is expected to reduce the company's net tangible assets per share from 10.52 US cents to 10.38 US cents, and its earnings per share from 1.09 US cents to 0.95 US cent.

Its gearing will go up from 0.21 times to 0.66 times.

For the first quarter ended March 31, Geo Energy's net profit fell to US$89,066, from US$5.13 million a year ago, as cost of sales almost doubled from an increase in equipment maintenance cost and transhipment cost.

Revenue slipped 7 per cent to US$16.6 million, on account of weak demand for coal with low calorific value and a drop in coal prices.

Geo Energy had said then that the Indonesian coal mining industry was under pressure from increasing supply and slow demand growth. With its key operating costs expected to increase along with inflation rates in Indonesia, the group will see its profit shrink if global coal prices continue to slide, it warned.

The counter gained 0.5 cent, or 1.64 per cent, to end trading at 31 cents yesterday.

site_title: Westports gets boost from China's objection to P3
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Westports gets boost from China's objection to P3

Published

Wed, Jun 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE unravelling of the P3 shipping alliance has dispelled lingering investor disaffection over Malaysian port operator Westports Holdings - its shares rose 2.2 per cent yesterday to RM2.75 apiece.

P3 was to have been an alliance of three of the world's largest container carriers - Maersk Line, Mediterranean Shipping Co (MSC) and CMA-CGM - and a threat to the future of Westports.

If the alliance had come to pass, it would have resulted in a revision of port calls and potentially divert CMA's throughput to the Port of Tanjong Pelepas (PTP), in which Maersk has an interest.

And CMA-CGM is Westports single largest customer - a factor which by itself had spooked investors against the generally well-run port operator, whose counter never really shot past its RM2.50 initial public offering price from the get-go last year.

P3's dissolution follows China's Ministry of Commerce's rejection of it on the grounds that the alliance would be anti-competitive. It also signals that the status quo would remain, and that Westports' stock is likely to be re-rated upwards.

Businessman G Gnanalingam, who controls 48 per cent of Westports, seemed cautiously cheerful. He told The Business Times: "It should augur well for us going forward."

Hong Kong tycoon Li Ka-shing's Hutchison Whampoa holds a 23 per cent interest in Westports.

P3 had, at one time, appeared poised for implementation, having received the approval of the European Commission and the US Federal Marine Commission.

China's Ministry of Commerce, in throwing a spanner into the works on Tuesday, said that the alliance would hold a combined 46.7 per cent market share, which it said was in breach of its anti-competition policies.

RHB Research cheered the collapse of the P3 plan and called a "buy" on Westports, saying that the development could lift the port operator's earnings for the year by 2-3 per cent. The bank also revised the stock's valuation, on a discounted cash flow basis, from RM2.91 to RM3.23 a share.

RHB Research said in a note yesterday: "The proposed alliance has been a dampener on the longer-term outlook of Westports, as P3 could potentially grow in size.

"Our earnings upgrades impute a FY15 price-earnings ratio of 22."

The regional industry average of the port operator's peers is 23.

Westports is awaiting government approval for a tariff hike, given that tariffs have remained flat for more than 11 years. RHB estimated that higher tariffs could add RM90 million to Westports' bottom line.

Another bright spot on the port operator's horizon is that it offers an annual dividend yield of at least 4 per cent and has no debt to speak of.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Premium travel outlook more positive

Nisha Ramchandani

Published

Thu, Jun 19, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE demand for premium seats in international markets appears to be stabilising with the number of travellers in premium cabins growing at a sharper 3.8 per cent globally in April, compared to just 1.9 per cent a month earlier.

"The outlook for premium travel markets is broadly positive," said the International Air Transport Association (Iata) in its latest premium traffic monitor.

"Global business confidence continues to signal economic growth, and May data suggests that conditions could be picking up after a slowdown in Q1. In particular, improvements in advanced economies will help sustain growth in premium travel ahead, as should easing downward pressure from emerging markets like China."

The Far East market also grew strongly in April, with the number of passengers travelling in premium seats increasing 7.2 per cent year-on-year, compared to the more muted 1.6 per cent seen in March as the Chinese economy posted slower GDP growth in 1Q14.

Markets linked to the Middle East - such as the Far East, Europe and Africa - continued to perform robustly in April as the Gulf nations recorded high levels of business activity on the back of healthy growth in non-oil-producing sectors.

Within Europe, the premium travel market was up 2.6 per cent - reversing the contraction of 2.5 per cent in March - with demand for regional air travel likely to improve, thanks to expectations of higher GDP growth in Q2.

Within North and South America, premium traffic growth was nearly flat and down 8.1 per cent, respectively. However, routes such as North America- Central America and North America-South America posted growth of 11.3 per cent and 3.6 per cent, respectively, supported by the improving economy in the US and strong Central American growth markets.

Since late last year, much of the rising demand for premium travel (which is linked to trade) has been underpinned by a pick-up in the European and US economies.

site_title: B787 fire at Heathrow linked to wiring
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

B787 fire at Heathrow linked to wiring

Blaze started in a battery in the plane's emergency locator transmitter

Published

Thu, Jun 19, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[NEW YORK] UK investigators linked the fire on board a parked Boeing Co 787 Dreamliner at London's Heathrow Airport last year to faulty wiring in the plane's emergency locator transmitter.

The blaze began in a battery in the unit made by Honeywell International, the UK's Air Accidents Investigation Branch said in a report released yesterday. The battery wires were improperly installed, and an inspection of the beacon's flame-damaged case suggested a short circuit, the agency said.

"This incident has highlighted that better coordination is required between battery manufacturers, equipment manufacturers, aircraft manufacturers and regulators to ensure equipment-level and aircraft-level safety," the agency said.

The report into the July 2013 fire on the Ethiopian Airlines Enterprise Dreamliner confirmed investigators' preliminary focus on the battery wiring. The blaze initially stirred fresh concern that the 787 had a serious electrical flaw after the global fleet was grounded following two meltdowns on a separate lithium-ion battery system.

US regulators that oversee Chicago-based Boeing should develop standards for certifying lithium-metal batteries in aviation, the UK board said. Batteries on the Honeywell-made beacons are of the lithium-metal type, and have a different chemistry than lithium-ion models.

The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) should ask manufacturers to determine the worst possible effects of a thermal runaway and to demonstrate that damage to a single battery cell wouldn't spread to others, causing a fire, the UK board said. The FAA and Boeing didn't immediately respond to requests for reaction to the report.

The FAA told operators last year to inspect planes with certain Honeywell-made beacons, which are used in thousands of aircraft.

Lithium-metal batteries are high-energy storage devices that aren't rechargeable, unlike the 787's rechargeable lithium-ion batteries. While Honeywell created cell separators and safety vents to mitigate the risk of thermal runaway, all five cells of the beacon's battery overheated, the British safety board determined.

The "most probable cause" of the Heathrow 787 fire "was a short-circuit caused by the improperly installed battery wires, leading to an uncontrolled discharge of the battery", the board said. - Bloomberg

site_title: China veto a wake-up call for world's dealmakers
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

China veto a wake-up call for world's dealmakers

Published

Wed, Jun 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[HONG KONG] Chinese regulators have sunk their first overseas transaction, killing a container-shipping alliance led by Denmark's Maersk . The particular national interest made this tie-up especially vulnerable. But there's a real risk China could torpedo other global deals.

Antitrust blocks from China are rare. Though Beijing has made acquirers such as Glencore wait months and agree concessions to win approval, this is the first time the Ministry of Commerce has denied a deal between non-Chinese firms. And it's only the second-ever "no" since the regulator blocked Coca-Cola's attempt to buy juice-maker Huiyuan in 2009.

This is a reminder of the wide-ranging powers granted under China's refreshed competition law six years ago. None of the parties to the deal were Chinese. But groups need only make US$64 million in annual sales in the People's Republic to face scrutiny.

Based on the ministry's terse announcement, the decision seems justifiable. Maersk wanted to cut costs by sharing ships with Switzerland's Mediterranean Shipping and France's CMA CGM. But Chinese shipping associations balked at the proposed "P3"network, fearing future price-fixing.

The ministry concurred, saying the tie-up would have raised the groups' control of the vital Asia-Europe route to levels that would stifle competition and harm the public interest.

There was an important wrinkle here. Chinese rules are stricter than US or EU laws on classifying some industry alliances as mergers. The P3 network sidestepped formal merger reviews in Brussels and Washington.

But Chinese law also allows authorities to look more widely at the industrial consequences.

The P3 alliance would have transformed a sector that houses big Chinese players such as Cosco and China Shipping. Moreover, as the world's largest goods trading nation, with US$4.16 trillion of exports and imports in 2013, China has an obvious interest in ensuring global trade stays cheap.

For dealmakers, the denial is a shot across the bows just as mergers and acquisitions activity takes off. Global M&A is up 68 per cent in the year to date, at US$1.51 trillion, according to Thomson Reuters data. Other tie-ups such as Holcim-Lafarge are awaiting clearance. And the ministry has just proved it isn't afraid to capsize deals it doesn't like.

site_title: Asia's millionaires set to overtake North America's
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Asia's millionaires set to overtake North America's

They will outpace the Americans in number and wealth

Published

Thu, Jun 19, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THIS year, the number of millionaires in Asia is expected to surpass that in North America. By next year, the wealth that these Asian millionaires hold will also overtake that of their North American counterparts, predicted a report by Capgemini Financial Services and RBC Wealth Management.

The two regions are already about neck and neck in the number of such high net worth individuals (HNWIs): Asia-Pacific has 4.32 million of them and North America 4.33 million. Together, they account for almost two thirds of the 13.7 million HNWIs in the world.

In terms of investable wealth, Asians hold US$14.2 trillion, and North Americans US$14.9 trillion. Together, they make up just over half of the world's US$52.6 trillion of HNWI wealth.

But Asia is growing at a faster pace. That is one of the key takeaways from the 2014 World Wealth Report, said Claire Sauvanaud, vice-president and senior account executive for Capgemini Asia Pacific.

"Among these high-growth areas are some 'old rich' ones like Kuwait and Norway and the likes of China, Taiwan and Singapore," she said. "Hong Kong is completely off the charts, having benefited from the growth of China."

Looking ahead for the next three years, every region except Latin America is expected to grow strongly, with Asia-Pacific growing at almost 10 per cent a year. By contrast, North America is expected to grow just 6.4 per cent a year.

HNWI wealth hit new records in 2013 despite relatively stagnant global economic growth. This is because many persistent economic woes like the eurozone recession and the US debt crisis had faded in intensity, leading to better performance in markets.

The numbers of the world's wealthy grew the most in the US and Japan last year. The US remains the country with the largest number of HNWIs around the world, at around four million. Japan is second, at 2.3 million.

Singapore's HNWI population grew 4.5 per cent last year to reach 105,000 individuals.

Growth was driven by the expansion in the economy but was constrained by flat or somewhat declining real estate and stock markets, the report said.

Meanwhile, wealth is unsurprisingly concentrated at the very top. Among the 13.7 million HNWIs with at least US$1 million in investable assets, a mere 0.9 per cent, or around 128,300, have US$30 million or more. These "ultra-HNWIs" hold a third of HNWI wealth.

Where asset allocation is concerned, HNWIs with more than US$20 million in investable assets are shifting their focus the most, from wealth preservation to wealth growth.

Cash levels around the world declined from 28.2 per cent in 2013 to 26.6 per cent in 2014. The money went into fixed income and alternative investments - mainly hedge funds and some foreign exchange.

The wealthy seek to make an impact on their society.

The top three priorities are health, education, and children's causes.

site_title: Real-life scares for cast of Malaysian horror movie
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Real-life scares for cast of Malaysian horror movie

Published

Thu, Jun 19, 2014 · 10:00 PM

HORROR films like The Blair Witch Project and The Exorcist were not just famous for scaring audiences but also notorious for supernatural incidents that took place on the sets.

Teddy Chin, 29, and Mindee Ong, 33 - the two leads in Malaysian horror movie The Transcend, which opened yesterday - also experienced a few scares of their own during the shoot.

While cast and crew fortunately survived the experience unscathed, Ong admits that they were largely superstitious about the whole affair. For example, they lost entire chunks of footage - not once, but twice.

"When we had to shoot again, we did everything we possibly could: we got a religious master to bless the set, made offerings, and everyone who believed prayed together. After that, filming went smoothly," Ong recalls.

"A lot of the crew also heard noises. We were filming in a hospital basement, and every day at around 2 or 3am, they would hear babies cry - but the hospital had already been converted into an old folks' home," adds Ong, though she admits she never had a direct encounter herself.

The film revolves around Yan Dong (Chin), a horror writer who doesn't believe in the supernatural, He joins a Taoist monastery to get a better experience for his next book and, there, he meets Shan Shan (Ong) - a member of the monastery's funeral troupe, who has many secrets of her own.

Chin says that, like his character, he doesn't really believe in ghosts either. However, he has had an encounter of a girl crawling towards him, upside down, which ended up being included in the film.

Surprisingly, both actors insist that neither of them is scared of ghosts. "I realised ghosts used to be people too, and if you can see them, you might be able to help them," says Chin.

"I think they're just a part of our life," adds Ong, who admits she often lets her imagination run wild, especially when they were filming in rural places, and scared herself during the filming process.

According to Chin, 80 per cent of The Transcend's plot is made up of real-life ghost stories that have been adapted, and his character and Ong's represent people's general attitude towards the supernatural - whether they are cynics or fervent believers.

She adds that The Transcend is different from other horror films as it is not the fear that audiences will remember afterwards, but the tragedy and backstory of the spirits in the film. There are also lessons to be learnt, she adds, such as being filial, and being able to let some things go.

"I love horror movies - I enjoy the thrill, and with a good storyline, it can make a very good film," shares Ong.

Additional reporting by RACHEL LOI

1997:

Eric Khoo's ensemble-cast heartland drama 12 Storeys became the first Singapore film to be invited for the Un Certain Regard section.

2003:

Tan Pin Pin's Moving House selected for the Kodak Emerging Filmmakers Showcase.

2005:

Eric Khoo's Be With Me - a 93-minute drama with less than three minutes of dialogue and the first local film to explicitly feature a lesbian relationship in the plot - opened the Directors' Fortnight.

2006:

12 Singapore films showcased at World Cinema (Tous les Cinémas du Monde) including the full-length features One Last Dance (Max Makowski), I Not Stupid Too (Jack Neo) and Perth (Djinn Ong); as well as short films G23 (Anthony Chen), Monkey Love (Royston Tan), and 9:30 (Yong Mun Chee).

2007:

Three Singapore works selected - Anthony Chen's short film Ah Ma (Grandma) got a Special Mention, while Pok Yue Weng's short film SuperDONG together with Ekachai Uekrongtham's feature film Pleasure Factory were screened at the Directors' Fortnight and Un Certain Regard respectively.

2008:

Eric Khoo's Tamil-language drama My Magic became the first Singapore film to compete for the prestigious Palme d'Or award.

2009:

Here by Ho Tzu Nyen selected for screening at the 41st Directors' Fortnight.

2010:

Boo Junfeng's coming-of-age debut drama, Sandcastle, was selected for the 49th International Critics' Week, and became the first Singapore film to debut in that section.

2011:

Eric Khoo's manga-inspired Tatsumi premiered in the Un Certain Regard section.

2013:

Anthony Chen's Ilo Ilo won the prestigious Caméra d'Or award while Jow Zhi Wei's short film After the Winter was shortlisted for the Cinéfondation Selection.

LOW-COST carriers Scoot and Nok Airlines have signed a joint-venture agreement to set up NokScoot by acquiring Pete Air, said Scoot's parent Singapore Airlines (SIA) yesterday.

It comes six months after the two parties signed a memorandum of understanding to establish the new Bangkok-based low-cost carrier.

In yesterday's regulatory filing, SIA said: "Acquiring Pete Air Co Ltd., instead of setting up a greenfield venture, would expedite the startup of NokScoot."

Under the joint venture agreement, Scoot and Nok Mangkang - a special-purpose vehicle set up by Nok Air - will each initially own 43.75 per cent of the share capital of Pete Air.

After subsequent restructuring, Nok Mangkang and Scoot will each hold 49 per cent of Pete Air, with the remaining 2 per cent held by Pueannammitr Co, a company formed by Nok Air's management.

Pete Air, which already holds an air operator's licence, will be renamed NokScoot Airlines.

The joint venture parties have agreed to invest an initial aggregate share capital of two billion Thai baht (S$76.9 million) in the airline, in proportion to their respective shareholdings.

In a statement last December, Nok Air - which is 39.2 per cent owned by Thai Airways International - and Scoot said that NokScoot will be based in Don Mueang International Airport, and will operate widebody aircraft on medium and long-haul international routes.

"Thailand is Asia's premier tourist destination and logical hub for Scoot to expand to," said Scoot chief executive officer Campbell Wilson. "In supporting Nok with Scoot's experience in medium-haul widebody operations, we look forward to developing a new market segment and offering Thai consumers and travellers to Thailand more travel options."

The establishment of the new airline is subject to regulatory approvals.

SIA shares climbed six cents yesterday to close at $10.44, before the announcement was made.

site_title: From champs to chumps, Spain looks to rebuild
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

From champs to chumps, Spain looks to rebuild

First defending champion to lose its first two group games

Published

Thu, Jun 19, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THEY say all good things must come to an end, but the Spanish team probably didn't expect their eventual descent from football's pinnacle to be this sudden and painful.

Champions at the last World Cup in South Africa four years ago, they turned out to be nothing more than chumps in Brazil.

Spain are used to creating history on the football pitch - but just not quite the way they've done so this time.

After dismissing the heavy defeat to the Netherlands last week as nothing more than a blip, the team nicknamed La Furja Roca (Spanish for "The Red Fury") were outfought, outmuscled and completely outclassed by a dominant Chile side yesterday.

On a day when Spanish King Juan Carlos was in tears as he sealed his abdication after a four-decade reign, his country's footballers were unceremoniously dumped from their own throne in 90 minutes.

There can be no more excuses. The entire squad of 23 players and head coach Vicente del Bosque must do a thorough post-mortem and find out how and why everything went pear-shaped.

Before the tournament, Spain were among the bookies' favourites for the crown. The tiki-taka masters had been prepared to stay in Brazil for the full month; instead, they will now head home before even the first week is out.

This is the earliest in the 84-year history of the tournament that a defending champion has been ousted before the final group game.

Spain also has the dubious distinction of being the first champion to lose its first two group games. The 1-5 loss to the Netherlands was the worst start to a title defence for a World Cup holder as well.

It wasn't meant to be this way, of course. But then again, since when did football - or any other sport, for that matter - ever follow a script?

Neither the Dutch nor the Chileans seemed to care much for Spain's golden era of dominance over the last six years, a run that included the World Cup trophy in 2010 sandwiched between European Championship glory in 2008 and 2012.

If Spain aren't careful, their final opponent Australia - the lowest- ranked nation among the 32 in Brazil - could well drive the final nail into their coffin when the two eliminated teams meet next week to escape the embarrassment of finishing at the bottom of Group B.

The game against Australia could well be the last time we get to see veterans like goalkeeper Iker Casillas and midfielders Xavi Hernandez and Xabi Alonso.

Coach del Bosque must also shoulder a large chunk of the responsibility for failing to blood in his younger guns much sooner.

The likes of Koke, Diego Costa and David de Gea are the future of this Spanish national side and must be given the chance to prove their worth.

For now, Spanish football, its dominance on the European club football stage notwithstanding, will enter a period of mourning.

Leading Spanish newspaper El Pais hit the nail on the head when it described Spain's debacle as "a nightmare that will last for all time, as will the successes".

Spain have ruled the football world since 2008, but it is now time to crown a new king of the sport.

The deposed Spanish players, once they are back home to nurse their wounds, can only look on and wonder what could have been.

site_title: Australia to revise MH370 search zone
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Australia to revise MH370 search zone

Satellite, other data being analysed to determine area

Published

Wed, Jun 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SYDNEY] Australian officials yesterday said that they will announce the new search zone for missing Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 by month's end, as mapping of the Indian Ocean seabed resumed.

The jet went missing on March 8 flying from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing. Despite a massive aerial and sea search, no sign of the aircraft - which was carrying 239 people - has been found.

An underwater probe of the Indian Ocean seabed where acoustic signals, thought at the time to have come from the jet's black box recorders, were heard also proved fruitless.

Australia's Joint Agency Coordination Centre (JACC) said that analysis of satellite and other data to determine the search area for the next underwater phase would be concluded soon.

"The search area will be confirmed before the end of June, after completion of extensive collaborative analysis by a range of specialists," it said in a statement. "It is already clear from the provisional results of that analysis that the search zone will move, but still be on the seventh arc (where the aircraft last communicated with satellite)."

The search has been frustrated by a lack of information, with experts modelling the plane's most likely flight path based on signals between it and an Inmarsat satellite.

The seventh arc, or "handshake", is the final signal from the plane and thought to be when the jet ran out of fuel.

Scientists from the British firm have suggested that searchers are yet to target the most likely Indian Ocean crash site because they became distracted by the acoustic signals detected in April.

"It was by no means an unrealistic location but it was further to the north-east than our area of highest probability," Chris Ashton at Inmarsat told the BBC's Horizon programme on Tuesday.

But JACC said that the area in which the Australian vessel Ocean Shield used a mini-sub to scour the ocean floor was "based on the best information and analysis available at that time", including from Inmarsat.

"The location was identified by the satellite communications sub-group, which included accident investigation agencies from the US and the UK along with their technical advisers, including from the aircraft manufacturer, the satellite manufacturer and Inmarsat as operator of the satellite," JACC said yesterday. "Based on analysis at the time, it represented the most likely location of the aircraft."

Australia, which is leading the hunt given the plane is likely to have crashed in its search and rescue zone, said that the vessel Fugro Equator, which it contracted, had begun its work in mapping the ocean floor.

It will be joined by Chinese PLA-Navy ship Zhu Kezhen in conducting the bathymetric survey crucial to carrying out the deep water search for the plane which is set to begin in August.

"So far, the Zhu Kezhen has surveyed 4,088 sq km of the ocean floor," before it was forced back to port for repairs, JACC said.

The survey of a 60,000 sq km search zone was expected to take three months. - AFP

site_title: Tigerair Mandala to stop flying from next month
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Tigerair Mandala to stop flying from next month

Its three shareholders decide to cease funding airline as it could not operate sustainably

Nisha Ramchandani

Published

Wed, Jun 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

LOSS-MAKING Tigerair Mandala will cease operations from next month after an unsuccessful effort to sell the struggling airline.

In a statement yesterday, Tiger Airways Holdings said the shareholders of Mandala had "vigorously explored various options in recent months" before deciding to cease funding the airline as it could not operate sustainably.

Tiger has a 35.8 per cent stake in the budget carrier while the Saratoga Group and PT Cardig International are the other main shareholders.

This comes after reports last week that budget carriers Citilink and AirAsia had both pulled out of talks to buy Tigerair Mandala.

Analysts have noted that with Tigerair Mandala's operations in the red and its limited market share in Indonesia, an acquisition would have made little difference to any carrier seeking to build up its own market share. Tigerair Mandala recently returned five planes to Tiger, leaving it with a fleet of just four as it restructured its network by cutting frequencies and pulling out of routes amid tough competition from the likes of Lion Air.

"Mandala's financial results reflect the challenges that it is facing in the difficult operating environment. The partners in Mandala have jointly come to the conclusion to cease funding the airline's operations," said Tiger's new group chief executive officer Lee Lik Hsin, stressing that the group would continue to maintain an active presence in Indonesia through Tigerair Singapore.

The Singapore Airlines (SIA) veteran recently took over from former chief Koay Peng Yen - who announced his resignation after less than two years with the group - effectively giving SIA a tighter grip on the reins. SIA owns 40 per cent of Tiger.

Pulling out of Tigerair Mandala will also allow Tiger to devote its full attention to its turnaround strategy, which includes fleet consolidation, strategic alliances and an asset-light growth model, the group said.

One analyst, who declined to be named, pointed out that the grounding of Tigerair Mandala could help curtail future losses since the budget carrier had contributed to the group racking up hefty losses for the financial year ended March 31, 2014.

At the same time, he added that this could also potentially mean more aircraft returning to the group. Tiger itself has announced plans to ground eight aircraft - which already included five from Tigerair Mandala - this financial year as it seeks to manage and right-size its fleet, citing overcapacity in the region.

Budget carriers in South-east Asia have been struggling with sliding yields as stiff competition and high costs are squeezing profits.

Meanwhile, Tiger has been divesting itself of or paring its stakes in its associates and subsidiaries of late as it seeks to get itself back on its financial footing. It sold 60 per cent of Tigerair Australia to Virgin Australia and more recently, disposed of its 40 per cent stake in Tigerair Philippines to the Philippines' largest airline, Cebu Pacific. With Tigerair Mandala now preparing to sing its swan song, the group is going back to basics by focusing primarily on its core unit Tigerair Singapore, which has been struggling too.

Tiger is also setting up a joint venture with China Airlines, but has limited its stake in Tigerair Taiwan (as it is known) to just 10 per cent.

Tiger said all customers affected by the cessation of Tigerair Mandala will be given a flight transfer where possible, or a refund on their ticket.

Shares in Tiger closed unchanged at 49 cents yesterday. The announcement came after the market closed.

site_title: How pervasive is insider trading?
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

How pervasive is insider trading?

Published

Wed, Jun 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

WHEN a stock rises or falls in unusual fashion prior to a major corporate announcement there are invariably complaints that the information was somehow leaked. And the talk is that insiders have benefited, either by buying or selling before the rest of the market. Because this is unfair and undermines confidence, calls are then made for regulators to investigate.

However, once the dust has settled and the clamour for official intervention subsided, there is usually resigned acceptance that because proving insider trading is so difficult, pushing for official probes would probably be a waste of time. As time passes, such incidents of what could have been insider trading are then forgotten.

Just how widespread is insider trading? Speak to market observers here and the response anecdotally is that it is fairly common. One dealer said: "It goes on all the time." This is arguably neither here nor there but over in the US, three North American finance professors recently attempted to answer this question through rigorous statistical analysis.

Professors P Augustin, M Brenner and M G Subrahmanyam in their May 2014 paper "Informed Options Trading prior to M&A Announcements: Insider Trading?" (reported in The New York Times on June 16, "Study asserts startling numbers of insider trading rogues") examined trading in the options market up to 30 days before M&A announcements and found that about 25 per cent of deals may involve some kind of insider trading.

The researchers also found that the Securities & Exchange Commission (SEC) litigated only 4.7 per cent of the 1,859 M&A deals in the study, that the average profit from insider trades was US$1.6 million, that the average insider transacts 16 days before the announcement date and that it took the SEC an average of 756 days or just over two years to publicly announce its first litigation in a given case.

To lend support to these findings, it was also calculated that the probability of such trades occurring through sheer chance was three in one trillion.

The suggestion from these findings, of course, is that US regulators are woefully behind the curve when it comes to prosecuting insider trading - not overly surprising, as was evidence that the SEC is more likely to prosecute the bigger deals since being resource-constrained, the regulator prefers cases which offer the biggest "bang for the buck" and are more widely covered in the press.

However, even though regulatory action appears slow and overly selective, once insider trading was proven, the penalty was on average US$3.5 million - more than twice the average profit and so painful enough to convey some sense of justice having been served.

The relevance in the local context of such a study should be obvious - ever since the US Federal Reserve announced in May 2013 that it was to taper its money printing, the consequent withdrawal of cash from these shores in favour of Western markets has meant the local market has had to rely on its own internal steam to keep the ball rolling.

In this regard, the corporate sector has not disappointed - since May last year there have been plenty to get traders excited. There have been reverse takeovers, large-scale investment in small companies by bigger, stronger names, the taking private of several financially sound firms by parent or controlling shareholders, dozens of rights issues and placements, profit-guaranteed agreements and various mega deals with eye-catching headline numbers.

All have helped keep alive flagging interest in the local stock market; all have offered insiders the potential to benefit illegally from privileged information.

Since there are no concrete indications that foreign money is looking to return in any big or lasting manner to emerging markets - at least not yet - it is to such corporate announcements that the local market will look in the days and months ahead for support and to keep interest alive.

Clearly, local regulators will have their work cut out for them, keeping an eye out for suspicious trades as more companies unveil projects, tie-ups and M&A deals to boost share prices.

After all, if one in four material announcements in the US probably involves insider trading, what might the proportion here be?

A feast for the eyes and ears

Published

Thu, Jun 19, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THEY say the third time's the charm, and Lourdes Hernandez, better known by her stage name Russian Red, was all charm as she stepped onto the stage at the mid-sized TAB last Friday for her one-night performance that was part of local music series The Gathering.

The soft-spoken 29-year-old Spanish indie pop princess, dressed in a sparkly sequin black attire, compared the intimate event to a reunion because she recognised a few faces in the crowd of 350 on what was her third visit to Singapore.

Widely known as the Catalan version of Feist because of the similar genre of quiet folk-pop both of them write and perform, the songs Hernandez picked for the 18-song set were mostly off her latest album, "Agent Cooper".

Her voice, famous for its ethereal, blues-like quality (think Lana Del Ray and Lorde combined) was in good shape and she kept the show's energy levels high with her stage banter and constant teasing of her male bandmates - the evening's running joke consisted of her confessions of love for her blushing bassist.

The gig was a visual feast as well with abstract images and videos splashed all over the screens behind her and colourful lighting and smoke to match the mood of each song. If pop music ever wanted to imitate an art performance, this must be it.

Just over an-hour long, the performance was a little brief but quality mattered more than quantity with Hernandez mixing the new songs with reworked versions of familiar ones from her previous albums such as "Loving Strangers" and "I Hate You But I Love You".

On the latter which she played before the three-song encore, Hernandez cheekily said that she'd written the lyrics before she came to Singapore. "But I've changed my mind, I only love you now," she announced to the roar of approval from her fans, as an indie class act is born and everybody in the audience looked forward to her fourth visit, which she promised will take place next year.

site_title: Shorter-tenure industrial sites to keep coming in H2
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Shorter-tenure industrial sites to keep coming in H2

MTI says this will keep prices affordable for industrialists

Published

Wed, Jun 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] The government will continue to supply shorter-tenure industrial sites in the second half of the year, reiterating that this will keep prices affordable for industrialists.

Among the 15 sites with a combined area of 18.87 ha to be released for industrial use between next month and December, three are 20-year leasehold plots - the shortest leases ever offered for industrial land. Before this, the shortest had been 21 years, offered mostly for small plots in Tuas South.

Back in mid-2012, the government slashed tenures of sites sold under the Industrial Government Land Sales (IGLS) programme, capping the leasehold period at 30 years.

Tenures used to stretch for as long as 60 years.

The Ministry of Trade and Industry said then that the cheaper shorter-tenure plots would help industrialists to manage costs.

Such plots also raise the government's flexibility for land redevelopment by lowering the odds that the state would have to buy back a plot from a private owner with compensation.

Of the 15 sites to be released in H2, nine are confirmed-list sites, which are launched according to a schedule, regardless of demand; these sites will yield 12.06 ha of land.

The remaining six sites are reserve-list sites, which will be launched for tender only upon successful application by a developer with a minimum bid price considered acceptable to the state; the reserve list will yield 6.81 ha.

The total of 18.87 ha for H2 compares to the 20.42 ha released in the first half of this year - 12.07 ha from confirmed list sites and 8.35 ha through reserve list sites.

A year ago, the H2 2013 programme released 14.52 ha through confirmed list sites and 8.32 ha through reserve list sites (see table).

Of special interest to market watchers is a 20-year leasehold site in Penjuru Road in the mature industrial estate of Jurong, to be launched for tender in October.

Targeted for multiple-user development, the 1.63ha site is zoned for Business-2 or heavier industrial use, and has a 2.5 plot ratio.

There are now no plans for strata sub-division restrictions for this site, unlike most other sites where strata sub-division is allowed only five years after the temporary occupation permit is obtained.

With no curbs on strata sub division, a developer can choose to sell or lease units to end users.

The acts of offering 20-year leases and allowing strata sub-division are aimed at lowering upfront costs for industrialists purchasing these shorter-lease units, but not all analysts agree they would have the desired effect.

Tan Boon Leong, the executive director of industrial services at Colliers International, said: "Prices are not just a function of shorter tenures. If developers think a site is good, they will still bid boldly."

SLP International executive director Nicholas Mak pointed out that the shorter tenure would not really help lower the price of the strata units because it is generally construction cost - not land cost - that makes up the bulk of the development cost of an industrial development.

Construction costs account for about half the total development cost; land cost accounts for about a third, he said.

The consensus among analysts was also that shorter land tenures will make it harder for buyers to get bank mortgages for these purchases. In issuing loans, some banks require a lease period of at least 10 years at the end of the term loan. Shorter-lease properties may mean higher monthly mortgages, and even if mortgages are successfully obtained, investors may not have enough time to recoup their investments.

Analysts also noted that all the sites offered in the next six months are zoned for Business-2 activities. This is because there are already enough Business-1 industrial sites (for lighter, cleaner industries) and because Business-2 sites are less likely to attract speculation in industrial land and property.

R'ST Research director Ong Kah Seng said: "B2-zoned plots cater more to end users who use the sites for conventional industrial production, whereas B1-zoned plots, while relevant to some users, have higher investment value, especially for strata and high-tech factories. What is needed now is sufficient, affordable industrial land for industrialists. Investors are not really the concern at this stage."

KS Energy unit sells rig for US$84.9m

Published

Thu, Jun 19, 2014 · 10:00 PM

A UNIT of KS Energy's 80 per cent-owned KS Drilling has sold a jack-up rig for US$84.88 million.

The consideration for the rig, sold on an "as-is, where-is" basis, is US$45.24 million above the aggregate book value of US$39.64 million as at March 31.

The deal agreement entered into by the unit, KS Rig Invest Three Ltd, is for the sale of the rights and obligations under a construction contract for the rig, KS Orient Star 1.

KS Drilling is an investment holding company. The main activities of its subsidiaries are the provision of onshore and offshore drilling services, rig management and support services and oilfield equipment ownership and leasing.

The group recently announced that some of KS Drilling's subsidiaries had won extension contracts relating to chartering and provision of drilling services worth more than US$60 million.

KS Energy shares closed trading unchanged at 43 cents yesterday.

site_title: The nuts and bolts of wine investment
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

The nuts and bolts of wine investment

If it's not profitable to sell, you can always drink up your wines. By N K YONG

Published

Thu, Jun 19, 2014 · 10:00 PM

I WOULD like to return to the subject of wine investment for this week's column, especially as a friend of mine has uncovered what looks like a scam.

My wine investments came about somewhat fortuitously. Interest in wine had led me to the Bordeaux 1982 en primeur campaign through my subscription to the highly respected Decanter magazine in early 1983. The March-June issues of that year were full of the Bordeaux 1982 vintage which was proclaimed as we now know was a very great vintage. And of course I could not resist buying.

With en primeur prices of Lafite, Latour and the like at £240 (about S$900 at that time) per case and Petrus at £500 per case (expensive at the time) I had no choice but to buy. In fact, I should have bought more!

At the time, I was familiar with only London's and Brussels' wine merchants but that was good enough. In later years I was fortunate to be able to purchase directly from Bordeaux trade and this made my en primeur purchases earlier, and cheaper.

Bordeaux Châteaux sell their first tranche (slice) of the wines every year in the en primeur campaign, meaning the "on first (sale)", only to the Bordeaux trade, which then re-sells the wines onwards to the rest of the world. This saved one "mark-up" in price which can result in quite considerable savings. When you are looking at paying 400 euros (S$680) to 1,000 euros per bottle for First Growths, saving one commission saves you quite a decent sum.

Over the years, until recently, about which I will explain later, it was possible with judicious selection of wines to see your wine stock increase in value by 10-15 per cent year on year. I figured this was better than investments in stocks and shares, and infinitely better than CPF! Besides which I know nothing about stocks and shares, how to read company reports, etc. But I did know a little about wines so it seemed a safer bet. And of course you end up with a lot of "liquidity" but not of the kind that you can use as downpayment on a new car or new house.

Another advantage of investing in wines is that should you find it not profitable to sell; you can always drink up your investment. Both ways you win.

There are basically two ways to go for those considering wine as an investment vehicle. You can purchase the wines yourself through reliable local or overseas wine merchants who do sell en primeur, which most of the local major wine merchants do. If you are on their mailing list you will get the "fliers" and promotional mailers around en primeur time - from end of March to June. You can also get on the mailing lists of the major UK wine houses. The advantages of en primeur sales are several.

They are accompanied by attractive payment terms - usually in two instalments, the first usually at the end of the year in question and the final instalment by the middle of the following year. En primeur prices are much lower than the prices when the wines are finally released from the Châteaux, which therefore saves you some money. Most important, you get access to premium wines at opening prices. These wines when their bottles are finally released will command much higher prices, thus already providing you with a profit. Note my example of Petrus 1982.

Another alternative is to invest through companies which specialise in wine investments. This is where caution must be exercised. Wine commerce is full of stories of wine companies, both here and in London which I personally know about, that have gone bankrupt. Those who bought wines en primeur from the companies lost their wines and their money.

The smart thing is to buy en primeur wines only from reputable wine companies, whether locally or abroad. It is not difficult to find out which local companies one can rely on. With foreign companies, preliminary enquiry from reliable sources is highly recommended.

The vintage sold en primeur this year was the 2013 vintage. This will be bottled in the second half of the second year following the vintage that is in 2015, but will only be released by the Châteaux in the first or even second quarter of 2016. Buyers will receive their wines in the second half of 2016.

The next item requiring attention is storage. If one buys from overseas merchants, that is London, the wines can be left with the merchant but will attract storage fees. My experience has been that UK storage fees are very reasonable. Storing with the overseas merchants has the advantage of lower storage charges and proper storage conditions. Always store with bona fide wine storage companies, for example Octavian in London.

A brief word about storage seems appropriate. For proper maturation and development of fine wine, with emphasis on the word "proper", long-term storage requires constant temperature and humidity; bottles stored lying down in a room, in the dark and free of any vibratory disturbances, for example a cellar lying under a busy road.

The temperature has to be a constant 10-14° C with a constant humidity of not less than 70 per cent. It pays to be very fussy about how your wines are stored.

As an aside here, for the benefit of those readers who have considerable stocks of fine wines stored locally, it would be an idea to enquire casually about the storage conditions of the commercial storage you (or your wine merchant) are using. While on this theme, it is also important to check on how the wines are transported from Europe to Asia. The gold standard is shipping by sea in refrigerated containers in which the wines are stored during transit, taking care not to ship in summer.

We used to think that air-freight is the best way until one was reminded that the cargo hold of an aeroplane is not heated and at high altitudes the temperature in the cargo hold can go close to or below zero centigrade. Readers who have had their wines air-flown from Europe may have wondered why occasionally one finds wine stains running down the label. Or even find a bottle or two with the corks partially extruded?

All one needs to know is that wine in the bottle is at atmospheric pressure. At 30,000 feet above sea level, the barometric pressure in the cargo hold is below the sea-level atmospheric, the wine will expand and thus the extrusion of the cork. Just simple physics!

The reason wines should be stored under optimum conditions for long-term storage is that it then allows them to develop and mature to their full potential. One should be like the wine-maker who says that his job is to do nothing except to prevent complications so that your wines will have the optimum conditions which under which they can develop and mature to their full potential.

Next week, the more interesting and sometimes contentious subject of what are the best investment.

Halcyon in talks to buy Lee Rubber's Indonesia plants

Published

Wed, Jun 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Singapore-listed rubber firm Halcyon Agri Corp Ltd is in talks to buy rubber processing plants in Indonesia from Lee Rubber for S$400 million to S$500 million, three people familiar with the matter said yesterday.

Slightly after noon yesterday, the rubber processor and trader requested a halt in the trading of its shares in Singapore pending an announcement.

Before the suspension, Halcyon shares rose as much as 7.7 per cent to a one-year high of S$0.975, valuing the company at S$386.1 million.

Halcyon, which owns and operates three natural rubber processing factories in Indonesia and two plants in Malaysia, has been seeking to acquire rubber processing assets to fuel its expansion, taking advantage of a weak rubber market.

Prices of rubber have fallen to their lowest since 2009 due largely to concerns over easing economic growth in top consumer China and a global oversupply.

Halcyon declined to comment on the purchase plan, although it said last week that the company was in talks on a potential acquisition of assets and properties, in a response to a query from the Singapore Exchange.

Halcyon debuted on the Singapore Exchange in February last year. Its top shareholders include Singapore-based private equity firm Credence Partners.

Privately-owned Lee Rubber, one of the oldest rubber trading companies in Asia, could not be immediately reached for comment. - Reuters

site_title: Qatar Airways leveraging new hub
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Qatar Airways leveraging new hub

US$15b Hamad International Airport is a third the size of Qatar's capital city

Nisha Ramchandani

Published

Thu, Jun 19, 2014 · 10:00 PM

QATAR Airways is banking on Doha's gleaming new airport, Hamad International (HIA), to bolster its network, even as elsewhere in the region the Gulf states are expanding capacity in ancitipation of further growth.

Covering 29 square kilometres, the US$15 billion HIA officially opened its doors last month - albeit after numerous delays - finally giving the capacity constrained Doha International a much needed breather.

Doha International had exceeded its 14 million annual passenger capacity by 2010, which often translated to flight delays and long queues for passengers. The airport, which served 23.3 million passengers last year, no longer operates commercial flights.

HIA, on the other hand, has been built with an eye on future growth. The current handling capacity of 30 million passengers per year will eventually be ramped up to 50 million per year, while its dual-runway system can facilitate up to 90 aircraft per hour.

"For Qatar Airways, it is an extremely exciting time as we funnel more global passenger traffic through our new Doha hub," said chief executive Akbar Al Baker. "HIA is an important global aviation hub and as Qatar Airways and other airlines add capacity and launch new routes, we anticipate passenger numbers to increase."

HIA, Qatar Duty Free and the airport's fast-track service Al Maha Services are all part of the Qatar Airways Group.

"HIA brings a much-needed addition of capacity for Qatar Airways' hub operations, as well as for the airline's oneworld partners," noted CAPA-Centre for Aviation in a recent report.

The airport may also see a second terminal in the years to come to further boost capacity, depending on traffic growth.

Spanning a third of the size of Doha city, the state-of-the-art airport offers 25,000 square metres of retail space and 15,000 sq m of food & beverage establishments. Meanwhile, 200 hotel rooms are slated to come onstream.

An automated people mover - an indoor train of sorts - enables travellers to make it to their gates more swiftly for connecting flights. Forty-one contact gates are operational but there will be a total of 65 when HIA is running at full steam.

The state carrier accounts for a significant number of the flights at HIA, although over 30 other carriers operate out of the new airport too, including Cathay Pacific and Jet Airways.

To cater to premium passengers, Qatar's national carrier has established a dedicated seated check-in area for First Class passengers and 16 check-in counters for Business Class. Premium passengers also have access to separate passport control counters and e-gates for security screening.

However, the airline's Business and First Class lounges are only set to open in another couple of months, as the contractor had "difficulty keeping up with the kind of finishes we want", Mr Al Baker was quoted as saying in a media report. Till then, these passengers will be accomodated in the airport's other lounges or given airport vouchers to use if the lounges are full.

Economy class passengers have the option of paying for the Al Maha fast-track service, which provides lounges with in-built clearance facilities so passengers can be swept speedily through immigration.

In recent years, the fast-growing Gulf carriers Emirates, Qatar and Etihad have been drawing traffic away from traditional air hubs, aided by their strategic location at the crossroads between Europe and Asia. They're also expanding at a staggering pace - albeit settling for thinner margins in the pursuit of high traffic volume - ordering next-generation aircraft such as the Airbus A350 and Boeing 777X by the dozens.

Qatar Airways, which is the launch customer for the A350, has a fleet of 134 aircraft and a further 300 worth US$60 billion on order. And Qatar isn't the only Gulf state building up infrastructure in size and scale.

Abu Dhabi - the home base of Etihad - is working on a new terminal building, due 2017, which will inject some 30 million in passenger handling capacity.

However, the title of the Middle East's biggest airport belongs to Dubai International, which saw nearly 66.5 million passengers last year. CAPA expects Dubai International to become the world's busiest by 2015, pipping London's Heathrow after Heathrow posted 0.5 per cent traffic growth in the first quarter of this year vis-a-vis Dubai's double-digit clip.

Dubai also opened a second airport, Al Maktoum International Airport, which began commercial flights late last year. While capacity is five million passengers annually, the long-term goal is to boost this to some 160 million per year.

With regional and Middle Eastern competitors raising the stakes, Changi Airport is working on new terminals as well as transitioning to a three runway system in a bid to maintain its edge. Traffic at Changi has also been rising, bolstered by an emerging middle class in the Asia-Pacific, with the airport hitting a record 53.7 million passengers last year.

Situated on the site of the former Budget Terminal, Changi's T4 will inject an annual handling capacity of 16 million passengers when it opens its doors in 2017. Between T4 and the upcoming mixed use development Project Jewel, Changi's capacity is set to rise from 66 million today to about 85 million by 2018.

And planning is also underway for Terminal 5, which will tack on an additional 50 million in passenger handling capacity come the mid-2020s.

site_title: Accepting life's harsh realities with grace
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Accepting life's harsh realities with grace

The Fault in Our Stars handles serious illness with minimum melodrama, says GEOFFREY EU

Published

Thu, Jun 19, 2014 · 10:00 PM

WHEN dying young is a major part of the plot and one or more of the protagonists is afflicted with an incurable disease, it's a foregone conclusion that tears will be shed - both by characters on screen and young females in the audience. Despite the constraints of the young-adult genre, however, The Fault in Our Stars handles its chosen topic with minimum melodrama and considerable aplomb.

The film, directed by Josh Boone and based on the novel of the same name by John Green, is witty and touching without being too simplistic or overly sweet and sentimental. Written for the screen by Scott Neustadtler and Michael Weber, it shamelessly manipulates our emotions - the audience demands that it does - while showing a strong respect for its source material. For a change, the story is about ordinary people who have real concerns and real conversations - with nary a lovesick vampire or kick-ass girl warrior in sight.

In a previous era, a generation of young women was weaned on a three-handkerchief weepie called Love Story (1970), which was notable for having one of the corniest lines in movie history: "Love means never having to say you're sorry."

The Fault in Our Stars targets a slightly younger female demographic but it also has its own candidate for a quotable quote - wisely attributed to a fictional author who happens to be an integral part of the tale. The line - "Pain demands to be felt" - is found in the favourite novel of 16-year-old Hazel Lancaster (Shailene Woodley), who relates to a cancer-stricken young girl in the book.

Hazel, who serves as the film's narrator, has fourth-stage thyroid cancer but - unlike her parents (Laura Dern and Sam Trammell) - accepts her fate with grace, good humour and a no-fuss philosophy. "The only thing worse than biting it from cancer is having your kid bite it from cancer," she says, almost nonchalantly.

At a support group meeting, Hazel attracts the attention of Augustus Waters (Ansel Elgort), a young man, and fellow cancer victim, with an impossibly sunny disposition and a desperate desire to make a positive impact on the world during the time he has left.

Gus has lost part of a leg to disease while Hazel's condition requires her to have tubes inserted into her nostrils and to lug a portable oxygen tank around. They're not your typical cute couple, but getting sympathy is not high on their agenda.

Both are interested in confronting the truth, no matter how painful it might be. Gus manages to obtain an invitation from author Peter van Houten (Willem Dafoe) to visit Amsterdam so Hazel can ask him to address some unanswered questions about the characters in his book. The trip marks a departure from a predictable storyline and turns into a journey of discovery in more ways than one.

The Fault in Our Stars may take a PG approach to a delicate issue but it does provide viewers with fully fleshed out characters that we learn to care about.

The prospect of death may be always present but these kids take on the harsh realities of life with (metaphorically speaking anyway) a spring in their step and a smile on their face; somehow, being in love makes those tough choices a little easier.

Rating:

B-

site_title: Singapore oil product prices up 3-5% on 'fear premium'
content:
Singapore oil product prices up 3-5% on 'fear premium'

Traders also staying 'long' on market after flare-up in Iraq

Published

Thu, Jun 19, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Following a spike in global crude prices, Singapore oil product prices have risen by 3-5 per cent on the back of a "fear premium" stemming from the latest flare-up in Iraq.

Some oil traders here told The Business Times that they are also staying "long" on the market at this time, lest they get caught out.

They were reacting to Brent crude shooting to a nine-month high of more than US$114 a barrel this week as Sunni militants opposed to Baghdad's Shiite government fought to take Iraq's largest refinery at Baiji - albeit one catering to just domestic Iraqi needs, with most of the oilfields in the country's south still intact.

Brent has spiked by more than US$4 since the escalation of the jihadist offensive last week, and is now up almost 9 per cent from April's US$105 level.

US benchmark West Texas Intermediate (WTI) has risen by US$2 in the last week to more than US$106.

Despite the latest price spikes, there is no palpable tension in the oil market here.

"Why is the market trying to spook itself?" questioned a trading boss.

"The world is more than sufficiently supplied, with the Saudis and Iran able to make up for any potential loss in Iraqi oil supplies.

"Besides, with Ramadan approaching, the US is unlikely to want to ratchet up tensions by getting involved," he reckoned.

Like what has happened for most of Q2, industry players said that trading activity here has remained quiet so far, especially with the economic slowdown in China. Most traders are not making money in the difficult market, one source added.

Another trading executive said that "while some Iraqi cargoes do come here, and comprises high-quality stuff, Iraq only accounts for a fraction of global production".

This is borne out by the just-released BP Statistical Review of World Energy 2014, which showed that Iraq - despite being the second-largest Gulf producer after Saudi Arabia - accounted for just 3.7 per cent of global oil production last year. In fact, rising oil production in the US (which accounted for 10.8 per cent of global production in 2013) and in Russia (12.9 per cent) is quickly closing in on Saudi levels (13.1 per cent last year).

"Thus despite oil product prices here rising across the barrel, the Singapore market in fact remains very quiet," another oil trader told BT.

Most product prices here remain in backwardation, he said, referring to a market situation where the price of a forward or futures contract is trading below the spot price.

"This is because global oil supply and demand remains balanced, with the current spike in prices due largely to traders speculating on the war," said the trading executive. "Otherwise Brent would have shot to US$150," he remarked, referring to the last all-time record price.

Still, if nothing else, the Iraqi flare-up has helped to ignite a spark in the otherwise "flat" market here. "Most players are taking a watch-and-see approach, to see if there are trading opportunities from the Iraqi situation," one player said.

Far East Orchard CEO to retire in September

Published

Wed, Jun 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] The man helming hospitality player Far East Orchard, Lucas Chow, 61, is retiring as group chief executive officer and managing director this September.

He will be succeeded by Lui Chong Chee, 54, whose last appointment was chief financial officer at another listed firm, Raffles Medical Group.

"During his tenure, Mr Chow played a pivotal role in the transformative growth of Far East Orchard" to become a major regional hospitality and property company, the group said yesterday.

After becoming group CEO in 2012, Mr Chow led a successful restructuring exercise to strengthen the group's property development and investment business.

Formerly known as Orchard Parade Holdings, Far East Orchard adopted its current name to reflect its alignment with parent company Far East Organization and to leverage the Far East brand. It also expanded into complementary businesses in hospitality management and healthcare real estate. It listed its hospitality assets in Far East Hospitality Trust in August 2012.

Through strategic partnerships forged with Toga Group in Australia and The Straits Trading Company Limited last year, Far East Orchard extended its footprint from existing markets Singapore and Malaysia to Australia, China, Denmark, Germany, Hungary and New Zealand.

Mr Chow will also retire as executive director of Far East Organization, where he provided strategic counsel on new business growth and brand development and served on several executive committees. He was chief executive at MediaCorp from December 2005 before stepping down in 2011 to join Far East.

While expressing deep appreciation for Mr Chow, Far East Orchard chairman Koh Boon Hwee also welcomed Mr Lui on board.

Mr Lui has extensive experience in finance and management in listed companies. Before becoming CFO at Raffles Medical, he was also CEO of CapitaLand Financial Limited and managing director of Citicorp Investment Bank (Singapore) Limited.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Asiatravel jumps as talk of Alibaba interest returns

Published

Wed, Jun 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

SHARES in Asiatravel.com leapt more than 9 per cent yesterday as talk that China-based e-commerce giant Alibaba could be poised for a stake in the company made a return trip to the market.

The stock of the Singapore-listed travel booking portal hit an intraday high of 35.5 cents before settling with a three-cent gain at 35 cents. Some 7.34 million units changed hands.

Market rumours of a possible suitor for the Singapore company first started circulating about two weeks ago, sending the stock soaring to 38 cents. It subsequently pulled back in tandem with the meandering broader market over the past week.

Talk of a takeover surfaced after Alibaba founder and chairman Jack Ma was reportedly in Singapore recently, presumably to hold talks with an unnamed firm.

It also followed an announcement of a deal for Alibaba to take a 10.35 per cent stake in Singapore Post (SingPost).

Asiatravel has been suffering losses in recent years. For the January-March quarter, its net loss inched up to $1.8 million.

But the fact that Alibaba could have set its sights on Asiatravel has sent the stock soaring to two-year highs.

On its part, Asiatravel has not shied away from publicly indicating that mergers and acquisitions may be on the cards.

Last month, the company disclosed it was in varying stages of discussions with various parties to explore strategic and M&A options.

Many other jurisdictions, including the US and countries in Europe, were putting similar plans in place, he said. - Xinhua

site_title: Well, how about debt? Bonds beat doubters
content:
Well, how about debt? Bonds beat doubters

Debt issuance beat initial forecasts to turn in a solid Q2, H1 for 2014

Published

Wed, Jun 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] It was obvious that the tightening of US monetary policy would lead to a rise in interest rates.

It was obvious that the improving US economy would lead to capital flight from emerging markets and from bonds.

It was obvious that this was to be the year that companies would issue stock instead of bonds.

It was obviously wrong.

Debt issuance beat initial forecasts to turn in a solid second quarter and first half of 2014, as a benign rates environment and strong local currencies kept the bond party in Singapore and the region going longer than expected.

"At the beginning of the year, the fear about the sudden interest rate hike was more rampant," DBS head of fixed income Clifford Lee said.

"They started putting on trades to favour shorter tenures, and the entire market was proven wrong, so now people have to reverse the trade."

Singapore-domiciled companies raised US$6.7 billion from debt capital markets during the April-to-June period, almost double the US$3.5 billion raised a year earlier, according to preliminary data from Thomson Reuters. Year-to-date, debt issuance from Singapore issuers rose 8.3 per cent year-on-year to US$12.1 billion.

In terms of all Singapore-dollar issuance, second-quarter proceeds rose 18.6 per cent year-on-year to S$4.7 billion. That brought the first-half total to S$10.9 billion, a 21.4 per cent increase. Singapore outpaced the region in the first half, with South-east Asian aggregate volume up 16.1 per cent at US$32 billion, said Thomson Reuters. "It's very much a record second quarter if you look at it on a US-dollar basis (in Asia)," ANZ head of Asia debt capital markets Jimmy Choi said.

Shows of strength were all around.

Hainan Airlines sold 1.7 billion yuan (S$341.5 million) of three-year offshore renminbi (RMB) bonds at a 6.25 per cent coupon last month to become the first corporate "Lion City" bond to be cleared and deposited in Singapore. Mr Lee said that investors in the offshore RMB space are looking more closely at credit now that the currency appreciation theme is no longer as assured.

"You don't have that speculation, so that market is on more fundamentally solid ground," he said.

Perpetuals also made a comeback, with Trafigura Beheer BV selling S$200 million of 7.5 per cent step-up perpetual securities. Elsewhere in the region, Hong Kong-listed Far East Horizon sold US$200 million of perpetuals, while Thailand's PTT Exploration and Production sold US$1 billion of perpetuals a week ago, a feat considering the country's recent coup.

"It just goes to show how much liquidity there is in the market right now, with investors looking to move down the capital structure to pick up slightly more yield," said Simon Page, head of debt capital markets in South-east Asia at JP Morgan. "It's a reflection of the increase in liquidity, low interest rates, and it comes down to people's rate expectations."

That interest rates did not go up as much as expected emboldened some companies to do some opportunistic fundraising.

"Companies are taking as much long duration as they can," Mr Choi said.

The banks also helped to boost issuance. "What's really driven the three bank-capital trades has been the strong market and the low interest rates," Mr Page said. "Both OCBC and UOB have old-style Tier 2 bonds maturing later this year and so they have been opportunistic in taking advantage of strong demand and low spreads to issue Basel III-compliant Tier 2's."

The bankers said that they were cautiously optimistic that the momentum of the first half of 2014 will continue into the second.

"Our view is that over time, as you probably know, rates will have to trend upwards," Mr Choi said. "Rates will be rangebound, spreads will come in minimally tighter because monetary policy is very accommodative . . . The biggest headline risk is geopolitical risk."

500 original artworks for new hotel and hospital

Published Thu, Jun 19, 2014 · 10:00 PM

IN what is the single largest art commission of its kind in Singapore, the Farrer Park Company has commissioned more than 500 original artworks for its 250-room hotel and 145-room hospital. The iconic commissions will be the monumental Apollo and Artemis apple sculptures by Kumari Nahappan, but visitors can expect to encounter art in practically every corner of the complex which will see three hotel concepts in one, medical clinics and a hospital.

Kumari was the first artist the Farrer Park Company commissioned, even before a space had been found for her works, says Richard Helfer, a board member and the man steering the hotel project. From there, the company went on to commission a number of artists from Singapore and Asia - with 60 per cent of the works from Singapore - to build up a corporate collection.

"As an owner-operated, independent hotel, we just saw the opportunity to build an art collection into the hotel at its design stage rather than as an after-thought," says Dr Helfer. "It's also a chance for us to support the art community in Singapore and the region, and work with them directly."

site_title: Funtasy, Bintan resort-style homes pull in S'pore investors
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Funtasy, Bintan resort-style homes pull in S'pore investors

Buyers unfazed by Indonesian rules on foreign ownership of property

Published

Wed, Jun 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Funtasy Island, just 16 kilometres from Singapore's Sentosa Cove, has already sold 510 villas and condo apartments amounting to about $250 million.

A significant 70 per cent of the buyers are Singaporeans, according to Michael Yong, director of Funtasy Island Development Pte Ltd.

Elsewhere, Bursa-listed Landmarks Berhad will be starting the sale of 300 serviced apartments in Phase 1 of the water resort city Treasure Bay Bintan later this year.

Treasure Bay Bintan's chief operating officer, Paul Leong, told BT that the target buyers will be Singaporeans and Indonesians.

Foreign buyers seem undeterred by the intricacies of Indonesian property laws, going by the recent popularity of resort-style homes in Indonesia.

Under Indonesian laws, foreigners are only allowed to hold the land use rights of a property but not the title deed. They can hold the Right to Use title or "Hak Pakai" for 25 years, which can be extended for a further 20 years, and is renewable thereafter.

Doris Tan, head of international residential properties at JLL, noted that buyers are attracted to homes in Bintan and Funtasy because of the lower quantum and guaranteed rental yield in some instances.

So far, overseas buyers are not overly concerned about foreign ownership restrictions on property in Indonesia, she said. "The law is transparent and people are comfortable buying from the big names."

Banyan Tree recently sold serviced apartments under its Cassia brand in Phuket and Bintan to buyers in Singapore at an average price of $250,000. It offers no rental guarantee but estimates that gross rental yields could be 6 to 7 per cent.

Mr Leong said that Treasure Bay Bintan will make sure buyers have the Right to Use title for the serviced apartments over a period of 60 years. It will also offer a guaranteed rental return over a period but this is not finalised yet. These four-star to five-star serviced apartments will be managed by an international hotel chain.

As for Funtasy Island, Mr Yong said that PT Batam Island Marina, the developer behind the project, has undertaken to pay the lease renewal up to year 2112 for foreign home buyers. The villas and condos are mainly targeted at Singaporeans and expatriates living here. The smaller units, typically under half a million dollars, come with average rental yield guarantee of 6 per cent for five years.

A joint-venture agreement was inked yesterday between Funtasy Island Development and Seven Seas Properties to develop a $200 million eco-theme park on Funtasy Island.

Seven Seas president and CEO Lim Chee Yong said he expects the payback period for this project to be five to seven years.

The 328-hectare park is touted to be the largest eco-theme park in the world when it is fully operating by 2017. A ferry service between Singapore and Funtasy Island will also begin next year.

"For this project, the key is nature," Mr Yong said. Only 30 per cent of the 810 acres of tropical islands making up Funtasy Island is set aside for villas, apartments, a convention centre and other facilities, while 70 per cent is reserved for nature sanctuary.

The number of visitors on Funtasy Island, including residents, will be capped at 1.5 million each year to prevent over-crowding and disruption to the environment.

Still, some 1,200 rooms are needed to accommodate one million visitors a year. There could be a shortfall of 274 rooms in 2017 which could increase to 783 rooms in 2019, Mr Yong said.

content:
