content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Customers here don't get service they want: poll

Within Asia-Pac, expectations gap is biggest in Singapore, reports AMIT ROY CHOUDHURY

Published

Sun, Jun 15, 2014 · 10:00 PM

As the services industry becomes an integral part of the Singapore economy, companies have been placing much emphasis on customer experience management (CEM). A recent survey, however, showed that within the Asia-Pacific region, Singapore had the biggest gap between customer expectations and the ability of businesses to provide the level of CEM technology support required to meet the need.

The survey was commissioned by business communications solutions provider Avaya. More than 1,500 business managers were interviewed across 13 countries for the survey. The findings indicated a direct correlation between technology and customer satisfaction.

The study investigated the emphasis that companies are putting on CEM and found that increasingly high expectations of customers are creating a business environment where a majority of organisations are struggling to keep up.

Some of its key findings:

Talking about the Singapore findings, Lee Chong-Win, Avaya's Asean managing director, told BizIT that while 95 per cent of businesses here believe that "customer effort" - i.e. how easy a company makes it for customers to do business with it - has an impact on customer spending, retention and satisfaction, only 37 per cent actually deploy customer effort initiatives.

Singapore also saw the biggest gap in the region in being able to link, in real- time, all threads of communication across different channels - 73 per cent of customers expect businesses to be able to do this across different channels (for example web, phone and social media) but only 35 per cent of Singapore companies actually do so.

Mr Lee added that, apart from the above, the top three challenges businesses in Singapore face in implementing CEM are:

"Singapore thrives on the service industry, which contributes to at least 70 per cent of Singapore's economy. In a market that relies so heavily on service, 68 per cent of consumers expect brands to treat them as unique and automatically deliver communications tailored to the individual's preference. (But) only 39 per cent of businesses are actually able to support this demand," Mr Lee said.

Impediments

He added that businesses in Singapore have a strong understanding of the need for CEM strategy. With strong government initiatives in place, Singaporean companies are actually well placed to deliver stronger customer service.

"Based on the Avaya survey, businesses in Singapore do not see technology limitations and buy-in from top management as top reasons preventing them from delivering personalised customer experience."

Mr Lee, however, noted that one of the main impediments is ownership. When too many different departments think they own part of the customer experience, and there is a lack of a single executive-level owner, the result is often fragmented or badly implemented programmes.

"This creates communication barriers between different functions, especially where there has not been a holistic view taken of the technology required to support an end-to-end customer experience," he said.

"Of course, budgets remain an issue for some, but the findings from the Avaya survey demonstrate how quickly an effective CEM strategy can start to deliver tangible results and, with a well-managed programme, those returns will only grow over time."

Mr Lee added that companies in Singapore need to look at their systems and ensure that they are joined up so that customers' past history and context are captured and used to help tailor services and responses.

"More importantly, companies must provide their staff with instant access to that information, regardless of which platform they are on, so their interactions can be personalised and relevant.

"Larger enterprises must ensure that their inbound and outbound customer contact systems are linked so that notifications are relevant and timely."

He added that countries such as China, India and Mexico have seen the significant impact that customer effort initiatives can have on business, and that has also resulted in a much lower gap between customer expectations and company ability to deliver - 33 per cent, 34 per cent and 37 per cent, respectively, in those countries, compared to Singapore, where the gap is at 58 per cent.

Mr Lee noted that there are significant CEM areas which have been overlooked by businesses in Singapore. The survey findings revealed that, despite 90 per cent of consumers expecting brands to provide automatic notification of potential problems so that proactive solutions can be offered, only 42 per cent actually do so.

"This gives a clear indication of the opportunities that businesses in Singapore can leverage to better cater to customers' demands. Specifically, in order to truly feel they are having a great customer experience, customers want to feel as though they are being treated as unique individuals with communications tailored specifically to them," Mr Lee added.

site_title: Sourcing for the internal audit function
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Sourcing for the internal audit function

A firm's internal audit operation must fit its corporate structure and requirements. By HENRY TAN

Published

Sun, Jun 15, 2014 · 10:00 PM

FOR such a critical function, internal audit is too often regarded as simply a box to tick on management's list of operational things to do. In actuality, the Singapore Code of Corporate Governance requires companies to establish an effective internal audit function that is adequately resourced and independent of the activities it audits (Principle 13). A more pressing call is how a company should approach its internal audit options to best fit its corporate structure and requirements. Essentially, there are three primary options: in-house, outsourced, or co-sourced.

In-house

In-house internal audits rely solely on company resources, staff and expertise.

For smaller companies, this option may simply not reap the necessary cost efficiencies available to larger players which can invest in the dedicated development of an internal audit department.

However, the benefits of the in-house option certainly include the internal familiarity with the company's business, and the strength of better networks and working relationships within the company.

Additionally, internal auditors can be groomed or they can be rotated to other departments, expanding their internal control knowledge throughout the organisation. The presence of such auditors also creates awareness of the crucial role internal audit plays in a company's operations.

Outsourced

Here, a company may delegate its internal audit function to an external service provider, usually one of the public accounting firms other than its external auditor.

A company may opt to go this route because of a lack of qualified internal resources and technical or specialty knowledge required, or just because the size of the organisation is simply too small to sustain an in-house team.

Outsourcing may then be both cost effective and provide for necessary independence.

One negative aspect of outsourcing is that the depth of the internal audit may be less thorough as the outsourced team is usually with the client for a shorter period.

The Institute of Internal Auditors offers a valuable caveat for companies that choose to outsource: oversight and responsibility for the internal audit activity cannot be outsourced.

An in-house liaison, preferably an executive or senior management employee, should be responsible for "managing" the internal audit activity. And the independence of the assigned in-house liaison must be evaluated if this individual has other (non-internal audit) responsibilities.

Co-sourced

Co-sourcing involves in-house internal auditors being the primary resource for executing the company's internal audit plan while engaging an external service provider, particularly in a specialised area, to provide the necessary support or to boost cost efficiency.

Co-sourcing can create a synergy that complements the strength of an in-house internal audit team and enables it to tap the broad capabilities available from an external service provider.

It also allows an internal audit department to pursue value added services that it otherwise could not do itself because of a lack of resources, time or capabilities.

This option may also save the company money because routine audit work may be less costly if provided by external service providers.

A 2013 survey conducted by the Singapore Accountancy Commission and consultancy firm KPMG indicates that 44 per cent of chief audit executives view co-sourcing as the most cost-efficient means of obtaining a diverse range of skill sets that may not be fully utilised in an in-house context.

Multi-pronged approach

The decision on the most appropriate option for a company relies on factors such as company size, structure, resources and management culture.

Some companies move on to different options as their organisations evolve or grow. One example of a large organisation that creatively worked out an effective solution for its internal audit needs is the Ministry of Health Holdings (MOHH), the holding company of the various public healthcare entities.

In 2010, after an extensive internal review and consultation and given its size, MOHH consolidated its internal audit function across the entire group.

Internal auditors from its subsidiaries which had in-house teams were transferred to a central internal audit department within the holding company.

In effect, the subsidiaries which previously had their own internal audit function then "outsourced" this function to the head office.

At the same time, the internal audit department at the head office also "co-sourced" specific functions, such as a whistle-blowing hotline, to external specialist service providers.

Benefits

MOHH found that the economies of scale of a central department provided for better management of and career progression for its large pool of internal audit staff.

At the same time, it achieved a higher level of independence of its internal auditors relative to the individual subsidiaries.

Its use of specialist outsourced service providers also complemented and supplemented its internal resources.

MOHH went further to create synergies and alignment at the board level by having the audit committee chairmen of its subsidiaries be members of the audit committee of the holding company.

In the final analysis, each company has to decide which option best serves its business practice. There is no clear-cut right or wrong answer.

However it is organised or executed, the internal audit function should be designed to be effective for its purposes and comply not just with the letter and form of regulations, but also the spirit and substance of it.

site_title: UBS plans to expand into China commercial property
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

UBS plans to expand into China commercial property

It may partner with a developer or a company with an ability to source existing assets

Published

Mon, Jun 16, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SYDNEY] UBS AG, Switzerland's biggest bank, is planning to expand its Chinese property investment business with a move into commercial real estate.

Office, retail and industrial properties are "where investor demand is certainly moving to" in China, Trevor Cooke, head of global real estate for Asia-Pacific at UBS Global Asset Management, said in an interview in Sydney. "The stock of investment grade assets in China is growing at about 35 per cent per year."

The bank would either partner with a developer or a company with an ability to source existing assets, he said.

Several cities in China are expected to experience improving rental demand for commercial space on the back of recent regulatory changes, including policies to boost growth in certain areas, CBRE Group Inc said in its Asia Pacific Office MarketView report. China was among the five most sought-after markets for retailers looking to open stores this year, a separate report by the broker, released in March, showed.

UBS already invests directly in Chinese residential property through a joint venture formed in 2008 with Shenzhen-based developer Gemdale Corp. The bank is planning a second residential fund, with an initial close of about US$100 million and a total of at least US$350 million, Mr Cooke said.

"It's hard not to acknowledge the macro sentiment around residential property in China right now, the concerns about a Chinese bubble," Mr Cooke said. "But that just puts the emphasis on the asset management credentials."

China's home sales fell 11 per cent in May from a year earlier. The value of homes sold declined to 446.1 billion yuan (S$89.6 billion) from 503 billion yuan in the same month in 2013, according to National Statistics Bureau data.

UBS plans to offer clients the option of investing in Chinese property using either US dollars or yuan, Mr Cooke said.

The bank, which has about US$66.4 billion of real estate under management globally, is also expanding in Australia through a joint venture with Melbourne-based developer Grocon Pty and through an agricultural partnership announced last week with closely held agricultural advisory company Bydand Global Agriculture.

UBS Grocon Real Estate is targeting as much as A$750 million (S$880.2 million) of assets under management by the end of this year, including Grocon developments, Mr Cooke said. The joint venture, which plans to have A$10 billion under management in five years, hasn't announced any investments yet.

UBS Grocon gives the bank the first right of refusal on the builder's A$2 billion pipeline, the latest addition to which is the Commonwealth Games village on Queensland state's Gold Coast. Grocon won the right to be preferred developer of that project in December.

UBS will team up with Bydand to help match investor demand with farms in need of equity capital.

"The Australian agricultural sector is carrying too much debt, and a significant amount of farmers are sub-scale and need an exit," Mr Cooke said. "Farmland provides a great portfolio diversifier and, structured right, it damps volatility and initial demand from clients in all parts of the world seems very strong." - Bloomberg

site_title: KL's invest plan for tax agency a bad idea
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

KL's invest plan for tax agency a bad idea

Published

Mon, Jun 16, 2014 · 10:00 PM

A BILL to amend the Inland Revenue Board of Malaysia Act 1995 is a bad idea to begin with. Its passage would allow the finance minister - currently Prime Minister Najib Razak - to set up an investment panel within the Inland Revenue Board (IRB). The passage of the bill would enable the panel to invest taxpayers' funds into equities, initial public offerings, bonds, debt paper, and even property assets. The bill would give the finance minister the power to appoint six of the seven members of the investment panel. The seventh would be the governor of the central bank, currently Zeti Akhtar Aziz.

The function of the IRB is to maximise the collection of tax revenue for the government, pure and simple. It is certainly not to invest taxpayers' funds in potentially risky assets. In any case, the government has already got at least 10 investment funds and sovereign wealth funds including the Employees Provident Fund (RM600 billion in assets), Permodalan Nasional Berhad (RM237 billion) and Khazanah Nasional (RM135 billion). All these funds have been around for a long time and have been generally transparent and fully accountable.

If the government wanted to increase the investment of its funds, it should simply increase its allocation to Khazanah. In any case, how much spare cash does the IRB have lying around anyway? It can't be very much given that the government expects to run a budget deficit of 3 per cent of gross domestic product this year.

Last year, the Board contributed roughly 55 per cent, or around RM120 billion (S$46.5 billion), of total government revenue. The difference between what it collects and what it disburses to government coffers can't be very much. The IRB has, however, a short-term holding fund for tax refunds, which it eventually pays out. It's not entirely clear just how much the fund amounts to, but the 2011 report indicated that it paid out over RM5 billion in refunds. The same report indicated that the Board had RM255 million in fixed deposits and money-market instruments from which it booked investment income of almost RM9 million. But those aren't risky investments, just routine treasury operations to preserve the value of surplus funds.

At the core of the hullabaloo and the opposition to the proposed bill is the notion that it would transform the IRB into an investment body, much like 1MDB that is directly under the control of the finance minister. And numerous press reports have made it quite clear that the quasi-sovereign wealth fund has had a less than stellar reputation for transparency or accountability.

There might have been a case - and it is still a weak one at that - for such a body to be established had the government been running budget surpluses for a considerable period of time. But there is none whatsoever at a time when the government has been nursing a deficit for 16 straight years. And to expose excess funds that have claims on them, such as uncollected tax refunds, to the vagaries of the marketplace is quite possibly sheer folly.

site_title: Budget device for multiple health tests
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Budget device for multiple health tests

Published

Mon, Jun 16, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] For years, patients here have had to contend with long waits, considerably high costs and non-comprehensive health tests when they seek medical care. But these pains may soon be a thing of the past, according to Michael Tan, co-founder of Singapore health start-up BioSenze.

He says help will come in the form of BioSenze's do-it-yourself diagnostic kit, which will allow patients to administer up to 200 common health tests from the comfort of their own homes, using their blood, urine or saliva samples.

These tests include those for top-of-mind diseases such as hand, foot & mouth, dengue fever and tuberculosis, as well as the measuring of regular glucose and cholesterol levels, and even one's daily platelet count.

To run a test, a patient will have to plug BioSenze's biometric device into his smartphone's earphone jack, open the free BioSenze app on his smartphone to power the device, and then position the device's suction tube over his fluid sample. Once that is absorbed and tested, the device will deliver results accordingly: positive or negative readings (for instance, for dengue fever), or metered readings (for glucose level).

Metered readings can even be sent to doctors, hospitals and healthcare platforms for regular monitoring, via a cloud server.

BioSenze's kit - comprising the biometric device and mobile app - will be the world's first, claims Mr Tan.

"It will potentially revolutionise the way medical assessments are conducted, and drastically simplify doctor-patient consultation - by enabling cheaper, faster and better testing, and by putting patients' needs first."

The biometric device, which will retail in pharmacies for not more than $10, will be about 28 times cheaper than the cost of an average health screening package in Singapore, Mr Tan adds.

It will also be ten times faster, with the ability to deliver test results in under 10 minutes - compared to two hours or even up to five days, which is the time typically taken by clinics and hospitals here.

"Moreover, BioSenze's kit is portable, has an accuracy of over 90 per cent, and is able to recommend related tests to provide patients with a more comprehensive health evaluation," Mr Tan says.

BioSenze's ultimate goal is to have global health institutions embrace its kit, and doctors prescribe it - for daily testing - to their patients, which will relieve the patients of the inconvenience of having to make their way down to clinics or hospitals for tests.

The kit can also be deployed in the event of an epidemic or natural disaster, Mr Tan said.

BioSenze, which launched last December, has since filed its patents and is currently awaiting certification for its biometric device from the authorities.

It will officially launch its kit at CommunicAsia 2014 - an information and communications technology trade event - later this week, with plans to expand into Asia, Europe and the US.

site_title: Tuned in to a fusion of flavours
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Tuned in to a fusion of flavours

Sofitel's in-house eatery Xperience may hit the high notes with its techno-pop ambience but remains firmly grounded in its East-West cuisine, says JAIME EE

Published

Sun, Jun 15, 2014 · 10:00 PM

NEW RESTAURANT

Xperience

Sofitel So Singapore

35 Robinson Road

Tel: 6701-6800

Open daily from 6.30am to 10.30pm

IN the lexicon of hotel design, I'm pretty sure that under "lobby", there must be something there that says "relaxed and welcoming ambience for travellers to check in without stress after a long flight". Methinks Sofitel So Singapore took that rule book and tossed it out of the window, along with other adjectives such as "sleek", "elegant", "minimalist" and "tasteful".

Instead, this hospitality upstart in the financial district is a full-on visual assault the moment you step in. This is no lobby - it looks more like the aftermath of a kamikaze attack by a grand piano. The glossy ebony-ivory colour theme is broken up in haphazard pattern, splattered with splotches of blood red rose displays, shiny glass and twinkling hexagonal light fixtures that remind you of Christmas trees or an SOS flare.

Whether you like or hate this display of psychedelic, groovy ostentation, you are at least guaranteed an experience, which, on the dining front at least, the inhouse restaurant Xperience offers.

Taking up almost half the lobby space, it's equally OTT with its head-pounding pulsating techno-pop (there's even an inhouse DJ spinning the decks) music, crystal-embedded glass table tops, rich velvet upholstery and plush cushions - along with a blue neon lit "bed" that acts as the chef's table. Breakfast in bed, get it?

Against this backdrop - and a droolworthy Molteni kitchen set-up - lady chef Anne-Cecile Degenne needs to do more than your garden variety all-day dining to stand out. That's why you get this quirky menu that's designed to look like a chef's notebook with whimsical sketches of cooking and hand-written notes. Instead of the usual demarcations of starter, mains and desserts, you get "crunchy", "zesty", "smoky", "spicy" and "juicy". The menu designer must have run out of steam because dessert is described as, well, "dessert".

Besides choosing your desired taste sensation, you can also tailor the size of your meal, from XS (tasting), XM (single portion) to XL (sharing portion). It gives you the flexibility to try a lot more things than you would normally do, and the tasting portions are decent enough to share between two people.

Chef Degenne's food leans towards East-West fusion and somehow manages to make it less pretentious than the surroundings. In fact, the food is probably the most grounded aspect of the hotel with its unpretentious, wholesome approach to cooking - so you're not going to find anything associated with the avant-garde or molecular movement here. Also, don't expect to find authentic renditions of local favourites, although the menu is peppered with familiar names such as siew mai, laksa, curry and chilli crab. It would be silly to expect chef Degenne to emulate the methods or flavours that local diners would just call her out on. None of the dishes tastes like the real thing, but what you can appreciate is the way they stand on their own for pure tastiness.

Foie gras and truffle siew mai ($15 for two in the XS serving) looks like the real thing apart from the familiar scent of truffle oil mixed into a bouncy, fluffy foie gras and mushroom mixture encased in the skin, with a blink-and-you-miss-it flake of truffle on top of each dumpling. Pleasantly earthy in flavour from the mix of fungi and liver, it's the delicate juices at the bottom of the dish that taste almost like a mild herbal soup that pique our interest.

Meanwhile, seared pork knuckle ($12 for XS) is stripped of bone and fashioned into a rectangular terrine of shredded pork and gelatinous bits panfried on each side to achieve a good crusty exterior with tender meat inside. Paired with marinated vegetable cubes and sliced radish, it passes muster.

Less successful is the chipotle chilli crab tacos ($24 for XM) with its bland mixture of crabmeat tossed with tomatoes and chilli piled into a tender warm taco and topped with shredded cabbage slaw. While we're no fan of the filling, we're won over by the taco's chewy tender texture and homemade taste. Switch the filling to something else and we're sold.

We're pleasantly surprised by the charcoal eggplant, organic grains and ricotta ($18 for XM) - one of the few choices not influenced by local cuisine. The eggplant's distinctive smokiness adds to the pleasure of chewing on plump barley, assorted grains and the melting-soft eggplant, rounded off with tangy ricotta cheese.

Not all will be enamoured of the lobster and scallop laksa risotto ($39 for XM) - but not because it doesn't taste like laksa. Rather, its al dente rice texture (with a slightly uncooked core which defines al dente as "firm to the bite") may not sit well with those used to thoroughly cooked rice. As for the laksa comparison, it tastes more like curried bisque with shredded laksa leaves, but the foundation stock is rich in flavour, and you get a good portion of scallop and meaty lobster claw. The downside is that risotto needs to be eaten really quickly or it gets stodgy, and the restaurant's air-conditioning speeds up its transformation into a gloopy, stodgy affair very fast.

Holding out better is the roasted lamb, lentil and coconut curry ($14 for a surprisingly big portion for XS). Pink lamb slices are served alongside a mild, fragrant lentil curry that stands out for the texture of the lentils - they're still whole and tender rather than turned into a creamy mash - although we would prefer more coconut milk in the curry itself, not in fancy swirls of foamy white sauce that's obtrusively salty-sour and detracts from the rest of the good stuff.

Desserts are passable affairs with an interesting lemon curd and marshmallow combination with fun pop rocks ($15) and "decadent chocolate" ($19) that features a smoky chocolate ice cream with an odd aftertaste paired with sticky chocolate ganache and crispy wafers.

Expect service to be slow and somewhat inexperienced. Can't really blame them, though. When you're working in a disco ball of a hotel, it's bound to be a distracting experience.

Rating:

7

WHAT OUR RATINGS MEAN

10: The ultimate dining experience

9-9.5: Sublime

8-8.5: Excellent

7-7.5: Good to very good

6-6.5: Promising

5-5.5: Average

site_title: Let them eat football, says Fifa
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Let them eat football, says Fifa

Published

Fri, Jun 13, 2014 · 10:00 PM

IF the ice cream-slurping child in your family started hurling stones at a Haagen-Dazs outlet, you'd be concerned.

And if, in the spiritual home of football, a Brazilian says "I hope my team loses in the first round", and goes to do battle with police over the World Cup, you know something is disturbingly wrong.

As you watch the first games, the protests will be ignored by Fifa-authorised cameras. But they will be there. This is not political activism. This is the showing of pain and outrage from a people whose deepest love has been prostituted.

More than one-fifth of all Brazilians live on less than US$2 a day and still love their football. When the country was awarded the World Cup, they partied like there was no tomorrow. But tomorrow came - and it was a nightmare.

Red card

Fifa ordered stadiums built to its specifications. Twelve new and refurbished structures started to take shape, but the favelas,

or shantytowns, of the poor were in their way. Some 250,000 homes were bulldozed.

All for a good cause?

Then, came the bills. Brazil, with its rutted roads and crumbling bridges, spent US$11.7 billion on the project. But Fifa was not satisfied. "Brazil needs a kick up its backside," said a Fifa official, who was unhappy with the pace of construction.

Then came the revelations. An auditor's report showed that out of the US$900 million spent on Brasilia's World Cup stadium, there was price-gouging to the tune of US$275 million. Builders, for example, billed the government US$1.5 million to transport prefabricated grandstands - an operation that costs just US$4,700, according to auditors.

Why were these inflated claims approved? One explanation is that the developers have suddenly ramped up their donations to political parties. After contributing just US$73,180 to politicians in 2008, one stadium builder upped its donations to US$37 million last year - 500 times more.

Set play

And then came the bullying. A festival that has been held on the streets of Rio de Janeiro every World Cup for 32 years was all set to show games on a public screen, when Fifa sent its organisers a US$10,000 bill for breaching broadcasting rights. Local snack sellers were told to take their business away from streets around the stadium to protect McDonald's, a sponsor.

Brazil had a law banning beer inside stadiums to stop unruly fans from attacking each other. This was scrapped because Budweiser is a sponsor.

Meanwhile, Fifa made a tax-free profit of US$1.1 billion on the event.

Brazilians protested. A new anti-terror law was passed to quell the uproar. Some 170,000 security men are being deployed to ensure this, and 27 protesters have died since last year.

Sorry, Bill Shankly. You said: "Some people believe football is a matter of life and death . . . I can assure you it is much, much more important than that."

This is a matter of life and death. Somehow, football seems less important.

site_title: IPO market could stir from slumber in H2
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

IPO market could stir from slumber in H2

M&A activity likely to keep pace, given access to easy credit

Published

Sun, Jun 15, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] A breezy access to favourable funding, and a shift from yield play may have lured listing candidates away, but pent-up demand could revive the initial public offering (IPO) market here in the second half of the year, bankers say.

So far this year, there have been just two mainboard IPOs, which raised a total of about $735 million, data compiled by BT showed. The same time last year, six mainboard listings raised $3.5 billion from their IPOs.

"We see a trend of companies looking for private fund-raising," said Tay Toh Sin, head of corporate finance at OCBC, referring to private investors such as Asian-based institutional funds. Companies want to shun the current market volatility too, she added.

The expected rise in interest rate, as the US Federal Reserve unwinds its stimulus programme, has had two key effects. Companies may choose to turn to cheap funding now, and lock in rates, rather than turn to the capital markets, said Ms Tay. It explains why there may be more Catalist listings than mega IPOs on the mainboard, given that smaller companies with a relatively poorer credit rating or history may find it tougher to get debt.

There have been four Catalist listings so far, one more than those listed at the same time last year.

The attention on higher rates now also means that real estate investment trusts (Reits) - a mainstay of the Singapore market - are less attractive today. The six mainboard listings in the first half of the year included two Reits and one business trust. "There is still a window, but the Reit issuers are mindful of how quickly the window may be shut," noted Ms Tay.

This comes as many investors have stayed at the sidelines to look for "extremely attractive" pricing, said Tan Jeh Wuan, DBS's head of capital markets in Singapore.

Also, many potential listings are companies with strong balance sheets and cash flows, and are therefore not in a hurry to sell their shares at giveaway prices, he added.

"We are beginning to see some investors coming back, especially in the Reits space. Issuers are also becoming more realistic in pricing and hopefully this will help bridge the valuation gap and enable IPOs to be done," he said. "We are optimistic that the IPO market will be more active in the second half, given the pipeline built up from deals deferred in the first half."

The hushed IPO market could also be stirred by more oil-and-gas listings, as investors expect oil prices to stay healthy, said OCBC's Ms Tay.

The largest mainboard listing this year is PACC Offshore Services Holdings, which raised $388 million through its IPO.

Notably, IPO volumes in Asia historically pick up significantly in the second half of the year, pointed out Neil Kell, Deutsche Bank's head of equity capital markets in Asia. "We should see this pattern repeat itself in 2014. The second half of 2014 will see several large transactions coming to market with the likes of Alibaba, WH Group, and 1MDB, which could potentially take the volumes higher than ever on record."

Mergers and acquisitions (M&A) activity in Singapore and the region is also likely to keep pace in the second half of the year, on the back of easy credit and compelling valuations of target companies.

Singapore stood out as the top acquirer country in South-east Asia with a record total of US$24 billion in cross-border M&A deals under its belt thus far, figures from Dealogic showed. This is also double the US$12.2 billion in M&A deals announced in the same period a year ago.

"The confidence in the long-term macro environment, benign credit markets, and the desire to expand or diversify has encouraged local acquirers to look more actively for the M&A option, which has not always been the case," said Mayooran Elalingam, Deutsche Bank's head of M&A in Asia.

There is some anticipation that Australian and Japanese investors may swoop in to shop, noted OCBC's Ms Tay. Some Australian resources and property firms are looking to diversify into the South-east Asian region.

Japanese corporates, meanwhile, have made public their ambitions to spend cash spilling over their coffers, estimated at over 220 trillion yen (S$2.7 trillion).

Part of the activity could be driven by private equity funds, too. Singapore was the most active private equity market in South-east Asia last year, with the deal value at US$3 billion, a Bain & Company report last month showed.

site_title: A well-dressed home
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

A well-dressed home

Top fashion labels including Kate Spade, Bottega Veneta and Hermes are expanding into the lifestyle business. By Tay Suan Chiang

Published

Fri, Jun 13, 2014 · 10:00 PM

YOU wear the clothes. Why not write in the notebooks or eat off the plates? That seems to be the business game plan of fashion labels which are branching out into the lifestyle business.

The latest to do so in Singapore is Kate Spade New York, which launched its Stationery and Gifts collection on Wednesday at novelty store Monoyono in Plaza Singapura.

The Kate Spade New York Stationery and Gift collection was launched in the United States last autumn, and is a partnership with fine gifts and accessories specialist Lifeguard Press.

Like its name implies, the collection comprises writing instruments, notebooks, greeting cards and desk accessories, as well as plates, glasses and napkins and even a picnic mat.

In line with the quintessential Kate Spade spirit, the items feature bold and colourful prints and motifs.

Charm of writing

With the stationery collection, Benny Low, managing director of Trendspot, which owns Monoyono, says: "We want to bring back the charm of writing in today's digital world, where typing and tweeting have become the norm."

He is confident that the lifestyle collection will appeal to existing Kate Spade fans. "But those who aren't will probably also want to buy a piece or two for their friends who already have Kate Spade bags," he notes.

Todd Ferrier, president of Lifeguard Press, says fans can expect more in the next collection. "We love the playful quotes that Kate Spade New York uses, and they have become iconic for the brand. We will continue to play on those quotes." Some of the quirky quotes include "talk is chic" and "how the devil are you".

Earlier this year, Calvin Klein showcased pieces from its Home collection in an architectural installation, designed to serve as a "concept house" at the Old Kallang Airport.

Quiet elegance

The Calvin Klein Home collection was started in 1995, when the designer could not find the right bedlinen that he wanted, according to Amy Mellen, the brand's creative director.

The collection is not yet available in Singapore, but it includes bedding, bath, dinnerware, tabletop, table linens, giftware and furniture. Like the fashion, the look of Home is about quiet luxury and elegance.

The two brands join the likes of Bottega Veneta and Hermes which have already dressed homes with their luxurious homeware.

As with the other labels, Bottega Veneta's home collection which was launched in 2006, evolved out of necessity. When its creative director Tomas Maier could not find specific furnishings for his residence or the retail stores which he decorated, he commissioned bespoke pieces. Then, he explains: "People wanted to buy the bench that was in the window, and I said: 'No, we'll make you one.' And one thing led to the next."

The full range of Bottega Veneta Home Collection is launched every two years at Milan's Salone Del Mobile. Its latest range was launched in April, and will be available for sale from September, at Da Vinci Home Collection in Upper Bukit Timah Road.

Da Vinci Home also carries home collections from other well-known fashion labels including Blumarine, Versace, Kenzo, Fendi and Armani. Jason Chua, Da Vinci Home's sales manager, says sales of home items from these brands have been positive. "They appeal to those who are already familiar with the fashion side of the brand," he adds.

site_title: CPF and the annoying thing about compounding
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

CPF and the annoying thing about compounding

Compounded interest seems like a pipe dream because its effects only show in the final years, says CAI HAOXIANG

Published

Sun, Jun 15, 2014 · 10:00 PM

COMPOUNDING interest will make you rich, they tell you. A cornerstone argument of personal finance and wealth managers, compounding interest - that is, money snowballing into Warren Buffett-like billions - is a seemingly unassailable argument for the need to save, and start early, and to invest with so and so or put your money in that financial product.

Just let compounding work its magic, goes the argument.

A popular rule of thumb to determine how long it takes for your money to double is known as the rule of 72. Essentially, take an interest rate, say 7 per cent a year. Divide 72 by that number - you get around 10. That means at a 7 per cent interest rate, your money will double every 10 years.

Sounds good? As 19th century Irish writer Oscar Wilde would say, the truth is rarely pure and never simple.

The most annoying thing about compounding is that its effects are only felt at the end.

In the words of the motto of a well-known boys' school here, "the best is yet to be".

Theoretically, money makes more money. You gain interest on a sum of money one year, and gain interest on that interest the next in addition to interest on the original sum.

The truth of the matter is, compounding starts off painstakingly slow, and only becomes truly spectacular right at the end.

And we all know what happens in the end, thanks to British economist John Maynard Keynes: "In the long run, we are all dead."

People can thus be forgiven for getting a little bit impatient with the compounding genie. All it makes are promises after promises without seeming to deliver much.

This is best illustrated with a current example.

Singapore's own Central Provident Fund (CPF) has been in the hot spot lately for purportedly giving low returns, insufficient for Singaporeans to meet their retirement needs.

Adding to the angst is the fear that more and more money will be locked away.

Currently, just about half of Singaporeans meet the minimum sum to qualify them for the maximum lifelong annuity payout called CPF Life. The minimum sum is now at $155,000.

But the government has said that most young Singaporean wage earners today will be able to meet the minimum sum by the time they retire, provided they buy property within their means.

An independent study on retirement commissioned by the Ministry of Manpower and conducted by National University of Singapore professors have also found that young workers today can replace their income upon retirement at rates similar to developed countries.

So why is there a disconnect? Why do the young feel that they will never be able to hit the minimum sum, even while studies have shown they can?

Part of the answer, perhaps, lies in how compounding works.

There are two main accounts everybody has in the CPF to deal with retirement: the Ordinary Account (OA) and the Special Account (SA).

At age 55, money from the OA and SA is transferred to a newly created Retirement Account. Any monies in the RA in excess of the minimum sum can be withdrawn. Otherwise, the remainder is used to buy the CPF Life annuity.

However, come age 55, people might not have enough in the OA to speak of.

Money there is typically withdrawn to buy a house, and then to upgrade to a bigger house, and so on.

That might leave the heavy-lifting for the minimum sum to the SA. The sum of money there, if you haven't lost it trading stocks, theoretically accumulates at a steady pace of at least 4 per cent a year.

The accumulation gets faster towards age 55 because the proportion of your wage that goes into the SA every month increases with age.

It starts at 6 per cent when you are below 35, and rises steadily, peaking at 9.5 per cent from age 50 to 55.

For a typical young person today, how much would he have in his account by age 55?

Basic assumptions

Let us assume our young chap starts off work earning the equivalent pay of a university graduate.

This is not an unreasonable assumption. About half of Singapore's 2.1 million strong resident labour force is currently either a diploma or equivalent holder (18.4 per cent) or degree holder (31.5 per cent), as of 2013.

The proportion of diploma and degree holders get larger if you zoom in to look at the data of younger age groups.

Out of the 210,000 economically active residents aged 25 to 29 last June, over half, 106,000, are degree holders alone. Another quarter, or 53,000, have a diploma or professional qualification.

According to the most recent graduate employment survey, the typical starting salary of a graduate is $3,000 a month.

The median wage of a typical resident, too, was at $3,250 a month last year.

To be conservative, let's start with a $3,000-a-month wage assumption, which adds up to $36,000 a year.

To be even more conservative, we don't factor in bonuses. No 13th month pay, no commissions, nothing.

The next assumption we have to make is how much wages rise by every year. Nominal wages have risen by an average of 4 to 5 per cent a year for the past five years, including the 2009 recession.

Again, let's peg wage rises conservatively at the core inflation rate of 2 per cent.

Our average young worker thus begins working at age 26. By the end of his first year of work, he has $2,160 in his SA. So his SA increases by slightly more than $2,000 every year, plus interest.

Fast forward 10 years, at the end of age 35, and he has just $28,000.

This is still a far cry from the minimum sum, however. And it's been 10 years.

Even at age 45, when another 10 years have passed, his SA stands at around $80,000.

Who knows what the minimum sum will be, then? His SA is increasing at a faster pace, but it still seems slow, and it is still half of the minimum sum of about $160,000 today.

So it took us 20 whole years to get the first $80,000.

But something dramatic happens to the numbers in the last few years of compounding, further boosted by an increase in the SA contribution rate.

This assumes, of course, that our hypothetical male person keeps his job and does not have to take a pay cut.

While it took 20 years to hit the first $80,000, it will take a mere 10 years to accumulate the next $100,000.

When our chap is 55 years old, he will actually have more than $180,000 in his SA.

While he accumulated just $2,000 to $3,000 in his SA every year in the beginning, the final two years will see him add $12,000 a year to his SA - all on conservative wage growth assumptions.

The way the numbers work is not intuitive. Nor can one easily understand the power of compounding from the vantage point of the 25-year-old, the 35-year-old, or even the 45-year-old.

The second most annoying thing

This sum of $180,000 will probably be lower than the minimum sum in 30 years' time.

Assuming it increases by core inflation of 2 per cent every year, our fresh graduate will need close to $300,000 by the time he hits 55.

Then again, the minimum sum might yet be met if we relax our conservative assumptions.

We also left out the role of the OA in providing for retirement savings altogether.

Assuming he buys a modest-sized flat costing about $400,000 with his wife of a similar earning capacity and age, right at the beginning of his working career, it is entirely possible that the couple can pay off their mortgage by age 45.

That leaves an additional 10 years in which the OA will add at least $80,000 to one's savings, without factoring interest. This adds up to total retirement savings of around $260,000 in the CPF.

And who knows, maybe he will get a promotion at work, and a pay rise in the earlier years. This leaves even more years for compounding to do its work.

And so we get to the second most annoying thing about compounding: the assumptions you use matter a lot.

The way the math works is that any seemingly small change every year will add up to exponential growth over dozens of years.

Wage growth of just one more percentage point, for example, will add $30,000 to the SA and another $20,000 to the accumulated OA from age 45 to 55.

In an optimistic scenario where wage growth is also 5 per cent, one will have $285,000 in the SA at age 55, and have an extra $170,000 in the OA accumulated between age 45 and 55.

This is more than one and a half times that of our base case scenario.

If one tweaks starting salary to $4,000 a month and keeps wage growth at 5 per cent a year, you end up with $380,000 in the SA at age 55, and an extra $225,000 accumulated in the OA - more than enough where the minimum sum will probably be concerned.

Young investors and savers can thus draw a few lessons from how compounding works.

First, don't expect to see results early.

When you are rolling your snowball, the first 10, even 20 years will seem frustratingly slow. It is easy to get impatient and deviate from, say, a blue-chip, conservative investment strategy and take bigger punts with penny stocks that give you a higher chance of failing.

Staying the course is more likely to reward.

Second, ensure your assumptions are conservative.

Being conservative has advantages. The chances of you being disappointed fall, and the chances of you being pleasantly surprised rises.

Some investment schemes might promise returns of 10 per cent a year or more. Many pension funds in the US were operating on the assumption of 8 per cent returns a year. This is unrealistic, as many are finding out.

A steady rate of return of around 4 per cent is probably safer.

Finally, work hard to boost returns early on.

Getting as high a starting salary as possible and socking as much away as possible to begin the process of compounding is probably the best strategy for younger folk hoping to retire comfortably before they are 55.

Whatever you do, and whatever your aims, the returns might not seem like much at the start. Once critical mass is reached, however, they might seem more than enough.

site_title: DBS buys rest of HK credit card company for HK$546m
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

DBS buys rest of HK credit card company for HK$546m

Published

Mon, Jun 16, 2014 · 10:00 PM

DBS Group Holdings has acquired the rest of a Hong Kong credit card company for HK$546 million (S$88 million).

In a filing to the Singapore Exchange, the bank, via wholly owned DBS Hong Kong, said it bought 50 per cent of the issued shares in Hutchison DBS Card Limited from Whampoa Ltd.

Before the deal, done on "willing buyer, willing seller basis", each owned 50 per cent of the company.

"This purchase is consistent with DBS' acquisition criteria, with cards being a strategic part of our consumer banking platform," said a bank spokeswoman.

"The acquisition is also expected to be earnings-accretive from the first year of acquisition through maximising revenue synergies through cross-selling," she added.

The book value and net tangible asset value of Hutchison DBS Card Ltd is HK$728 million as at Dec 2013.

The above transaction is not expected to have any material impact on the company's financial position for the current financial year, said DBS.

DBS has over the past couple of years repositioned its Hong Kong business to deepen relationship with China companies, as well as expand its domestic small and medium enterprise franchise and get a bigger share of the affluent segment.

In its 2013 annual report, DBS said efforts to reposition consumer banking in Hong Kong have paid off as income from investment and insurance products rose 18 per cent.

DBS opened its first DBS Treasures Private Client centre in the city to serve the wealthy.

In 2013, Hong Kong achieved a record year as total income and net profit reached new highs. Total income rose 22 per cent to $1.86 billion while net pro-fit was up 19 per cent at $851 million, contributing to 24 per cent of the group total.

site_title: Beckham's boots up for grabs - for at least $1,250
content:
Beckham's boots up for grabs - for at least $1,250

Lee U-Wen

Published

Sun, Jun 15, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] A pair of David Beckham's football boots, signed by the retired star himself, is the centrepiece of an ongoing auction to raise funds for two local charities.

The former England national team captain was in town on Saturday to donate the pair of bright pink boots, which bear the names of his four children - sons Brooklyn, Romeo and Cruz and daughter Harper.

The boots are among 22 items going under the hammer for an auction organised as part of Marina Bay Sands' (MBS) Sands for Singapore festival.

This is the second time that the 39-year-old, who has played for clubs such as Manchester United and Real Madrid, has donated a personal item for the integrated resort's corporate social responsibility programme.

Last year, he contributed an autographed jersey of his final club, Paris Saint-Germain of France, for the auction.

"One of the things I'm very passionate about is charity," he said during a football clinic with 90 young athletes at MBS. "It gives me a lot of happiness. (These boots) are special because it has my family's names; they are my support."

The auction proceeds will go to The Business Times Budding Artists Fund - which helps underprivileged children aged five to 19 develop their talents in music, dance, theatre and the visual arts - and The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund, which gives a monthly stipend to students from low-income homes to help them with school-related expenses.

Each of the 22 auction items has a minimum bid price. The Beckham boots, for instance, start at $1,250.

Among the other items are a set of boxing gloves signed by Manny Pacquiao and Brandon Rios, two caps signed by the main cast and director of The Amazing Spider-Man 2 movie, and a Manchester United jersey signed by ex-player Rio Ferdinand.

Seven of these items will be auctioned off at the BT Dream Ball on Aug 1, a dinner event that will feature performances by international ballroom dancing champions.

All in, MBS hopes the funds raised from the auction and other events will surpass the $3.6 million raised from its inaugural festival last year.

The money will benefit various designated charities including the Singapore Association for the Deaf, Art Outreach Singapore and the Association for Persons with Special Needs.

Those keen to take part in the auction, which runs until Aug 1, can visit

bit.ly/sandsforsingapore

.

The festival itself, an annual charity event, will be held from Aug 1-3.

site_title: Director sales up for 2nd week
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Director sales up for 2nd week

About-turn after May buying spree; week's purchases less than $1m while disposals exceed $16m

Published

Sun, Jun 15, 2014 · 10:00 PM

AFTER posting heavy purchases in May, a reverse trend among directors is emerging as their buying slowed and disposals rose for the second straight week, according to filings on Singapore Exchange in the week of June 9-13. A total of 13 companies recorded 22 purchases worth $890,000 compared with 13 firms with 28 disposals worth $16.3 million. The buy figures were down from the previous week's 14 companies, 24 purchases and $3.8 million. The sales, on the other hand, were sharply up from the previous week's eight firms, 14 disposals, and $1.9 million.

Aside from directors, the buyback activity fell with eight companies posting 22 repurchases worth $9.2 million. The number of firms and trades were slightly down from the previous week's nine companies and 23 repurchases. The value, however, was sharply down from the previous week's turnover of $12.6 million.

With the surge in the selling last week, the bulk of the significant trades were disposals with insider sales in Anchun International, Gallant Venture, UMS Holdings, M1 Ltd, SBS Transit, StarHub Ltd and QAF Ltd. Also negative last week was AIA Group with sales in Mapletree Commercial Trust, Mapletree Industrial Trust and Starhill Global Reit.

Anchun International Holdings

COO Liang Gong Zeng recorded the first on-market sale by a director in integrated chemical systems engineering firm Anchun International since the stock was listed in October 2010. He sold 900,000 shares June 11 at 8 cents each. The trade reduced his deemed holdings to 44.700 million shares or 8.88 per cent of the issued capital (registered holder is Giant Yield Global Ltd).

The sale was made on the back of the 29 per cent rebound in the share price since February from 6.2 cents. Despite the rebound in the share price, the counter is still down since September 2013 from 12.9 cents. Mr Liang's sale price was sharply lower than the IPO price of 28 cents. The counter closed at 8.5 cents on Friday.

Gallant Venture

Non-executive chairman Lim Hock San recorded his first on-market sale in industrial parks operator, utility, hospitality and property development firm Gallant Venture since the stock was listed in June 2007 on SGX Mainboard with 1.7 million shares sold on June 12 at 35.5 cents each. The trade reduced his direct holdings by 50 per cent to 1.714 million shares or 0.04 per cent.

The sale was made on the back of the 25 per cent rebound in the share price since March from 28.5 cents. The counter is also sharply up since February from 24.5 cents. Mr Lim previously acquired an initial 1.71 million shares in March 2012 at 31 cents each. The counter closed at 34.5 cents on Friday.

UMS Holdings

CEO Andy Luong and Applied Materials unloaded shares in contract equipment manufacturer UMS Holdings. The sales were made on the back of the rise in the share price since March from 58.8 cents. Mr Luong sold 19 million shares from June 5 to 10 at an average of 66.8 cents each.

The trades, which accounted for 50 per cent of the stock's trading volume, reduced his deemed holdings by 21 per cent to 69.608 million shares or 20.25 per cent. He previously sold 7 million shares from March 3 to 4 at 65 cents each. Prior to his sales this year, Mr Luong sold 1.9 million shares in March 2013 at an average of 44.2 cents each and 12.6 million shares in April 2012 at an average of 47.6 cents each. Prior to his sales since 2012, Mr Luong acquired a net 5.5 million shares from April to October 2008 at 26 cents to 16 cents each, 4.2 million shares from March to November 2007 at 45 cents to 36 cents each and 1.57 million shares from April to December 2005 at an average of 43.5 cents each.

Applied Materials, on the other hand, ceased to be a substantial shareholder following the sale of 3.85 million shares from June 3 to 5 at 92.5 cents to 69.3 cents each, which lowered its deemed stake by 19 per cent to 16.600 million shares or 4.83 per cent.

The group reported an initial filing in October 2007 of 16.1 million shares via exercise of options at 37 cents each, which raised its interest to 5.67 per cent. The counter closed at 56 cents on Friday.

M1 Ltd

CEO Karen Kooi Lee Wah recorded her first on-market trade in telecom and broadband services provider M1 Ltd since September 2013 with 100,000 shares sold on June 6 at $3.56 each. The trade reduced her direct holdings by 9 per cent to 1.000 million shares or 0.11 per cent of the issued capital. It was made on the back of the 12 per cent rebound in the share price since December 2013 from $3.17. The disposal was made at a profit based on the one million shares that she acquired via exercise of options from Jan 10 to 15 at an average of $2.04 each.

She previously sold 1.56 million shares from February to September 2013 at an average of $3.10 each. Some of these were options-related sales, The sales since February 2013 are her first on-market trades after her appointment in April 2009. The stock closed at $3.53 on Friday.

SBS Transit

Independent non-executive director Cheong Yip Seng recorded his first on-market trade in bus operator SBS Transit Ltd since the stock was listed in December 1997 with 50,000 shares sold on June 6 at $1.70 each. The trade reduced his direct holdings by 27 per cent to 135,000 shares or 0.04 per cent.

The sale was made on the back of the 47 per cent rebound in the share price since March from $1.16. Despite the rebound in the share price, the counter is still down since January 2011 from $2.13. The stock closed at $1.71 on Friday.

StarHub Ltd

Independent non-executive director Nihal Vijaya Devadas Kaviratne unloaded shares of cable, mobile and Internet platform information, communications and entertainment services provider StarHub Ltd at sharply higher than his acquisition prices from August 2011 to November 2012 with 40,300 shares sold on June 6 at an average of $4.21 each.

The trades reduced his direct holdings by 73 per cent to 15,000 shares. He also has deemed interest of 175,812 shares or 0.01 per cent. The disposals were made on the back of the 18 per cent rise in the share price since November 2012 from $3.59.

He previously acquired 6,000 shares in November 2012 at $3.66 each, 35,000 shares in February 2012 at $2.89 each and 88,000 shares in August 2011 at $2.82 each. The stock closed at $4.27 on Friday.

QAF Ltd

Executive director Tarn Teh Chuen recorded her first on-market trade in baked products manufacturer QAF Ltd since her appointment in June 1995 with 62,000 shares sold on June 9 at 85 cents each. The trade reduced her direct holdings to 1.182 million shares or 0.22 per cent. The sale was made on the back of the 19 per cent drop in the share price since August 2013 from $1.05.

Despite the fall in the share price, the counter is still up since October 2011 from 53.5 cents. The disposal was made at a profit based on the 250,000 shares that she acquired via exercise of options on April 1 at 52 cents each. The counter closed at 85.5 cents on Friday.

Mapletree Commercial Trust

AIA Group recorded its first notice in real estate investment trust Mapletree Commercial Trust since November 2013 with a disposal-related filing on June 12 of 2.5 million units at $1.29 each. The trade reduced its deemed holdings to 123.991 million units or 5.93 per cent. The filing was made on the back of the 14 per cent rebound in the unit price since December 2013 from $1.135.

The group previously reported a disposal-related filing in November 2013 of 618,000 units at $1.21 each. Overall, AIA's stake is down by 15 per cent since November 2013. The group became a substantial shareholder in April 2011 after it subscribed for an initial 142.045 million units or 7.63 per cent in the IPO at 88 cents each.

The sentiment is not entirely negative this year as there were purchases by Schroders plc and non-executive director Hiew Yoon Khong. Schroders reported a purchase-related filing on May 19 of 15,000 units at $1.34 each, which increased its deemed holdings to 125.089 million units or 6.0 per cent.

The group previously reported an initial filing on Feb 24 of 74,000 units at $1.18 each, which raised its interest to 5.0 per cent. Mr Hiew, on the other hand, purchased 110,000 units on April 24 at $1.29 each, which boosted his deemed stake to 2.320 million units or 0.11 per cent. He also has direct interest of 489,000 units of 0.02 per cent. He previously acquired 210,000 units on February 17 at $1.19 each. The counter closed at $1.31 on Friday.

Mapletree Industrial Trust

AIA Group lowered its stake in real estate investment trust Mapletree Industrial Trust to below 5.0 per cent of the issued capital at sharply higher than its initial filing price in October 2010. The group ceased to be a substantial shareholder on June 9 following the sale of 1.35 million units at $1.45 each, which reduced its deemed holdings to 84.182 million units or 4.93 per cent.

The filing was made on the back of the 16 per cent rebound in the unit price since December 2013 from $1.26. Despite the rebound in the unit price, the stock is still down since May 2013 from $1.60. AIA became a substantial shareholder in October 2010 after it acquired an initial 79.116 million units or 5.4 per cent in the IPO at 93 cents each. The counter closed at $1.42 on Friday.

Starhill Global Reit

AIA Group and AIA Singapore Pte Ltd recorded sales in retail and office buildings investor Starhill Global Reit. AIA Group sold two million units on June 11 at 81.3 cents each, which reduced its deemed holdings to 191.873 million units or 8.91 per cent.

The group previously reported a purchase-related filing in August 2012 of 460,000 units at an estimated price of 73.5 cents each and a disposal-related filing in March 2011 of 1.1 million units at an estimated price of 62 cents each. Overall, AIA Group's stake is down by 11 per cent since March 2011.

AIA Singapore, on the other hand, recorded its first notice since September 2012 with a disposal-related filing on June 9 of one million units at 82.5 cents each, which lowered its direct stake to 172.032 million units or 7.99 per cent. The group previously reported a disposal-related filing in September 2012 of one million units at 75 cents each. The counter closed at 81.5 cents on Friday.

The writer is managing director, Asia Insider Ltd

site_title: More spectrum to be freed up for broadband-type services
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

More spectrum to be freed up for broadband-type services

New rules framed after conclusion of public consultation

Published

Mon, Jun 16, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE]The government will soon introduce regulation for the use of radio spectrum in the TV White Space (TVWS) - that is, the unused spectrum within TV broadcast bands - in order to maximise the use of spectrum.

Singapore will become one of the first countries in the world to implement such a framework for TVWS when the regulations come into effect in November.

These bands can be used for alternative wireless broadband communications similar to Wi-Fi capabilities but at a lower price, lower cost and longer range.

Recent advances in TVWS technology have enabled regulators to adopt new ways to optimise the use of TVWS spectrum by allowing opportunistic access to the unused spectrum in Singapore's television broadcast channels without causing interference to existing operations. This will make available an estimated 180 MHz of spectrum.

The regulations were framed after the conclusion of a public consultation which started in June last year. Taking into account inputs from the industry, these regulations will set out the TVWS equipment requirements, spectrum channels to be made available for TVWS use, and how TVWS equipment should communicate with geo-location databases in order to identify the available spectrum channel to use, among others.

The geo-location databases will help to ascertain the available channels for use, before services can be broadcast over those channels. Companies interested in developing and managing a geo-location database service in Singapore will be required to apply for a licence.

Through the licensing framework, the government will be able to ensure that the geo-location database operations comply with the technical parameters and regulatory requirements. Further, to facilitate and encourage the adoption of TVWS technology, the government will waive the licence fees for the first two years.

An Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore (IDA) spokesman said the regulations will also provide business certainty to companies which intend to offer services over TVWS.

This signals Singapore's commitment to support TVWS technology as businesses roll out innovative applications and solutions over TVWS. Interestingly, such applications may include machine-to-machine communications, smart metering and outdoor environment and security monitoring services. All these fall under the gamut of the so-called Internet of Things.

The spokesman added that consumers will stand to benefit from this additional spectrum.

As more Internet-capable devices are launched, more spectrum is required for increased data consumption. However, consumer products will be available only at a later stage when the necessary chipsets become available for inclusion into devices.

Businesses that wish to deploy or use TVWS technology may do so without applying for a licence from the IDA, subject to technical parameters and regulations for the use of TVWS. Consumers may benefit from new services provided over TVWS by various service providers.

IDA's Leong Keng Thai noted that the TVWS regulatory framework is a step towards Singapore's vision on being the world's first "Smart Nation".

"Regulators all over the world are exploring different ways to efficiently use spectrum, so that they can plan for their countries' future needs.

"The additional spectrum made available through the TVWS regulatory framework will ensure that Singapore efficiently allocates and uses this available bandwidth to support the growing demand for data communication," said Mr Leong, who is IDA's deputy chief executive and director-general (telecoms and post).

site_title: Transgenders' blight
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Transgenders' blight

Published

Thu, Jun 12, 2014 · 10:00 PM

WHEN Avant Theatre's artistic director G Selvanathan first decided to stage the controversial play Akka (which is Tamil for "sister") back in 1991, his goal was to be a voice for Singapore's transgender community.

"The issue we highlighted was that society was not giving them space to be themselves," says Mr Selva. "We wanted to give them the courage to say,'I'm moving on with my life whether or not you accept me'."

Though it was a taboo subject at the time, the play was well received as one of the first transgender texts presented on stage in Tamil in Singapore.

Akka was revived again last year through a reading at Artistry cafe in Jalan Pinang, where, Mr Selva says, those in the audience encouraged him to pen a sequel.

The result is Akka: The End, which will play at the School of the Arts (SOTA) Drama Centre in July. The show will be done entirely in Tamil but with English surtitles. The first 40 minutes is a condensed version of the original Akka, followed by the new material in the next 90 minutes.

"This sequel will talk about how things haven't really changed," says Mr Selva. "For example, they are not allowed to hold certain jobs. They can't be phone operators because their voices are too rough, and they aren't allowed to work in certain shops because of the brand's public image." Even in his own experience, he has noticed how many of his transgender friends and acquaintances hold relatively low-paying shift jobs despite having a good education.

"These people have commitments like children, husbands, and families to take care of too. And it's not that they lie around and not want to do anything," he points out. Which is why many of them end up as sex workers against their will. "Everybody thinks transsexuals go into their trade as sex workers because they want to, but actually they have no choice. Who would want people to come to them with weird fetishes, and harrass them, and make them do things they don't want to?" he says.

Of course, as the show's director, Mr Selva acknowledges that the play might end up coming across as rather aggressive in getting his message across, but that's exactly what he's going for. "These transsexuals in the play are not actors, they are real people, just being themselves. Because it is their reality we want to depict, we want them to tell the story. Anybody else telling their story would be fake." he explains.

He says he was compelled to write Akka after hearing the stories of his own transgender friends, who told him their experiences of having people throw stones or packets of water at them just for the fun of it.

"I want audiences to feel the pain of these people. It won't be melodramatic and make them cry, but it should make them think. That's what theatre is for, right?" he adds.

site_title: Living the wild life
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Living the wild life

Not knowing what each day will be like is what has been keeping Safari guide Peter Allison in the bush for nearly 2 decades. By Tay Suan Chiang

Published

Fri, Jun 13, 2014 · 10:00 PM

WHAT do you do when a herd of wild animals decides to charge at you? If your first instinct is to run, don't. Do you think you can outrun a lion, an elephant or a buffalo?

Safari guide Peter Allison says "whatever you do, don't run". That is also the title of his first book, which he wrote in 2008, based on his experiences in the safari. "You have to stand your ground," says Mr Allison, who has trained himself not to run. He advises to "make yourself look bigger by putting your arms out, show confidence, step forward, and in some cases, roar back at the lion. Of course, it helps to practise all these in your head".

He bursts into laughter when he reveals that instead of roaring, he finds himself turning into a panicky mess. "And when the lion sees what a pathetic prey I am, he is no longer interested."

For the record, he has been chased by buffalos three times. "The trick is to stand your ground and only jump out of their way at the last minute," he says, and often he finds himself jumping into a thorn bush. "Buffalos have taught me that while you can jump into a thorn bush, you cannot jump out of one," says the Australian-born guide, who then has to cut himself free of thorns to get out.

Another time, he found himself in between two herds of lions that were about to attack each other. "Three males came running in my direction, but I was invisible to them. They were so focused on attacking the other, that even if I had been naked and waving a pink towel, they would not have noticed me," he says as he recalls his memorable moments in the safari. "These lions run at over 60km per hour, and their fight was the most powerful thing I had ever seen."

The charismatic guide, who grew up in Sydney, first headed to Africa in 1994, when he was 19. The plan was to spend a year there before returning home, possibly to study law. On his choice of location, the animal lover says "it was a toss-up between Africa or South America". A toss of a coin determined the destination. After six months of backpacking, he was offered a job running the bar of a safari lodge in South Africa, and soon after that became a guide.

That one year in Africa has since turned into almost two decades. Mr Allison now works with Wilderness Safaris, widely acclaimed as the continent's foremost eco-tourism operator.

For him, not knowing what each day will be like, is what has been keeping him in the bush. "I don't need the unexpected on a daily basis, but I like the opportunity that it presents." He explains that city living is predictable, and most people would know what to expect from Mondays to Fridays. "But in Africa, you never know when something extraordinary could happen," he says. "Put simply, I don't want to sleepwalk through my life."

Having lived in countries such as Botswana, Namibia and now South Africa, and having seen countless animals, Mr Allison says he is still struck by the wildlife there. "There is nowhere in the world like Africa, when it comes to wildlife, and I have checked that," he quips.

Elephants are his favourite, as "they are very intelligent, and lead emotionally rich lives".

Among the big cats, he has a soft spot for cheetahs, "they are fast but vulnerable, and are often bullied by the other cats", he says.

He adds: "What happens in the animal kingdom is much like what happens in the boardroom or in real life."

He explains that cheetahs are runners, but when the lions, which are physically stronger, come along, the cheetahs would flee. "Just like how a local drink company may decide not to run its business any more, when a bigger and stronger competitor comes along," he says. "Often, I've clients saying that just watching the animals hunt in the wild, is much like what happens in their office, but this time, with spotted animals."

Most of Wilderness Safaris' clients are from the United States, but he hopes to attract more nationalities to the beauty of a safari. "Not only do they get to see the wildlife, but they begin to understand more about conservation, and help bring the message back home," he says.

There are still misconceptions about safaris, one of which is how people think that Africa is unsafe. "Africa has 54 countries. Often we hear only the bad stuff, but there are countries that are safe," he says.

Another misconception is that travellers don't realise the level of comfort they can have on a safari. Wilderness Safaris has over 70 properties in nine countries. "You get the traditional lodge to the most luxurious lodges," says Mr Allison. In between the fine dining meals and enjoying the surrounds of the lodges, safari trips are done about twice a day, and they can range from going around in a Land Rover, going up in a hot-air balloon or paddling in a canoe.

Sense of curiosity

Since his first book in 2008, Mr Allison has written two more: Don't Look Behind You, which has more stories of his life in Africa, and How to Walk A Puma, about his misadventures in South America. "My trip to South America was fuelled by my sense of curiosity, which is stronger than my common sense," he says with a laugh.

He plans to continue living in Africa, to help drive the conservation and eco-tourism message across. On top of drawing in tourists, Wildnerness Safaris also helps the local communities by providing them with jobs, and building schools and clinics.

With many stories to regale and his chatty nature, Mr Allison would be the ideal candidate as a host for a safari TV programme, but that is not going to happen. He reveals that he rejected an offer from a TV network. "They are more interested in the host, than in the animals, and that is not something I agree with."

SUBSCRIBERS

Oceanus still in a sea of red ink

Published

Fri, Jun 13, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

ABALONE producer Oceanus Group is not out of the soup yet.

The company posted a narrower quarterly loss yesterday, but revised its 2013 results to a significantly wider loss even as its auditor said it did not have enough evidence to give an opinion on the company.

Oceanus' fiscal first-quarter net loss from continuing operations shrank to 19.1 million yuan (S$3.8 million) from a year-ago 46.4 million yuan deficit as abalone prices fell amid frugality measures imposed by the Chinese government.

Including discontinued operations, net loss attributable to shareholders narrowed to 17.1 million yuan, or 0.47 fen per share, for the three months to March 31 compared with 45.2 million yuan a year ago.

The company also adjusted its net loss for 2013 wider to 444.7 million yuan from 265.3 million yuan after its auditor revalued assets and recognised certain losses.

Auditor Foo Kon Tan Grant Thornton also withheld its opinion on the state of affairs of the company as at Dec 31, 2013, citing the inability to obtain sufficient appropriate evidence.

Whether the company can continue as a going concern also hinges on an issue of loans and warrants, but the auditor said it could not ascertain if the company will be able to pay its debts as and when they fall due.

Oceanus said it remains in discussion with existing warrant holders and potential new investors for a funding solution to its existing loans and warrants issue, which is due in June 2015, and to finance ongoing operations.

Oceanus this year replaced the senior management of its China operations after substantial and abnormal deaths of its abalone stock. Given the weak prices of abalone, the company said it is focusing on growing its abalones rather than selling them.

The company has had three straight years of losses.

Shares of Oceanus closed at two cents yesterday, higher by 5.3 per cent, or 0.1 cent, before the announcements were made.
