site_title: Tougher terms ahead for frequent fliers
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Tougher terms ahead for frequent fliers

More airlines tag points to fares, not distance flown

Published

Thu, Jun 12, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[NEW YORK] It's a sad day for anyone who has ever known the joy of carefully hoarding frequent-flier miles.

United Airlines announced that, beginning March 1, 2015, members of the company's MileagePlus programme will earn award miles based on the price of their ticket, rather than how far they are travelling.

This means that the system will reward those who have more money to spend: travellers with corporate expense accounts, people who pay for first-class tickets and anyone else who doesn't mind paying full price for airfare, especially for last-minute flights.

For everyone else who usually flies coach or at least likes to shop around for the best ticket prices, the changes mark a further erosion in the benefits of airline frequent-flier programmes.

As part of the change, United will start awarding five points per dollar spent. Those with elite status - from premier silver to premier 1K - will get anywhere from seven to 11 points per dollar spent. The chart for how many points are needed to redeem free flights remains unchanged.

As part of the announcement earlier this week, the company has added a few new redemption choices so that consumers can use points towards, for instance, upgrading to Economy Plus seats that offer more legroom.

"These changes are designed to more directly recognise the value of our members when they fly United," Thomas O'Toole, United's senior vice-president of marketing and loyalty and president of MileagePlus, said in a statement on Tuesday.

The trouble is that for those who shop for a great bargain price for a trip to Tokyo from, let's say, Washington, you'll be rewarded as much as someone who massively overpaid for a last-minute flight to Los Angeles.

United seems to be following its competitor Delta Air Lines, which made almost the same change to its SkyMiles programme earlier this year. Smaller carriers, including JetBlue and Southwest, already have programmes that calculate points based on dollars spent rather than miles. The news from United means that among the three biggest US carriers - United, Delta and American Airlines - only American has not made the change.

It's not obvious that it will follow suit, says Brian Kelly, founder of the website ThePointsGuy.com and self-described "frequent flier mile and credit card point ninja" on Twitter.

"I think American might use this as a differentiator: 'We value customers, not just those who pay full-fare and first-class,'" said Mr Kelly, who notes that American Airlines introduced the first frequent-flier programme.

But he said that it's only a matter of time before airlines begin making it much harder for customers to redeem reward tickets by raising the number of points needed. One easy way is to make redemption requirements based on the cost of the ticket as well, so that suddenly a US$12,000 first-class flight to Asia requires many more points than it used to simply because the full fare is extraordinarily expensive.

So what should consumers do?

Mr Kelly says MileagePlus users who are unhappy about the changes could call American Airlines for what's called a "status match", where a member with elite privileges through United's programme can transfer that status to American. Another option is to rely more on credit cards to accrue points, especially those that make it easy to transfer points to multiple airlines. That way, a consumer is not tied to one airline and subject to increasingly frequent changes to its awards programmes. - WP

site_title: Father's Day guide to buying art
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Father's Day guide to buying art

Here are creative ideas for the man of the house, whether he's a connoisseur or if you think it's time he became one, writes HELMI YUSOF

Published

Thu, Jun 12, 2014 · 10:00 PM

For the deep-thinking dad

Does your dad enjoy ruminating on the big, unanswerable questions such as God, nature and existence? If that's the case, he might prefer artworks that are more abstract than representational. Filip Gudovic, a promising young abstract artist newly graduated from Lasalle College of the Arts, is showing several works at iPreciation Gallery on Cuscaden Road, and one artwork at Equator Art Projects in Gillman Barracks. As a newcomer, his prices are still low, between $2,800 and $3,200, while his canvases - such as this 210 x 160cm work titled Design of an Italian Restaurant - are large enough to peer deep into and get lost in. Incidentally, he comes highly recommended by his teacher, Cultural Medallion recipient Milenko Prvacki, whose works are showing alongside his at iPreciation.

For the hipster dad

If your dad is a bit of a rock-and-roller, you might want to check out the cool, psychedelic, street graffiti-inspired artworks of Wedhar Riyadi. Riyadi is an up-and-coming Indonesian artist who has been selected for prestigious shows such as the Asia Pacific Triennial and the Indonesian Eye. Fusing a riot of hallucinogenic colours with street art symbols such as skulls and bones, his trippy series of artworks are likely to be enjoyed by the hipster-at-heart dad who prefers a Harley to a Jag, and Bob Dylan to Beethoven. Wedhar's works are priced from $3,400 and are available at Yavuz Fine Art on 51, Waterloo Street, where he currently has a solo exhibition. Call on 6338-7900.

For (art)clueless dad

IF your father thinks the Old Masters are a bunch of ageing golfers, maybe it's a good time to enlighten him somewhat. Make the transition easy with Optical Art or Op Art, for short. The image comprises an illusion that tricks the eye and baffles the mind. The Op Art movement began in the 1960s and is popularly used in advertising today. Its famous proponents include MC Escher and Victor Vasarelly, whose works are available as posters on art.com for as little as $20. For a more contemporary take, check out Noma Bar whose elegant and minimalist Op Art works are sold on online gallery eyestorm.com. The work here, titled Look Out, is in a limited edition of 50 and retails for $1,570.

Introduce him to the real Old Masters, whose works are more accessible to the novice than contemporary art. Caravaggio, Rembrandt, Goya and da Vinci are just a few wonderful artists to check out. You'll find thousands of their gorgeous artworks on posters on art.com for a low price. Better still, make him something yourself, or with your kids, if you have any. Art jamming places such as Arteastiq and My Art Space will give you a canvas, a dozen brushes and as much paint as you want, for a set price. A painting by his kids and grandkids is bound to get any doting dad to start his own collection.

For the nostalgic dad

The images of German-born, Singapore-based shutterbug Philipp Aldrup will send a pang of wistfulness down your spine. His photo series on Capitol Theatre and Golden Mile Complex are simultaneously dramatic and poignant as they showcase two buildings that were once regarded among the most impressive in the world but which have long lost their lustre. Capitol Theatre 6 is one of his most powerful photos, as it offers a simultaneous window into the theatre's grand past, sad present and uncertain future. The photograph measures 42 by 28cm and is available in an edition of 15 from online art gallery artloft.com for US$370.

For the traditional dad

A favourite among local art collectors, Tay Bak Chiang is a gifted local Chinese ink painter who interprets nature motifs in beautiful abstract forms - as seen here in his latest work Scarlet (124 x 124cm). Tay's clean, precise and elegant lines will easily appeal to dads whose tastes in art lean towards classical Chinese works with a modern twist. Tay's paintings are priced upwards of $6,800, and are currently available at HaKaren Art Gallery, which is set to open a group exhibition later this month featuring Tay and three other Chinese ink artists. You can contact the gallery on 6733-3382 or e-mail

info@hakaren.com

with enquiries.

For the heartland dad

Did your dad grow up in an old HDB block that has since been torn down? You might wish to track down acclaimed photographer Darren Soh to ask if he has a photo of that block. For more than a decade, Soh has been scouring the island for old HDB blocks, playgrounds, schools, cinemas and other buildings that were or are scheduled for demolition. He then captures them artfully in his photographs for posterity's sake.

Some of these photographs are for sale. This one, for instance, depicts Block 20, Lorong 3 Geylang, before it was razed to the ground last year. The work measures 59 by 42cms and is available in an edition of 25 at online gallery theartling.com for US$600.

For the photographer dad

Anyone who loves photography can see why Sebastiao Salgado is regarded as one of the greatest photojournalists of all time. His varied, global interests in social, political and economic issues see him venturing into forgotten corners of the earth with his cameras. At the moment, the Brazilian shutterbug is showing 245 stunning black-and-white photographs at the National Museum of Singapore. He is also showing numerous works at Sundaram Tagore Gallery in Gillman Barracks, which are priced between US$11,000 and US$96,000. The photo featured is called Iceberg between Paulet Islands & the Shetland Islands, Antarctica, and was shot in 2005. Stunning, isn't it?

site_title: Those squads now in Brazil? They're worth a total S$6.6 billion
content:
Those squads now in Brazil? They're worth a total S$6.6 billion

736 players from 32 countries among the most costly talents the sport has seen

Lee U-Wen

Published

Thu, Jun 12, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Got just under S$6.6 billion to spare? That's the astounding amount one would need to fork out to buy the entire squad of players that are now in Brazil for the World Cup.

The 736 players from 32 countries are not only the world's best footballers, but also among the most expensive talent the sport has seen.

Based on the most recent transfer prices, they are collectively worth £3.13 billion, or about S$6.57 billion at today's exchange rates.

It's not that big of a surprise to see Brazil's 23-man team topping the chart with a combined value of £407 million, especially with the recent news of French league champion Paris Saint-Germain agreeing to pay Chelsea a whopping £50 million for defender David Luiz.

A large chunk of Brazil's total is also thanks to striker Neymar, the young Barcelona star who joined the Catalans last year for a fee believed to be worth over £71 million.

The reigning World Cup champion, Spain, is second on the list with its total of £315.2 million.

Head coach Vicente del Bosque has the luxury to call upon some of the planet's priciest players, including the likes of Chelsea's Fernando Torres (£50 million), Manchester United's Juan Mata (£37 million) and Manchester City's David Silva (£23 million).

It may surprise some to see Belgium sitting pretty in third, given that it has never won a World Cup or European Championship in its history.

Still, there are those who believe this star-studded squad, worth £222.7 million, could be the tournament's dark horse.

Marc Wilmots' side, which begins its campaign on Day 5 against Algeria, has many household names such as English Premier League stars Vincent Kompany, Eden Hazard, Romelo Lukaku and Adnan Januzaj.

As for perennial underachievers England, the squad adds up to £179.6 million, behind heavyweights Portugal, Argentina and France but just ahead of rivals Germany.

And what of the "cheapest" squad that is on show in Brazil? That would be Iran, whose 23 players are valued at a paltry £3.6 million by comparison.

This could be due to several factors, such as some players remaining with their boyhood clubs throughout their careers, moving to other teams on a free transfer, or being involved in a swap deal.

Transfer fees aside, the amount of wealth that will take to the pitch over the 64 World Cup matches is staggering, to say the least.

Earlier this week, Wealth-X - a Singapore-based ultra high net worth intelligence and prospecting firm - released its list of the ten richest players competing in the event.

Cristiano Ronaldo, who plies his trade for Portugal and Real Madrid, is king of the crop with an estimated net worth of US$230 million - nearly a quarter of the combined net worth of the entire top ten.

England has three representatives on the Wealth-X list - Wayne Rooney (US$95 million), Frank Lampard (US$60 million) and Steven Gerrard (US$55 million), while Spain has just one, Torres, who has an estimated net worth of about US$50 million.

But what of the coaches, the men responsible for leading their charges into battle at each match en route to the July 13 final?

Russia's Fabio Capello is the most well-paid of all 32 national team coaches, with the Italian drawing an annual salary of £7 million.

English coach Roy Hodgson, who is the next biggest earner, draws just half that amount, or £3.5 million. Third is Cesare Prandelli who is paid £2.57 million a year for his services to the Italian team.

Don't blame Mexico's coach Miguel Herrera if he feels a tad envious after seeing those numbers. He has the unwanted distinction of being the lowest earner at the World Cup at just £125,000. Russia's Capello, by comparison, takes less than a week to earn that very amount.

site_title: STATS ChipPAC shares dive as takeover talks end
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

STATS ChipPAC shares dive as takeover talks end

But discussions with other interested parties still going on, says company

Published

Thu, Jun 12, 2014 · 10:00 PM

SHARES of STATS ChipPAC took a hard knock yesterday on news that talks with a third party interested in taking over the loss-making semiconductor group have been discontinued.

The stock dived by as much as 14.6 per cent initially to an intra-day low of 55.5 cents before closing at 58.5 cents, still down 10 per cent from the previous day's 65 cents. Some 66.5 million shares with a traded value of $39.8 million changed hands.

In its announcement yesterday on the discontinuation of talks, STATS ChipPAC also said that discussions with other interested parties were still going on.

Despite the hit yesterday, the price of the stock was still well above the 33 to 34 cents that it traded at before takeover speculation hit the market.

"Speculators are taking positions based on whether talks were dissolved due to disagreements or just a simple expiry of the interest to buy, which would be less negative in the market's eyes as the party could still come back to the table," Kevin Foy, director of equity sales trading at brokerage Maybank Kim Eng, told The Business Times.

Roger Tan, chief executive officer of Voyage Research, said a 10 per cent fall was quite significant. He saw yesterday's movements as rationality returning to the market, which he thought had previously "took it as 100 per cent that the takeover was going to happen".

"But this was more of a rationalisation than total disappointment" given that the sell-off did not wipe out all the gains the stock had earlier garnered, he said.

Another broker saw a brighter side of the late-morning news. While talks with the interested party had been discontinued, discussions with other parties to explore a possible acquisition were still on-going.

"There's perhaps a better suitor. The old suitor's approach was perhaps not right," he said.

On the talks with other parties, STATS ChipPAC said yesterday: "There is no assurance that any such discussions will result in any definitive agreement or transaction. The company will make an appropriate announcement in the event that there are any material developments on this matter."

STATS ChipPAC began as ST Assembly Test Services in 1994. It was two thirds owned by Temasek Holdings when it merged with American firm ChipPAC in 2004 to create one of the world's largest chip testing and assembly entities.

Temasek then made a takeover bid for the firm at $1.75 a share in 2007, ending up with an 83 per cent stake. Today, it has an 84 per cent stake.

Last year, STATS ChipPAC reported a US$47.5 million net loss. Its largest segment, serving the mobile communications market, had suffered a slowdown. Consumers moved away from high-end smartphones to low-cost ones, where the company had a more limited presence.

In the first quarter ended March 30, 2014, the group reported a further US$15.8 million net loss on lower revenues of US$365.5 million.

Shares jumped in mid-May on takeover speculation, and the company announced that it had received a non-binding expression of interest from a third party keen on buying all its shares.

Early this month, it said other parties had contacted the company to explore a possible acquisition.

Yesterday, a Temasek spokesman declined to comment on the company's latest announcement.

Looking ahead, based on the stock's technicals and trading activity, Mr Foy of Maybank Kim Eng expects it to trade down to around 53 cents.

This was a level "at which, barring no additional news flow, would be a more attractive level to pick up the stock", he said.

site_title: Emirates cancels order for 70 A350 aircraft
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Emirates cancels order for 70 A350 aircraft

Loss is estimated to be a tenth of Airbus's 2014 orders

Published

Wed, Jun 11, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[TOULOUSE] Emirates airline delivered a huge blow to European aerospace group Airbus yesterday, cancelling an order for 70 new-generation A350 airliners, which analysts estimate represents about a tenth of the aircraft maker's 2014 orders.

The long-distance aircraft, due to go into service this year, is the Airbus flagship project of the moment to compete with the Boeing 787 which has been flying since 2011.

The size of the cancellation is the biggest-ever by a prestigious customer for a civil airliner. Airbus said that the cancellation followed an order placed by Emirates at the Dubai air show in November for an extra 50 A380 superjumbo planes. The cancellation decision was made following "ongoing discussions with the airline in light of their fleet requirement review", Airbus said.

The deal was said to be worth US$16.5 billion when it was announced in 2007, but Airbus said that customers were already interested in taking up the cancelled aircraft.

The sudden announcement by Emirates sent Airbus Group shares down more than 5 per cent at one point. The were showing a loss of 3.3 per cent to 52.08 euros in afternoon trading in Paris market, down 0.65 per cent overall.

And in London, aero-engine maker Rolls-Royce warned that the decision would cut the value of its order book by £2.6 billion (S$5.4 billion).

The cancellation "amounts to 11 per cent of orders which Airbus expects to take in 2014", said analyst Christophe Menard at brokers KeplerChevreux.

The airliner business accounts for the main part of activities by Airbus Group, formerly EADS, and the head of its sales division John Leahy said: "It's not good news commercially but it has no impact financially."

Opening an innovation show by Airbus at its headquarters in Toulouse, Mr Leahy, who has played a major role in the rise of Airbus over the years, said that he had time to find other customers for the cancelled planes which were due to be delivered from 2019. He had only just heard of the cancellation, he said, so the decision was not a direct counter-balance to the order placed in Dubai. "I am amazed that we already have enquiries, there is already a queue of people," Mr Leahy added.

In Dubai, Emirates also ordered 150 Boeing very-long-haul 777-8 and 777-9 airliners which are due to enter service from 2020. It also took an option on another 50 of this version.

An Emirates spokesman said: "The contract which we signed in 2007 has lapsed. We are reviewing our fleet requirements."

Airlines had been making massive aircraft orders in anticipation of a pick-up in air traffic as advanced economies recover from a slump and with emerging economies expected to deliver a boost in demand.

Airbus added that it was still very confident in the A350, with a fuselage made largely of composite materials, and noted that it had orders from 28 airlines for 742 aircraft six months ahead of the plane entering service.

"The programme of test flights for the A350 is progressing well and is on schedule for certification (by the Aviation Authorities) in the coming months," said Airbus. - AFP

Not everyone is as deserving: I was invited as a member of the Association of American Correspondents in London.

site_title: Ads following S'poreans into the Web
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Ads following S'poreans into the Web

Revenue in Internet advertising market seen growing at CAGR of 10.3%

Published

Wed, Jun 11, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Most Singaporeans are always connected to the World Wide Web either via their smartphones or through broadband. The Internet has become the first choice for consuming news, entertainment and for social connectivity.

It's little wonder then that companies are increasingly moving their advertisement spend to the Web. Singapore's Internet advertising market revenue is expected to be worth US$183 million this year. From US$162 million last year, this is going to grow to US$264 million by 2018 - that's a compound annual growth of 10.3 per cent.

For context, during this period, traditional newspaper advertising revenue will grow from US$788 million in 2013 to US$905 million in 2018. While the absolute numbers are higher, the CAGR (compound annual growth rate) is 2.8 per cent. TV advertising, meanwhile, will grow with a CAGR of 3.8 per cent, taking the 2018 total to US$456 million.

Within Internet advertising, display - that is the ads that show on webpages - is the largest segment, garnering 43 per cent share of total Web advertising revenue last year. Search, however, is growing more quickly than display: paid search Internet advertising revenue is forecast to grow at a CAGR of 9.7 per cent (compared with 6.6 per cent for display) to reach US$77 million in 2018. At 30 per cent of the total Internet advertising pie, search has the second-largest share, and large global sites dominate the market as a result of Singapore's size and ethnically diverse population.

The data comes from PwC's Global entertainment and media outlook 2014-2018. PwC's Greg Unsworth says that Singapore is an affluent market and is one of the most digitally advanced on the planet. "It possesses a very high broadband penetration (estimated at 116 per cent) and many advertising companies base their Asian regional offices in Singapore; all this helps to promote growth in Internet advertising."

Mr Unsworth, who is PwC Singapore's technology, media & telecommunications leader, however, adds that as a proportion of the total advertising spend, Singapore still lags behind many of the developed mature markets in digital advertising revenues.

The research data shows that Singaporeans are avid gamers. Total video games revenue in Singapore was US$357 million last year, up from 2009's figure of US$313 million. Revenue is forecast to grow by a CAGR of 9 per cent to reach US$550 million in 2018. "Singapore has one of the world's highest smartphone penetration rates which, combined with gamer-friendly mobile data services, has driven mobile games revenue. In 2013, mobile games revenue accounted for 42 per cent of total video games revenue. This will fall slightly to 41 per cent in 2018, at which point mobile video games revenue would have reached US$223 million."

Online gaming is increasingly popular in Singapore and online games revenue will reach US$179 million in 2018. High broadband penetration has allowed the online gaming segment to flourish, as has the free-to-play model.

Mr Unsworth notes that, at a time when newspapers elsewhere are losing money, total newspaper advertising revenue in Singapore will continue to grow steadily in the near term. "The average daily unit circulation total has been falling, the total had been buoyed in the past by free dailies but they are now also losing readers. However, increases in advertising revenue will more than compensate for the reduction in circulation."

He, however, adds that it's important for traditional media companies to understand their customers' evolving expectations in a digital world. "Increasingly, consumers are looking for content when and where they need it on multiple platforms and devices. This is driving a number of traditional media companies to develop content for digital consumers first and foremost and then enabling this to be also distributed through traditional platforms."

Traditional media companies need to ensure they are developing content that is relevant and available when and where consumers need it. "Given the sharing of data by customers online, it's also important to establish trust with consumers that data will be protected and that relevant content and services are provided in return for their willingness to share personal details. Finally, traditional media companies need to encourage innovation at all levels, experiment with new business models and ensure they are developing the right talent that understands technology and are able to respond to the needs of today's consumers."

To a question on what is the right business model for media companies online, Mr Unsworth notes that the "freemium" service for online games is a good example of one model that is proving quite successful. "Providing free access and then monetising through advertising and game upgrades is proving successful for many, particularly in China. We also expect to see development of subscription based access to books and news content continuing to evolve although unlikely to transform the industry in the short term."

SUBSCRIBERS

Home of millionaire accused of murder sets Aussie sale record

Published

Wed, Jun 11, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SYDNEY] The Sydney harbourfront mansion of millionaire Australian property developer Ron Medich, who is accused of murder, was sold for close to the A$40 million (S$47 million) asking price, setting a 2014 Australian record.

The five-bedroom home in the eastern suburb of Point Piper went to a local buyer on Tuesday night, said Bill Malouf, principal at broker LJ Hooker Corp Double Bay, who handled the sale. He declined to confirm the identity of the buyer or the exact price.

The sale of the house, with harbour views, a private jetty and a full-floor master retreat, follows another transaction a week ago for more than A$30 million in the same suburb.

Two other properties, also in the eastern suburbs, are vying to become Australia's most expensive sales, as record-low interest rates, rising share prices and demand from overseas buyers boost demand for luxury properties.

"Like everything else, there were a lot of Asian buyers interested, but it was a matter of having the necessary approvals," Mr Malouf - who jointly marketed the property with Ken Jacobs, Sydney-based managing director of Ken Jacobs Real Estate, the Australian affiliate of Christie's International Real Estate - said by telephone. "Since it ended up going to a local buyer, that wasn't needed finally."

Medich is awaiting trial after he was charged by police in October 2010 with soliciting to murder businessman Michael McGurk. The two were involved in litigation in federal court and Mr McGurk was shot on Sept 3, 2009, outside his home in the Sydney suburb of Cremorne. Medich pleaded not guilty to the murder in November 2013 and is due to stand trial on Aug 25.

Australia's most expensive home, in the Perth suburb of Mosman Park, was sold for A$57.5 million in 2009. The A$52 million sale of the nine-bedroom mansion belonging to publisher Deke Miskin and his swimsuit-designer wife Eve, set the Sydney record in May 2013.

Medich and his former wife listed the mansion in 2011, seeking A$55 million, TheAustralian newspaper said yesterday. Mr Malouf and Mr Jacobs have had the listing for the past 18 months, Mr Malouf said. - Bloomberg

site_title: Airbus pitches A380 after Emirates snub
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Airbus pitches A380 after Emirates snub

Published

Thu, Jun 12, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[TOULOUSE] A day after its biggest order cancellation ever, Airbus is back out pitching for new customers.

The planemaker was showing its Airbus A380 flagship to analysts and investors in New York yesterday, including a promotional flight over the city, with the goal of enticing US airlines that so far have shunned the world's biggest commercial jet.

Joining Airbus is Mark Lapidus, a Russian-born financier who wants to lease 20 A380s to airlines. The number of customers he has won since his pledge last year to buy the plane: zero.

Airbus suffered a blow on Wednesday when Emirates cancelled its entire order for 70 A350 wide-body aircraft valued at US$16 billion. While Emirates is also the biggest buyer of the A380, that aircraft has failed to attract a new airline customer in two years, raising pressure on both Mr Lapidus and Airbus to show their leasing model, so far unique to the A380, will pay off.

"Airbus has been trying to sell the A380 for 14 years now, with minimal success outside Emirates," said Richard Aboulafia, vice-president of the Teal Group, a Fairfax, Virginia-based advisory group. He has faulted Airbus for including the Lapidus order in its books, calling it a "speculative" deal that doesn't belong on the company's firm order book.

Yesterday's event in New York, organised by Mr Lapidus and his team at the leasing company he recently renamed Amedeo, will feature Airbus chief operating officer John Leahy as well a senior executive from Emirates to pitch the operating economics of the plane. Participants get a free 75-minute ride in an Emirates A380 above Manhattan skies.

The idea, according to Mr Lapidus, is to warm analysts and financiers to the aircraft's prospects, in a bet that once the investment community better understands the plane, airlines, too, will embrace the double-decker.

"Is this plane really something that you can lease?" said Zafar Khan, an analyst with Societe Generale in London. "The original concept for the A380 was this kind of bespoke flagship, highly customised cabins for each and every airline. They're trying now to make it all things to all men. It remains to be seen whether this works."

The A380, which typically seats about 525 people on two decks, has won orders in Europe, the Middle East, Australia and Asia, though the aircraft is absent from the fleets of carriers in the US, the world's biggest aviation market. Mr Lapidus had said his leasing plan would attract airlines that previously had shied away from the high purchase costs of the airliner.

Airbus needs to broaden the customer base of the A380 if it wants to avoid unsold slots for the aircraft as early as 2015. While the plane is popular with customers, some airlines - including Deutsche Lufthansa and Air France-KLM Group - have deferred some orders. Purchase plans of carriers including Virgin Atlantic Airways remain in limbo.

Emirates' cancellation, announced on Wednesday, revealed a preference for Boeing Co's planned 777X, for which the carrier has committed to buy at least 150. Still, the Dubai-based airline remains the biggest cheerleader for the bigger A380, with contracts for 140 of the 304 total ordered.

Amedeo's road show for the A380 remains unusual, said Jon Bogaard, a Chicago-based attorney who specialises in aircraft financing. Carriers occasionally offer investors a sneak peek at a new model after they've already committed to the deal, he said. - Bloomberg

SUBSCRIBERS

URA's landscape renewal to cover more areas

Policy extended to include residential, commercial, hotel, mixed-use projects

Published

Thu, Jun 12, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) yesterday announced enhancements to the 2009 Landscaping for Urban Spaces and High Rises (LUSH) programme, aimed at encouraging developers to plan for more green spaces in Singapore.

Termed LUSH 2.0, which includes the landscape replacement policy, it will now cover more geographic areas.

Developments in strategic areas must replace the full site area with green communal spaces - at least 40 per cent must be planting areas and the remaining 60 per cent landscaped communal areas.

Additionally, the policy has been expanded to cover all residential, commercial, hotel and mixed-use developments outside strategic areas to set a minimum greening standard island-wide.

Developments have to replace between 30 and 40 per cent of the full site area with planting areas depending on its gross plot ratio. More intensive developments will need to produce more greenery.

The policy to cover more areas is effective Sept 12 this year. Ng Lang, URA's chief executive officer, said this effort involves many partner agencies including developers and building owners working together.

UOL Group's president (property), Liam Wee Sin, said Singapore's identity as a "city in the garden" distinguishes it from other cities.

Mr Liam said one concern would be to replace less intensive development sites with 30 per cent planted area, of which two-thirds must be on the ground.

While more challenging, Mr Liam said this can be overcome with conscious effort and upfront planning.

Thus far, UOL has 10 developments under LUSH. Of these, landscaped spaces (including vertical greenery) in Parkroyal on Pickering replaces lost greenery by more than two times. For Newton Suites, the figure is 1.3 times.

Under the new initiative the bonus gross floor area (GFA) for outdoor refreshment areas on landscaped roofs in existing commercial and mixed-use developments is also extended to include new developments, areas and multiple roofs.

Mr Liam said LUSH has been broadly adopted by most developers. In the past two years, over half of new residential developments and a third of shopping malls, offices and hotels have taken up LUSH incentive schemes.

Mr Liam does not expect difficulty in convincing developers as greenery on a skyrise level is a definite benefit, and may even be a marketing tool.

"The long-term tangible and intangible benefits of having a green building will outweigh the costs," he said.

site_title: The Game Plan
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

The Game Plan

Stay calm and get through the entire World Cup tournament - even with its ungodly kick-off times of midnight, 3am and 6am - with these tips from company bosses, health experts and more, write DYLAN TAN and GEORGINE VERANO

Published

Thu, Jun 12, 2014 · 10:00 PM

IT'S that time in four years when: productivity drops; your stockbroker doesn't return your calls; co-workers behave like the walking dead and can speak only in terms of penalties, goals and who's running the office pool.

The month-long World Cup kicked off at 4am this morning, and companies are already expecting more staff to go on medical leave while CIMB trader Manoj Chamanlal says: "We'll definitely see a lot of football zombies over the next month". Not just men, either. "A lot of women are talking football these days, too, especially in my office."

But rather than rub their hands in exasperation, companies are surprisingly good-natured about potential lapses in the workplace over the next few weeks. Many of them are taking heed of Mr Chamanlal's "personal request" to employers. "If your employees look a bit tired, please turn a blind eye just for this month."

In that sense, companies are taking things in their stride. Shipload Maritime Pte Ltd's CEO and managing director, Captain Raymond Ambrose, says, "My team is quite close-knit, and I don't think the World Cup will disrupt it too much; my team is used to being disturbed at night - in their line of work, they're trained in responding and going back to sleep."

Some even embrace it as a chance to forge bonds among employees, like Cushman & Wakefield. "The core of our organisation is that it has a collaborative culture, we see this as a chance to bond and build relationships in an informal setting," says MD, Toby Dodd.

Not sure how to get through the month and stay employed at the end of it? Check out this survival guide with tips from bosses and experts to make sure you emerge from the World Cup in one piece.

Advice from the top

1 Pray for an understanding boss

It helps if the big guy you're working for is as into the World Cup as you are, especially one like Toby Dodd, MD of Cushman & Wakefield. Mr Dodd, who also participated in The Business Times-Coca-Cola World Cup Charity Drive, says World Cup fever has taken over their office; not only will they be wearing their favourite football shirts on Fridays, but weekly breakfasts and events will be organised for employees and clients to catch the 6am games - all paid for by Cushman & Wakefield.

"Hopefully this will motivate people to get into the office for some great World Cup banter!" says Mr Dodd. Raymond Ambrose, CEO and MD of Shipload Maritime Pte Ltd, is as excited about the matches as his employees, saying, "We'll probably get into the office early, since we're hooking up the monitors to the World Cup feed for the whole office.

"We may get the whole office to go out and watch in a public place, and the company will pick up the drinks tab."

Captain Ambrose is confident his younger employees will be able to cope with football and work but he's also prepared to give some leeway for some of his older managers who might not have the same stamina.

2 Adopt an investment strategy

If you're young and energetic, you can afford to be aggressive and enjoy yourself during this event, says Wong Kok Hoong, senior vice-president of Maybank Kim Eng's Sales Trading department. "However, if you're like me - already middle-aged and with a family - best to adopt a more cautious approach by using a mix of low-risk and low-beta strategies," he advises. "Take a few selective days off, change sleeping habits a little, use technology (record the games) and be selective about which games you watch - as in investing, choose a few stocks in your portfolio and watch them carefully."

Mr Dodd recommends adjusting your day to the game you intend to watch, "For the early games, get to bed earlier, and for the late games, start your day later. We all need our sleep, and it's important to be fresh and energised for the day ahead."

3 Planning is everything

Toby Koh, MD of Ademco (Far East) Private Limited, says his secret to getting work done during the World Cup season is having really good time management and planning skills. Stock up on sleep, and if you can, work from home, but be extra-efficient and rally yourself," he says.

Another good tip is to fit work in between the match schedules. "Now's a good time to make overseas conference calls in between matches, plan it well so you can still get work done. For example, I've got plans to do conference calls with America in between matches."

He also recommends taking leave in advance so non-football fans can cover your duties while you're enjoying the beautiful game.

Eat right and stay comfy

1 Eat healthy

Don't limit yourself to pizzas; FoodPanda.sg delivery service will have you supping like a king from the comfort of your own living room. Healthyoptions include sushi, salads and sandwiches from Maki-san to Golden Pillow's ginseng salted chickens.

2 Stay stimulated

You'll need all the caffeine you can handle to get through the all-nighters you'll be pulling this month (good luck putting on your shoes without a proper pick-me--up first).

The Nespresso Inissia coffee machine ($238 at Nespresso boutiques) gets you your morning cuppa in just a few minutes with a heat-up time of 25 seconds and automatic pre-programmed coffee buttons.

Otherwise try Common Man Coffee Roasters's single origin filter coffees such as Colombia Primavera (available from Common Man Coffee Roasters at $19). Filter coffee also has more caffeine than espresso-based drinks so that will get you through the day.

4 Stay calm during the matches

Soothe those jangly nerves mid-game with a rubdown at Tang Dynasty Massage and Spa (2 Chun Tin Road, tel: 6894-6466, advanced booking recommended) which will be extending its opening hours to dawn on the weekends. If that's not late enough, Spell Spa (278 Lavender Street, tel: 6396-8008) is open round-the-clock.

If you really can't keep your eyes open on a work day, head to We Need A Hero (57 Eng Hoon Street, tel: 6222-5590) for their quick fixes (Head, Neck & Shoulder massage, S$25 for 20 minutes; S$50 for 40 minutes) during your lunch break to return yourself to the world of the living.

No time for a massage? Keep a bottle of Spa Esprit's Lemon-Aid essential oil blend from Happy Oil Book ($30) handy to help combat fatigue.

5 Relax in style and comfort

Watch the game like a professional couch potato with the thickly padded Tivoli sofa, headrest and ottoman set. (Available online at www.ambientlounge.sg, at the special price of $399 during the World Cup period, usual $509). Or go with the fuss-free VIP PU Leather Bean Bag sofa and ottoman set by PiMP original bean bags. If you celebrate a little too enthusiastically when your team scores and accidentally make a mess, don't stress, the dirt wipes right off. (Available online at

www.pimpbeanbags.sg

, at the special price of $299 during the World Cup period, usual $469.)

6 Get driven

Don't take a risk with peak-hour traffic if you're sleep-deprived; hire a private driver instead with Uber (available on Google Play, Blackberry World and iTunes App Store). Unlike regular taxis, you can track the arrival of your ride through the mobile app, allowing you to wait in the comfort of your home or spend a few more minutes in the shower. Choose between high-end sedans, SUVs or limousines. Like our Facebook page (

www.facebook.com/BTLifestyle

) and get $20 free credit to try out Uber's service

Health Tips

1 Go easy on drinks

Don't go overboard with the beer. Sujyot Sakhrani, founder and Senior Nutritional Consultant of BIOTAILOR, a clinical and holistic nutrition company, says that stimulants like alcohol or nicotine tend to tire our bodies out and cause dehydration. Alcohol also affects the quality of your sleep, so you could end up worse for wear the day after.

2 Hydrate yourself

Charles Au, Verita's Naturopath and head of Research and Development, knows that football season means late nights, early mornings and poor diets. "The challenges to our body and mind during this time are, dehydration (from the heat, alcohol and singing), disrupted sleep patterns, liver and adrenal stress," he notes.

As such, he says, hydration is especiallyimportant if you like a few pints with your game." One's diet should be focused on lots of fruits of the citrus type or watermelon," Mr Au adds, "And no barbecues!"

He also suggests salads, coconut water and healthy smoothies to replenish the minerals in your body, as well as snacking on nuts through the day to keep your energy levels up. Hydration also means you'll feel less tired.

"Basically, drink fresh, eat fresh to stay fresh,"says Mr Au, "Bag a few well-chosen supplements of practitioner quality and have a great time. Moderation is key, so you can have your cake and eat it too."

Ms Sakhrani adds that one cup of coffee depletes about two cups of water from your body, so for those who rely on caffeine to get them through the day, this is especially crucial.

Take your supplements

Vitamins are key to helping your tired body pull through the tournament. You might need formulas for liver detoxification (to prevent damage caused by alcohol), Mr Au suggests oral supplements such as N-Acetyl Cysteine or Riboceine, which he says will help to regulate phase II detoxification. If your sleep cycle is being disrupted, he suggests brain formulas (nootropics) with ingredients such as 5-HTP, melatonin and activated B6 to balance brain chemistry.

Ms Sakhrani also emphasises the importance of consuming vitamins. which are depleted by stimulants. Certain supplements, such as Vitamin B complex and C have the added benefit of combating stress and tiredness. Powerful anti-oxidants such as Co-enzyme Q10 also support energy levels and good circulation.

site_title: At fever pitch worldwide
content:
At fever pitch worldwide

For the host country, fans and players, the tournament is worth every effort

Published

Wed, Jun 11, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE day that most employers were dreading is finally here. With the first of 64 World Cup matches kicking off tonight, offices across the island will, for the next 32 days, probably see scores of bleary-eyed workers trooping in each morning after pulling an all-nighter to watch their favourite teams in action.

Productivity will, in all likelihood, take a dip over the coming days until the tournament wraps up on the morning of July 14.

A recent survey by global recruitment agency eFinancialCareers found that nearly 40 per cent of football fans plan to stay up for the matches - which kick off at midnight, 3am and 6am here on most days - and then head to work that same morning.

This was based on a poll of about 140 finance professionals who visited the agency's Singapore website. A third of them said that they would either call in sick or take leave if they had to.

The World Cup is, after all, not just any other sporting tournament. It takes place only once every four years, and it's safe to say that the excitement levels for this edition - held in Brazil, football's spiritual home, for the first time since 1950 - have reached fever pitch.

But the build-up to the big day has been marred by subway strikes, construction delays and protests by groups of Brazilians blaming their government for corruption and far exceeding the original budget for the event.

President Dilma Rousseff rejected criticism of the inflated World Cup expenditure, insisting that preparations for the tournament would improve the country's infrastructure and give a much-needed boost to the economy over the long run.

"The result and final celebration are worth the effort," she said in a televised address to the nation yesterday. "Brazil overcame the main obstacles and is prepared for the Cup, on and off the field."

There are, however, concerns that the opening game between the hosts and Croatia tonight (Friday 4am, Singapore time) may not proceed smoothly, given that this will be the first time the Corinthians Arena in Sao Paolo will have a full house of 61,600 spectators.

Work on the stadium was still taking place earlier this week, with construction workers seen putting the finishing touches on electrical wiring and carpeting.

Organisers have promised that the stadium - also the site of a glittery opening ceremony that will be watched by a global television audience of over a billion people - will be ready on time, along with several other arenas that are desperately racing against the clock to be completed.

One can only hope that, at the end of the day, it will be the sport of football that takes centrestage at this year's World Cup.

Brazil, for all its problems off the pitch of late, faces immense pressure to win the tournament on its home turf.

Defeat, or even a draw, in tonight's match against Croatia would be unthinkable for the host nation, the odds-on favourites to win the famous golden trophy for a record sixth time.

Many of the other 31 countries won't go down without a fight. Defending champion Spain, Argentina, Germany, Italy, France and the Netherlands are naturally fancied to do well, while dark horses such as the likes of Mexico, Uruguay, Belgium and Portugal could spring a surprise or two along the way.

Asia's hopes, meanwhile, rest on the quartet of Iran, Australia, South Korea and Japan.

The South Koreans - semi-finalists back in 2002 - are in an unpredictable group with Belgium, Russia and Algeria, and will struggle to make it to the Round of 16.

The Samurai Blue, as Japan are known, will be confident of making the knock-out stage after being grouped with Greece, Ivory Coast and Colombia.

Iran, a team that hasn't played much of late, will probably be one of the first to fly home after the group stage. Australia, too, should depart Brazil early, given that they are the weakest team in the so-called Group of Death along with Spain, the Netherlands and Chile.

After 820 qualifying matches spread out over two years involving 207 countries, the stage is set for one of the final 32 to reap the efforts of that hard work and go on to be crowned the best footballing nation in the world.

SUBSCRIBERS

Famous Irish hotel, two others go on sale for 30m euros

Published

Wed, Jun 11, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[LONDON] The Malton, where Jacqueline Kennedy and her children vacationed in the 1960s, and two other Irish hotels were put on sale for 30 million euros (S$51 million). That's 10 million euros less than The Malton alone sold for in 2006.

The hotel, opened in 1854, is in Killarney about 290 kilometres southwest of Dublin and it's where parts of Ryan's Daughter starring Robert Mitchum was filmed. The 172-bedroom Malton is being sold together with the Metropolis Hotel in Cork and the Kilkenny Remand Hotel in the city of the same name, broker Savills plc said on Tuesday.

"This is the first portfolio of Irish hotels to be offered for sale in almost a decade," said Tom Barrett, head of Savill's hotel and leisure unit in Ireland. The hotels are profitable and "considerable interest" is expected, he added.

Irish commercial property values fell by as much as two-thirds after a real estate bubble burst in 2008. An improving economy is boosting demand for business properties, which gained the most since 2006 in the first quarter. Revenue per available room, a hotel-industry measure of occupancy and rates, rose 11 per cent to 71 euros at Irish hotels last year, according to data compiled by researcher STR Global.

The decision to sell the properties was made after domestic and overseas investors approached the current owners to ask about purchasing them, according to Savills. The owners weren't identified.

The Malton sold for about 40 million euros in 2006, according to broker CBRE Group Inc. Originally named The Railway Hotel, it was built on land acquired from Lord Kenmare on the condition that he and his family would have free rail travel and that trains would be held at the station if he was running late, according to the hotel's website.

Other guests to have stayed at The Malton include Princess Grace of Monaco, actor Charlie Chaplin and former Irish prime minister Jack Lynch. The presidential suite is named the Kennedy Suite. - Bloomberg

site_title: Nature's role in Asian culture
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Nature's role in Asian culture

Artist Lucy Davis's exhibition explores the varied ways culture and nature in South-east Asia are imagined, represented and performed, reports CHEAH UI-HOON

Published

Thu, Jun 12, 2014 · 10:00 PM

ARTIST Lucy Davis's ongoing project on wood has taken on several layers of meaning, from collecting discarded wooden objects in Little India to gathering stories about deforestation in the south Sulawesi island of Muna. The multifaceted exploration into where and how wood comes to us in its final form will be presented in a collaborative art installation - covering details as intimate as the thumbprint of a furniture restorer in Singapore to the bigger picture of deforestation in a remote Indonesian island.

It all started some five to six years ago when Davis was living in Little India, and found that "recyclers" weren't picking up the timber and wooden objects that get thrown out. They preferred metal or plastic objects, leaving everything else by the road side. "So when I started collecting them, it's not like I was depriving a karung guni man of his livelihood," she hastens to explain.

She picked up mostly domestic objects made of wood, made prints of them and these were first featured in an exhibition in 2009 at the former Post Museum on Rowell Road. In 2010, she formed a loose "umbrella" project called Migrant Ecologies, which included other collaborators' art practice-led inquiries into culture and nature. They've had several exhibitions of their works in Singapore and Edinburgh.

Davis is a visual artist and art writer, and assistant professor at the School of Art Design and Media (ADM), Nanyang Technological University Singapore. Her art practice and writing over the last five years concerns ways in which culture and nature in South-east Asia are imagined, represented and performed.

This is the third exhibition within Migrant Ecologies, and features the latest incarnations of the research process. "When you get closer to the heart, you may find cracks ..." - Stories of Wood by The Migrant Ecologies Project is an inquiry into human relationships with trees, forests and forest products in South-east Asia - explored in terms of materials, metaphors, magic, ecological resources, and history. This is a curatorial collaboration between NUS Museum and Jason Wee from Grey Projects.

A 1950s teak bed salvaged from a second-hand furniture shop is the entry point into this exhibition, and artists Davis, Kee Ya Ting and Shannon Lee Castleman traced the DNA of the bed back to the location where the trees might have come from - Muna Island.

"We even found an advertisement for the bed in The Straits Times, in 1937. Then we did cell tests on the wood and made prints of the bed - which is what I've always done for the wooden objects I've found, since 2009," explains Davis. "The migratory wood tells the story."

The imprinting of the bed is like fingerprinting the natural world and from the DNA profiling, in cooperation with Double Helix - which has devised the tracking technology to combat illegal logging - Davis and Castleman tracked the bed's wood source to Muna, south of Sulawesi. There they found an island that had its teak forests ravaged in the teak boom from the 1970s to the 90s, to the extent that it affected the water table, thus affecting water supply.

"What happened in Muna is a micro-situation of the bigger story of what's going on in South-east Asia. And that one micro-investigation of the bed brought forth different stories," relates Davis.

Castleman's photography is mostly related to the experiences in Muna, where she documented the scale of deforestation, the replanting of teak trees and the consequences of declaring logging "illegal". One of her photographic series is the Tree Wounds Portraits which documents the enormous cuts seen on the older teak trees in the conservation forest on the island.

Castleman explains: "As felling teak in 'Konservasi' forests is illegal, impoverished villagers who pass by large teak trees over a period of months will give a tree one cut with an axe after another. . . until finally the tree falls or dies and no one is to blame."

She had brought an enormous piece of black velvet to use as a backdrop for the photos, found at the edges of the conservation forest. Overall, the narrative of Migrant Ecologies' exploration isn't just to showcase the effects of uncontrolled or "illegal" logging, as their micro and macro investigations showed more complex situations.

"These complex micro-macro stories have grown from the grain of the wood," notes Davis, citing also her encounter with an Indonesian-born timber towkay in Sungei Kadut - one of the last remaining timber factories on the Island Republic. As for the project's relevance to Singapore - its entrepot economy also played a part in the South-east Asian timber trade and therefore deforestation.

Davis's exploration into wood also stemmed from the historic 1950s-60s Singapore/Malayan modern woodcut movement. "The movement then was leftist and also poetic. Ironically, woodcut artists worked with Jelutong wood, which had also been over-harvested before."

The woodcuts which provided the inspiration for this six-year project will be referenced in this exhibition for the first time. Fragments of iconic woodblock prints from the NUS Museum collection are reconstructed in the show as animated shadows.

The complexities of Davis's and other artists' findings are exemplified in the title, that somehow when you get to the heart of an issue, there are several fault lines there. In line with artistic practices, the complexities will be imprinted upon the audience, though not the solutions.

'When you get closer to the heart, you may find cracks. . .' - Stories of Wood by The Migrant Ecologies Project will be on from today until November at NUS Museum, University Cultural Centre, 50 Kent Ridge Crescent, National University of Singapore. Admission is free and opening hours are from 10am-7.30pm (Tue-Fri), 10am-6pm (Sat & Sun)

site_title: Regulatory needs impact returns of banks' China units: Barclays
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Regulatory needs impact returns of banks' China units: Barclays

Published

Thu, Jun 12, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE China subsidiaries of Hong Kong and Singapore banks are facing low returns due to strict regulatory restrictions and ongoing investment spending, said a Barclays equity research report.

Returns are generally unattractive for foreign banks in China (except for HSBC), even seven to eight years after local incorporation of the mainland banking subsidiary, owing to tough regulatory requirements (slow branch opening and financial limitations) and heavy investment spending (IT, staff and premises).

"We do not expect this to change in the near term," Barclays said yesterday.

The return on equity (ROE) of the Hong Kong and Singapore banks' subsidiaries in China averaged 5.5 per cent last year, compared with ROEs in excess of 20 per cent for the large local Chinese banks, it said.

The ROEs of the China subsidiaries of the three Singapore banks in 2013 were 1.7 per cent for OCBC, 3 per cent for DBS and 3.3 per cent for United Overseas Bank, said Barclays. Their group ROEs were much higher, between 11.5 per cent and 13.1 per cent.

Barclays listed three issues facing foreign banks: margin pressure from gradual interest-rate liberalisation; slower volume growth as onshore liquidity conditions ease; and a potential rise in credit costs.

"Foreign banks generally benefited from liquidity tightness in China last year from higher returns on interest-earning assets, but interest rates have since moderated and our China economist expects more significant monetary easing in the coming weeks," it said.

DBS Group Holdings chief executive Piyush Gupta had said last month that the bank's overall net interest margin (NIM) for Q1 2014 rose, because the bank had priced up trade loans on tighter liquidity conditions in China, as well as higher margins from new mortgage sales.

The People's Bank of China raised overnight rates to 6-7 per cent. They have since come back down to about 3 per cent, "moderating NIM increase", he said.

He expects China's liquidity to continue improving.

Barclays said the improving liquidity will put pressure on foreign banks' margins in China and may result in lower demand for cross-border financing.

Banks are also managing for slower growth amid weaker economic conditions in China, it said.

Still, banks remain committed to the banking business in China despite poor returns in the near term.

"Key opportunities in the long term include the internationalisation of the RMB, the internationalisation of Chinese companies, gradual deregulation and government initiatives (eg, the Shanghai Free Trade Zone, mutual market access), development of capital markets where the foreign banks have expertise," Barclays said.

Separately, Maybank Kim Eng said in a June 9 report that UOB's outperformance was expected to continue and that it was cautious about OCBC.

Contrary to market expectations, UOB's share price continued to outperform even after posting the weakest Q1 results among the three Singapore banks because of lingering concerns surrounding the China exposure of DBS and OCBC.

In the year to June 9, UOB's share price has risen 7.1 per cent. This compares favourably with those of DBS (-0.1 per cent) and OCBC (-4.3 per cent) and the Straits Times Index (+4.2 per cent).

The brokerage said the execution risk related to the acquisition of Hong Kong's Wing Hang Bank has made investors cautious towards OCBC.

OCBC's proposed $6.2 billion acquisition of Wing Hang Bank will give it an additional 15 outlets in China. It now has 16 in Beijing, Shanghai and Guangzhou.

OCBC's management has said that Wing Hang Bank is a long-term acquisition, so it would be some time before the market recognises the benefits of the acquisition. "Until then, we expect the overhang to remain," said Maybank Kim Eng.

As for DBS, the brokerage said that with Greater China being a key driver of the bank's prospective earnings, lingering concerns over shadow banking and the spectre of a weaker economy in China, "DBS's share price may struggle in 2H14 until there are clearer signs that short-term interest rates are on the rise".

DBS's Q1 pre-tax profit from Greater China was 35.6 per cent; it was 25.2 per cent in 2013. OCBC's Q1 pre-tax profit from Greater China was 11.9 per cent (5.8 per cent in 2013) and UOB's was 11.4 per cent (7.6 per cent in 2013).

"Despite its outperformance, UOB's relative price to book value valuation to DBS and OCBC remains modest from a historical standpoint," said Maybank Kim Eng. "We therefore think it is too early to downgrade UOB purely because of its outperformance."

Yesterday, DBS closed three cents higher at $17.06, UOB was down five cents at $22.50, and OCBC ended two cents lower at $9.77.

AirAsia debuts in India amid price war

It sets a target for its India venture to break even in just four months

Published Thu, Jun 12, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[NEW DELHI] Asia's biggest budget carrier has set a target for its India venture to break even in four months. Some of its local rivals haven't achieved that in three years.

The India venture of AirAsia Bhd started operations yesterday as airlines in the world's second-most populous nation offer base fares lower than two US cents to woo 61 million domestic fliers. Jet Airways (India) Ltd and SpiceJet Ltd have posted annual losses, while Kingfisher Airlines Ltd, saddled with US$1.4 billion of debt, has been grounded since 2012.

AirAsia's entry heightens competition in India, where over the last seven years, airlines are estimated to have lost US$22 every time a passenger has stepped on board. That's added up to a US$10 billion loss in a market where the number of domestic travellers is forecast to triple in the decade to 159 million by 2021. The challenge is how to make money while fares continue to drop even as costs increase.

site_title: Tokyo's Olympic venue plans under review
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Tokyo's Olympic venue plans under review

Rise in consumption tax, construction and labour costs not in original proposal

Published

Wed, Jun 11, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[TOKYO] Rising labour and construction costs are forcing a review of Tokyo's venue plans for the 2020 Summer Olympic Games and could lead to a scaling back of facilities, Japanese officials said yesterday.

The review will include all 10 venues that Tokyo plans to build for the sporting extravaganza that the city won the right to host last September on the strength of its financial clout and pledges to keep most competition sites close together. "There is no choice but to review the plans within the scope of our commitments to the International Olympic Committee (IOC)," Hakubun Shimomura, education and sports minister, said yesterday.

Construction and labour costs have been pushed higher around Japan by the country's expanding economy and rebuilding efforts after the March 11, 2011 earthquake and tsunami.

Questions have also been raised about the cost of maintaining the venues after the Olympics and how useful they will be to Tokyo citizens, both points that Tokyo Governor Yoichi Masuzoe raised in proposing the review on Tuesday.

The original Olympics proposal, which budgeted some 153.8 billion yen (S$1.9 billion) for venues, did not take into account the impact of the Japanese consumption tax hike that took place in April and did not predict the sharp rise in construction costs, a Tokyo government official said. "We still don't know what venues will be involved or what the scale of the revisions might be," he added. "As to whether the venues will be smaller or not, the rising costs are a worry, so the review will have to be centred on keeping the budget in check."

Following the review, a revised plan will be submitted to the IOC in February next year.

Tokyo won a decisive victory over rivals Istanbul and Madrid to become the first Asian city to host the Summer Games for the second time with its slick presentation and US$4 billion war chest. The official said that it was far too early to say whether the original budget would be sufficient but that final calculations for a number of expenses, including tests on the reclaimed land being used for several venues, still needed to be made.

The review will not include the new main stadium, which has been slammed for being too large for its site and too expensive to maintain after the Games, since it is being paid for by the national government and not Tokyo.

Plans for the stadium, which was designed by London-based architect Zaha Hadid, who designed the aquatics centre for the 2012 London Olympics, have already been scaled back due to rising costs.

Bids for work to demolish the current National Stadium, built for the 1964 Olympics, had fallen through and may lead to a slight delay in construction, said an official at the Japan Sport Council, which is in charge of the arena. "But delays will be quite minimal, not even a month or two," she added. - Reuters

But this speaks more of the lower-than-expected inflation of one per cent in Q1. Economists, in fact, believe that domestic costs will stay high for the rest of the year due to persistent wage pressures.

The 23 forecasters who responded to MAS' quarterly poll in late May had a median inflation forecast for this year of 2.2 per cent, down from 2.8 per cent in the March edition of the survey. Obama signs water projects bill to fund port deepening

Published

Wed, Jun 11, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[WASHINGTON] US President Barack Obama signed into law a US$12.3 billion water-projects plan that will pay for deepening ports for bigger ships, cutting costs for exporters.

The law is the first water infrastructure bill since 2007 and authorises 34 projects including dredging, flood control, hurricane recovery and environmental restoration. A key part of it is funding the dredging of US ports to accommodate bigger ships being built to pass through the expanded Panama Canal.

"World class infrastructure is one of the reasons America became a superpower in the first place," Mr Obama said. He urged lawmakers to follow up the water-projects legislation with action on a surface-transportation funding bill.

Lawmakers changed the way US shipping projects are funded. The bill permits ports to pay the cost of deepening harbours up front and seek federal reimbursement later.

The dredging will increase the number of US ports that can handle super freighters built by Maersk Inc and Mediterranean Shipping Co to take advantage of a US$5.2 billion expansion of the Panama Canal, scheduled for completion in 2015. - Bloomberg

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Muted response to deals by SingTel's Amobee

Analysts take wait and see attitude; SingTel's credit ratings not affected

Published

Thu, Jun 12, 2014 · 10:00 PM

SINGAPORE Telecommunications' US$359 million acquisition of digital advertising companies Adconion and Kontera through its digital advertising arm Amobee met with fairly muted market reaction after the purchase was announced on Wednesday.

Yesterday, SingTel shares traded mostly flat at $3.86. The stock opened trading unchanged at $3.86 and inched up a cent shortly after to reach the day's high of $3.87. In the early afternoon, it fell to a low of $3.84, but crept back up to close unchanged at $3.86.

Analysts The Business Times spoke to were in wait-and-see mode, saying SingTel has made a good bet, but that it is still early days - given that the management has given the currently-loss-making Amobee three to five years to become profitable and contribute to the telco's bottomline.

Meanwhile, credit rating firms Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor (S&P) both said SingTel's latest acquisitions will not affect its ratings - Aa3 by Moody's and A+/Stable/A-1 by S&P.

Both ratings, a measure of credit worthiness, reflect a high-quality company subject to very low credit risk.

Nidhi Dhruv, an assistant vice-president and analyst at Moody's, said: "From a financial perspective, the acquisitions are likely to dilute margins, a credit negative, and are also likely to require additional cash investment by SingTel. However, the acquisitions are small, equating to approximately 1.2 per cent of SingTel's total assets and 1.5 per cent of revenue for the 12 months ended December 2013."

Even if both acquisitions are fully debt funded, SingTel's pro-forma leverage for financial year (FY) 2013-2014, measured by adjusted net debt or earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortisation (Ebitda), would grow by only 1.5 to 1.6 times, added Ms Dhruv, Moody's lead analyst for SingTel.

Given the telco's healthy liquidity profile, Moody's said it believes SingTel has the flexibility to provide moderate financial support to its newly-acquired entities as well as its Group Digital L!fe unit.

But the unit, which recorded a negative Ebitda of $170 million (compared to the group's consolidated Ebitda of $5.2 billion) in FY2013-2014, is likely to continue making losses, although the impact on SingTel's overall finances will be limited, said Moody's.

S&P said SingTel's Group Digital L!fe unit will remain a drag but will not materially affect the telco's overall operating performance or rating level.

The latest acquisitions are in line with its expectation that SingTel will spend $1.5 billion on digital life acquisitions between fiscal 2015 (year ending March 31) and fiscal 2017.

In 2012, SingTel set aside $2 billion to establish its Group Digital L!fe unit in a bid to ramp up digital advertising. To date, more than a quarter of the fund has been used, said Allen Lew, the chief executive officer of the unit and chairman of Amobee, at a media briefing on Wednesday.

S&P also expects SingTel's ratio of funds from operations to debt to stay above 45 per cent in fiscal 2015. "The pace and size of SingTel's future digital life acquisitions remain an important rating factor," it concluded.

Amobee, which SingTel acquired two years ago for US$321 million, will buy Adconion, a cross-channel digital advertising firm, for US$209 million, and Kontera, a big-data advertising firm, for US$150 million, to become a one-stop digital-advertising platform.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Downside of populist campaigns in Indonesia

Published

Wed, Jun 11, 2014 · 10:00 PM

ELECTION campaigns are well known to generate more rhetoric than substance, and the contenders in Indonesia's upcoming presidential contest appear to be fully living up to this expectation. But the rampant populism on display can do more harm than good.

The strikingly similar agenda being offered to voters by the two candidates, Jakarta Governor Joko Widodo and retired general Prabowo Subianto, is a blend of nationalism and protectionism that is unapologetically business-unfriendly. For instance, they both want to limit the role of foreign investment in the economy, impose taxes on exports of resources and maintain the ban on mineral ore exports. Favouring state-sponsored infrastructure projects, both are also trying to outdo each other on how many thousand kilometres of roads and rail tracks and how many airports and seaports they plan to construct, with no mention of where the funding for all this will come from.

Some analysts suggest that much of this is just electoral rhetoric and that good sense will prevail once the new president is in office and actually starts to govern. Hopefully they are right. But there is a danger that nationalistic populism can take on a life of its own, especially when such ideas are seen to be vote-winners. Expectations can be created and vested interests can coalesce around policies that may then be difficult to reverse. Foreign investors would also feel uncomfortable by some of the overtones of the campaign, which even if not translated into policy, can be whipped up again and again.

Moreover, sentiments can spread from one sector to others. As OCBC Bank economist Wellian Wiranto has pointed out: "Even as the nationalistic measures may be focused predominantly on the resources sector, a policymaking atmosphere that might be misconstrued as being anti-foreigner could affect investment in other sectors, such as manufacturing, as well."

This is a risk that Indonesia should not be courting given that its economy is already slowing - the World Bank projects that its GDP will grow at 5.3 per cent this year, compared with an average of 5.7 per cent over the last decade. And foreign investment cannot but be part of Indonesia's growth story. The country needs not only financial inflows to cover its current account gap which is running at 3.3 per cent of GDP and but also the technological expertise in areas ranging from mining to manufacturing, to infrastructure and services.

Indonesia also needs to reassure financial markets that it is serious about attending to its fiscal problems. It has a fiscal deficit which, in the absence of action to reduce fuel subsidies, could come perilously close to the legal limit of 3 per cent of GDP this year. None of these uncomfortable facts are being aired during the campaign. Hopefully when it is all over, the reality will not match the rhetoric.
