site_title: Piaggio Aero seeks China production partner
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Piaggio Aero seeks China production partner

Smaller planemakers drawing inspiration from carmakers

Published

Tue, Jun 10, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[BEIJING] With 100 years of aviation heritage, Piaggio Aero Industries has only ever made planes in its native Italy. Now, the supplier of private aircraft for the Ferrari motor racing team is looking into a new joint venture far from home - manufacturing in China.

With the Ferrari family still owning a small stake, Piaggio Aero has talked to Chinese state companies and provincial government officials about setting up a joint venture to make planes, according to Giuliano Felten, its chief commercial officer.

If Piaggio Aero finds a partner, it will join a growing string of smaller aircraft makers who have drawn inspiration from the way global carmakers teamed up with local partners over 20 years ago, eventually turning China into the world's biggest car market.

For planemakers from Cessna to Embraer, the business jet market in Greater China offers the prospect of rampant growth. Deliveries could top 2,400 over the next 20 years, worth more than US$65 billion and eight times the current fleet, according to Canadian aircraft maker Bombardier - a fraction of the US$257 billion expected in sales in North America over the same period, but still a major growth opportunity.

"It will be easier for everybody to play in this country while having an ambassador participating in the country as opposite to importing the products from abroad," Piaggio Aero's Mr Felten told Reuters at a recent industry showcase in Shanghai.

"We are considering this very seriously," he said, declining to identify potential partners in China. There is no project on the table for now in what is "a future possibility", he said.

Drawing aircraft makers to China fits with Beijing's plans to make the country a major manufacturing base for aircraft production, from small aircraft to full-fledged commercial planes that can compete with the likes of Airbus and Boeing. Yet, while China's car manufacturing base has expanded rapidly, its own carmakers still struggle to compete with Western rivals.

In the car industry, China, unlike Brazil or India, requires foreign carmakers who want to manufacture in the country to team up with local partners, who share half the proceeds and use the joint venture production to bolster their own earnings. Foreign aircraft makers are also required to team up with a local partner to make jets in the country.

At the higher end of the small aircraft industry, some say that the smaller volumes in the business jet industry mean it makes little economic sense to construct new plants in China. Business jets cost millions of dollars to buy, or thousands of dollars to rent by the hour.

For William Schultz, responsible for developing Textron Inc's aviation business in China including the Cessna brand, it was a rational choice to team up with a well-connected partner like Caiga, China Aviation Industry Co's (Avic) general aviation company.

"In most airplane transactions today, there is always a local connection even when we are selling to entrepreneurs," Mr Schultz told Reuters at the Shanghai industry event. "It's important for us to have a partner like Caiga, which has sound relationships and can now introduce our products, our joint ventures to them."

Brazil's Embraer also agreed in 2012 to start assembling its Legacy 650 business jet at Harbin Embraer, another JV with Avic in north-east China.

The lure of the world's second-biggest economy remains beyond question for small planemakers such as Piaggio Aero.

Chief commercial officer Mr Felten remains optimistic, expecting considerable growth in the business aviation market. While a joint manufacturing venture remains a future possibility, the company in April appointed a local firm as the first authorised service centre in mainland China for its twin-engine turboprop P180 Avanti - a plane in the range used by Ferrari. - Reuters

site_title: India's economic goals give cause for cheer
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

India's economic goals give cause for cheer

Published

Tue, Jun 10, 2014 · 10:00 PM

PRIME Minister Narendra Modi has promised to kickstart India's stalled economic growth. On Monday, his government revealed its roadmap through an address to a joint session of Parliament by President Pranab Mukherjee, who said the priorities for the government would be energy, infrastructure and the creation of manufacturing jobs.

Mr Mukherjee's clear articulation of goals should give businesses and investors cause for cheer, particularly after the previous government's waffling over policy decisions. He promised tax rationalisation and acknowledged that retrospective tax laws, ironically introduced by him when he was Finance Minister in the previous government, is not a step in the right direction. He also reiterated the government's commitment to implement a GST (goods and services tax) regime to replace India's arcane tax laws. GST has hit a roadblock on account of opposition from many state governments, particularly those ruled by Mr Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP). A government panel has noted that a countrywide GST regime could add 1-2 percentage points to India's GDP. Mr Mukherjee also reiterated the government's commitment to push growth to 8 per cent and above, a rate that the country needs in order to create enough jobs for the 20 million or so new entrants into the workforce every year. Separately, Mr Modi has stated that one of his priorities would be to curb runaway government spending and lower the current account deficit.

There are signs that the economy may already be improving. In its first review of the monetary policy since the election, the Reserve Bank of India has held the Repo rate steady at 8 per cent. This should release liquidity into the system and help to boost confidence and fuel investment. The stock markets have gained around 3 per cent since the elections results were announced and, till last week, foreign institutional investors (FIIs) had pumped in about US$1.2 billion, post-elections, into the stock market. The Indian rupee has also rallied against the US dollar. Tax consultancy Ernst & Young has predicted an uptick in economic growth to 6.2 per cent this fiscal year and 8 per cent over the next three years.

While specific policies are important, if Mr Modi can correct the policy paralysis of the previous government, then that itself would boost growth. A recent government report showed that as many as 285 projects, involving investments of around US$270 billion, are held up because of a lack of necessary clearances or turf wars between different government departments. A project monitoring group has been set up under a senior civil servant to speed up clearances of these projects. Mr Modi has also set up groups to monitor implementation once projects are cleared. It remains to be seen if he can turn around India's economy the way he turned around that of Gujarat state. But as the improved investor sentiment suggests, he has made a positive beginning.

site_title: World Cup 2014 to rake in US$4.28b for Fifa: Sportcal
content:
World Cup 2014 to rake in US$4.28b for Fifa: Sportcal

Its estimate is higher than the US$3.66b earned in 2010 in South Africa

Published

Mon, Jun 9, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THIS year's World Cup in Brazil - despite being beset with a host of domestic problems ranging from street protests to delays and deaths in the construction work leading up to the tournament - is set to be a financial juggernaut for Fifa, the international governing body for football.

Sports market intelligence company, Sportcal, estimates that the 2014 World Cup will bring in commercial revenue of US$4.28 billion; that's up from the US$3.66 billion earned in the 2010 competition in South Africa and the US$2.35 billion in the 2006 event in Germany.

Sportcal's estimate is also well above the US$3.8 billion that Fifa had budgeted from television and marketing rights for the full cycle of the competition from 2011 to 2014.

Fifa's secretary general, Jerome Valcke, said last year that 60 to 65 per cent of the revenue for the present cycle - a large majority of which relates to the tournament in Brazil - would derive from broadcast rights, and 35 to 40 per cent from marketing.

Fifa's event-related revenue from 2011 to 2013 totalled US$3.23 billion, of which television broadcasting rights accounted for US$1.74 billion and all other income US$1.49 billion, with one year of the cycle to run. This compares with the overall revenue of US$3.89 billion for the previous full cycle from 2007 to 2010.

"The numbers show the continuing desire of broadcasters and sponsors to be associated with soccer's biggest festival, which in an increasingly fragmented media landscape, has the almost unique power to unite a nation in front of the television and attract mass audiences across the globe," said Sportcal deputy editors Simon Ward and Martin Ross, in their article for the latest issue of the magazine Sportcal Insight.

And in what is probably of no surprise to Singaporeans, the writers added that "broadcast rights sales will once again represent the largest share of turnover for Fifa from its showpiece tournament, as was the case four years ago".

"As one of the sport's few mass audience events, the World Cup continues to offer broadcasters not only millions of eyeballs and advertising dollars, but also prestige and, for the likes of pay-television operators BelN Sports in the Middle East and North Africa, and SingTel in Singapore, valuable subscription revenues," they said.

They noted that Fifa has enjoyed considerable success selling media rights for the 2014 World Cup, largely through concluding deals in-house with broadcasters, but also via lucrative agreements with agencies in Asia and tie-ups with broadcasting unions in Europe, Latin America and sub-Saharan Africa.

The Sportcal writers said that, based on Mr Valcke's estimates 12 months ago, media rights were set to account for between US$2.4 billion and US$2.6 billion of revenues for World Cup 2014, though additional deals have been signed since. Fifa has also inked valuable media rights deals for future tournaments in important territories.

Ticket sales are also soaring. Ahead of the final ticket sales phase, 2.6 million had already been allocated. Fifa has also revamped its sponsorship structure for the 2018 and 2022 tournaments, with the six "national supporters" to be replaced by up to 20 "regional supporters" from different territories - which Fifa expects will lift its income by as much as 30 per cent.

But what of Brazil itself, which has invested some US$11 billion - US$4 billion for new and renovated stadia and US$7 billion for related infrastructure - into hosting the World Cup?

Doubts remain over how much the country can recoup. Recent surveys of the population have shown that many believe the tournament will do more harm than good to Brazil.

Fifa, for its part, has denied that it is taking money away from Brazil in staging the tournament there.

"Fifa is not asking for any financial support from the Brazilian authorities and whatever is spent by the cities and by the government will remain within the country," Mr Valcke said. "It is in the infrastructure (and other) things which will be used by the country and will not be taken away by Fifa when we fly away from Brazil on the 14th of July, after the final."

site_title: Morgan Stanley puts Singapore stocks as region's top picks
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Morgan Stanley puts Singapore stocks as region's top picks

Published

Mon, Jun 9, 2014 · 10:00 PM

IN a region where it makes sense to behave defensively, Singapore equities are Morgan Stanley's top pick compared with those of Thailand and Indonesia, given the former's attractive valuations.

"In a rising rate environment, we believe Singapore could be a relatively safe haven (despite its higher earnings volatility), excluding its relatively vulnerable property sector," a report by Morgan Stanley Research said yesterday.

Singapore's relatively low political and policy risk, its healthy banking system and well managed cash-generating firms are among the characteristics that this market has in its favour, according to the report.

This state of affairs stands in contrast to the continued political uncertainty in Thailand and the fact that positive developments on the Indonesian macroeconomic front appear to have already been priced in by equity investors. While the Morgan Stanley report was neutral on Indonesia, Thailand was the analysts' least-preferred market.

On the Singapore front, the report noted that the country's firms are facing "severe pressure on profitability" with net income margin expected to come in at its lowest since 2000 - 7.6 per cent for 2014 based on consensus estimates.

Even so, Morgan Stanley believes that a "trend reversal" in profitability could be on the horizon, both because of the low base effect and a better growth outlook.

"Interestingly, consensus also expects Singapore's overall profitability to trough in 2014 at 7.6 per cent, and sees improvement in margins to 7.7 per cent and 8.0 per cent in 2015 and 2016, respectively," the report noted.

Within the country, Singapore Airlines is one of the firms that Morgan Stanley analysts have an "overweight" rating on. They foresee the airline group pulling in an average net income margin of 5.1 per cent for 2014-2015, above the consensus estimate of 3.3 per cent.

"Our above-consensus estimates stem from higher-than-consensus top-line assumptions," the report said.

"We believe this stems from higher-than-consensus yield growth assumptions. We expect passenger yields to improve by 3 per cent in FY2015 and 1.7 per cent in FY2016. . . . We believe the market has yet to price in potential improvement in passenger yields, and think risk is now on the upside."

Wilmar International, also rated "overweight", received some favourable attention in the report, with Morgan Stanley forecasting the former's 2014-2015 average net income margin at 3.1 per cent against the consensus estimate of 2.7 per cent.

"We think Wilmar's near-term margin outlook is soft because of oversupply in the Chinese soya bean crushing business," the report said.

"However, we forecast margins will improve gradually as industry oversupply in the China soya bean crushing business get absorbed over time. We believe Wilmar margin will normalise towards peer levels over the long term."

site_title: Asia-Pac banks' China exposure rising: Fitch
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Asia-Pac banks' China exposure rising: Fitch

A Deloitte report says China's shadow banking system has grown to record size

Published

Mon, Jun 9, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE China-related risks of Asia-Pacific banks are continuing to grow, even as the country's "shadow banking" system has grown to an unprecedented size, observed two unrelated reports released yesterday.

Rating agency Fitch Ratings noted that Asia-Pacific banks had accumulated about US$1.2 trillion of China-related exposure as at the end of last year, with Hong Kong accounting for the bulk of this - 34 per cent of system assets amounting to US$798 billion. Macau is next with 20 per cent, followed by Singapore (12 per cent) and Taiwan (7 per cent).

Concentration for larger countries is relatively low: Australia at 1.2 per cent and Japan, 0.6 per cent.

Fitch said: "Most exposure is trade-related, financing foreign companies' operations in China and Chinese entities' outbound expansion, the latter comprising predominantly state-owned enterprises or large Chinese corporates."

Financing small and medium-sized enterprises and retail activity resides with the banks, which are driven by their regional aspirations to build the most developed onshore subsidiary operations, it said. Fitch listed HSBC, Standard Chartered, Bank of East Asia, DBS and ANZ as the Asia-Pacific banks with the most developed onshore subsidiary operations.

The rating agency commented that a "hard landing" for China's economy was a low-probability - but high-impact - downside risk to banks in Hong Kong and, increasingly, across the Asia-Pacific. Fitch said it expected regulators such as the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) to take a closer look at emerging China concentrations.

Regulators are unlikely to place a cap on banks' China business but maybe behind the scenes, in particular the HKMA, are investigating and talking to the banks on their exposure, said Mark Young, Fitch head of Asia Pacific financial institutions.

Singapore-based banks have been increasing their lending to the region, in particular to China and India, said the Monetary Authority of Singapore Financial Stability Review last December. The increasing exposure to these two Asian giants should be seen in the context of their rising economic importance, though banks must manage their risks, it said.

The total volume of loans to China, comprising interbank loans, non-bank loans and trade bills, has been trending up since 2009. During this period, the composition of loans has changed significantly.

Since August 2011, trade bills overtook interbank loans to become the primary component of loans to China. As at last September, trade bills accounted for about 65 per cent of total loans from Singapore to China.

Separately, Deloitte yesterday noted that China's "shadow banking" system, made up of trust companies set up to circumvent the restrictions on formal banking, has grown to a record size despite the government's curbs on it.

Deloitte said in a near-term outlook piece on the region: "It appears that, despite government efforts to the contrary, credit in the non-bank shadow banking system continues to rise rapidly." The government has reported that, in the first quarter, trust company assets had grown 8 per cent from a year ago to 11.7 trillion yuan (S$2.34 trillion), a new high. "The average return on trust assets has declined," it said.

The trusts lend money to private enterprises, including property investors, and raise money by selling trust products to private investors, usually offering a return far higher than is available through formal banks.

"The trusts are often informally backed by banks."

The problem is that trusts have loaned money for many projects that are not expected to generate positive returns; increasingly, they could face trouble meeting their obligations and may require help from banks.

Deloitte said: "Banks, in turn, could find themselves in trouble. Thus, further growth of this shadow banking activity is worrisome.

"Although it contributes to economic growth in the short term, it creates more stress on the financial system in the longer run. It is thus not a sustainable model for future growth."

site_title: CWT carves out space in commodities bit by bit
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

CWT carves out space in commodities bit by bit

It is now a global trader of base metal concentrates

Published

Sun, Jun 8, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] As the metals sector matures in Singapore, a company here - switching from Swiss to Singapore parentage - has grown in tandem.

MRI Trading has seen its revenue grow five-fold since it was acquired by CWT Limited, known for its warehousing and logistics business, in 2011.

The acquisition, in which CWT paid US$94 million for a 73.8 per cent stake, propelled the mainboard-listed group to become a global trader of base metal concentrates - the raw materials from which metals such as copper, zinc and lead are refined.

Since then, the firm has diversified into new products such as naphtha, and earlier this year, metals such as copper and nickel.

CWT had made the acquisition after observing trading houses and banks snap up warehouses then.

"If they can buy their own warehouses, why can't we buy trading houses?" said CWT CEO Loi Pok Yen in an interview with BT.

He also saw it as one way that an Asian player could emerge as a big player in the commodity trading sector.

"Hopefully this is something more unique as well, where you are marrying the strength of a trading business with the physical reach of a logistics company."

Besides moving MRI's headquarters from Zug, Switzerland to Singapore, the group has also placed its chartering, risk management and global accounts functions here.

There was also a management change at MRI last year due to differences in management style.

Having its headquarters in Singapore "made a lot of sense", since 80-85 per cent of its non-ferrous products are sold into China, and a quarter is sourced from Asia-Pacific, said Alan Kuek, who took over as CEO of MRI Trading in May last year.

The firm now trades about 1.5 million tonnes of metal concentrates, ranking behind only Trafigura - which also has its global headquarters here - as the second largest independent trader of metal concentrates in the world. By MRI's estimates, Trafigura trades twice the amount of copper concentrates, MRI's main product, as it does.

In naphtha, a product that the group chose to start trading due to Singapore's strength as an energy hub, MRI already occupies 8-10 per cent of the three largest importing markets of Japan, South Korea and Taiwan, said Mr Kuek.

"We pick commodities where we can have significant share," he said. "Otherwise if you try to be everything to everybody, you end up being nothing to nobody. That's why we are very focused."

The group also moved into metals to tap the synergies and its existing relationships with smelters, and has generated $490 million in turnover from metals alone in the first four months of this year.

CWT recorded net profit of $35 million for the first quarter of this year on $4.5 billion in revenue, with commodity marketing contributing 38 per cent of its gross profit.

Seeing that traders today need a "bigger suite of activity" to service counterparties, MRI has also grown its structured finance team, which deals with pre-payment, project financing, and credit insurance.

The next stage of development for MRI will come from CWT's brokering division Straits Financial, which was recently granted the licence by the Monetary Authority of Singapore to conduct trading in futures contracts, allowing it to expand beyond over-the-counter derivatives.

"Now that we have access to the futures market as well, it will be a more holistic business rather than just sticking to the traditional trading house model," said Mr Loi.

This is also part of CWT's philosophy to provide "a whole suite" of solutions for its clients, all the better to beef up margins within the commodity trading business where profit margins are usually razor-thin.

But Mr Loi is not in a hurry to tie the various businesses of warehousing, commodities trading and brokerage services together for greater synergies.

"Every single division needs to be fully independent first and foremost. They must be able to stand on their own two feet," he said.

"If you chain all your businesses and force them to work with each other, you will end up with some that are uncompetitive and just relying on each other to give them the daily bread."

site_title: NWC: Staying relevant
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

NWC: Staying relevant

As a CEO and employer, what is your response to the National Wages Council's recommendations each year? How can the NWC enhance its role in today's economic climate?

Published

Sun, Jun 8, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Dhirendra Shantilal

Board Director & Head of Asia Pacific

Fircroft

AT Fircroft, we look at a number of factors to ensure our employees receive highly competitive salaries. We consider market wage rates but also take into account international pay scales, the cost of living, bonuses, performance-based pay, benefits, training and development. And as a firm in the recruitment industry, we see the NWC guidelines largely as markers that allow us to measure where our packages stand. The tripartite mechanism remains extremely useful as it ensures all the key stakeholders meet and establish realistic and mutually beneficial wage guidelines.

To remain relevant, the NWC must continue widening its focus by offering best-practice recommendations across wage brackets. Industry-specific feedback should also be included, as wage guidelines for the energy sector may differ from those in retail. Broadly the council should not look purely at wages but also issue guidelines that encompass training, bonuses and healthcare benefits that ensure the needs of workers and employers are balanced.

Brad Adams

Head of HR Research in Asia

CEB

TO compete in Asia, companies need a comprehensive talent strategy - not just fair pay policies. That is true for hourly workers and corporate talent alike. Business leaders can only maximise people investments if they apply the same level of rigour to them as they do other corporate investments. CEB research shows talent as the number one driver of sustainable corporate performance. In today's hyper-competitive global economy, corporate winners and losers are defined by companies' ability to attract, deploy, and retain the best talent, not just their ability to achieve fair pay policies.

Singapore lags behind 27 other major economies on employee willingness to put in extra effort at work and intent to stay with the company. However, these productivity and retention challenges cannot be solved by pay alone. Upward career mobility, broader management practices, and especially work-life balance, come before pay in motivating Singapore- based employees to produce more and stay longer.

Laletha Nithiyanandan

Managing Director

Talent Design Potential

FIRST of all, I think we have to see the real situation for what it is. The cost of living has gone up considerably, year on year. It's consistent with what's happening in the market. This is a real cost that employers have to pay for the services they are receiving.

Why is it that we are willing to pay more rent for our facilities but gripe about paying people slightly more? In my view, this is not about NWC and its relevance. It's about employers and business owners being more community-minded. Whilst profit is important, the needs of this group of employees cannot be overlooked. NWC is relevant as they seem to be the only voice for this group of people. An extra $60 isn't much for most of us, but it makes a big difference to the lives of people who earn less than $1,000 a month.

Lim Soon Hock

Managing Director

Plan-B Icag Pte Ltd

THE pay rise of at least $60 for workers earning below $1,000 is another step in the right direction to close the bourgeoning wage gap between high wage earners and their low wage counterparts. At $60, ie, at least a 6 per cent raise, the pay rise is more than inflation, making it also meaningful and true to the objective of the recommendation.

That said, both employees and employers must continue to improve productivity, to negate the increase in costs. Every ten $1,000 workers will cost a company at least $7,200 annually; the wage hike goes up by a factor of 10 for a 10-fold increase in headcount. For a company with 1,000 such employees, it's an additional $720,000 in the annual wage bill.

Other than productivity increases, employers can explore other cost measures to support this recommendation. One way, as has been suggested by others, is to set aside a portion of the compensation of senior management for this group of workers. Employers should also take advantage of the government's wage credit scheme. The NWC provides an objective and independent view of wage management in Singapore. It thus has a useful role to play in today's economic climate, rising above the public, private and people sectors.

Allen Ang

MD

Aldon Technologies

LIKE in the previous year, we support NWC's recommendation to give workers earning less than $1,000 a $60 increment. Against the backdrop of rising living costs, this group of workers needs special assistance. However the built-in wage hike coupled with increases in overall business costs will add more pressure to many SMEs. The only solution is to raise the productivity of this group of workers quickly. At Aldon all our workers are crossed-trained to handle precision engineering tasks involving specialised equipment and tools of different processes. All of them are earning well above the minimum wage level.

We would like the NWC to focus on its economic role in providing guidelines for a sustainable and competitive wage structure.

Chris Comer

CEO

Castlewood Group

IT is widely acknowledged that the cost of living in Singapore is on the rise, so it's necessary for the NWC to look after the needs of workers, in particular low-wage earners.

As an employer that already implements a wage structure that is reflective of our business performance, we have discovered firsthand how this approach is a sustainable way to reward productivity whilst still keeping an eye on the bottomline. This approach is implemented across a number of departments, rather than the conventional method of focusing on sales teams. Apart from providing our staff with a good basic salary, the real bonus is delivered in direct response to department performance as we find that not only does this motivate staff to deliver, it also keeps productivity and employee satisfaction high - essential to retaining talent in the tight labour market. Companies need to clearly communicate how staff can progress in their career and earn bigger salaries in order to ensure an ongoing increase in productivity and performance.

Whilst the NWC's recommendations aren't mandatory, we must remember that smaller firms are still reeling from the increase in the employers' CPF contribution for workers. So this latest wage recommendation may be tough on some right now. Personally, this is where I think the NWC needs to extend its responsibilities by supporting smaller firms and ensuring that they are taking advantage of the various Transition Support packages on offer, such as the Wage Credit Scheme.

As the labour market is expected to tighten later this year due to the revamped foreign workforce policy, perhaps the NWC should also look at ways to help support companies that rely on foreign workers as they fight to retain talent at a time when productivity is so crucial to business success.

Hugues Delcourt

Country Executive, ABN Amro Bank NV Singapore, and

CEO of ABN Amro Private Banking Asia & Middle East

WE support NWC's annual recommendations as it provides a helpful benchmark and seeks to improve people's livelihood. Given today's challenging economic climate, businesses also have to be mindful of the need to improve productivity and performance, in order to ensure the sustainability of wage increments.

The greatest and most invaluable resource is our people. We strongly believe in being a responsible employer and in investing in them, not only through monetary perks but also by providing training and development opportunities. Allowing our employees to upgrade their skills ensures that they can progress in their career, are self-sufficient and able to make valuable contributions to the business. Taking a long-term perspective and investing in our employees' development and upward mobility will support our growth and help us to remain competitive in the current challenging business environment.

Low Lee Yong

CEO and Founder

MHC Asia Group of Companies

WHAT we do not want is a situation where market forces are distorted by policy interference. Wages should be more than a cash salary. Incentives like company trips, surprise awards and individualised gifts for deserving staff help inject fun and excitement to the workplace. There are also the less tangible aspects like the workplace culture, supportive colleagues, and a fun working environment.

All these are possible areas to look into as part of a more holistic remuneration system.

Haider Rashid

Country President Singapore & Region President

South Asia

ABB

AS a global engineering company, ABB takes its responsibilities as a major employer seriously, whether it is reward and recognition, health and safety or learning and development. As part of this, we have long-standing, collaborative relationships with employee groups around the world, be it an on-site union representative, local unions or on a pan-regional basis such as with the European Works Council.

In Singapore, we support the NWC and its important efforts to bring together the different perspectives of unions, government and private-sector employers. We believe that the guidelines ensure that wage increases are consistent across industries and in line with the general health of the economy. At ABB, we strive to pay all our employees competitively as part of our attraction and retention strategies. For lower-wage earners, we collaborate with the union to ensure that salary increases are adequate against any rise in the cost of living by having a fixed dollar amount in addition to a percentage increase.

Annie Yap

Managing Director

AYP Associates Pte Ltd

THE NWC's proposed wage increase is aimed at closing the income gap between low wage workers and middle income workers as well as increasing productivity in the long run. As such, it is a welcome recommendation to help low-wage workers. Nonetheless, the effectiveness of the pay rise in ultimately benefiting the workers will be limited if the company is unable to increase their productivity and has instead to raise product prices.

In today's economic climate, NWC's role is relevant as it serves as a guide to both employers and employees on the wages to ensure Singapore remains competitive and in tandem with our economic growth. However, NWC's role is just a guide and ultimately, to be able to attract the good employees, companies have to go beyond just giving the average pay to employees.

Christophe Duchatellier

CEO

Adecco Asia

THE National Wages Council's recommendations and efforts are highly commendable in promoting and advocating equity in the workplace. It is good to note that all employees, regardless of rank and pay scale, are covered and that there is extra care given to low-wage earners.

Singapore's highly competitive marketplace - and being one of the most expensive cities in the world - impacts not just low-wage earners but middle-income earners as well. The NWC's continued engagement with business and organisations can rise to a mutual advantage for both employers and employees. Adecco offers competitive compensation packages and continually reviews its compensation schemes in line with the industry as well as the current economic climate.

Dora Hoan

Co-Chairman/Group CEO

Best World International Ltd

I AGREE with the National Wages Council's recommendation to grant wage increments subject to company performance. In addition, as espoused by NWC, companies should also focus on raising productivity in this tight labour market. The wage increment has to be in proportion to productivity gains.

I feel that the recommendations by NWC are valid. NWC has helped us overcome numerous challenges over the last few decades by offering useful recommendations to local companies. This has brought about a sustainable long-term growth that has also benefited the workers in Singapore. I believe that this will continue.

Robin C Lee

Group COO

Bok Seng Group

ONE main concern in today's society is the ever-widening gap between the rich and poor. To have a peaceful world, especially on the socio-economic front, redistribution of wealth must be aggressively promoted to ensure that the Gini index narrows to create a more equitable society. Any further widening of our wealth gap will slowly but indelibly create social difficulties which may lead to a deep rupture of the social fabric. As such, I feel that efforts must be made to assist the lower-income group by helping them to better cope with rising inflation which has made cost of living in this country unbearable.

I am supportive and appreciative of NWC's continual recommendation to guide and prompt companies to assist the lower paid workers. However, manpower costs cannot increase indefinitely and we have to have parallel improvements in efficiency and productivity; therefore it is vital that the government continues to provide support and incentives to get companies in this direction.

David Leong

Managing Director

PeopleWorldwide Consulting Pte Ltd

THE National Wages Council proposes wage adjustments according to shifting economic and labour conditions but it has no teeth. However the toothless advocate sets the tone and direction of wage adjustments. The quantum for adjustments are mostly debatable but at least it sets the direction - rise or fall or simply stay flat. Without NWC's recommendations, employers, particularly SMEs, may not be guided by macro trends in employment and wages. NWC sets a reference point for companies to peg themselves against and to adjust according to their circumstances.

NWC is still very relevant and its role should continue. NWC's formulation must be tied to the inflation rate and cost of living levels, but wage adjustments must take into account productivity improvements. Ultimately, NWC must be seen to set fair and balanced recommendations. Finding the balance is always a challenge.

Sam Yap

Group Executive Chairman and Co-Founder

Htwo Investment Holdings Pte Ltd

THE NWC's recommendations and guidelines serve as a useful benchmark for employers in considering wage adjustments for their employees. Employers however will have to consider other factors like the company's overall performance, their respective sector growth, the labour market, industry competitiveness and related issues.

As the guidelines are not compulsory or mandatory, companies have the flexibility to use them as reference in their annual wage adjustments. Some businesses may be able to implement the NWC guidelines but for others, there may be constraints.

In my mind, companies should endeavour to take steps to stay competitive and adopt productivity and innovative efforts in their work processes to drive positive outcomes and business growth. Employers will duly reward their staff accordingly and fairly.

site_title: Qingdao probe raises more questions
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Qingdao probe raises more questions

It could be an isolated problem or endemic at ports

Published

Mon, Jun 9, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[QINGDAO] Is the metal stored in a Chinese warehouse really there? Has the peanut oil shipment a bank lent money against been swapped for worthless water?

Basic questions have begun to play on the minds of traders and bankers doing business in the world's largest raw material importer, after an investigation began at Qingdao Port, a huge trading hub in the north-east, into whether more than one licence had been issued against the same material.

The duplication, which leaves someone out of pocket when they claim what they thought was theirs, may be the result of deliberate fraud by a company using the same metal to raise multiple loans.

The case of Qingdao, the world's seventh-largest port, has yet to play out and could be an isolated problem involving one or a handful of companies, rather than endemic at ports.

But for many Western traders eyeing the gargantuan growth of China's commodity demand, credit is a touchy issue that brings back memories of the 2008 financial crisis, making them especially jumpy when credit related issues arise.

Last Friday, Qingdao Port said that it had been asked by China's Public Security Authority to help with an investigation relating to aluminium and copper products under the name of a third-party cargo shipment agency on behalf of a cargo owner.

It did not say how much metal was involved, but said that it was an "immaterial proportion" of its total annual throughput, and added that none of its employees were under investigation.

Yet, in a country where oversight of commodity warehousing is generally accepted as weaker than in developed financial centres, the case is making people nervous.

Already, some copper cargoes being held at Qingdao are being shipped to warehouses outside the country that are regulated by the London Metal Exchange (LME), industry sources said, in what one trade executive called a "classic flight to quality".

A full-blown scare at Qingdao and beyond would not only affect the supply chain and price of commodities.

Raising money using copper, iron ore or soya beans as collateral for relatively cheap loans is big business in China, a ready source of credit for investors who can then pour the funds into other ventures such as property.

It is also increasingly important in China as banks become stricter in extending credit.

Commodity finance deals in China were worth as much as US$160 billion, about 31 per cent of the country's total short-term foreign exchange loans, Goldman Sachs said in March.

The immediate fallout from the investigation could make such financing in China - already under scrutiny by authorities - even harder and costlier. "Since the Qingdao case, we, as well as others in the market, have become a lot more cautious and are very selective on who we trade with," said the head of a metals unit at a Chinese state-owned trading firm. "As for us, we are now only willing to work with big trading companies, those with which we've had a long-term working relationship or companies that have solid finances. This will be the strategy for many of us until we get more clarity."

Standard Chartered said that it was reviewing metals financing to a small number of companies in China. Three sources said that the lender had suspended new metal financing to some customers in the country.

An executive in charge of commodity financing at an Australian bank said that lenders would pause to take stock of how serious the problem in China was.

"If it's concentrated around one particular firm, we can probably quarantine it in that way and get ourselves back to a level of comfort relatively quickly," he said. "If there's not already, it probably points to the fact that there needs to be a central registry of warehouse receipts."

Greater oversight of Chinese warehousing is needed to reduce the risk of future lapses, say China legal experts. - Reuters

Published Mon, Jun 9, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE Japanese economy grew much faster in the first quarter of this year than initially estimated, according to revised official data released yesterday, which showed that gross domestic product (GDP) rose at an annualised rate of 6.7 per cent in the period rather than the 5.9 per cent previously reported.

The strong growth - the fastest in more than two years - was mainly due to a surge in private capital spending which jumped by 7.6 per cent rather than the initially estimated 4.9 per cent. This, analysts said, augured well for continuing growth in the world's third-largest economy

site_title: Chance to check out Internet of Things
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Chance to check out Internet of Things

Trade show CommunicAsia is back next week with more than 2,000 vendors

Published

Sun, Jun 8, 2014 · 10:00 PM

LONG-RUNNING annual IT trade show CommunicAsia returns next week and promises attendees a preview of what the future of the Internet of Things (IoT) will look like.

To be held between June 17 and 20, CommunicAsia is one of the region's largest industry trade shows, and has historically seen many vendors unveiling new products here. The Singapore government also typically takes the stage to announce new plans or initiatives during the show.

This year, more than 2,000 vendors will pack five floors of the Marina Bay Sands exhibition hall across a combined floor space of 58,500 square metres, slightly bigger than last year's 57,600 square meters.

Some 50,000 visitors are expected at the show, a figure similar to last year's.

Victor Wong, project director for both CommunicAsia and sister show BroadcastAsia, said this year's event throws a spotlight on connectivity and mobility equipment. BroadcastAsia will be held concurrently with CommunicAsia at the Marina Bay Sands, and features professional audio and video technology.

This will run the gamut of possible services, including mobile payment, smart metering and remote sensing, he said.

The focus on mobility services has risen on the back of trends such as Bring Your Own Device (BYOD), and vendors at the show are keen to exhibit what the future of these technologies will mean for businesses, Mr Wong said.

This is why there has been a greater focus on satellite communications technology from the industry. In previous years, satellite technologies mainly covered offerings for defence agencies, but there has been growing interest in machine-to-machine (M2M) communications from the industry, said Mr Wong.

M2M technologies are closely related to the larger IoT concept that has recently come to mainstream attention. IoT refers to a network of interconnected gadgets and systems, and includes "smart" appliances such as Web-connected refrigerators and wearable smartwatches connected to mobile phones, for example.

The idea is gathering steam because more gadgets and appliances are being made to "talk" to one another as sensor prices come down. This is vastly expanding the possible applications of IT to be able to intelligently detect and offer information to users based on their lifestyles.

Research firm Frost & Sullivan forecasts that the total connected devices market will reach US$731.7 billion by 2020. Within this, spending on smart city infrastructure will contribute the largest proportion at 54 per cent, fuelled mainly by smart government and e-education projects. Connected enterprises will comprise 31 per cent, and digital home equipment the remaining 15 per cent.

Some of the new technology to be seen at the show include audio manufacturer Sennheiser's connected audio for business spaces, Panasonic's first 4K 20 inch tablet running Windows 8.1, and home medical kits for smartphones from BioSenze.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Where is liner shipping heading?

It could be an industry with mega-vessels or a monopoly

Published Tue, Jun 10, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THERE are two incompatible but widespread views on today's liner shipping industry. One is that it is a highly efficient money-making machine that is increasingly dominated by a few players, to the

detriment of cargo owners and, ultimately, consumers. The other is that, despite continual efficiency gains, unregulated competition and resulting overcapacity prevent the carriers from ever seeing sustained returns that could justify their huge investments.

The Global Shippers' Forum (GSF), of course, adheres to the first point of view. So, it is not surprising to see that the body representing cargo interests has welcomed the recent decision of the European Competition Commission to closely monitor the new giant P3 container shipping alliance for compliance with EU competition rules.

content:

Blumont rallies after crashing to May low

The stock, most actively traded, closed 43% up at 5.3 cents yesterday

Published

Mon, Jun 9, 2014 · 10:00 PM

SHARES in Blumont Group shot up 43 per cent on the back of heavy trading yesterday to become Singapore Exchange's most actively traded stock. The counter closed at 5.3 cents, up 1.6 cents, with almost 220 million shares changing hands.

Blumont, a products sterilisation company turned mining holding company, joined fellow penny counters LionGold Corp and Asiasons Capital in a revival since May 14, when all three stocks bottomed together.

Investor and stock activist Mano Sabnani, who does not hold any positions in the three, told The Business Times that there could be speculation that the investigations by the Commercial Affairs Department into trading activities involving these counters might result in actions against individuals instead of the companies as some had feared.

"If that's the case, there could be a sigh of relief. Also, there will always be bargain hunters," he said.

The three had plunged last October, wiping billions of dollars off their market capitalisations, after adding them just months before.

After the big crash, the three stocks continued to trade down. On May 14, Blumont hit a low of 2.1 cents, Asiasons 3.7 cents and LionGold, 8.2 cents.

They have all recovered since. Blumont is now up the most, by around 150 per cent from its May low. Asiasons is up 67 per cent, while LionGold is up 18 per cent.

Blumont is now trading at a 37 per cent discount to book value, Asiasons, a 60 per cent discount, and LionGold, a 57 per cent discount, Bloomberg data showed.

Mr Sabnani noted that if these companies are given a clean bill of health in terms of corporate disclosure or compliance, they might be attractive candidates for reverse takeovers.

Last Friday, Blumont announced supplementary bidder's statements to two takeover bids it is involved in: Australia-listed Merlin Diamonds and Genesis Resources.

These contained recent corporate updates. Arran Tan Gim Kang, 52, was appointed to the Blumont board as an independent director on May 30. Mr Tan is assistant general manager of SY Precast. On June 2, lead independent director Goh Boon Kok, 74, resigned from the board for personal reasons.

Some terms relating to a US$30 million loan facility from Wintercrest Advisors, a wholly owned unit of multi-strategy hedge fund Platinum Partners Value Arbitrage Fund, have also changed.

Among other things, the principal amount was reduced to US$23.5 million. US$13.5 million had already been drawn down. The maturity date was extended to March 2015. The interest rate increased from 10 to 12 per cent, while accrued interest is to be paid on the maturity date instead of on a monthly basis.

Frasers Hospitality Trust IPO could raise up to US$358m: sources

Published

Mon, Jun 9, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Thai billionaire Charoen Sirivadhanabhakdi's Singapore real estate company Frasers Centrepoint Ltd (FCL) could raise as much as US$358 million by listing a hospitality industry trust business in the Republic, two people with direct knowledge of the matter said.

The deal size is slightly below an earlier estimate for the initial public offering, made before Frasers Hospitality Trust (FHT) began pre-marketing last week. The trust comprises six serviced residences controlled by FCL and six hotels such as Singapore's InterContinental Hotel, owned by Mr Charoen's TCC group.

FCL indicated to investors the newly listed firm will have a market capitalisation of between S$1.02 billion and S$1.12 billion, one of the people told Reuters. The parent plans to sell a 30 per cent to 40 per cent stake in FHT to investors, raising up to S$448 million, both people said.

The sale could be formally launched as early as next week, they said. A formal indicative range is yet to be disclosed, but one source said FHT could offer an indicative dividend yield of 6.5 per cent to 7.5 per cent.

The listing would mark the first step in merging the property assets of Mr Charoen's business empire, comprising Singapore-listed FCL and his Bangkok-based TCC Group, after the Thai tycoon won control of the drinks-and-property conglomerate Fraser and Neave in a US$11 billion deal last year.

Banks DBS, HSBC, Morgan Stanley, Standard Chartered and United Overseas Bank are advisers on the deal. - Reuters

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Managing rising data volume

Hitachi Data Systems provides a way to extend the lifespan of hardware, reports AMIT ROY CHOUDHURY

Published

Sun, Jun 8, 2014 · 10:00 PM

WITH The Internet of Things (IoT) rapidly becoming mainstream in the Asia-Pacific, some research reports suggest that there could be as many as 766 million connected smart devices in the region by next year. This will result in a deluge of data which in turn will put pressure on companies to find new ways and resources to store and process this data. The trend is already noticeable in the region.

Ravi Rajendran, vice-president and general manager for Asean & India at Hitachi Data Systems (HDS), tells BizIT that the "daunting challenge" of Big Data is becoming a very real problem and "businesses on flat IT budgets are struggling to manage the rapid increase in data volume and complexity".

HDS provides high-end storage systems as well as software and services for data storage.

Mr Rajendran says that ultimately the goal of IT for most companies these days is two-fold; the first is to ensure the provision of optimal service to various business functions and customers. The second is for IT to shift from being a cost-centre to a revenue generator. This can be done by mining Big Data for business insights, or through the conversion of applications into revenue streams.

"These goals have changed the way companies traditionally view IT and data, and have paved the way for the creation of the business-defined IT," he says.

One spin-off from this is that CTOs (chief technology officers) and other traditional IT gatekeepers are no longer the sole decision makers for technology purchasing, Mr Rajendran notes. Technology, data and analytics have become more relevant than ever before and different business units are taking the lead in deciding what and when technologies are to be deployed within a company. Staying competitive is the name of the game.

"Take, for example, the healthcare industry. We are seeing more frontline medical professionals, such as doctors and technicians, playing a bigger role in deciding their organisation's IT roll-out and implementation. This is because they have a much more in-depth understanding of not only their patient's needs, but also the processes that they use which can impede or improve their efficiency in delivering optimal patient treatment and care."

As a company that provides storage systems, software and services, HDS has been planning for this shift to Big Data for six years, in collaboration with its parent company Hitachi, says Mr Rajendran.

"Already, across the various markets, we are seeing functionality clearly moving to the software level and that is no less true for HDS. What we have achieved with our updated product lines is a happy medium between both our hardware and software businesses, with 50 per cent of our revenue today coming from customers who understand the value of managing actionable data in a cost effective manner.

"Our recent announcements are a step forward towards cementing our technology leadership on the infrastructure layer. We have brought together the best of both worlds, in hardware and software specifically with capabilities around storage virtualisation and management in mission critical environments."

HDS presents customers with a way to better manage and extend the lifespan of existing hardware and improve their IT infrastructure and applications without buying more hardware to accommodate the explosion of data, adds Mr Rajendran.

In terms of availability, the product updates will allow the maintenance of application service levels even during technology refreshes, spikes in data flow and data migrations, ensuring that companies experience zero downtime, says HDS.

"By automating, companies can roll out new IT environments faster and optimise the performance of their IT infrastructures, lowering overall costs and freeing up resources to focus on new business initiatives. Lastly, by providing an increased level of agility through software-led virtualisation and orchestration, companies can redeploy workloads faster, leading to faster time to market, while future-proofing IT assets," Mr Rajendran adds.

He says that Asean is a growth engine for HDS, but the region itself is very diverse, with each market being at different points in their technological journey and adoption, and hence are facing their own unique challenges. "To help customers around the region, we are continuing our investment in the region, including developing markets like Vietnam and Myanmar."

A tighter integration of both engineering and business drivers is shaping the direction of HDS, pushing initiatives such as converged cloud infrastructure and deeper partnerships with Hitachi and with other key players in the market, adds Mr Rajendran.

site_title: Director interlocks and conflicts of interest
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Director interlocks and conflicts of interest

Though Singapore has a Competition Act, there are no specific provisions that prohibit interlocks among rival firms. By EUGENE KANG

Published

Sun, Jun 8, 2014 · 10:00 PM

IN my previous article, "Multiple Directorships - How many is enough?" (The Business Times, May 19, 2014), I examined the concern of time fragmentation of a director who is on too many boards. Another concern with multiple directorships which I will now explore is the creation of director interlocks between firms that generate conflicts of interest which may impede directors in the proper discharge of their duties.

Before discussing the two variants of interlocking directorships - horizontal and vertical - it is important to note that interlocks are not restricted to firms that appoint common board members.

The OECD report, Antitrust issues involving minority shareholding and interlocking directorates, suggests that the concept of interlocks should be extended to cover situations where, for example, a director of one firm is a top executive in another firm, or where the director's spouse is a director or top executive in another firm.

Horizontal interlocks

Interlocks between firms in the same industry are referred to as horizontal interlocks. From a governance perspective, directors are required to discharge their duties and responsibilities as fiduciaries of their firms.

However, an interlock between rival firms can create serious conflicts of interest if it prevents an interlocking director from exercising his objective judgement and discharging his fiduciary duties to both firms.

In certain jurisdictions, horizontal interlocks attract anti-trust scrutiny. For instance, the Clayton Antitrust Act in the US currently prohibits, with certain exceptions, one person from serving as a director of two rival firms.

While Singapore has a similar Competition Act, there are no specific provisions here that prohibit interlocks among rival firms.

This overlapping of business interests led to the resignation of Eric Schmidt, then CEO of Google, from Apple's board in 2009.

The Wall Street Journal reported that both firms faced regulatory scrutiny over their interlock due to anti-trust concerns.

Steve Jobs, then CEO of Apple, also commented that "Eric's effectiveness as an Apple board member will be significantly diminished, since he will have to excuse himself from even larger portions of our meetings due to potential conflicts of interest."

Quite apart from anti-competition concerns, conflicts of interest led two directors of SGX-listed Jurong Cement Ltd to resign from its board in 2009 because they were also employees of YTL Corporation, a competitor of Jurong Cement.

According to the company's announcement, the rationale for the resignation was to address potential conflicts of interest when the board discussed "competitive sensitive information in the presence of the directors representing a direct competitor".

Vertical interlocks

Vertical interlocks are formed between firms in a buyer-seller relationship.

A director that represents a buyer owes a duty to secure the lowest possible price from the seller. Conversely, a director that represents a seller owes a duty to secure the highest possible price from the buyer. When the same director represents both firms, it is easy to see how a conflict of interest arises.

The key issue in interlocks, whether vertical or horizontal is, therefore, that conflicts of interest can arise, and regulators and boards tend to have rules and policies focused on such situations.

Conflicts of interest

Transactions between firms connected by vertical or horizontal interlocks can potentially be classified as interested party transactions (IPTs) under the SGX Listing Rules.

IPTs extend to transactions between a listed firm and its directors, CEO, controlling shareholders, or an associate of the aforementioned persons.

In particular, Listing Rules 905 and 906 require material IPTs to be disclosed to, or even approved by, shareholders.

In 2011, the SGX reprimanded KXD Digital Entertainment Ltd for failing to announce and seek approval for sales by it to LG North America Inc.

Both firms were vertically interlocked as the chairman and CEO of KXD and the CEO of LG were spouses. The SGX noted that not only were Listing Rules 905 and 906 breached, the sales also resulted in substantial bad debts that had a material adverse impact on KXD, and which were detrimental to its minority shareholders.

This illustrates a key concern with interlocks. In some cases, the interlock can facilitate the expropriation of shareholder wealth from one company through inter-firm transactions on terms that favour the interested person.

Whether an interlock is horizontal or vertical, Section 156(1) of the Companies Act applies to require every director of a firm who is, in any way, interested in a transaction or proposed transaction with the firm to declare the nature of his interest.

While the disclosure of the conflict is the responsibility of the director concerned, it is the responsibility of the entire board to safeguard the interests of the firm and its shareholders by ensuring that any conflicts that arise are adequately and effectively addressed and that the firm complies with all relevant Listing Rules and regulations.

The author is a member of the Advocacy & Research Committee of the Singapore Institute of Directors.

site_title: Demand for Spanish shopping malls starts picking up
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Demand for Spanish shopping malls starts picking up

Purchases of large-scale complexes may reach 1.5b euros this year

Published

Mon, Jun 9, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[MADRID] After a six-year slump, demand for Spanish shopping malls is showing signs of picking up as buyers bet that more and more consumers will return.

Purchases of large-scale retail complexes may reach as much as 1.5 billion euros (S$2.6 billion) this year as investors like Orion Capital Managers LP and Intu Properties plc anticipate a recovery in consumer lending, said Gema de la Fuente, an analyst at real estate agent Savills in Madrid. That's at least 10 times more than in 2012.

Growth in Europe's fifth-largest economy is gaining momentum, kindling consumer demand by creating jobs and allowing the government to ease the toughest austerity measures in more than three decades.

Spanish borrowing costs have dropped, with yields on 10-year government bonds last week hitting their lowest since Bloomberg began compiling the data in 1993.

"The value of retail property is heating up," said Andres Escarpenter, real estate broker JLL's chief executive officer for Spain, who estimates the price of stores in the swankiest districts of Spanish cities jumped as much as 15 per cent over the past year. "Investors are also starting to factor into the pricing a recovery in consumption."

Banks are getting ready to finance the upturn in consumer demand as the cost of covering their bad loans begins to abate.

Banco Santander SA, Spain's biggest, last October bought a controlling stake in the finance unit of El Corte Ingles, the largest retailer, while Banco Popular Espanol SA is seeking to buy Citigroup's Spanish business, partly to tap its expertise in credit cards.

CaixaBank SA and Bankia SA, the third- and fourth-biggest banks, say they are already starting to ramp up consumer lending. FinConsum, the consumer-credit arm of Barcelona-based CaixaBank, boosted lending by 40 per cent last year.

The recovery in consumer demand is still far from clear-cut with the data for retail sales still ambiguous, said Israel Casanova, managing director for Spain and Portugal of Redevco, an Amsterdam-based property management company that specialises in retail premises.

Sales rose an annual 0.1 per cent in April, down from growth of 0.4 per cent in March, and they shrank 0.3 per cent in February, according to statistics office INE.

National Association of Financial Credit Establishments chairman Oscar Cremer said in March that sustained recovery in credit probably wouldn't come until about 2017, when the economic recovery has created more jobs and given fresh impetus to the housing market.

"It's still far too early to say if the recovery is really solid but there does seem to be confidence," Mr Casanova added.

Household spending overall grew 0.4 per cent in the first quarter from the previous three months, helping economic growth in the period to accelerate to 0.4 per cent from 0.2 per cent in the final quarter of 2013, INE said in May 29. Lending for consumption fell an annual 1.8 per cent in April, the smallest decline since January 2009, according to the European Central Bank (ECB).

Spanish consumers were hammered as unemployment reached 27 per cent, driving retail sales down for 38 consecutive months through September last year, according to INE.

The process drained 47 billion euros of loans from the Spanish economy as consumer lending slumped 44 per cent from mid-2008, according to the ECB.

The deals getting done in Spain's retail property market anticipate a renewed demand from shoppers, Mr Casanova said.

A fund managed by Orion paid 144.5 million euros in October last year to buy the 50 per cent stake it didn't already own in Puerto Venecia, a 890,000 square-foot retail park in Zaragoza, Spain, from British Land Co. The deal added to Orion's purchase in 2009 of Plenilunio, a mall in Madrid where the company has a waiting list of retailers looking for space and may be able to raise rents in the future, said Aref Lahham, a founding partner at London-based Orion.

"We basically thought that it was good to own dominant shopping centres which are very resilient in the downturn," he said. "Dominant malls go from strength to strength as secondary malls die and you can capture their market share."

Intu, the UK's biggest shopping-mall owner, teamed up with Canada Pension Plan Investment Board to buy Parque Principado, an 800,000 square-foot mall in Asturias last October.

"What we're seeing now is people that were previously invested in other sectors such as offices or warehouses are now looking at retail space - especially if it's premium," said Angeles Perez, director of high street retail at JLL in Madrid.

"There's a clear trend for investors repositioning themselves for a recovery in consumption." - Bloomberg

site_title: Tech firms muscling in on aerospace action
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Tech firms muscling in on aerospace action

Work with Google and SpaceX, says Airbus CEO

Published

Mon, Jun 9, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[CAEN, France] The aerospace industry must embrace competition from technology companies such as Google and SpaceX which are already having a revolutionary impact on the sector, the head of the Airbus Group told AFP in an interview.

Describing the scale and speed of innovation in Silicon Valley as both "frightening and fascinating", Tom Enders said that the increasing digitalisation of the economy was having a profound impact on his company's business.

"I think that in the future, our industry will have to work much more closely with these new high-tech companies . . . if only because these guys are increasingly intruding on our territory," said Mr Enders, 55, who is half-way through a four-year mandate as CEO of the European aerospace giant.

Mr Enders cited SpaceX, the space transport company founded by former PayPal entrepreneur Elon Musk, whose Falcon launch vehicles are taking on the market-leading Airbus-built Ariane in the commercial satellite launch market.

SpaceX has also mounted a legal challenge to the monopoly held by Boeing and Lockheed Martin for the launch of US government satellites.

Google in April acquired the drone start-up Titan Aerospace which aims to compete with Airbus in making high-altitude unmanned planes that are meant to take on tasks traditionally done by more expensive satellites.

"Aerospace is still a rather young industry but these people are even younger," he said. "And I think there is no debate as to which of us is the more vibrant industry. They are."

"The speed of decision and risk taking and all that is amazing," said Mr Enders, speaking while in Normandy for events to mark the 70th anniversary of the D-Day landings.

A 25-year veteran of the European defence and aerospace industry, Mr Enders also complained that the European Union was stifling innovation and warned that it must cut red tape.

"It should make us think as we look at the software industry, when you look at the IT industry at the Microsofts, Amazons, Facebooks, SpaceXs, Yahoos. It is all coming from the US."

Mr Enders said that many successful entrepreneurs in the United States were "bright young Frenchmen and bright young Germans" who had been forced to leave Europe to seek venture capital and a dynamic entrepreneurial environment.

Mr Enders was appointed CEO of European aerospace giant EADS in June 2012 and immediately attempted a merger with Britain's BAE systems, a deal that would have seen the group replace Boeing as the world's biggest aerospace and defence company.

After the deal was blocked by Germany, Mr Enders initiated an overhaul of the group's structure which reduced political influence.

He rebranded EADS into Airbus Group, reoganising the company into three divisions by merging the defence and space businesses. He has since led a push to expand the group's business outside its home base in Europe, notably in Asia, the United States and the Middle East.

Airbus decided in 2005 to set up a joint venture in China to assemble the medium-range A320 passenger jet, and the company plans to open an assembly line in 2015 in the southern US state of Alabama.

Mr Enders said that Airbus considered the project in the Chinese city of Tianjin a success, and that it was vital that the company develop a local identity as it expanded into foreign markets.

He said that Airbus had allayed reservations from Chinese airlines about taking a China-made plane. "We have demonstrated that they are just as good, some people say even better, as those assembled in Europe."

The Airbus Group would continue to embed itself abroad through new assembly lines, engineering centres and supply partnerships. "We clearly have beachheads that I hope we will be able to expand." - AFP

site_title: Global private wealth in 2013 up 14.6%
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Global private wealth in 2013 up 14.6%

Strong equity-market rebound drives growth in nearly all countries: report

Published

Mon, Jun 9, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Driven mainly by equity markets and the creation of new wealth in rapidly developing economies (RDEs), global private financial wealth grew 14.6 per cent last year - up from 8.7 per cent in 2012 - to reach US$152 trillion.

The Boston Consulting Group's 2014 report on the global wealth management industry released early today said that in nearly all countries, the growth of private wealth was "driven by the strong rebound in equity markets that began in the second half of 2012".

This, as all major stock indexes, namely the S&P 500, the Nikkei 225 and the Euro Stoxx 50, rose in 2013, spurred by relative economic stability in Europe and the United States.

A further contributing factor were signs of recovery in European countries including Spain and Ireland.

The report added that globally, the growth of private wealth was fuelled primarily by returns on existing assets.

It said asset allocation "shifted significantly" towards a higher share of equities as the amount of wealth held in equities grew by 28 per cent, with increases in bonds (4.1 per cent) and cash and deposits (8.8 per cent).

The Asia-Pacific (excluding Japan) continued the high growth trend in the new world and is projected to be the second wealthiest in 2014 and the wealthiest region in 2018.

As it stands, the Asia-Pacific (excluding Japan) region is trailing behind Western Europe (US$37.9 trillion) and North America (US$50.3 trillion).

In 2008, Asia-Pacific had 50 per cent less private wealth than North America, but it has now closed the gap by half.

The report said globally the amount of wealth held privately rose by US$19.3 trillion last year, nearly double the increase of US$10.7 trillion in 2012.

Over the next five years, global private wealth is projected to post a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 5.4 per cent to hit an estimated US$198.2 trillion by end-2018.

In line with the current trend, the Asia-Pacific region and its new wealth are expected to make up about half the total growth, with the possibility of overtaking North America as the largest wealth market in 2018 at a projected US$61 trillion.

Continued strong GDP growth and high savings rates in RDEs will be key drivers of the growth in global wealth, the report said.

Not surprisingly, more millionaires also emerged last year, with the total number of millionaire households (in US dollar terms) reaching 16.3 million in 2013, up from 13.7 million a year earlier.

The US had the highest number of millionaire households (7.1 million), as well as the highest number of new millionaires (1.1 million).

China's robust wealth creation helped it overtake Japan to the second spot in 2013.

Wealth held by all segments above US$1 million is expected to grow by at least 7.7 per cent per year through 2018, as opposed to the average of 3.7 per cent per year in segments below US$1 million.

Meanwhile, offshore wealth is projected to grow at a 6.8 per cent CAGR to reach US$12.4 trillion by end-2018.

In 2013, Switzerland remained the leading offshore booking centre with US$2.3 trillion in assets, representing 26 per cent of global offshore assets.

But the report noted that its status is being challenged by Singapore and Hong Kong, which now account for 16 per cent of global offshore assets.

Assets booked in Singapore and Hong Kong are predicted to grow at CAGRs of 10.2 per cent and 11.3 per cent, respectively, through 2018.

content:
Wine start-up savours $1m funding

E-commerce and subscription outfit The French Cellar now valued at $5m

Published

Sun, Jun 8, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] A Singapore start-up looking to disrupt the way that Asian wine lovers purchase and appreciate wine has raised some $1 million in Series A funding, and is now valued at $5 million just eight months after its launch, its chief executive officer Vincent Morello told The Business Times.

The French Cellar, the first wine subscription e-commerce platform in Asia, lets users discover exclusive French wines that are not sold in the region and personally handpicked by resident sommelier Nicolas Rebut, a former chef sommelier at two 3-starred Michelin restaurants: Louis XV (Monaco) and Le Meurice (Paris). Upon subscription, members receive two different wines - along with wine tasting notes - monthly, and they can also re-order their favourite bottles whenever they wish to, at a discounted price.

This latest round of funding comes from ESW Manage, a Singapore-headquartered private equity firm. Post-money, ESW will own a 20 per cent stake in The French Cellar; its founder and chairman Wong Yat Foo will also join the start-up as a director.

This comes shortly after Jackie Lee, managing partner at Kyosei Ventures, joined The French Cellar as chairman in March.

"Our immediate plans are to increase the adoption of wine subscription as the preferred way to consume wine in Singapore, as well as expand into Malaysia, Indonesia, China and Japan through joint ventures or greenfield projects," said Dr Morello.

Demand for curated wine subscription and guided wine discovery is growing in Asia, he added.

"For one thing, wine lovers find it a challenge to choose their French wines because of the sheer volume of available choices. In France, there are currently over 300 appellations, and 115,000 winemakers producing more than seven billion bottles of wine yearly. This diversity is both an attraction and a problem."

Moreover, mass affluents - the fastest growing segment in Asia - increasingly desire to learn more about their purchases as much as they desire high-quality goods. The French Cellar's wine discovery model - with tasting notes - allows this, said Dr Morello.

Building a community of wine lovers is also something the start-up takes pride in. It holds at least one wine tasting session monthly, for members to discover new wines and network.

"We believe this is a happier and cooler way to run the business, rather than just a cold e-commerce website. When we flew Mr Rebut down for a recent wine tasting session to meet with our members, the response was electrifying," gushed Dr Morello.

The French Cellar currently boasts "hundreds of subscribers", and has clocked over $250,000 in revenue since October 2013. It most recently emerged as one of Asia's Top 50 Start-ups at Echelon 2014 - the largest tech start-up conference in Asia - and will be exhibiting at the event later this week.
