site_title: Directors' purchases drop but sales rise
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Directors' purchases drop but sales rise

Menawhile, companies' buybacks are up with several significant corporate shareholder trades

Published

Sun, Jun 8, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE buying fell for the first time in the past three weeks while the selling among directors rose based on filings on the Singapore Exchange in the first week of June. A total of 14 companies recorded 24 purchases worth $3.8 million versus eight firms with 14 disposals worth $1.9 million. The buy figures were down from the previous week's 16 companies, 29 purchases, and $4.65 million.

The sales, on the other hand, were up from the previous week's four firms, nine disposals, and $1.47 million.

While the buying by directors fell last week, the buyback activity rose with nine companies that posted 23 repurchases worth $12.6 million. The number of firms and value were up from the previous week's seven companies and $8.6 million. The number of transactions, on the other hand, was not far off from the previous week's 25 repurchases.

There were several significant corporate shareholder trades last week. BreadTalk Group resumed buying back at higher than its previous acquisition prices.

On the directors' side, there were rare insider buys in CH Offshore Limited and OUE Commercial Reit and sales in Nobel Design Holdings and Sarine Technologies. On the substantial shareholders' front, there were purchases in GK Goh Holdings and Asiatravel.com Holdings and a sale in Frencken Group.

BreadTalk Group

Baked goods retailer BreadTalk Group resumed buying back at higher than its previous acquisition prices with 100,000 shares purchased on June 3 at $1.32 each. Although the company resumed buying back at a higher price, the acquisition was made after the stock fell by 11 per cent from $1.49 on May 6.

The group previously acquired 183,000 shares from Jan 7 to 8 at 89 cents each.

Prior to the buybacks this year, the company acquired 200,000 shares on May 15, 2012 at 48.3 cents each and 2.56 million shares from March 2009 to October 2011 at 28.5 cents to 59.5 cents each or an average of 43 cents each.

Investors should note that the stock rose by an average of 32 per cent six months after the group bought back shares based on 19 filings since 2009. The stock recorded a price gain six months after on 84 per cent of those filings. The counter closed at $1.385 on Friday.

CH Offshore

Non-executive director Peh Kwee Chim recorded his first on-market trade in vessel operator for the offshore oil and gas industry CH Offshore Ltd since December 2010 with 356,000 shares purchased on June 6 at 43 cents each.

The trade increased his deemed holdings to 171.913 million shares or 24.38 per cent of the issued capital (the purchase increased Chuan Hup Holdings Limited direct holdings to 167.553 million shares or 23.76 per cent). Mr Peh also has direct interest of 43.922 million shares or 6.23 per cent.

The acquisition was made on the back of the 19 per cent drop in the share price since October 2012 from 53 cents. Despite the fall in the share price, the counter is still up since August 2011 from 33 cents.

The director previously acquired 2.048 million shares from November to December 2010 at an average of 46.9 cents each. Mr Peh was appointed to the board in June 2010.

Also positive this quarter is non-executive director John Cheak Boon Heng with 200,000 shares purchased on May 5 at 42 cents each, which boosted his direct stake by 7 per cent to 3.158 million shares or 0.45 per cent. He previously acquired 119,000 shares in November 2013 at an average of 41.8 cents each and 369,000 shares from May to June 2011 at an average of 44.5 cents each.

Prior to the purchases since 2011, the director acquired 100,000 shares in November 2010 at an average of 46.5 cents each and 690,000 shares from December 2003 to January 2009 at 54 cents to 23 cents each or an average of 37.7 cents each. The counter closed at 45 cents on Friday.

OUE Commercial Reit

Independent director Loh Lian Huat recorded his first on-market trade in real estate investment trust OUE Commercial Reit since the unit trust was listed in January with an initial 100,000 units (direct) purchased on June 5 at 80 cents each. The units bought represented 0.01 per cent of the issued capital.

He also has deemed interest of 150,000 units or 0.017 per cent. The director's purchase price was on par with the IPO price of 80 cents.

Also positive this quarter is Wealthy Fountain Holdings Inc with 14 million units purchased from May 6 to 14 at 79.5 cents each, which increased its direct holdings to 139.200 million units or 16.05 per cent.

The group became a substantial shareholder on Jan 27 after it acquired an initial 125.000 million units or 14.04 per cent in the IPO. The unit trust closed at 79.5 cents on Friday.

Nobel Design Holdings

Independent and non-executive director Heng Chye Yam recorded his first on-market trade in interior design and residential furnishings supplier Nobel Design Holdings since December 2013 with 1,000 shares sold on June 4 at 47 cents each. The trade reduced his direct holdings to 231,000 shares or 0.12 per cent.

The sale was made on the back of the 18 per cent drop in the share price since April from 57 cents. The disposal was made at a profit based on the 46,000 shares that he acquired via exercise of options on May 12 at 21 cents each.

The director previously sold 1,000 shares in December 2013 at 58 cents each and 75,000 shares from July 2011 to September 2012, some of which were options-related sales, at 30 cents to 46 cents each or an average of 39.3 cents each. Mr. Heng was appointed to the board in April 2005. The counter closed at 46 cents on Friday.

Sarine Technologies

Independent director Valerie Ong Choo Lin recorded her first on-market trade in diamond grading and gemstone production tools developer and manufacturer Sarine Technologies since the stock was listed in April 2005 with 25,000 shares sold on May 30 at $2.70 each. The trade reduced her deemed holdings to 600,000 shares or 0.17 per cent.

The sale was made on the back of the 89 per cent rise in the share price since September 2013 from $1.43. The counter is also sharply up since December 2011 from 58 cents.

Also negative last month was chairman Daniel Benjamin Glinert with 225,000 shares sold on May 15 at $2.56 each, which lowered his deemed stake to 54.051 million shares or 15.53 per cent. He previously sold 403,000 shares from August to October 2013 at an average of $1.79 each.

Those sales were made at a profit based on the 375,000 shares that he acquired via options in August 2013 at 40 cents each and 23,000 shares in the open-market in January 2013 at $1.06 each.

Investors should note that FIL Ltd reported a disposal-related filing on April 15 of 1.39 million shares at $2.61 each, which reduced its deemed holdings to 23.321 million shares or 6.74 per cent. The group previously acquired a net 620,000 shares from Jan 8 to March 10 at $1.90 to $2.27 each.

Prior to the notices this year, the group reported a purchase-related filing in September 2013 of 2.27 million shares at $1.50 each and an initial filing (for the second time since March 2012) in June 2013 of 963,000 shares at $1.32 each, which raised its interest to 5.17 per cent. The stock closed at $2.63 on Friday.

GK Goh Holdings

GKG Investment Holdings Pte Ltd recorded its first on-market trades in brokerage services provider GK Goh Holdings since October 2013 with 167,000 shares purchased from June 3 to 5 at an average of 85.7 cents each.

The trades, which accounted for 84 per cent of the stock's trading volume, increased its direct holdings to 182.546 million shares or 57.75 per cent.

The purchases were made on the back of the 9 per cent rebound in the share price since November 2013 from 78.5 cents.

The group previously acquired 767,000 shares in October 2013 at an average of 85.7 cents each and 1.76 million shares from June to November 2011 at an average of 64.8 cents each.

Prior to the purchases since 2011, the shareholder bought 1.04 million shares from March to December 2010 at an average of 58 cents each, 2.74 million shares from March to December 2009 at an average of 44.5 cents each and 5.76 million shares from March 2007 to September 2008 at an average of $1.02 each.

Overall, GKG Investment's stake is up by 11 per cent since March 2007. The counter closed at 86 cents on Friday.

Asiatravel.com Holdings

Pemberton Asian Opportunities Fund became a substantial shareholder of on-line lodging and flight reservation services provider Asiatravel.com Holdings on May 30 following the purchase of 250,000 shares at 30 cents each. The trade increased its direct holdings to 14.250 million shares or 5.04 per cent.

The initial filing was made on the back of the 81 per cent rebound in the share price since July 2013 from 16.6 cents. Despite the rebound in the share price, the counter is still down since January 2010 from 81.5 cents.

Also positive this year is shareholder Ong Nai Pew with a purchase-related filing on March 17 of 1.017 million shares at 20.6 cents each, which boosted his deemed stake to 17.974 million shares or 6.36 per cent.

He previously reported an initial filing (for the second time since Oct 7, 2013) on Oct 29, 2013 of 300,000 shares at 21 cents each, which raised his interest to 5.0 per cent.

Overall, Mr Ong's stake is up by 27 per cent since that initial filing in October 2013. The counter closed at 38 cents on Friday.

Frencken Group

CIM Investment Management Ltd ceased to be a substantial shareholder of high-technology capital and consumer equipment services provider Frencken Group on May 30 following the sale of 500,000 shares at 39 cents each. The trade reduced its deemed holdings to 19.826 million shares or 4.91 per cent.

The filing was made on the back of the 15 per cent rebound in the share price since May from 34 cents.

The group previously reported a disposal-related filing on March 21 of 2 million shares at 34 cents each and a disposal-related filing on Feb 19 of 360,000 shares at 33.5 cents each.

Overall, CIM Investment's stake is down by 29 per cent since February.

Prior to those sales, the group reported a purchase-related filing in August 2013 of 188,200 shares at 21.9 cents each, a purchase-related filing in July 2011 of 110,000 shares at an estimated price of 30.5 cents each and acquired 5.53 million shares in June 2011 at an estimated price of 32 cents each.

CIM Investment became a substantial shareholder in May 2011 following the purchase of 500,000 shares at 30 cents each, which raised its interest to 5.03 per cent. The counter closed at 37 cents on Friday.

site_title: SingHaiyi eyeing more distressed US property
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

SingHaiyi eyeing more distressed US property

Published

Fri, Jun 6, 2014 · 10:00 PM

HONG KONG-listed Heng Fai Enterprises may have guided SingHaiyi, previously a struggling interior fit-out firm, into Singapore's property development scene in 2006 and helped its market cap to grow hundred-fold to about $400 million in the immediate years that followed, but Heng Fai's exit last year also left it in the lurch, saddled with a portfolio of residential projects amid government measures to quell property speculation.

Although three of its four projects have sold well, sales at one - the 56-unit freehold CosmoLoft in Balestier - have been slow with only 10 per cent sold. This led SingHaiyi to record an impairment of $10.5 million for FY2014 after the company compared its sales and selling prices to other projects in the vicinity.

In a recent interview, SingHaiyi's management told The Business Times that more than just diversifying out of residential projects into the more resilient commercial space - evident from its taking of a 20 per cent stake in TripleOne Somerset earlier this year - the Catalist-quoted real estate firm is increasingly focusing on purchasing distressed properties in the US.

For FY2014, SingHaiyi's US operations accounted for $11.8 million (versus nothing for FY2013) or one-fifth of the group's revenue, mainly from the sale of units at its Vietnam Town commercial condominium in San Jose, California, as well as rental revenue from its Tri-County Mall in Cincinnati, Ohio.

Both of these are troubled assets acquired at huge discounts to their net book values through a sister company, American Pacific International Capital (Apic), which is owned by the controlling shareholders of SingHaiyi, Gordon Tang and his wife, Serena Chen.

The third and latest acquisition is the one the team is most excited about: a half-occupied office building sitting on 4.7 acres (204,300 square feet) of prime waterfront land along San Francisco Bay that will be demolished to make way for a high-end community for seniors.

Chairman Neil Bush, son and brother to two former US presidents, said: "There is a very clear trend for the continuing care retirement community concept in the US. I'm really excited about the low supply and high demand as the senior population from the baby-boomer generation grows in size. It's very affordable for people who have homes to sell their homes and buy this concept, so we get the benefit of the upfront entrance fee plus recurring income from their stay."

This housing concept for the elderly, although not common in Singapore, is a mature one in the US, having been around since the 1970s. Residents pay US$3,500 to US$7,500 monthly to live in a unit there, depending on the level of care they need.

Asked if troubled assets make wise acquisition targets given the effort needed to clean them up, Ms Chen, who is also group managing director, replied in Mandarin: "We are picking them up cheap, but these are not rubbish, these are projects with potential. We're very careful in our selection, that's why we've only picked three so far, despite having looked at 40 projects."

It will take some time but stable recurring income from these new acquisitions are expected to shake up the current US-to-Singapore's 20:80 revenue ratio over the next few years.

Of the US$180 million SingHaiyi raised last June to grow its US real estate portfolio, it still has about US$80 million left to deploy.

site_title: Digital perpetrators making more sector specific attacks
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Digital perpetrators making more sector specific attacks

Published

Sun, Jun 8, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] The digital bad guys are making far more targeted attacks tailored to work on businesses in a specific industry, say security specialists.

Gone are the days when attackers mounted blanket campaigns across industries. These days, the hacks carried out on the financial industry, for example, are different from those committed against retail businesses.

The intrusion method of choice for the financial industry is via websites; for retail businesses, the preferred way in is via the point-of-sale system.

Web app attacks are most often performed on finance, IT, trade and utilities companies; the mining, transportation and manufacturing industries are hot targets for cyber espionage, but spying makes up less than one per cent of attacks on finance and retail verticals.

This information is from a recent global study from Verizon Enterprise Solutions, said its head of managed identity and security solutions for the Asia-Pacific, Rob Parker.

The other piece of bad news the Verizon study uncovered is that attackers are working faster, but the time between the intrusion and the discovery of the breach has stayed relatively stagnant.

"The point is, the bad guys are innovating faster than the good guys. That's not encouraging," said Mr Parker.

Attackers are getting more savvy, and are focusing their campaigns to raise the chances of a successful break-in, compared with the past, he added.

Web attacks come in various forms, so industries more exposed to a certain type of attack could dedicate more resources to putting up more defences in that area, said Mr Parker.

Attackers can choose to target the building blocks of a website - from breaking into the server on the backend to intercepting data transmitted between the frontend and backend application.

Phishing, through which hackers try to trick users into revealing their credentials, continues to be a common attack method.

The Verizon report said: "Many attacks in 2013 targeted off-the-shelf (Web) content-management systems to gain control of servers."

Denial-of-service (DoS) attacks, generally carried out on the victim's servers, were popular last year. Attackers typically overload the servers with requests, causing them to go down, temporarily incapacitating the operations of the business.

Industries that suffer from DoS attacks could consider engaging a managed-service provider; third-party providers tend to have more robust, distributed resources that can withstand larger attacks, said Mr Parker.

Industries could also shift some resources to the cloud.

For companies which rely heavily on Web apps to serve customers, Verizon recommends that they monitor outgoing connections to identify suspicious behaviour. They should also restrict multiple log-ins within a short timeframe and invest in two-step authentication systems.

The study also found that intrusions coming through user devices have been growing over time, because these have offered an easy foot in the door. Although most intrusions come in through servers, the central storehouse of information, user devices such as smartphones, tablets and computers have overtaken kiosks in terms of the devices of choice for interacting with banks. As a result, more financial services firms have come to rely on them to reach users.

Stuart Christmas, the director of future technologies at Tigerspike, said that the company is seeing a huge rise in the need for mobile security, although actual take-up lags behind that.

The global personal media company produces apps for enterprise clients, which have included Shell, The Economist and Woolworths.

"Companies pay a lot of lip service to being dedicated to security and privacy, but are typically unwilling to take action. Security in general tends to be something you 'need' only when it's too late," he said.

This security lag is larger with mobile apps than with traditional software, and the banking industry is leading the way with mobile security, he added.

Typical attacks on apps tend to exploit weaknesses in crypto-algorithms, with attacks attempting to sniff out data transferred between app and server.

Most apps use third-party libraries, which can introduce layers of insecurity to the final product. "If you know what they are, it's not hard to know how to steal from the backend systems," he said.

site_title: HK's Capital Today to launch China's first evergreen fund
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

HK's Capital Today to launch China's first evergreen fund

Published

Fri, Jun 6, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Hong Kong

A PRIVATE equity firm which has made huge profits off investments in China's technology sector is launching a fund unprecedented in the country for its ultra-long horizon.

Hong Kong-based Capital Today, an early investor in e-commerce company JD.com Inc and helmed by one of China's top dealmakers, aims to raise a US$400 million "evergreen" fund, according to its term sheet.

The fund's long-term structure is typically shunned by private-equity investors, because the global industry is built around investing, and getting returns, over much shorter periods.

Capital Today founder and former Baring Private Equity senior executive Kathy Xu declined to comment on the new fund, citing legal restrictions.

Private equity firms traditionally make investments using 10-year funds, and sell them after three to five years. Any gains made are returned to investors in the fund. But Internet companies such as Alibaba Group Holding Ltd, Baidu Inc and Tencent Holdings Ltd continued to grow strongly long after private equity firms sold their stakes.

An evergreen fund would allow Capital Today to hold stakes in emerging Chinese companies for far longer than is usual, enabling the firm to share in future profits, according to an investor familiar with plans for the new fund.

The new fund, Capital Today Evergreen Fund, will charge a regular 2 per cent management fee, but will have a 28-year life, according to the term sheet. That is likely to appeal to investors who are comfortable investing over a long period, such as US endowment funds or family offices.

Capital Today's evergreen fund comes off the back of a series of lucrative investments. Bets on Chinese technology companies in particular have earned big payouts for the firm's investors, which include International Finance Corp and CDC Group PLC, according to Thomson Reuters data.

The new fund is widely believed to be the first of its kind in China, and comes with the firm sitting on a windfall from its stake in JD.com. Other Capital Today interests include web-based broadcaster China Central Television, video sharing site Tudou.com, and logistics and distribution company Shandong Rongqing Logistics Co Ltd. Reuters

site_title: Bonds, stocks get ECB boost; euro unfazed
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Bonds, stocks get ECB boost; euro unfazed

Published

Fri, Jun 6, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE big question is whether European Central Bank (ECB) chief Mario Draghi's monetary bullets will be a shot in the arm for the sclerotic eurozone economies.

Negative interest rates and a 400 billion euro (S$684 billion) cheap central bank facility aimed at boosting business lending lifted equity and bond prices slightly, but the shotgun fired blanks at the euro.

After falling to a five-month low of 1.35 against the US dollar, the euro rebounded to around 1.365 on the back of short-covering from hedge funds, which had built a substantial bear position against the currency.

Regardless of short-term market reactions, however, the ECB regards the current foreign exchange rate as uncomfortably high. In central bank-couched language, ECB officials hinted broadly that a devaluation of up to 10 per cent would boost exports and reduce imports of low-priced goods, which are causing disinflation and the possibility of a deflation downward spiral, leading to business and consumer-spending delays and a slide towards recession.

As the table shows, the economies of Italy, Ireland and Greece are still contracting; those of France and Spain are teetering on the brink of recession.

Only Germany has been spurting ahead, but with a sizeable proportion of its exports geared towards the uncertain economies of China and other Asian and emerging markets, the most powerful European nation is in danger of slowing down. Illustrating the dependence on a weaker euro to stimulate foreign sales, the German stock market DAX index surged to an all-time peak of 10,000 when the currency dipped to its lows and then slipped back when the currency rallied.

France, Italy, Spain and other eurozone members are even more desperate for euro devaluation, hoping that it will fall towards the currency's purchasing power parity (trade valuation) of around 1.18 to the US dollar.

The currency over-valuation against Asia-Pacific currencies is even more extensive. Since 2012, the euro has appreciated by 12 per cent against the Singapore dollar, a relatively strong currency in the Asia-Pacific.

Steven Barrow of Standard Bank and other currency analysts said that, in the generally unpredictable foreign exchange market, the euro could decline to around 1.27 in a year and 1.20 in two years. But they do not believe that such a decline would be sufficient to counter deflationary threats.

In 2012, Mr Draghi set European financial markets alight by stating that the ECB would protect the euro at all costs. The result has been a sharp decline in government bond yields and soaring European stock markets.

The advantages of Mr Draghi's "jawboning" has been much cheaper borrowing for governments and finance for cash-strapped companies.

The eurozone economies have recovered from their 2011 to 2012 crisis nadirs, but with the exception of Germany and, to a lesser extent, France, these economies' gross national products are well below levels seen six years ago, before the global financial collapse.

Some monetary measures to boost the eurozone economies have received mixed reviews from economists.

The ECB cut its three key interest rates, but the most widely expected was a decision to set a negative interest rate on the ECB's deposit facility. The aim of this measure, which effectively requires banks to pay the ECB for excess deposits, is to encourage them to lend more. Analysts believe this could work, given that the measure comes into effect almost immediately.

Another incentive is a four-year 400 billion euro targeted long-term refinancing operation (TLTRO) scheme, under which banks will be able to borrow from the ECB at exceptionally low interest rates, on condition these funds are then lent out to the private sector - largely to companies. Analysts fear this measure, which is not massive given the lengthy period, only comes into operation from September. The eurozone cannot afford any delays, they warn.

The ECB also intends to create a transparent asset-backed securities (ABS) market. This measure, which would kick in if the latest policy fails, will enable the ECB to eventually purchase assets of banks and other institutions, cutting yields and boosting liquidity in the eurozone economy. This measure will not have any impact until the ECB buys.

If the measures fail, Mr Draghi has promised a major quantitative easing (QE) programme to boost liquidity, similarly to that of the US Federal Reserve Board.

The danger of all the monetary ease and QE is the creation of bond, share and property bubbles that could burst, causing another financial collapse and recession. This is the problem that the US Fed also faces and it has raised global uncertainty.

site_title: Era of slow fashion
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Era of slow fashion

A new breed of socially responsible designer and retailer places a premium on the painstaking process of fashion creation rather than being driven by profits or the latest fad. By May Yip

Published

Fri, Jun 6, 2014 · 10:00 PM

OVER a year after the Rana Plaza disaster, during which the collapse of the factory building in Bangladesh killed over 1,300 people, intricately made apparel with traceable origins has become more appealing to consumers with a conscience. Now, despite the continuing demand for $10 tank tops to don and dump, the notion of buying a $200 scarf that took four days to handcraft isn't quite as foreign as the ingestion of chia seeds to a McDonald's devotee.

"Because we are so used to mass-produced goods at affordable prices, consumers often neglect to recognise that someone else is actually trading their own precious time and effort to physically create a product," says Colin Chen, co-founder of Tyrwhitt General Company.

"We decided to focus on artisanal and crafted goods because we believe that there is more to buying than just the physical transaction and ownership. Consumers have a right to know how the goods came about, the story of the makers behind the goods, why they are doing it and even the social impact of production."

Back to the source

Established in late-2012, Mr Chen's retail store located above Chye Seng Huat Hardware cafe attempts to support artisanal labels, many of which are local. Perhaps a counter-movement in reaction to the environmental and social evils of fast fashion, several independent retailers and designers are pivoting their attention from maximising profit margins to sourcing for reliable creators of quality wares.

Case in point: Apart from committing to much lengthier, artisanal modes of production, "socially motivated" brand Matter relies on craftsmen personally sought out by its founder Renyung Ho to ensure its products are ethically created and of a high quality.

"It kicked off last year when I drove a tuk-tuk covering 3,000 km from North to South India for a charity drive," recalls Ms Ho, a former associate director at Banyan Tree Hotels & Resorts.

"I fell in love with the country and met some key people I work with now. It was sort of a domino effect. Each of our supply chain partners is chosen through a set of criteria emphasising product integrity, community integration and good business practice. We personally visit each partner to establish that long-term relationship."

Besides relying on socially responsible manufacturers, some homegrown designers such as scarf-maker Linda Solay, a Singapore-based Swedish designer who creates "nuno-felted" scarves, personally craft each product they sell. Relatively time-consuming and completely bucking the trend of high volume fashion production, these designers give new meaning to the notion of a "hands-on approach" to business.

For now, Ms Solay, who moved to Singapore to pursue a master's degree in fine art, makes every scarf herself by hand, from selecting the wools and silks, to laying out a design; rolling, shaping, detailing; and labelling and packaging. It takes from 10 hours for a scarf of regular size and complexity, to over four days for a larger scarf or shawl with detailing.

The manual felting process also involves laboriously applying water to slowly interlock wool fibres with a fine silk base. Hence, plans to start training and employing a couple of dedicated staff with a keen eye for detail are under way.

"At a time when anything can be purchased with money, appreciation for the slow and genuine craft form is being revived, not the least because it allows to further have a piece custom-made according to one's wishes," says the artist, who recently held a nuno felting workshop here, and adds that half her sales come from local customers.

Likewise, it takes 80 days to make a pair of Matter pants - about a month for the fabric to be woven, another month for printing, and 20 days to cut and stitch. Weaving and printing require more time as the fabrics are hand-woven and the silk-cotton blend used comes directly from only one supplier; block printing, on the other hand, involves multiple steps where the production process is highly dependent on weather conditions.

"We see the rise of the 'maker culture' and indie labels. There's a definite growth in the demand and valuation of buying local," says Ms Ho, who co-founded a collaborative workspace for creative entrepreneurs called Kennel prior to kick-starting the apparel company, which currently retails a line of trousers for women and dwells on provenance and quality. "Singaporean shoppers, however, still prioritise affordability and convenience. And although conscious consumerism is on the rise, businesses still have to ensure they can provide that."

Pricing craftsmanship

While the majority of shoppers may pay stratospheric prices for the perceived value of a designer product, they may still baulk at shelling out for relatively unknown labels - especially if they are local. Which is why Tyrwhitt General Company manages a blog to showcase its designers as well as holds regular workshops to introduce old-school skills such as leathercraft and box-making to educate customers on the effort that goes behind a handmade object.

"When you can find a decent pair of Oxfords in, say, H&M for $80, you will find it shocking to see another pair costing $400," says Mr Chen, who also helms accessories brands Fabrix and Miller Goods.

"We've just held a series of shoe-making workshops during which participants handcrafted a pair of slip-on leather shoes from scratch. It took each participant nearly 10 hours just to complete a very simplified pair. Most of them have a newfound respect for shoe-makers now."

For some designers, the act of personally creating products is not just an outlet for creative expression, it stems from a desire to shift consumers' pursuit of cheap and instant gratification. Founded by sisters Paige, a former primary school teacher and marketing officer, and Lynette Lee, a fresh graduate, two-year-old homegrown label 30Versions features only accessories handmade by its owners in a home studio. The duo describes their designs as "art wearables" rather than mere jewellery, and, indeed, pieces such as a silver necklace embellished with pyrite - a type of mineral - have an almost sculptural quality.

"It'll take more than just awareness to alter the mindsets of people who are more inclined to follow trends and pay for lower-quality, fast fashion products," admits Paige.

"We believe that brands like us are generally spurred on by a different motive as opposed to fast-fashion producers. We create with a purpose in mind, hoping to either share our love of well-designed goods or spread a certain message to people through our designs. Profits are not our main source of motivation."

Shopping subculture

With the convenience of online shopping and ubiquity of cookie-cutter styles from massive fashion chains, our national obsession with shopping has ironically spawned an aversion towards mass consumption.

"Indeed, the fast-paced life and mass consumerist patterns of Singaporean have indirectly spun off another subculture of individuals seeking to break free from the homogeneity," mulls Mr Chen.

"In a way, everyone wants to be unique and special, down to their personal styles and things they own. Hence they seek options by crafters and makers that resonate with their own individuality. In a way, it's all about going back to basics and back to the roots."

Just like how some gourmands who crave a connection to their sustenance have turned to foraging to determine the precise source of ingredients for dinner - Sengkang Riverside Park is apparently a frequent haunt of such "locavores", serious shoppers want to be clued in on the origins of their purchases.

Apart from learning how to make their own shoes, they would perhaps shop at flea markets such as MAAD to engage in a conversation with the makers of a necklace they wish to buy, or visit online shopping portals such as Haystackt which curates a group of indie creators and offer some insights into their work processes.

"With the rise of conscious consumerism, even the fast-fashion industry knows that their model of fast, disposable fashion is no longer the way forward. H&M's Conscious Collection is a great example of a fast-fashion giant moving in a different direction," says Ms Ho.

"Our label isn't just a place for people to buy pants; it's about understanding where a great product is made and by whom it's made. This personal experience with the brand is something fast fashion cannot deliver."

site_title: Cargoes at Qingdao moved to LME warehouses
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Cargoes at Qingdao moved to LME warehouses

Probe driving banks, trading houses to take precautions

Published

Sun, Jun 8, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SYDNEY] Some copper cargoes held at China's Qingdao Port were being shipped to more regulated LME warehouses, industry sources said, as banks and trading houses took precautions over a probe into metal financing at the world's seventh-busiest port.

Shares in China's Qingdao Port International, the main operator, also weakened in their Hong Kong trading debut as investors responded cautiously.

The investigation is looking into whether single cargoes of metal were used multiple times to obtain financing, according to industry sources. Trading houses and banks have sent executives to the port to physically check on their exposure, while some banks have stopped new metal financing to some clients in China.

Jeremy Goldwyn, a director at brokerage Sucden Financial, said that some customers at the port were likely to ship metal out to more regulated London Metal Exchange (LME) warehouses "in a classic flight to quality". "Indeed, we hear metal is already en route to Korean LME locations," added Mr Goldwyn. The LME licenses warehouses all around the world including in South Korea, Singapore and Taiwan in Asia, but is not permitted to have warehouses in China.

Traders said that holders of copper in Qingdao that were having difficulty obtaining finance could also be forced to deliver to LME warehouses in East Asia to raise capital.

Ships carrying 10,000-20,000 tonnes of copper from Qingdao would arrive in South Korea over the coming weeks, one physical trader in Singapore estimated.

Most metal financing deals in China are done outside exchanges, and in those deals warehouse receipts are used as proof of ownership of metal. This is agreed typically by a bank or a trading house with a warehouse.

In contrast, in some other developed financial centres there is greater oversight. The LME licenses warehouses and monitors stocks held in exchange inventories.

London copper prices fell to the lowest in a month on Friday, as concerns over the probe continued to take a toll. "You're seeing material being sold for two reasons - because those financing deals are being unwound, and people who picked up material purely on a speculative basis will take profit now," one Singapore trader said.

Qingdao Port said on Friday that it had been asked by China's Public Security Authority to help with an investigation relating to aluminium and copper products under the name of a third-party cargo shipment agency, on behalf of a cargo owner.

It did not name the cargo owner or the shipment agency, and said that Qingdao had not been party to the agreement between the two. The metal had merely been stored at its Danang branch.

It did not say how much metal was involved, but said that it was an "immaterial proportion" of its total annual throughput. It also said that none of the company's employees were under investigation.

Qingdao Port International is the primary operator, handling about 76 per cent of the port's total cargo last year. "Everything in Qingdao port is running normally," the operator's chairman, Zheng Minghui, told reporters at the company's listing ceremony at the Hong Kong stock exchange, but declined further comment.

Its shares ended down at HK$3.71 on Friday compared to their IPO price of HK$3.76. - Reuters

site_title: HK developer plans to turn Cairns into new Macau
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

HK developer plans to turn Cairns into new Macau

A$8.15b casino resort in the gateway to the Great Barrier Reef will be bigger than S'pore's two integrated resorts put together

Published

Thu, Jun 5, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SYDNEY] Once a stop on the hippie trail, Cairns is now a haven for backpackers and divers. By 2019, Tony Fung predicts it will be a gambling destination to rival Macau.

The Hong Kong property developer last week won early-stage government backing for plans to build an A$8.15 billion (S$9.5 billion) casino resort on a former sugarcane farm north of the town.

With targeted first-stage completion in late 2018 and 7,500 hotel rooms around an artificial lagoon, 18-hole golf course and water park, it'll nearly triple the region's hotel accommodations and be bigger than Singapore's two integrated resorts put together.

"We are extremely confident that Cairns can be a global destination," said Justin Fung, Mr Tony Fung's son and chief executive officer of development company Aquis Resort at the Great Barrier Reef in an interview last week.

"This is the closest western city to China," he said of the tropical Australian city.

Mr Tony Fung's quest faces competition across the region as investors locked out of Macau, which has licensed just six casino operators to tap its US$45 billion gambling market, plan new resorts from Sri Lanka to South Korea, the Philippines and Japan.

With Chinese spending on overseas trips rising 26 per cent during 2013 to US$129 billion, the country is already the world's largest source of outbound tourist revenue.

Competition from Asian gaming resorts and gambling websites is a challenge to Australia's casino industry, according to a November report by researcher Ibisworld.

Revenue growth will slow to 2.9 per cent a year over the five years to June 2019, from 3.6 per cent over the previous five, Ibisworld estimates.

With A$4.8 billion of expenditure by Chinese tourists in 2013, Australia is currently capturing less than 4 per cent of China's tourism exports. Casinos' revenue of A$3.5 billion accounts for just 18 per cent of a gambling sector dominated by slot machines in pubs, sports betting and lotteries, according to a 2010 government report.

Cairns's existing Reef Casino Trust, the city's only casino operator, posted A$24 million in revenue last year, and competes with Crown Resorts and Skycity Entertainment Group gambling halls in Perth and Darwin that are also less than eight hours' flight from Hong Kong.

That's not deterring the government of the city's Queensland state, which plans to issue three new casino licences to lure Asian gamblers and stimulate job growth amid a fall in coal prices that will help drive a A$324 million decline in government mining royalties by June 2017.

Proposed developments in Cairns, Brisbane and the Gold Coast could bring the same benefits that Genting Singapore's Resorts World Sentosa and Las Vegas Sands' Marina Bay Sands brought to Singapore, Queensland Premier Campbell Newman said last October.

The hotels helped fuel a 20 per cent jump in tourist numbers to the city-state after they opened in 2010, he said.

Shares in Echo Entertainment Group, which operates existing casinos in Brisbane and the Gold Coast and has said those cities' gambling markets can't support much more development, fell as much as 2.6 per cent before closing down 0.4 per cent at A$2.74 in Sydney. The benchmark S&P/ASX 200 index declined 0.2 per cent.

"Everyone's seen the success of Singapore, which is just being used as a blueprint elsewhere," Killian Murphy, an analyst at CIMB Group Holdings Bhd, said. "Potentially Australia as a whole becomes a better sell into the Chinese market" if it has more resorts for tourists to choose from.

Cairns is well placed to exploit that market, said Mr Fung. Another Fung family company has already bought about 77 per cent of the Reef Casino Trust as part of a A$214 million takeover.

"We're sitting on the doorstep of the Great Barrier Reef," he said. "As the Chinese middle-class and wealthy travel, one of the first things they're going to embrace is the natural environment. Cairns has that in spades."

Floods, cyclones, a strong Australian dollar and the rise of competing markets in Asia have stymied growth at some resorts along the Great Barrier Reef.

Properties on Dunk and Bedarra islands, for example, sold in late 2011 for about 15 per cent and 20 per cent of their 2007 values respectively.

Chinese-Australian billionaire William Han paid A$12 million for Lindeman Island in 2012, a 10th of what Club Mediterranee SA had spent to buy and expand it in the early 1990s.

Sandwiched between the volcanic Atherton Tablelands and the lagoon of the barrier reef and fringed by mangrove swamps populated by man-eating crocodiles, Cairns has attracted Chinese visitors since gold prospectors flocked to the region in the 1870s.

It's grown into a tourist spot and jumping-off point for visits to the Great Barrier Reef, the world's largest coral system, "a perfect place to meet other travellers" whose downtown is "more board shorts than briefcases", according to the Lonely Planet tourist guide. It's home to more than 10 scuba-diving schools and 40 backpacker hostels.

Not everyone welcomes the proposed development.

"It's horrific," said Gayle Hannah, who came to the region as an 18-year-old in 1971. "Most likely it's going to sit there and moulder and just be a headache."

Building such a big resort in the region is "crazy", she said. "The Asian market is looking for the things we already have - the reef, rainforest, quiet, birds, good food," she said.

An online petition opposing the development has attracted 1,753 signatures at the website communityrun.org.

The 343-hectare site for the Aquis resort will include two theatres, a convention centre, a sports stadium, a water park, and an aquarium, as well as shops, restaurants, and 1,800 homes for staff, according to a July 2013 proposal to the government.

Stage 1 of the Aquis resort would have 4,000 rooms, and there's no date set for the expansion to 7,500, Ben Ready, a spokesman for the Aquis project, said yesterday.

Once complete, the complex of eight hotels will be as large as Moscow's Izmailovo Hotel Complex, the world's biggest, and surpass the 5,044-room MGM Grand in Las Vegas.

"I see more luxury projects creating a gaming destination for the Asian market," Mr Fung said. "If you can create enough quality product, then certainly the demand is there."

The Fung family has spoken to financial institutions about funding the resort and haven't yet committed to any, he said. He didn't name any partners for the project.

Queensland may struggle to digest such a sharp increase in gambling tourism, said CIMB's Mr Murphy.

"I just think three new integrated resorts is stretching it," he said. "Trying to convince a gambler to come here can be difficult. You're talking a nine or ten-hour flight" from cities in China.

The entire Tropical North Queensland region including the city contained only 3,892 hotel rooms in June 2013, according to government data. Those hotels had occupancy rates of 68 per cent in the year and average room rates of A$143 a night, about 25 per cent below the national average, separate data show.

That's not deterring Hong Kong-based Mr Fung. The right facilities can attract visitors in numbers such as those who've been lured by other casino resorts in the region, he said.

"We're on the doorstep of Macau and we've seen the incredible growth of that market. We're close to Singapore and we've seen what just two properties there are capable of doing," he said. "There is that aspect of 'If you build it, they will come'." - Bloomberg

site_title: Deciding based on market cap
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Deciding based on market cap

It is just as important to consider, when analysing stock investments, the relative size of a listed company or trust, says GEOFF HOWIE

Published

Sun, Jun 8, 2014 · 10:00 PM

WHETHER we are looking to buy a house, a car or a new set of clothes, a product's relative measurements such as weight, length and capacity can be just as important to our purchasing decisions as the price tag or brand name.

A brand new Harley-Davidson, for example, is not of much practical use to a family of five as a means of transport, even if it is going for a good price. Getting the right size is important not only for our own purposes but also when we think about resale potential.

It might not be too different with stock investment decisions.

Stock listings come in all shapes, sizes and flavours. While investment analysis often centres on the industry sectors and geographic markets, it is just as important to consider the relative size of a listed company or trust.

In many ways, a stock's market capitalisation, or "market cap", is just as critical to an investor as the name of the stock issuer. Market cap is measured by the number of shares issued by a company multiplied by their subsequent share price. It is one of the key ways of measuring a company's size and market value relative to its peers.

In May 2010, Apple became the world's largest technology company when its market cap on the Nasdaq exchange exceeded that of Microsoft, a moment seen by many as a symbolic turning point in the history of the world's big technology brands.

Stocks are generally categorised into large caps, mid caps and small caps. Individual investors often ask their brokers and remisiers about the average sizes of large, mid or small-cap stocks in Singapore - in addition to any difference in the nature or risk of these different categorisations. This is because investors categorise and group stocks according to certain criteria.

Simple methods include the relevant business sector and where in the world assets are based or revenue is generated. These can change over time as a company either expands or contracts, or makes strategic acquisitions or disposals.

This is particularly the case in Singapore with a highly diversified stock market by business line and revenue reach. Perhaps, one of the most important criteria that can change over time is the market cap of the listed company. In tune with the share price, the market cap can move through the traditional classifications of large caps, mid caps and small caps. Hence, small-cap stocks can become mid-cap stocks or large-cap stocks and vice-versa.

In the case of Singapore stocks, FTSE Group publishes indices that group stocks according to their relative sizes. Using this method of categorisation, the majority of stocks listed on the SGX Mainboard fit into one of four indices: the FTSE Straits Times Index (STI), FTSE ST Mid Cap Index, FTSE ST Small Cap Index and the FTSE ST Fledgling Index. Together, these indices represent 499 of the stocks listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX).

The stocks included in the STI, Mid Cap Index and Small Cap Index together make up the FTSE ST All Share Index. This index is a broader performance benchmark of the Singapore stock market than the Straits Times Index (STI).

At the end of May, the average market capitalisation of an STI constituent was about $18 billion. For a constituent of the Mid Cap Index, it was $2.4 billion, and for the Small Cap Index, it was $488 million. The average market capitalisation of a Fledgling Index constituent was $72 million.

A capitalisation of $1 billion marked the general threshold between a Mid Cap and Small Cap index constituent at the end of May. That is, most of the lowest capitalised stocks of the Mid Cap Index maintained a market capitalisation above $1 billion, while most of the largest capitalised stocks of the Small Cap Index maintained a market capitalisation near or just below $1 billion.

For the mid cap to large cap threshold, the largest weightings of the Mid Cap Index maintained full market capitalisation levels around $5 billion, as did the smallest weightings of the STI.

Ascendas Reit moved to the STI from the FTSE ST Mid Cap Index last week. Ascendas Reit was the largest weighting of the FTSE ST Mid Cap index and maintained a full market capitalisation of $5.9 billion as at May 30.

The 185 stocks of the All Share Index are made up of 30 STI stocks, 50 stocks of the Mid Cap Index and 105 stocks of the Small Cap Index. By comparison, the Fledgling Index is made up of 314 stocks.

Small cap, high volatility

Small-cap stocks have generally been more volatile than their larger counterparts in recent years. This is confirmed through a comparison of annualised volatility levels of the STI, Mid Cap Index and Small Cap Index. Over the five years ended May 30, the Small Cap Index generated annualised volatility of 20.4 per cent, versus 16.4 per cent for the Mid Cap Index and 14.3 per cent for the STI. Hence, the average price swings of the small caps as represented by the Small Cap Index were more significant than the large caps as represented by the STI over the past five years.

Meanwhile, the largest weightings of the FTSE ST Mid Cap Index include Suntec Reit, UOL Group, CapitaCommercial Trust, Keppel Land, Singapore Post, Ezion Holdings, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, Sats, Keppel Reit and Venture Corp. The average market capitalisation of the 10 largest constituents at the end of May stood at about $4 billion. As noted earlier, the average market cap for all constituents of the FTSE ST Mid Cap Index is $2.4 billion.

With CapitaMalls Asia being deleted from the STI last week, Ascendas Reit left the FTSE ST Mid Cap Index and joined the STI. As noted in this column a month ago, the STI reserve list comes into play if a constituent is deleted from the index during the intra-review period.

Meanwhile, Ezra Holdings moved from the FTSE ST Small Cap Index into the FTSE ST Mid Cap Index. Following Ascendas Reit joining the STI, there are now 17 of the 50 Mid Cap Index constituents represented in the Real Estate Investment Trust (Reit) sector, according to the Industry Classification Benchmark (ICB).

Reit impact

Hence, Reits and stapled property trusts still have had the largest sectorial impact on the recent performance of the Mid Cap Index. These 17 related constituents make up as much as 40 per cent of the free float capitalisation of the Mid Cap Index. The Reits and property trusts, which average an indicative dividend yield of 6 per cent, have had an impact on the dividend distributions associated with the Mid Cap Index.

This is supported by 47 of the 50 Mid Cap constituents maintaining an indicative dividend yield. As at end-May, the Mid Cap Index returned 7.2 per cent in price and 9.9 per cent in total return.

The impact of the Reits and property trusts on the FTSE ST Mid Cap Index has gradually increased over time. In October 2011, the then 14 Reits and stapled property trust constituents made up 36 per cent of the free float capitalisation of the Mid Cap Index.

The five best-performing constituents in the year-to-date through to end-May were GuocoLeisure, Oxley Holdings, United Engineers, Vard Holdings and Bumitama Agri. These five stocks each represented a different ICB sector. The five worst-performing constituents of the Mid Cap Index over the timeframe were Super Group, Ezra Holdings, Yangzijiang Shipping, Neptune Orient Lines and Rowsley.

Small Cap Index

The 105 constituents of the Small Cap Index also have significant affiliation with the Reit Sector, albeit to a lesser extent. Of the 10 largest constituents of the Small Cap Index at the end of May, there were seven Reits or stapled trusts - Cambridge Industrial Trust, AIMS AMP Capital Industrial Reit, Cache Logistics Trust, Sabana Shari'ah Compliant Reit, Frasers Commercial Trust, Ascendas Hospitality Trust and First Reit. Together, these seven trusts accounted for one fifth of the Index weightings.

Outside of the Reit Sector contingent, there are 27 more ICB Sectors represented in the Small Cap Index. The remaining three corporations that helped make up the 10 largest weightings at the end of May were United Envirotech, Ezra Holdings and Yoma Strategic Holdings.

However, as mentioned earlier, Ezra Holdings left the FTSE ST Small Cap Index to join the FTSE ST Mid Cap Index last week. The average market capitalisation of those 10 largest constituents at the end of May was about $930 million. The average market cap for all constituents of the FTSE ST Small Cap Index was $488 million.

As in the case of the Mid Cap Index, the five best-performing constituents in the Small Cap Index this year at the end of May each represented different sectors. These stocks were AusGroup, UMS Holdings, Stats ChipPAC, BreadTalk Group and Q&M Dental Group. The five worst-performing constituents of the Small Cap Index over the timeframe were Blumont Group, Asiasons Capital, Liongold Corporation, KrisEnergy and Hu An Cable Holdings. As at end-May, the FTSE ST Small Cap Index had returned 3 per cent in price and 5.5 per cent in total return.

In the first quarter of 2014, both the Mid Cap Index and Small Cap Index generated more similar performances. In the second quarter through to the end of May, the Mid Cap Index outperformed the Small Cap Index by 4.4 per cent on a total return basis.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Football still a lucrative game: Deloitte report

Cumulative revenue of the 'big five' European leagues grew 5% to 9.8b euros in 2012/13

Published

Fri, Jun 6, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

FOOTBALL continues to be a beautiful and lucrative game; toplines and wages in Europe's top leagues are still on the rise, according to the latest edition of Deloitte's Annual Review of Football Finance.

The report said the cumulative revenue of the "big five" European leagues grew 5 per cent to 9.8 billion euros ($16.7 billion) in 2012/13. That's about half of the overall size of the entire European football market, whose takings went up 2 per cent to 19.9 billion euros.

The top five leagues are the Premier League in England, the Bundesliga in Germany, the La Liga in Spain, the Serie A in Italy and Ligue 1 in France.

Not surprising to football fans is the report's finding that the Premier League continues to rake in the highest takings - it earned 2.9 billion euros in total revenue for the period, almost 50 per cent more than the Bundesliga, the second-highest earner. The Premier League's earnings were also 7 per cent up from the year-ago period.

Much of the revenue growth in these top five leagues was driven by a limited number of eminent clubs; in the Premier League's case, these were Manchester United, Manchester City and Liverpool, which accounted for over 60 per cent of this growth.

In Germany, Bayern Munich and Borussia Dortmund were responsible for over 80 per cent of the Bundesliga's earnings increase.

In the case of Serie A, Juventus accounted for over three-quarters of the league's revenue growth, thanks to its return to the Champions League. The Champions League is the region's most prestigious tournament, featuring the top teams from each of Europe's strongest national leagues.

For Ligue 1, Paris Saint-German accounted for all of the league's earnings growth for the second year running.

All five leagues, with the exception of the Bundesliga, derived their earnings mainly from broadcast revenue and commercial sources.

The Bundesliga was also the league which had the best handle on its costs. Its wages-to-revenue ratio was 51 per cent, compared to the Premier League and Serie A's 71 per cent, Ligue 1's 66 per cent and La Liga's 56 per cent.

The 2012/2013 period also marked the first one in which the Premier League's wages-to-revenue ratio crossed the 70 per cent threshold for the first time. Six of the league's clubs had total wages above the average £89 million ($187.7 million). And Manchester City chalked up a wage bill of £233 million - the highest recorded for a football club, or any professional sport for that matter.

Still, Deloitte said, the overall £125 million rise in Premier League wages for the period was not as significant an increase as anticipated, demonstrating that restraint is being shown at some clubs. "We expect 2013/14 to see another rise in wages as the first payments of the new broadcast deal flow through, but this may be tempered to an extent by the new financial regulations," it said.

Deloitte expects the value of global premium sports broadcast rights to rise by 14 per cent to £16 billion in 2014. And it sees the big five leagues' combined revenue to breach 11.5 billion euros in 2014/15.

For the Premier League, it expects commercial revenues to exceed £1 billion in 2015/16, for overall revenues to go over £3.3 billion, and for player spending to total £2.5 billion in 2016/17.

Stock bulls face two headwinds now

Published Sun, Jun 8, 2014 · 10:00 PM

LAST week, US stocks finished at record highs as a rate cut from the European Central Bank (ECB) and a strong jobs report gave stock bulls a second wind.

The momentum of the latest bull run could carry the market higher for another week. Having closed less than 100 points away, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is almost sure to test the 17,000 level. If they are to run much further, however, the bulls must fight two headwinds: valuation and rising interest rates.

As anticipated, the ECB cut deposit rates for banks below zero, effectively making it cheaper for lenders to give loans than to sit on reserves. This sparked the late-week rally, and the jobs report supported it. A higher-than-forecast 217,000 jobs were added to payrolls in May and the unemployment rate held steady at 6.3 per cent. While the four-month aggregate of jobs added was the highest since the 1990s, what observers such as Dallas Federal Reserve president Richard Fisher have called "structural" problems persist. A low participation rate still shows that millions have been left behind in the recovery.

site_title: MAS proposes amending laws to fight 'dirty money'
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

MAS proposes amending laws to fight 'dirty money'

Published

Fri, Jun 6, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

THE Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) intends to increase cooperation with other financial supervisors to fight money laundering and terrorism financing (ML/TF).

It is proposing changes to the MAS Act and the Trust Companies Act (TCA) for more effective international cooperation in countering ML/TF.

In a consultation paper released on Thursday, it said that the MAS Act will be amended to include financial holding companies so that they will be subject to appropriate anti-money laundering and countering financing of terrorism (AML/CFT) laws.

The MAS Act will be amended to set out the need to perform customer due diligence and keep proper records in primary legislation, it said.

It proposed that failure to comply will result in a fine not exceeding $1 million and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine of $100,000 for every day during which the offence continues.

"The inclusion of these provisions in the MAS Act will demonstrate Singapore's commitment to adhere to international standards," MAS said.

It said that countries such as the United States, Australia and New Zealand have adopted a similar approach.

MAS also said that "given that ML/TF can be transnational, effective international cooperation is essential to combat and deter such crime".

"In this regard, international standards for information sharing and cooperation to detect and recover illicit proceeds have recently been raised to better facilitate the consolidated supervision of international financial institutions."

MAS already has powers to obtain and exchange supervisory information with foreign supervisors, it said.

It is proposed that these powers be broadened to increase the level of cooperation, so that MAS will be able to share information, including protected information, with foreign counterpart authorities and other Singapore authorities for AML/CFT supervisory, investigation and law enforcement purposes.

On the proposed change to the TCA, it is to facilitate inspections of Singapore-incorporated licensed trust companies which are subsidiaries of foreign financial groups by their parent supervisors.

The current TCA allows MAS to authorise only on-site examinations by foreign supervisors of trust companies incorporated outside Singapore, but operating here as branches.

DBS, the only one among the three local banks with a holding company, said it does not expect any impact from the proposed amendment.

"As DBS Group observes stringent AML/CFT standards, extending the proposed enhanced AML/CFT regime to the financial holding company (FHC) of DBS Bank Ltd will not have any significant impact as we expect the FHC to comply with the same group standards," said a spokeswoman.

"HSBC Singapore continually invests in risk and compliance capabilities to achieve the highest standards in the fight against financial crime, which knows no geography," said a bank spokeswoman. "As an international bank, we welcome any regulatory proposals that can strengthen the bank's efforts to combat financial crime," she said.

Wilson Woo, EY financial services partner, said private banks are already covered under the Banking Act, for inspections by foreign supervisors.

"However, the proposed amendment to enhance the transnational exchange of customers' private and confidential information will have some impact to the private banking industry in a positive way - it will deter the entry of "dirty money" into the country, which enhances Singapore's AML/CFT regime," he said.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Ex-banker Edwin Khoo may be heading for the motor trade

He is said to be joining Audi dealer Premium Automobiles soon in an advisory position

Published

Fri, Jun 6, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

AFTER revolutionising the car financing business, former banker Edwin Khoo could now be heading for the motor trade itself.

Mr Khoo, who retired from DBS Bank last year, is said to be joining Audi dealer Premium Automobiles soon in an advisory position. The company, owned by tycoon Hadi Tanaga, has been without a CEO since Marc Singleton left more than two months ago.

Mr Khoo is best known for devising Citibank's clever balloon loan scheme in the late 1990s. To help buyers financially, only a smaller downpayment was required upfront, together with lower monthly instalments which progressively increased and culminated with a final lump sum payment at the end of the loan period. The idea behind it was that the instalments would increase with buyers' income levels.

According to one dealer, "the balloon later burst because incomes didn't rise as fast as expected and the economy went south".

But rather than run Premium Automobiles on a day-to-day basis, Mr Khoo is expected to leverage his banking expertise and experience from the backend, where he is likely to identify areas for improvement, such as seeking better financing terms for both the company and its customers.

"He is an expert in trade financing and if anyone can cut financing costs and squeeze more out of the business, it will be him," said the managing director of a luxury dealership. "And with his wealth of banking contacts, he could even raise the image of the Audi brand further."

The director of another luxury dealership called Mr Khoo a "business strategist with a lot of bright ideas".

"I think he will come with a new insight into the business because even as a banker, he was intimately linked to the auto business," said the director. "He worked with SMEs previously and he knows the ground very well. He is versatile; he can be talking to a towkay in a coffeeshop one minute, and the next, he can put on a tie and talk to a CEO."

At DBS, which he joined in 2003, Mr Khoo was in charge of the enterprise banking unit which handled the financial and banking needs of small and medium-sized enterprises.

In the first quarter of this year, Audi was ranked Singapore's sixth most popular brand with a 5.7 per cent market share, down from fifth place and an 8 per cent market share as at end-2013.

Its main rivals, Mercedes-Benz and BMW, are currently in No 1 and No 3 positions, respectively.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

XinRen gets nod to raise smelter stake

Published

Fri, Jun 6, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

THE move by China-based XinRen Aluminium Holdings to raise its stake in an aluminium smelter in Xinjiang by 30 per cent was given the go-ahead by its shareholders at its extraordinary general meeting yesterday.

This comes after the Singapore-listed company exercised its option to increase its stake in the smelting plant for 3.15 billion yuan (S$633 million) in April.

The company first bought a 21 per cent stake two years ago in China Leading International, which fully owns the plant; with that purchase, it was granted a second call option. The completion of the acquisition will bring its total share in the plant to 51 per cent.

Aluminium prices hit a low of US$1,600 a tonne in the first half of this year, but have since risen to US$1,800 a tonne. Despite the weak prices, the Xinjiang plant, with its low production costs, has enabled XinRen to remain profitable, it said.

Now in its third phase of development, the plant produced about 400,000 tonnes of aluminium last year and contributed 93.6 million yuan to the company's full-year earnings of 61.6 million yuan. Output is expected to double this year and reach its full capacity of 1.6 million tonnes a year by the end of 2016.

About 80 per cent of aluminium producers in China are in the red, said Xinhua's China Economic Information Service.

The Xinjiang plant has managed to keep its costs low because of its access to an abundant source of coal, XinRen said yesterday. Xinjiang has about 40 per cent of China's coal resources and coal prices in the area are about a quarter of the national average. The plant also makes savings from its in-house power generating units.

Zeng Chaolin, XinRen's executive chairman, said: "Our increased investment in the Xinjiang plant is in line with the group's drive to stay profitable, even during this trying industry downturn, and remain as one of China's leading integrated upstream aluminium producers."

As the Chinese government aims to cut aluminium over-capacity and high-cost producers are forced out of the market, China's existing aluminium capacity of 30 million tonnes could be trimmed by 30 per cent in the next three years - at a time demand for aluminium is on the rise.

Increasingly, aluminium is being used to make lighter, more fuel-efficient vehicles, as well as healthcare products and packaging, paving the way for a rise in aluminium prices, said Mr Zeng.

XinRen's executive director Liang Hongbo said the currently low aluminium prices enabled the company to acquire the additional share and ready itself for the market's recovery.

site_title: Evolving homescape
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Evolving homescape

As an interior designer Isabelle Miaja is constantly finding something to add to her home and moving furniture around so as to keep her place looking fresh. By Tay Suan Chiang

Published

Fri, Jun 6, 2014 · 10:00 PM

IF there is one thing that French interior designer Isabelle Miaja dislikes, it is to be associated with a certain look. The founder of Miaja Design Group has been designing interiors for prestigious hotel groups, resorts, boutiques, corporate and high-end residential clients for nearly 20 years. The Singapore-based firm is known for its "unique and distinctive" approach to each project. "There is no one style, since it all depends on the site, and every place has its own soul," says Ms Miaja.

The most recent hotel she designed in Singapore is the Sofitel So, where the interiors are a blend of French chic and Singaporean design with touches of old and new. The same rule applies for her home in Upper Bukit Timah, where she lives with her three children. The two-storey terrace home has an eclectic feel because of the many artworks as well as decorative pieces that Ms Miaja has amassed over her many trips to South-east Asia, Europe, the Middle East and the United States.

The single mum, who received her training in Los Angeles says that "as I'm an interior designer, the home is always evolving". They have been living at this address for 12 years, and there has never once been a total revamp. "Instead I'm always finding something to add," she says. Their previous home in Singapore was an apartment closer to town.

Her children, aged 15 to 25, are used to their mum constantly filling up the home. "But at the same time, they warn me not to turn the home into a museum," she says with a laugh. "I must stop buying, because the kids say that if I buy one more item, I would be considered a hoarder." But still, she sometimes sneaks in a piece or two.

She is quick to decide whether to buy an item or not, but at the same time, is critical about what she purchases. "My work allows me to look at many beautiful items, but it takes a lot for me to fall in love with something," she says. "The piece has to make me feel that I've never seen it before." She speaks excitedly about a painting of a tulip, in a frame made of mosaic tiles. "The tulip is my favourite flower, and I love how the artist has used mosaic tiles to create a painting of sorts on the frame," she explains.

While she designs bespoke furniture pieces for her hotel projects, Ms Miaja is very much into having art in her home, including some of her own design.

Standing in the corner of her living room is a rototem - a rotating totem, similar to the three that she designed for the Sofitel Mumbai. The rototem comes with images of nature and animals. "It tells the story of my life, the things I love," she explains. "I like art pieces that I can touch, hence the pieces of the totem rotate." She adds that sculptures are her favourite art form, because, "I can create some breathing space around the art piece, unlike paintings, which are usually up against a wall."

Ms Miaja is a firm believer that the personality of the art collector can be seen through the selection of art. "I'm someone who appreciates colours and strokes, so hopefully people can tell I'm an extrovert with a love for the eclectic," she says. Her love for animals is obvious, not only because she shares her home with a cat, two dogs and three rabbits, but also in her choice of decorative items.

Standing in the garden are a pair of life-sized metal giraffes, which were shipped back from South Africa. Horse figurines feature widely in the home, "because these animals are my passion", while several chicken and rooster figurines take their place in the kitchen. "I didn't grow up with animals because the apartment had little space, so perhaps now I want to always surround myself with them," she says.

Her work takes her overseas many days of the month, but when she is home, the kitchen is her favourite spot.

"When we have guests over, everyone loves to be in the kitchen, and they spill out onto the patio too," she says. And her speciality dish? "I can make the best paella in Singapore," she says with a firm nod.

While colours feature largely in most parts of the home, softer shades of beige and off-white reign in her bedroom. The look here is more feminine and elegant, very much like how Ms Miaja is. "It is always nice to come back to my own bedroom," she says.

Without missing a beat, she says "hire me" when asked how homeowners can constantly keep their abode looking fresh.

She goes on to say that regardless of the look, a place must always "feel good. It is difficult to explain but there must be a balance of energy". From her many projects around the world to her own home, it is clear that she has this skill down pat.

But for the decoratively challenged homeowner, her advice is "to be daring and constantly move things around the home till it feels right". She still does this, such as replacing a duller art piece at the entrance with a mirrored one, which instantly brightens up the home.

"And add fresh flowers - they always do the trick," she says.

site_title: China growth to ease to 7.6%: World Bank
content:
China growth to ease to 7.6%: World Bank

IMF forecast the country's growth to be around 7.5% this year

Published

Fri, Jun 6, 2014 · 10:00 PM

CHINA'S economic growth is expected to ease slightly to 7.6 per cent this year from 7.7 per cent in 2013 and to moderate further to 7.5 per cent next year, the World Bank said yesterday while cautioning that structural transformation of the world's second largest economy is unlikely to be an even process.

"The rebalancing is not smooth, and quarterly growth is volatile," the World Bank noted in its latest China Economic Update. Recent data suggest, however, that "growth has stabilised and growth momentum is expected to accelerate in the second quarter of 2014".

The World Bank report came a day after the International Monetary Fund published the results of a regular economic consultation with Chinese authorities in which the IMF forecast that China's growth should be around 7.5 per cent this year, but could slip to 7 per cent in 2015.

The IMF said bluntly that "activity in China since the global financial crisis has been too dependent on credit and investment, including in real estate. While this has supported growth and provided a boost to global demand, it is not sustainable and (creates) rising vulnerabilities."

Both institutions expressed overall confidence in the China's ability to achieve a controlled slowdown or soft landing while also pointing to a series of risks.

"Recent growth rates (in China) have been significantly below levels observed over the past decade as drivers of economic growth shift from manufacturing to services on the supply side, and from investment to consumption on the demand side," the World Bank said in its update.

The growth slowdown in the first quarter of this year "reflected a combination of dissipating effects of earlier growth-support measures, subdued external environment, and tighter credit, especially for real estate activities".

In recent months, however, economic activity, including industrial production has started to show signs of acceleration, the World Bank said. This is "expected to continue into the next two quarters of this year - partly reflecting the effect of new growth-supporting measures, robust consumption, and a recovery of external demand".

A planned decline in Chinese investment growth will be largely offset by a gradual increase in consumption growth, supported by an increase in household incomes, the World Bank said.

"The fundamental drivers of the global recovery remain intact and should provide a favourable tailwind to China's net export growth. However, headwinds from a gradual deceleration of credit growth can be expected to weigh on domestic economic activity."

The World Bank said that the main channels of a possible disorderly unwinding are related to local government financing, which in case of a disorderly deleveraging could trigger a sharp slowdown in investment growth, and to prospects of sectors such as real estate, which in case of an abrupt change in the cost of capital could result in debt service difficulties.

It called for fiscal and financial sector reforms to address financial stability risks in the medium term. The first task involves effectively managing rapid credit growth, including the less well-regulated shadow banking system.

"The second, gradual and orderly deleveraging of large stock of local government debt accumulated through off-budget and quasi-fiscal platforms. Both of these reforms could potentially be disruptive to growth in the short run."

The IMF said, meanwhile, that activity in China since the global financial crisis "has been too dependent on credit and investment, including in real estate".
