site_title: AA may pay shareholders cash
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

AA may pay shareholders cash

Board considering options such as dividend, buyback

Published

Thu, Jun 5, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[DALLAS] American Airlines Group's board is considering options and timing to return cash to shareholders, a step that may include a dividend or buyback, and expects to make a decision by the end of the year.

The issue was among several discussed on Tuesday by directors ahead of Wednesday's annual meeting in New York, chief executive officer Doug Parker said.

It's the first shareholder gathering since the company was created in a December merger with US Airways Group.

"We are early in the merger," said Mr Parker, 52. "I would like to get more integration work behind us before settling on a return plan."

Making a choice this year on capital allocation would add to American's fast start since the US Airways tie-up formed the world's largest airline.

Fort Worth, Texas-based American may earn an annual profit of US$3.87 billion, based on analysts' estimates compiled by Bloomberg, which would be a record for the US industry.

American's share gain has extended the shares' year-to-date advance to 70 per cent, the most among major US airlines.

Before deciding on returns to shareholders, the 11-member board wants to ensure American has sufficient capital to complete its integration with US Airways, to reduce any high-interest debt and cover other needs, Mr Parker said.

American had US$10.6 billion in cash and short-term investments through March.

Last month, Delta Air Lines and Southwest Airlines announced plans to increase dividends and repurchase stock. Delta reinstituted a dividend last year, after a decade-long break that included a bankruptcy and the acquisition of Northwest Airlines. Dallas-based Southwest has paid a dividend since 1976.

American has reduced its shares outstanding since the merger by settling a convertible note and paying tax withholdings for employees in lieu of issuing common stock as compensation under its bankruptcy reorganisation plan.

The steps amount to a US$710 million return of capital to shareholders, Mr Parker said.

The carrier has a debt covenant that limits what it can do in the way of share repurchases or dividends unless it refinances the note. If the company waits until next March to refinance, a make-whole provision in the note would not apply, chief financial officer Derek Kerr has said.

Mr Parker told shareholders at the New York meeting that the airline is likely to exceed its US$1 billion estimate for merger revenue synergies from combining networks, winning back corporate contracts and other steps.

"So far, we believe we are going to exceed that target," he said.

The airline previously said that it had identified other ways since the merger that could generate US$400 million more with moves such as adding seats to some aircraft models. - Bloomberg

site_title: A visual feast right from the beginning
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

A visual feast right from the beginning

Published

Thu, Jun 5, 2014 · 10:00 PM

CHEF, a feel-good film about food in the age of social media, starts off on an upbeat note and maintains the tempo throughout.

Jon Favreau, a filmmaker with indie roots before hitting the big time with the Iron Man franchise, serves up the cinematic equivalent of a perfectly grilled cheese sandwich - it tastes great but never challenges the palate.

Not that there's anything wrong with that, of course. Favreau, who wrote, directed and stars in Chef, doesn't make any attempt to push the creative envelope because there's always another time and place - and movie - for that.

This time around, it feels like he simply wanted to get together with some celebrity buddies (including Dustin Hoffman, Scarlett Johansson and Robert Downey Jr in cameo roles) and hit the road for a bit of culinary fun - while weighing in on some current trends along the way.

Favreau clearly enjoys his food, and it's not his generous girth we're talking about. There are big names in the cast but food is the undisputed star of the show. From the opening scene depicting celebrity chef Carl Casper (Favreau) doing prep work and crafting a meal in his LA restaurant, this film is a visual feast. By the end, it will have you licking your lips and going through a mental checklist of your favourite dishes.

There are times when Chef feels like a blend of The Food Network and The Discovery Channel, with basic instructions on how to start a food truck business thrown in for good measure. Not surprising, since the LA chef and food truck guru Roy Choi - founder of Kogi BBQ - schooled the cast on kitchen culture and food truck ways.

The film also tackles the influence of Twitter on the modern-day food scene, showing how a tweet from anyone with a loyal following - from a powerful food critic to a blog-savvy 10-year-old kid - can help to make or break a chef's career.

Like many chefs with an ounce of talent, Carl loves to cook - but he also needs to impress his audience, including the important food critic Ramsey Michel (Oliver Platt) who comes to dine in his chic eatery one evening.

Problem is, the restaurant's owner (Hoffman) insists that Carl stick to his signature items, those tried-and-tested dishes (like chocolate lava cake) that diners love - but which fail to fire the imagination.

After Michel pans the food - and the chef - with a brutal tweet, Carl responds by going ballistic, while his right-back-at-you tweet goes viral.

Pretty soon, Carl is trending like crazy but he's also out of a job and down in the dumps, so it's left to ex-wife Inez (Sofia Vergara) and their Twitter-knowing young son Percy (Emjay Anthony) to pick up the slack.

The solution: Cuban sandwiches and starting over by going the food truck route. In Miami, the city where he first attracted Michel's attention, Carl refurbishes a rickety food truck and heads back across the country with Percy and a chirpy chef pal (John Leguizamo).

It's a father-son bonding exercise coupled with a whirlwind tour of the American South and classic Southern cuisine.

The food scenes elicit the desired audience response and the film also gets a major boost from the great soundtrack.

Chef is an easily digestible morsel that gives us an entertaining glimpse of the American food scene. Go watch it - then tweet all about it.

Rating:

B-

site_title: Making music as they go along
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Making music as they go along

Published

Thu, Jun 5, 2014 · 10:00 PM

MUSIC acts typically don't start touring unless they have a new album to plug, but American alternate rock trio Blonde Redhead are not adhering to that. The band, consisting of lead singer Kazu Makino and twin brothers Simone and Amedeo Pace, had announced in March that they had finished a new album, but have since been mum about the title and release details.

They will, however, be touring Asia, making stops in Taiwan, the Philippines, China and Singapore, where they will be performing as part of the line-up for urban music festival Hostess Club Weekender.

Over the phone, drummer and singer Simone Pace guarantees their fans will be in for a surprise. "We've been working on the new album, and we'll be playing some of the new songs on this tour. It's sort of a promotional tour and preview."

The last time Blonde Redhead was in Singapore in 2011, while promoting their album Penny Sparkle, but Pace says their sound has changed since quite a bit. "It's a bit more electronic, a bit more instrumental music," he explains. "There are quite a few new elements, so I'm really excited about it. I think our music has evolved."

Although their music has been described as dream pop and indie, Pace says they prefer not to label it. "For us, it's just our music, what we like and play; we don't like to name it, I think that restricts it," he adds. "Music, I think, is relative. For you it might sound like dream pop, for someone else it might be indie - it's up to the listeners."

Pace says they draw inspiration from experiences in life - for example, their album Misery Is a Butterfly had several songs inspired by Makino's accident with a horse.

"Kazu writes the lyrics, I just sing and play them," he laughs. "But, like our sound, the lyrics' meanings are relative too. To listeners, it might sound like a love song, but to Kazu, it might be a song about her horse!"

The band are excited to be back on the road, and Pace says they are very happy with where they are now, and what they are doing in terms of music. It's been quite a long road to recognition, but he says he never thought of anything else. "When I was younger, I already knew I wanted to pursue music seriously," he reveals, and adds that staying true to their sound has helped the band get to where they are today since forming in 1993. "Our music is not really influenced by anyone else but ourselves."

site_title: Sweet blend with Sandler's signature bad taste
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Sweet blend with Sandler's signature bad taste

Dylan Tan

Published

Thu, Jun 5, 2014 · 10:00 PM

AN Adam Sandler family comedy for the school holidays? Who would have thought Hollywood's notorious man-child would decide it's time to act his age with recent efforts such as the Grown Ups duology and That's My Boy all finding him maturing every so slightly and displaying a more sensitive adult side.

Blended, a new rom-com which pairs the 47-year-old comedian with Drew Barrymore for the third time after The Wedding Singer (1998) and 50 First Dates (2004), could well be Sandler's family-friendliest live-action film (bar his animated hit Hotel Transylvania) to date. It also reunites them with Singer's director Frank Coraci.

Predictable but sweet on the whole, Blended's main draw is the easy chemistry between the two leads and neither disappoints, drawing laughs effortlessly with their natural comic talents.

Sandler fans need not be totally disappointed because even with its PG rating, screenwriters Ivan Menchell and Clare Sera have slipped more than a handful of crude jokes into the script for those who bought a ticket expecting some Old School Sandler.

The Brady-Bunch-styled storyline finds Barrymore and Sandler playing Lauren and Jim respectively, single parents who first meet on a blind date so disastrous they decide they're never going to see anybody again. But as a Hollywood comedy plot and a healthy suspension of disbelief would have it, both of them coincidentally run into each other again when they end up holidaying in the same African resort - this time complete with their kids in tow.

Jim is the widower who has no idea how to raise his three daughters after his wife dies of cancer. His clueless-ness extends to him naming the girls Larry (short for Hilary), Espn (like the sports cable network) and Lou.

Lauren herself doesn't fair any better in the parenting department after her jerk of an ex-husband (Joel McHale from the sitcom Community) abandons the family and leaves her to raise two boys - a rambunctious nine-year-old and a puberty-stricken teenager with a porn obsession - on her own.

Opposites attract in more ways than one as Jim bonds with Lauren's father-figure-less boys through sports while Lauren gives Jim's tomboy girls makeovers.

As expected, both adults also slowly forget about their bad start and things get a little mushy near the end though a running gag involving the ample bosom of a fellow resort guest is firm reminder that Blended may be marketed primarily as a family and date movie, but it never really leaves Sandler's signature bad taste territory.

C+

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Latam Airlines threatened by strike just before World Cup

Published

Thu, Jun 5, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SANTIAGO, Chile] Maintenance workers for Latam Airlines have threatened to delay or cancel flights throughout South America in support of a strike by Peruvian colleagues in the days ahead of the World Cup.

Latam workers in countries where the airline operates were handing out flyers to passengers to warn them of disruptions, Dario Castillo, president of the union of maintenance workers for LAN Chile, told Reuters on Wednesday. "We are going to support our Peruvian colleagues with flight delays and cancellations and that applies to the whole Latam network," Mr Castillo said.

The World Cup kicks off next Thursday, with Brazil expecting one of the biggest influxes of tourists it has ever seen.

Latam Airlines was formed in a merger of Chile's LAN and Brazil's TAM in 2012. Latam, the region's biggest airline, has operations in Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Ecuador, Paraguay and Peru.

Aircraft maintenance workers from LAN Peru have threatened strike action over demands for better pay, after negotiations with the airline broke down last week.

A union leader in Lima, Freddy Nakashima, said that around 250 to 300 technicians would go on strike in Peru, an action which he said would paralyse the country's network.

No date has been decided yet, but the aim would be to hold a strike when it would affect the World Cup in order to apply pressure, Mr Nakashima, said, adding that the strike would go ahead even if approval from the Labour Ministry was not received.

Union members posted photos on Facebook on Wednesday showing them handing out leaflets at Buenos Aires' Ezeiza airport. The union said in an open letter that there would be delays "in upcoming days" but did not give specifics.

Latam Airlines declined to comment. - Reuters

site_title: Adult film spoof caught with pants down
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Adult film spoof caught with pants down

Dylan Tan

Published

Thu, Jun 5, 2014 · 10:00 PM

FOR obvious reasons, the sex comedy tends to be a lucrative genre and ever since it made a comeback in Hong Kong cinema with a 3D reboot of the Sex and Zen franchise, filmmakers there have been steadily churning out similar skin flicks.

The latest is 3D Naked Ambition, a loose sequel to the 2003 raunch-fest that starred Louis Koo and Eason Chan. Directed by Lee Kung Lo, it is already one of the highest-grossing films in Hong Kong this year, collecting HK$18 million (S$3 million) at the box office.

Like the original film, the adult entertainment industry is once again spoofed but the focus this time shifts from soft-porn magazines to adult films instead. As an added bonus, six real-life Japanese female porn stars - Anri Okita, Maiko Yuki, Kana Yume, Nozomi Aso, Tsukasa Aoi and Yui Tatsum - have cameos (by that, it just means they drop their clothes on-screen).

The always-versatile and funny Chapman To plays Wyman, a freelance writer who loses his gig writing erotica for a newspaper. A visit to the set of an adult film shoot while on holiday in Tokyo, however, leads to him standing in for a disgruntled actor who leaves in a huff.

When news of that eventually reaches Hong Kong, Wyman turns into an overnight Internet sensation. He relocates to Japan where he turns into full-time porn star Mario Ozawa (a play on popular Japanese adult video star Maria Ozawa's name), and is managed by Cuzuki Hatoyama (Josie Ho), an acquaintance who has a little history of her own. Wyman's reign, however, is threatened when cocky newcomer Nagasaki Naoki (Louis Koo) appears on the scene.

Written by Chan Hing Ka, whose screenwriting credits include A Better Tomorrow, 3D Naked Ambition, as one would expect, titillates and stimulates its audience everywhere except their brain cells.

Chapman To hamming it up as the accidental porn star who lets things get to his head is about the best thing about the film; next to the parodies of porn films with their ridiculous plots that typically involve crowded public transport and hot female teachers pandering to male fantasies. Too bad the novelty doesn't last and a hurried climax that exposes the plot's lack of ideas leaves 3D Naked Ambition with its pants down.

C+

site_title: A must-watch for art lovers and Rothko fans
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

A must-watch for art lovers and Rothko fans

Published

Thu, Jun 5, 2014 · 10:00 PM

DISCUSSING abstract art with an art lecturer and learning how to prime and stretch canvasses were some of the preparations for the production of Red, a play about the legendary abstract expressionist painter Mark Rothko.

"I'm sure quite a few artists will be watching the play; we wouldn't want them to think the actors are holding the brush wrong," quips Samantha Scott- Blackhall, founder of Blank Space Theatre and director of American playwright John Logan's Red, which the company is producing.

The Esplanade Theatre's curator Tamares Goh also taught the actors how to appreciate Rothko's painting techniques, and will make sure they portray artists accurately. Red, after all, is an insightful play about a mid-20th century artist who made the headlines when he was commissioned to paint a series of murals for New York's famed Four Seasons restaurant.

Rothko took two years to work on the commission, then the highest in modern art history, with a young assistant, Ken, in his studio in New York City.

Scott-Blackhall explains that she was drawn to the play because she's a fan of biopics. "I am intrigued by the events that made the person who he or she was - the challenges, the victories and the stories no one even knew about."

Logan's play about Rothko covers a very specific period of his life (1958-1959) which many people say informed the next 10 years of his life until his eventual suicide.

"Besides the challenge of presenting a man as iconic as Rothko, the actors have quite a meaty script to juggle. The dialogue between Rothko and his assistant Ken delves into the history of art, American politics in the 1950s, the culture of a changing and modernising world, the importance of documenting and respecting history, philosophy and how it informs the creating of art," she notes.

Red was the winner of the 2010 Tony Award for Best Play; it made its debut at the Donmar Warehouse in London in 2009.

"The actors and I researched all factual references in the script in order to give meaning and further contextualise through body language and tone for the audience. You can't just say a line without knowing what it means," elaborates Scott-Blackhall.

The play has only two characters - Rothko and his assistant - played by Daniel Jenkins and Gavin Yap respectively.

As to whether the play is timely, given the rise in visual arts fairs and art investment in Singapore, actor Yap notes that "any play that deals with art, the importance of art and is able to educate as well as entertain is a play for the times".

Yap, who was last seen in Wild Rice's The Importance of Being Earnest and Pangdemonium's Fat Pig, adds: "I also feel that we're at a similar crossroads as Rothko was. The 1950s in America was when consumerism was really taking shape after the Second World War and this was also the time when TV and pop art entered the fray. For Rothko, this was all very disposable, nothing he would classify as art.

"And now, the idea of art and celebrity is even more saturated. As someone who grew up without the Internet and reality television, I completely relate to Rothko's frustrations with the way the world was changing around him because it's not at all far removed from how I feel about, say, The Kardashians."

Red is a must-watch for art lovers and Rothko fans (and perhaps even detractors). Scott-Blackhall says that the artist's Bowery Street Studio will be re-created on stage, and there is also a lot of actual painting that takes place on stage.

"Rothko and Ken are constantly priming canvases, mixing paints and, at one very dynamic point in the play, they fully paint a six foot square canvas with red paint in less than two minutes! It is very exciting to watch!" she declares.

What she and the two actors will be doing is to create a "space" and "atmosphere" that invite the viewer into the world of the painting, and Rothko's own relationship to art as well.

'Red' by Blank Space Theatre is part of The Esplanade's The Studios season, and will run from July 10-13. For tickets of $28, go to

www.sistic.com.sg

Company Briefs

Published

Thu, Jun 5, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Innopac to report larger loss for FY2013

INNOPAC Holdings will report a larger loss in its audited group financial statements for FY2013 than was previously reported in preliminary results released in February, mainly due to additional provision for a derivative receivable transaction subsequent to the preliminary results. The group's loss will increase by about $34 million from that previously reported. The company said: "This provision will be written back if the obligations of the counterparty are fulfilled, and the company's profit will correspondingly increase by this amount." It earlier reported a net loss of $20.8 million for the year ended Dec 31, 2013.

ES Group's subsidiary wins orders worth $17m

A WHOLLY-OWNED subsidiary of ES Group has been awarded repeat orders for jack-up drilling rig blocks worth about $17 million from a major shipyard in Singapore, the group said yesterday. The jack-up blocks, part of a jack-up rig's main hull, are expected to be delivered next year. ES Group said the order is expected to contribute to its financial performance for the second half of the financial year ending Dec 31, and for the following financial year.

No change to constituents of STI following review

THE constituents of the Straits Times Index (STI) will remain unchanged following a quarterly review. Its reserve list comprising the five highest-ranking non-constituents by market capitalisation will be Keppel Land, UOL Group, CapitaCommercial Trust, Suntec Reit and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding. Companies in the reserve list will replace constituents that become ineligible as a result of corporate actions before the next review.

Centurion's associate company buys land

CENTURION Corporation said it has set up an associated company in Malaysia known as Oriental Amber Sdn Bhd, of which it owns 49 per cent. The associate yesterday entered into a sale-and-purchase agreement to acquire, in cash, a 7.6-acre freehold plot in Johor Baru for RM11.7 million (S$4.6 million). No valuation was done of the land.

China New Town sells land parcel

CHINA New Town Development said it has auctioned the land use right of a plot of land in the Shanghai Luodian new town project for 124.5 million yuan (S$25 million) or 8,860 yuan per sq m. The buyer is Shanghai Ruilong Investment Co Ltd, a subsidiary of Powerlong Real Estate Holdings in China. China New Town holds a 72.6 per cent stake in the Luodian project joint venture company.

GKE assessing impact of Qingdao port probe

A PROBE by the authorities in the Chinese port of Qingdao may affect GKE Corporation's business, the logistics service provider said on Wednesday. The probe has halted shipments of aluminium and copper. GKE Corporation said that it is assessing the potential impact on its subsidiary, GKE (Shanghai) Metal Logistics, which engages in metal logistics in China.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Miclyn Express eyeing SGX listing in 2-3 years

Delisted from ASX, it wants to tap the greater liquidity and keener interest here

Published

Thu, Jun 5, 2014 · 10:00 PM

SINGAPORE-BASED Miclyn Express Offshore (MEO), which delisted from the Australian Securities Exchange (ASX) last December, is eyeing a listing on Singapore Exchange (SGX) in the next two to three years.

Its chief executive, Diederik de Boer, said the provider of offshore-service vessels is looking to tap into greater liquidity and keener interest in the sector here.

"There is bigger retail investor interest in Singapore than in Australia, so SGX is perfect for our (company) size," he told The Business Times.

The 35-year industry veteran added that the conditions for listing here were favourable, given that SGX is trying to position itself as a capital-markets hub for offshore and marine stocks.

The recent listings of PACC Offshore Services Holdings, Pacific Radiance and Kim Heng Offshore & Marine are, to him, encouraging signs of investor interest in such stocks, he said, and noted that Pacific Radiance was about the same size as MEO.

MEO now has a fleet of about 135 vessels operating in South-east Asia, the Middle East and Australia, where it was listed until the end of last year with a market capitalisation of US$700 million.

Macquarie Capital, the investment-banking arm of Macquarie Group, had sold its majority stake in MEO to two private-equity firms - Champ Marlin Holdings and SEA6 Limited, a subsidiary of Hong Kong's Headland Capital Partners - prompting its exit from its public listing Down Under last Dec 17.

Mr de Boer pointed out that the two private-equity firms are likely to seek an exit from MEO in the next two to three years, at which point the company is likely to seek a listing on SGX.

He added that it was possible that MEO's private-equity owners may also look at a trade sale to exit, so it was difficult to say conclusively for now.

MEO improved its cash balances this year by selling its Batam shipyard to ASL Marine Holdings for US$20 million; the yard was deemed a part of its non-core business and had resulted in the group's overhead reduction, it said in its first half-year financial results in March.

For those first six months of its financial year, MEO recorded significant improvement in its operating cash flow over that of the corresponding period last year; some of that came from a refinancing of its loan package and a $200 million bond raising.

With deeper pockets, MEO acquired the remaining 30 per cent of shares from minority shareholders in its growth business, Express Offshore Solutions.

Mr de Boer disclosed that MEO will leverage its stronger cash position to buy new vessels, which it will deploy in South-east Asia and in the Middle East.

A strong balance sheet and an expanding core-business growth will tee up MEO for an eventual listing here - if and when it does happen.

site_title: A Little Talk about cityscapes
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

A Little Talk about cityscapes

Published

Thu, Jun 5, 2014 · 10:00 PM

WHEN she graduated from university with a degree in advertising, design and fine art, Jieun Park did what any filial Asian child would do - she honoured her parents' wishes and took on a "stable, corporate job" at a design company.

"My parents were strict and objected to my wanting a career as an artist," says Park, who was born in South Korea.

"But I found that I could not let go of the brush in my hands. I would constantly paint into the late hours or during weekends, until later I realised I loved the feeling of accomplishment whenever I finished a painting. So I guess working at that company just made me realise how passionate I've always been about art," she adds.

After working for a couple of years, Park decided to quit her job and embarked on a career as a full-time artist - a gamble that seems to have paid off so far.

In fact, not long after leaving her job, she did a solo exhibition in Seoul in January 2013, and quickly followed up with one in Hong Kong later that year.

She has also taken part in group exhibitions in countries like France, Italy and New Caledonia.

And next week, the artist's exhibition A Little Talk will be on display here in Singapore at the REDSEA Gallery, with a collection of up to 30 paintings priced from $4,000 to $18,000.

This series of work showcases various cityscapes painted into calligraphy characters, and is somewhat a record of the cities that Park has travelled to such as Paris, Prague, Florence, Hong Kong, Seoul and most recently, Singapore.

She explains: "I like to express my emotions that I derive from my travels through my painting. Each time I travel, yes I feel thrilled and excited, but at the same time, I am lonely. I feel a loneliness lingering in these cities. I want to express these contrasting emotions in my work, hence, one is able to spot this contrast of black and white, Western and Eastern elements that co-exist in them."

These elements Park is referring to are the colourful acrylic paints that outline the cityscapes within the calligraphic brushstrokes which are painted using black Chinese ink on layers of Korean paper.

"My inspiration comes from travelling to those cities themselves. While painting, I constantly recall my feelings and the weather and the sounds of the city. Doing so makes me very happy because it always feels like I am back there," says Park.

"What I hope is for people who look at my art to be immersed in the city I have created, instead of just experiencing them from a perspective they are already familiar with. I enjoy sharing my emotions and feelings that I get from my travels."

'A Little Talk' runs from June 12 to 29 at REDSEA Gallery at 9 Dempsey Road. Opening hours are from 9.30am to 9pm daily. Admission is free. Log on to

site_title: Watch 'The Two Towers' with live soundtrack
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Watch 'The Two Towers' with live soundtrack

Published

Thu, Jun 5, 2014 · 10:00 PM

IF you're afraid to admit the number of times you've watched The Lord of the Rings trilogy, fear not. Here's another way to indulge while raising your cultural profile.

This weekend at The Star Theatre, a special screening of The Two Towers will be accompanied by nearly 300 musicians on a stage, who will perform the entire film score live while audiences watch the show.

This is the second time such an event will take place, with the first being a similar screening of The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring last year.

That concert was also performed by Singapore's Metropolitan Festival Orchestra (MFO), and it saw an impressive attendance of over 7,000 people.

On why they decided to do part two of the show as well, Chan Tze Law, music director of MFO, says it's simply because of popular demand. "Plus, it is MFO's mission to regularly bring Singapore audiences orchestral offerings that are making waves around the world."

For this year's concert, they have once again invited American conductor Justin Freer, who also did last year's show and was keen to repeat the experience.

Prof Chan says: "I, like many around the world, became fascinated with Tolkien's stories and characters when I was a small child. I adore the musical colours and textures that Howard Shore created for The Two Towers, and of course it's impossible not to fall in love with Gandalf once again when he returns from the 'dead'."

Performing with the MFO will be vocalist Rosalind Waters, the Vocal Associates Festival Chorus, the Children's Choir and boy soprano Samuel Yuen.

It's a mean feat to be conducting such a massive score, especially for such a famous movie, admits Freer.

"It is both humbling and exhilarating. . . Due to the sheer amount of music, the vast number of tempo and meter changes and the demand of having to keep everything tightly together over the course of multiple hours, this project comes with a sense of heavy expectation," he explains.

But in the end, what he hopes to do is to give audiences a different experience of this well-loved film, and that this unique presentation format will help more people be aware of the power and impact music can have on film.

"It is our responsibility to communicate to the audience through Howard's music the myriad of emotions, thoughts and actions coming from the film. If even one person walks away from this concert with a newfound appreciation for film music as an art form, then I would have done my job well," he adds.

'The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers' will be screened today at 7.30pm and tomorrow at 1pm and 7.30pm at The Star Theatre. Tickets cost from $28 to $188. Log on to

site_title: Nepal upgrading air safety to end EU ban: official
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Nepal upgrading air safety to end EU ban: official

Published

Thu, Jun 5, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[KATHMANDU] Nepal will install new radar and weather monitoring systems to improve safety and try to get its airlines removed from an EU blacklist, a government official said.

The Himalayan nation, which counts tourism as a major revenue-earner, has suffered a number of air crashes in recent years which have usually been blamed on inexperienced pilots, poor management and bad maintenance.

In the latest accident, just weeks after the European Commission banned Nepalese airlines from flying to the European Union, all 18 people aboard died when their plane crashed into a hillside in the country's mountainous west last February.

The new radar system will be installed within three months and will be located on top of a hill south of the capital Kathmandu where it will track air movements around the country, tourism secretary Sushil Ghimire said on Wednesday.

"These efforts are directed at improving Nepal's air safety standards and get us off the EU's blacklist," said Mr Ghimire, speaking on the sidelines of an aviation conference on the outskirts of Kathmandu.

Advanced weather monitoring systems will also be set up throughout the country to provide real-time updates.

Nepal currently has only one radar system, installed over a decade ago at Kathmandu's airport.

At the time of the blacklisting last December, EU transport commissioner Siim Kallas said that the country's safety record "does not leave us any other choice". - AFP

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Dual role for S'pore in Modi's economic plan

Published Thu, Jun 5, 2014 · 10:00 PM

IT is time for newly elected Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi to put into action his promises of economic growth and reform. It is very likely that the former chief minister of Gujarat is going to turn to East Asia for help to materialise his economic strategy for India, paving the way for Singapore to revitalise its economic engagement with the country.

Mr Modi's admiration for East Asia is quite apparent. In his previous position as supremo of Gujarat, he had visited Japan, China and Singapore and declared his respect for their economic success and development. Indeed, going by his development approaches for Gujarat, he may prefer to adopt the East Asian economies' investment-led growth models, rather than, say, Thatcherism or Reaganomics.

In Asia, Japan is a natural partner, having already established a strategic relationship with India. Notably, Tokyo may well be the destination of the first official trip for the new Indian leader, who's an admirer of Abenomics. Japan, on its part, could see its growing relationship with India as another dimension in its developing strategic nexus against China in Asia. But Mr Modi has made clear that economics, and thus pragmatism, will take centre stage in his foreign-policy considerations. This is likely to frame his engagement of China. Unlike the previous Indian government, which failed to effectively balance its engagement of both Beijing and Washington, Mr Modi is likely to lean towards the growing economic might of China to help spur his country's development.

site_title: Wine as an investment - initial thoughts
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Wine as an investment - initial thoughts

NK YONG provides tips on what advice to look for and where and how to find it

Published

Thu, Jun 5, 2014 · 10:00 PM

AN OLD friend needed advice on how to manage his collection of wines which had been purchased some 10 years ago. Following our discussions it occurred to me that there may be others who may have also accumulated a sizeable collection of wines and need help and advice on how best to get the most out of that collection. This week's column attempts to provide guideposts as to what advice to look for and where and how to find it.

People who "collect" wine fall roughly into two groups. One is made up of people who did not really start off to collect wine. They began by learning to drink wine with their meals, found that they liked the taste and the combination, began to drink wine fairly often with or without their meals and in due course built up a collection of wines initially meant for personal consumption but now has assumed proportions in excess of their needs. They had bought the wines they liked or wanted to drink, then with more experience and confidence the selection became more and more eclectic, and so the collection became larger and larger. Somewhere along the line they had also learnt that buying en primeur made good sense, and their collection then began to include en primeur as well as collector's items! The result after 20 years of this pattern of buying is not difficult to imagine - a collection running into thousands of bottles!

The other class of wine investor is the true-blue investor, who sets out to build a portfolio of wines in place of stocks and shares. He has heard that wine gives good yields, even better than stocks and shares, and that you never lose because if the wine goes down in price, you can always drink it rather than sell it at a loss - something you cannot do with stocks and shares! It also confers a sort of status symbol to be able to claim that you also invested in wine. Someone like him does not need this column.

Whichever way one starts, there are some fundamentals to distinguish wines from stocks and shares.

Just as in the stock market so it is with the wine market. The most important first thing to learn is WHAT to buy - and, more importantly, WHAT NOT TO BUY. Just as in the stock market, what are the fundamentals? The wine-lover turned wine collector (Group A) looks at this question from a different viewpoint than the pure investor in wine (Group B) whose fundamentals are very, very different.

The wine lover-cum-collector (Group A) does not bother too much about dry uninteresting facts such as yields, and investment potential. He buys what he wants and likes to drink; he may decide to buy them young or even en primeur so that they can be brought to full maturity under his care. He will then have the satisfaction that these wines cost him a fraction of what he would have had to pay were he to buy the mature items on the current market. That is his profit! The priceless and supreme advantage is that his wine has been properly looked-after, and thus has been able to achieve its maximum potential. If by selling a part of his collection he is able to buy the wines he has been eyeing for some time, for example Romanee-Conti, but has not hitherto been able to afford, that is a huge plus from his wine hobby for him.

The wine investor (Group B) works on a totally different basis. He is cold-blooded about wines. They are just investment vehicles. He studies the market. He sees which wines appreciate the most and the least, which are red-hot wines everyone is looking for and hence command premium prices. He takes note of each country's stock markets, and economies, knowing full well that they will impinge on wine consumption and wine investments. There are companies which specialise in wine investments, who not only advise but also are able to secure allocations of the most sought-after en primeur releases, for example Romanee-Conti, Chateau Petrus, Lafite, Latour, etc for their clients as part of a fee for service system. They provide a full investment service, advising, assisting clients to procure wines for their wine portfolios in much the same way as other companies provide stock-market portfolio management for their clients.

With such wine investment services so readily available on a fee for service basis, does the wine investment client need to do any work himself? Can he leave it all in the hands of his wine investment adviser? Which is where this column comes in.

I hold the view that an investor, whatever the vehicle he chooses to use, has the responsibility (to himself if to no one else) to learn as much as is within his grasp about what he is investing in. No doubt that the investment service he has engaged to advise and look after his investment has the duty to give him the best possible advice. Notwithstanding that this contractual undertaking exists, it would be sensible for the investor to learn and understand the nuts and bolts of his investments.

Not only is there a need to know what the investment items are, in this case where wine is the vehicle of the investments, the issue of the quality of storage conditions of the wine is a matter of the greatest concern. In simple language, investor must be assured that his assets are properly stored, and in view of the fact that they are fine wines, certain optimum conditions apply.

I guess I have something of a compulsive-obsessive nature. Whatever my stock of fine wines, I would want to know: (a) the full list of wines; (b) where they are stored; (c) the physical conditions under which they are stored - that is, (i) where is the store, (ii) are the bottles stored lying on their sides, in darkness except when it is necessary to inspect them; (iii) are they subject to vibrations, from example from proximity of the warehouse to a railway line; (iv) what is the ambient temperature of the store where the wines are; (v) what is the ambient humidity? I would expect my wines to be stored lying down in the dark (except on the occasions when it is necessary to inspect or identify them), in a vibration-free environment at 12 degrees centigrade, or better still at 10° C; and at maximum of 70 per cent relative humidity.

The above are minimum services I would expect from a commercial wine investment service or consultant. The bottom line is this: If one does not take the trouble to understand what one should expect for a fee-for-service wine investment consultant one has to share responsibility for any mishaps or shortfalls that may befall your wine investment.

Around Town

Published

Thu, Jun 5, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Pick of the Week

Summer Lotus Pond:

Presented by famed Shandong painter Lu Dong, who is renowned for his lotus works, Summer Lotus Pond combines both vivid colours and detailed sketches. The exhibition features more than 35 paintings that portray a lotus pond during the four seasons.

Lu, who describes the lotus' image as almost perfect, chooses to return the lotus to its natural habitat in his works, highlighting the tranquillity of the pond's ecosystem. He views his works as performances; the pieces have both vibrant colours and mystical atmospheres. He has a personalised, distinctive way of painting the lotus, with a good balance of colour, composition and oriental details.

Lu uses mainly ink paint as his medium, and calls his work "not traditionally meticulous", but as spiritual and rich, and even contemporary. He believes that the artist's feelings and thoughts are the basis of innovation, and that the value of the art depends on them. Summer Lotus Pond is his representation of that belief, natural, spiritual, and lively.

'Summer Lotus Pond' will run from tomorrow till June 29 at The Riverwalk. The exhibition is open on Saturdays and Sundays from 11am to 6pm. Admission is free

>Exhibition

On the Wings of a Jabiru:

Named after the Australian Jabiru, this exhibition by Australian artist Sobrane Simcock features 30 artworks, focusing on native Australian birds and presented in inks and pastels. Join Simcock on a visual voyage of exploration and freedom through her depiction of each bird and their stories. Capturing the essence of nature in her work is what Simcock is famous for, gathering inspiration from all walks of nature in Australia, and she shares this in her new exhibition.

'On the Wings of a Jabiru' runs till June 26, at 7Adam Gallery Restaurant. The exhibition is open from 11am to 8pm daily. For more information log on to

www.7adam.com

The Autumn Rain is Coming:

Feng Lumin captures fleeting youth and existence in his childhood series The Autumn Rain is Coming. Here, Feng portrays children in more agrarian areas, riding bicycles, smiling or with bravado expressions. Taking care not to overly focus on the effects of China's economic ascent, his paintings seek to speak about modernity and progress by focusing on the optimism that radiates from the smiles of the children who, to him, represent hope for the future as well as a longing for the nostalgic past.

'The Autumn Rain is Coming' will run till July 31 at Art Retreat inc Wu Guanzhong Museum, from Tuesdays to Saturdays at 11am to 5pm. For more information log on to

olivingallery.com

Panorama - An Artistic Journey:

Presented by Galerie Belvedere, Panorama: An Artistic Journey presents a series of works from 18 international contemporary painters and sculptors hailing from North America, Europe and Asia.

The wide variety of works includes contemporary realist paintings, contemporary Indian art, and abstract paintings. The exhibition will feature the works of British artist Sacha Jafri, Filipino artist Lydia Velasco and Canadian painter Rene Lemay.

'Panorama: An Artistic Journey' will run till June 30 at Galerie Belvedere, from Mondays to Fridays at 11am to 7pm and Saturdays and Sundays at 12pm to 5pm. For more information log on to

www.galerie-belvedere.com

>Performance

l'Academie de Danse 2014 Year End Performance:

l'Academie de Danse presents its annual year-end recital, a grand display of all the work and commitment put in by the students and instructors during the school year. Ballet lovers will enjoy the performance put on by the only French ballet school in Singapore. The academy has more than 250 students from the international community, and was established by Maud Toledano in 2007. It is currently led by Jonathan Guillarme.

'l'Academie de Danse 2014 Year End Performance' will be held on June 8 at University Cultural Centre Theatre, NUS. Performances will be at 3pm and 5pm. Tickets cost $28 and $35, and can be purchased via Sistic

>Talk

A Day With The Wolf of Wall Street:

Spend a day with "The Wolf of Wall Street", Jordan Belfort himself, as he talks about his "Straight Line System", a set of guidelines on how to navigate sales conversations and close deals. Belfort discusses both his failures and successes and shares his experiences with the audience. The seminar will cover topics that show you how to create instant rapport, to condition your mental state and to build a case for buying that's elegant and effective.

'A Day with The Wolf of Wall Street' will be held on June 8 at Garnet Rooms, Max Atria at Singapore Expo. The talk begins at 2pm. Tickets are available at Sistic at $188, $268 and $388

site_title: China's metal financing probe rattles lenders
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

China's metal financing probe rattles lenders

The same cargo of metal at Qingdao could be used many times as collateral

Published

Thu, Jun 5, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SHANGHAI] Global trading houses and banks were scrambling to check on their exposure to a probe into metal financing at China's Qingdao port, as concerns grow that a crackdown on commodity financing could hit trade in the world's top metal buyer.

The investigation at the world's seventh largest port is looking into whether single cargoes of metal were used multiple times to obtain financing, according to industry sources.

This means different banks and trading houses were holding separate titles for the same metal.

The inquiry has revived concerns about the impact of China's deepening credit crisis on its metal imports, much of which piles up in warehouses to be used as collateral.

"Now the banks are all flying down to the port and literally, together with the warehouse people and the traders, are physically counting the stocks," said a source at a global trading company who visited the port this week.

"When we were there, we did hear a couple of traders holding the same title. One was saying that one (cargo) belongs to him, another trader said it belongs to him. They had the same document."

Standard Chartered yesterday became the latest to say it was monitoring the situation at Qingdao.

Standard Bank Group and a part-owned unit of Louis Dreyfus Corp, Singapore-listed GKE Corp, also warned on Wednesday of potential losses.

A spokesman for Trafigura said this week that the trading house was following events at the port and gathering information.

Another major player, Glencore, which also uses the port, declined to comment earlier this week.

Copper prices in London fell to their lowest in more than three weeks on Wednesday, partly due to worries over the probe, though prices steadied yesterday.

On Wednesday, Standard Bank said that it had started an investigation into potential irregularities at Qingdao port.

The bank, whose Standard Bank subsidiary conducts commodities trading, was responding to media enquiries relating to concerns over stocks of metal held in bonded warehouses at the port. "Standard Bank Group is not yet in a position to quantify any potential loss arising from these circumstances," it said.

The bank said that it will work with the local authorities as part of its investigations.

Authorities at the port in north-east China have not officially confirmed an investigation, and have said that exports and operations are running normally.

But Xinhua news agency reported that the port had said that it was investigating whether iron ore warehouse receipts were fraudulently used multiple times to raise finance from different banks.

Trading and warehousing sources also told Reuters some shipments of copper and aluminium into the port had been disrupted, relating to an investigation into the use of metal as collateral in financing.

Traders estimated 80,000 tonnes of aluminium and 20,000-45,0000 tonnes of copper with a combined value of US$285-460 million could be affected by the investigation.

According to traders and warehousing sources, port authorities at Qingdao's Dagang wharfs have been examining whether there had been multiple issuing of receipts for single cargoes of metal tied to a trading company and linked companies.

Logistics provider GKE Corp warned shareholders on Wednesday that the investigation by port authorities might affect the business of a metals logistics unit in China.

"The company is currently assessing the potential impact of the investigation on the business," GKE said. - Reuters

site_title: Hunt for higher CPF yields entails trade-offs, risks
content:
Hunt for higher CPF yields entails trade-offs, risks

There are complex issues to be considered, say specialists

Published

Thu, Jun 5, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Raising the returns on the Central Provident Fund (CPF) may seem the most desirable and direct way to secure a decent retirement for the country's rapidly ageing population. But doing so is far from straightforward.

Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said last week that results of a review of the CPF system will be shared in August, during a parliamentary debate which saw at least eight Members of Parliament rise to urge changes to the CPF. Online, debates over the CPF also persist.

Even after setting aside tricky issues such as separating home ownership from the CPF - which would hit the property market, hiking employers' contribution rates further - which would add to high business costs, or forcing Singaporeans to save more, the demands for better CPF returns still require a sober assessment of risk-return trade-offs, pensions researchers and economists said.

CPF savings are currently invested in risk-free Special Singapore Government Securities (SSGS) that are not traded and pay a coupon rate equal to the CPF interest rates, which are pegged to market rates of risk-free assets. As interest rates have remained low, the CPF interest rates sit at the legislated minimum of 2.5 per cent on Ordinary Account (OA) savings and 4 per cent on Special Account (SA) savings.

Obtaining higher returns would mean venturing beyond the safety of SSGS, with all the attendant implications.

"The decision to invest the public, specifically the average citizen's, money into riskier assets, is a contentious one. Fact is, implicit acceptance of downside by average citizens for a statutory board's investment decision cannot and should not be assumed. So the default position is that the government will have to hunt for higher yields, while standing ready to absorb (losses)," said Mizuho Bank economist Vishnu Varathan.

Benedict Koh, Singapore Management University finance professor and director of the Centre for Silver Security, thinks the government should not offer artificially high, guaranteed returns which it cannot consistently earn from the financial market. "If they try to do so, they must take unusually high risk. If there are investment losses, they may need to balance the books by either raising taxes or draw down on reserves," he said.

There is also the issue of clarity - a formula pegged to riskier returns has to hedge against bad years, said Walter Theseira, who has served as a short-term consultant with the World Bank's Social Protection Team. Prof Theseira, also an assistant professor of economics at Nanyang Technological University, said: "The current formula for all its issues is well understood. In some countries, pension benefits are set and reviewed by politicians regularly. But this means that the value of benefits can fluctuate depending on politics - so it doesn't guarantee retirees a more stable income than a system where benefits are determined by a market-based formula, as in Singapore."

Going into riskier assets will weaken that very guarantee. "If you take on more risks, you can expect a higher return, but there is no guarantee of a higher return," said Joseph Cherian, director, Centre for Asset Management Research and Investments, NUS Business School.

Instead, he proposes that the government issue inflation-indexed bonds, which CPF funds can then be invested in.

This idea seemed to have been shelved last July, when the Monetary Authority of Singapore said that it would not issue such bonds, which are based on expected inflation. Investors would be worse off than if they had bought a plain vanilla bond, should inflation fall under expectations, MAS said. It also deemed the premiums - estimated at 10 cents a dollar for a three-year bond, in the current low interest rate environment - to be too high for investors.

Prof Cherian thinks otherwise. "There will come a time when the cost of bonds is cheaper." But he understands the government's reluctance. "Much of Singapore's inflation is imported, so if they cannot fully control the cost of goods, to deliver the yield they would have to find resources through taxation and reserves."

With headline inflation in recent years skewed upwards by housing and car prices, he believes that a more accurate gauge of the average Singaporean's cost of living is the MAS core inflation rate. That was 1.7 per cent last year - both the OA and SA's floor rates of 2 and 4 per cent were higher.

Mr Varathan, who also thinks inflation-linked bonds are worth considering, pointed out that if interest rates pick up in the coming years, CPF rates can be expected to rise - just as the high 6.5 per cent CPF interest rate of the 1970s and early 1980s was driven by higher global interest rates.

One way to raise returns but have members bear their own risks could be to further liberalise the CPF Investment Scheme. But history does not bode well for CPF members taking their savings into their own hands. Of those who invested OA funds via the CPF Investment Scheme between 2004 and 2013, 47 per cent incurred losses and 35 per cent could not beat the guaranteed OA interest rate of 2.5 per cent. Only 18 per cent reaped gains of more than the OA rate.

Prof Koh suggested that CPF offer more "default investment options" - inflation-indexed bonds, life cycle funds or other passive, low-cost, diversified portfolios - to members who lack the financial knowledge to take risks with their savings.

Bank of America Merrill Lynch economist Chua Hak Bin's suggestion, also to reap economies of scale, is for CPF to offer members the option to invest directly into a GIC or Temasek-managed fund, leveraging on the two sovereign wealth funds' experience and capabilities. But he thinks that should be restricted to CPF members with savings above a certain threshold, which may not achieve the aim of raising returns for those most in need of retirement security.

CPF debate must reflect policy realities

It is necessary to manage a web of policy goals and trade-offs

Published Thu, Jun 5, 2014 · 10:00 PM

IT'S not too difficult, looking at how the Central Provident Fund (CPF) system has evolved over the decades, to conclude that some of the central issues it faces today resulted from past policy-making. That may even be the correct conclusion, too.

What is important, however, is to place those policies in context, and to see them for what they are - responses to the policy questions of their time.

Such perspective is important, if the current debate on the CPF is to be one that is cognisant of the complexity of the present issues.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Australia investigating possible MH370 witness account

Published

Wed, Jun 4, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SYDNEY] Australia was yesterday investigating an account from a sailor who said she may have seen Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 on fire, as officials said the hunt for the plane could involve diving into much deeper waters.

The Australian Transport Safety Bureau (ATSB), which is leading the search at the request of the Malaysian government, is looking at the claim a British yachtswoman made this week.

"The ATSB received ... a message from a member of the public, reporting that they had seen what they believed to be a burning aircraft in the sky above the Indian Ocean on the night of the disappearance of MH370," a spokesman said.

"That information has been forwarded to the ATSB's MH370 Search Strategy Working Group for review."

Flight MH370, which was en route from Kuala Lumpur to the Chinese capital Beijing when it was inexplicably diverted, is believed to have crashed in the southern Indian Ocean.

An extensive search for the plane, which vanished on March 8 with 239 people on board, has so far found nothing. Search efforts included an intensive underwater hunt with a mini-sub that could dive to 4,500 metres.

British yachtswoman Katherine Tee added to speculation about the location of a possible crash site by revealing that she saw a glowing plane over the Indian Ocean in March.

The 41-year-old said she told Australian authorities of her sighting of a plane with "what appeared to be a tail of black smoke coming from behind it" while she travelled from Kochi in India to Phuket in Thailand.

"There were two other planes passing higher than it - moving the other way - at that time," she wrote on sailing site Cruisers Forum, a firm for which she also works.

"I recall thinking that if it was a plane on fire that I was seeing, the other aircraft would report it." She said she told no one at the time because she and her husband, who was onboard but asleep, had been having difficulties and had not spoken for about a week.

"And most of all, I wasn't sure of what I saw," she said. "I couldn't believe it myself." But after confirming her yacht's position using GPS data in recent days, she said she knew she was in the "right place at the right time" and told the authorities.

MH370's last known position, as tracked by military radar, was roughly west of Phuket, although the search area has focused on a zone hundreds of kilometres further south. - AFP

site_title: Masks hide faces, but plight still grim
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Masks hide faces, but plight still grim

Leading Cambodian artist Khvay Samnang highlights the issues confronting a building's dwellers through his photos. By HELMI YUSOF

Published

Thu, Jun 5, 2014 · 10:00 PM

KHVAY Samnang is one of Cambodia's most prominent artists who's frequently invited to show his works at international art events including the Singapore Biennale.

But like many Cambodian artists, he is cautious when talking about his art, for fear of government reprisals should his art be deemed anti-government.

His photo exhibition titled Human Nature at Tomio Koyama Gallery embodies that fear.

From a distance, these photographs appear ordinary, with various people of different ages being shot in their own homes. Yet each one of these men, women and children wear a peculiar mask with minimal features, appearing almost alien in their home environments.

Samnang explains: "These people are afraid to speak up. They're afraid to express their worries of being resettled by the government. So the only way most of them would allow me to photograph them was if I let them wear a mask."

Samnang made dozens of masks out of cloth and papier mache and let his subjects choose which ones they liked to wear, so that, "at least, some aspect of their individuality comes through," he says.

The subjects of these photographs live in what's known as the White Building on the busy Sothearos Boulevard in Phnom Penh.

In 1963, the government housing project was erected and hailed for its "Corbusier-inspired architecture". The building sat close to a national theatre and public gardens, and provided social housing for artists, cultural workers and civil servants.

When the brutal Khmer Rouge took over the country, much of these facilities were destroyed. About 90 per cent of artists were either killed or exiled. The remaining 10 per cent continue to live in the White Building, which has since fallen into grave disrepair.

The building - once the pride of the arts community - is now notorious for dangerous and unsavoury activities, even though it continues to house about 2,500 people.

Samnang says: "The artists and other residents of the building want to renovate or repair the exterior, but the government won't allow it. Meanwhile, private developers are trying to move people out with offers of compensation - but the money is too little to buy another place in the city."

According to Samnang, the Human Nature series was conceived as a way to document these homes and inhabitants before the seemingly inevitable destruction. The masks the subjects wear, with their anodyne features, are grim symbols of their powerlessness against the march of development.

Since the mid-2000s, Samnang has focused much of his practice on concerns over the impact of change and urbanisation on Cambodians.

His works, with their trenchant political messages, have caught the attention of many curators, critics and collectors.

His five-channel video work at the Singapore Biennale, for instance, was lauded by the local press. It showed him standing at five different locations and pouring one bucket of sand after another on himself.

He made the work as a statement against the way his government allowed various lakes to be filled with sand so that the area could be sold to developers. Meanwhile, thousands of families who rely on the lakes for their daily water needs suffer the consequences.

Samnang adds: "I make art for people who are affected by these changes but don't know how to speak up, or don't think they have the right to speak up. I want to show the world what they need, and what they've lost."

RBS tightens home loans, following Lloyds example

Income-based limits on mortgages, term capped at 30 years

Published

Wed, Jun 4, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[LONDON] Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) has followed rival Lloyds Banking Group in placing restrictions on mortgage lending to tackle rising British house prices.

RBS, which is 81 per cent owned by the British government, will introduce a four times loan-to- income cap and maximum term of 30 years for all mortgages worth £500,000 (S$1.05 million) or more, according to sources familiar with the matter.

The move is designed to be an extra safeguard on top of the affordability checks RBS already has in place.

"We are focused on looking after the interests of our customers and ensuring that they only take on mortgage lending that they can afford," the bank said on Tuesday.

Britain's house prices rose at their fastest annual pace in nearly seven years last month, fanning concerns that the property market could be overheating.

Bank of England governor Mark Carney has singled out the housing market as the biggest threat to Britain's economic recovery and the European Commission has said the government should consider scaling back its "Help to Buy" mortgage scheme.

On Tuesday, RBS reiterated its support for the scheme, which provides guarantees for mortgages worth up to 95 per cent of the value of a property.

The bank has only a 9 per cent share of the mortgage market in London, where house prices have risen the most, and one of the sources said the move will affect only about 2.6 per cent of the bank's lending in the capital. - Reuters

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Tanker carrying disputed Kurd crude turns back

Published

Tue, Jun 3, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[DUBAI] An oil tanker shipping crude from Iraq's semi-autonomous Kurdish region turned back after getting almost 200 miles across the Atlantic Ocean, amid a challenge over the shipment's legality.

The United Leadership, able to haul one million barrels, signalled that it was about five miles off Mohammedia in Morocco at about 6 pm local time on Tuesday, according to information entered by the ship's crew and captured by Coulsdon, England-based IHS Maritime.

It turned back on May 30 after getting about 190 miles west of Gibraltar, at which point it was sailing to the US Gulf. The shipment is illegal, SOMO, Iraq's oil marketing company, said on Tuesday.

The tanker "has arrived at its destination", Kurdish news website Rudaw reported late on Tuesday, citing Safeen Dizayee, a spokesman for the Kurdistan Regional Government (KRG). Rudaw didn't specify the destination.

"There will be a lot of attention focused on where that tanker heads because it is potentially a milestone, the first cargo," Richard Mallinson, an analyst at Energy Aspects Ltd in London, said by phone.

"That would discourage any potential buyers. It may also limit the Kurds' options, it may force them to accept discounts on the price that they can sell for," Mr Mallinson added.

Three calls to the Kurdish Regional Government's natural resources ministry weren't answered and an e-mail wasn't returned.

United Leadership is owned by Marine Management Services MC, according to a database IHS maintains for the United Nations' shipping agency. Four calls to the company's offices in Piraeus, Greece, on Tuesday weren't returned and the line went dead when Bloomberg News asked for an e-mail address for Marine Management's directors. A message to the company's generic e-mail address wasn't immediately returned.

The KRG estimates its region has about 45 billion barrels of crude reserves. Iraq itself has about 150 billion barrels. A dispute between the two sides escalated last month when the Kurds began pumping oil through their own pipeline to Ceyhan, the Turkish port in the Mediterranean sea from where ship tracking data show United Leadership loaded its cargo.

Iraq said on May 23 it sought arbitration over Kurdish oil sales at the International Chamber of Commerce.

SOMO said on June 1 that buyers should not purchase the cargo. The KRG says it's abiding by the Iraqi constitution, according to its website.

Shipping signals can be wrong because much of the information is entered manually and because not all data are captured.

"Nowadays, due to technology, it has become easy to track any shipped oil and anyone who will deal with this oil may face problems," Asim Jihad, a spokesman for Iraq's oil ministry, said on Tuesday.

Disputes about cargoes sometimes delay merchant ships. A tanker called the ETC Isis spent months marooned off Singapore in 2012 as part of a dispute between northern and southern Sudan.

Earlier this year, US special forces boarded a tanker shipping crude from eastern Libya that the nation's government said was illegally shipped. - Bloomberg

site_title: Singapore salaries last year up 5.3%: MOM report
content:
Singapore salaries last year up 5.3%: MOM report

It also reveals that more companies are adopting flexible wage measures

Published

Thu, Jun 5, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Salaries in the private sector grew 5.3 per cent on the back of a tight labour market and improved economic conditions last year, up from 4.2 per cent in 2012.

Taking into account lower inflation, real total wages rose by 2.9 per cent in 2013, after declining by 0.4 per cent in 2012, according to the latest report on wage practices released by the Ministry of Manpower's Research and Statistics Department.

As of December 2013, 77 per cent of private establishments with employees earning a monthly basic salary of up to $1,000 gave or intended to give wage increases to these employees in 2013, up from 60 per cent in 2012.

This included the 57 per cent that gave at least $60 built-in wage increase as recommended by the National Wages Council in 2013, up from the 28 per cent that gave at least $50 recommended in the preceding year.

Rank-and-file employees received a basic wage increase of 5.4 per cent, the highest in 16 years and up from 4.3 per cent in 2012. This was the first time since 2002 that the basic wage increase for the rank-and-file exceeded that of the non rank-and-file at 4.7 per cent.

DBS economist Irvin Seah said that the salary growth was in line with his expectations. "In terms of real wage growth, it is quite a significant improvement as inflation was actually higher in 2012. This reflects an improvement in productivity and a tighter labour market," he said.

Toby Fowlston, managing director of Robert Walters Singapore, said: "There has been an increased focus on hiring local talent, resulting in greater competition for this limited talent pool, especially in certain sectors with high demand. This drives wages up, but not for every industry."

The MOM report also revealed that there has been a general uptrend in the implementation of flexible wage measures. In December 2013, 86 per cent of private sector employees worked in establishments which had at least one of the flexible wage components recommended by the tripartite partners - employers, workers and government.

Having a narrow maximum-minimum salary ratio was the most common wage recommendation adopted at 63 per cent. This was followed by linking variable bonus to Key Performance Indicators (51 per cent) and having the Monthly Variable Component (34 per cent) in the wage structure.

Bonuses did not go up as much as basic wages in 2013 as the annual variable component in the private sector averaged 2.21 months of basic wage in 2013, up by 0.9 per cent from the 2.19 months in 2012. Consequently, the annual variable component formed a slightly higher share of total wages at 15.6 per cent in 2013, than the 15.4 per cent in 2012.

Cham Hui Fong, assistant secretary-general, National Trades Union Congress, said that the labour movement will continue to push for the Progressive Wage Model to be pervasive in all sectors.

"This will not only raise productivity and upgrade skills, our workers can also look forward to better wages and better career progression. We also call on employers to tap on the various funding schemes and programmes, so as to achieve higher productivity growth," she added.

Economists like Selena Ling, head, treasury research and strategy at OCBC Bank, added that the wage growth is expected to continue.

"The economic and business cycle is picking up globally, albeit at a choppy pace, and it is not unexpected that more firms are turning the corner. Real wage growth should be sustained this year, especially since inflation is subsiding. It will be very encouraging if the wage share increases over time as well," she said.

site_title: Eclectic, unexpected cinematic pleasures
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Eclectic, unexpected cinematic pleasures

The film programme for The OPEN, a pre-event of the Singapore International Festival of Arts, has some true gems. By HELMI YUSOF

Published

Thu, Jun 5, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE OPEN, a pre-event of the Singapore International Festival of Arts, starts this month and boasts an eclectic film programme of 19 films that range from the excellent to the eye-opening to the downright weird.

For a standard ticket of $45, you can watch any or all of these films, though you have to register for each title on theopen.sifa.sg because of the theatre's limited seating capacity.

Besides the films, you can also catch dozens of performances, talks and exhibitions.

But if time is scarce, BT picks out five of the best:

WEB JUNKIE

74min/Israel-USA/In Mandarin with subtitles

One teen played the Warcraft series of computer games for 300 hours, with occasional naps. Another stayed glued to his computer screen for two months. In the crazy world of computer addicts, however, sleep is not the only thing that's sacrificed. School work, diet and exercise, and, most importantly, relationships with friends and family are completely neglected. Being connected online means near-complete disconnection from reality.

Filmmakers Shosh Shlam and Hilla Medalia were interested in the phenomenon of Internet addiction and took their cameras to China where the problem is on the rise. They spent four months inside Internet detox facilities where dozens of young men and women were being treated. Many were forcibly cut off from the Internet and made to spend time with their families and other youngsters instead.

Web Junkie suggests, however, that computer addiction goes beyond the attraction of games and the Web, and that, perhaps, poor family dynamics and China's one-child policy lie at the heart of the problem.

WADJDA

100min/Saudi Arabia/In Arabic with English subtitles

Quite likely to be an audience favourite, Wadjda tells a simple but touching story of the titular girl who dreams of owning a bicycle. But she lives in Saudi Arabia, where girls are discouraged from riding bicycles just as women are not allowed to drive.

Wadjda tries to break away from the constraints placed on girls, even as she watches her mother struggle in vain against the misogyny of their society. When she realises the only way she can buy a bicycle for herself is if she wins the prize money of a Koran-reading competition, Wadjda buckles down for the fight of her young life.

Directed by Haifaa al-Mansour, the country's first and only female feature director, Wadjda won rave reviews when it premiered at the Venice Film Festival. It went on to earn numerous awards on the international festival circuit.

Ironically, it is the first film to be selected by Saudi Arabia to compete for the Best Foreign Language Film Oscar - even though director al-Mansour had to sometimes direct the film from a distance through a walkie-talkie because she could not be seen in public working with her male crew members.

HOLY MOTORS

115min/France/In French with English subtitles

This may be the strangest, most surreal, most indecipherable film you'll see this year. But it will likely appeal to hardcore cinephiles because of the astonishing way it overturns many cinematic conventions to create something quite original, lyrical and cosmic.

Dennis Lavant plays a man who appears ordinary as he bids goodbye to his kids and leaves for work. But when he steps into his chauffeur-driven limo, he puts on a costume and prosthetics. And when he steps out of the limo, he becomes an entirely different character.

From here on, the film veers wildly from being a drama to a sci-fi fantasy to a gangster flick to a musical to a drama again. Is this a study of the actor's craft, a loving tribute to cinematic genres, or a spiritual allegory of reincarnation and past lives?

It's hard to say because the film is in parts comic, in parts tragic, and in parts dull.

Its director Leo Carax was once the darling of avant garde cinema with films like Mauvais Sang (1986) and Lovers On The Bridge (1991), both starring Juliette Binoche. But he stopped making feature films in 1999 - returning only in 2012 with Holy Motors to received cheers and jeers at its Cannes premiere.

For fans of his iconoclastic style of filmmaking, however, Holy Motors is worth the wait.

VERONIQUE DOISNEAU

37min/France/In French with English subtitles

A must-watch for dance fans, Veronique Doisneau is a 37-minute documentary about ballet dancer Veronique Doisneau, who is 42, married with kids, and about to retire from the world of dancing.

Standing on a bare stage of the Paris Opera, she delivers one last performance which details the physical and emotional sacrifices she has made in her career as a dancer.

Blending a monologue with live dancing, she talks about her love of Balanchine and Petipa, and her work with Nureyev and Cunningham.

She also demonstrates moves from different dances, showing how ballet makes excruciating demands on the body and ultimately extracts a high toll.

Understated and poignant, the documentary is directed by choreographer Jerome Bel, who is presenting Disabled Theatre in September at the Singapore International Festival of Arts. The work will features dancers with mental disabilities and is one of the highlights of the festival.

WHAT NOW? REMIND ME

164min/Portugal/In Portuguese with English subtitles

A film that's not for everyone, this emotionally-draining, almost three-hour-long documentary is a film diary of Joaquim Pinto.

Pinto is a well-known sound mixer who once worked with important Portuguese directors such as Raul Ruiz and Joao Cesar Monteiro.

Struck with Hepatitis C and HIV, he takes a road trip from his home in Portugal to a clinic in Spain for a drug trial. Along the way, he shoots himself musing about mortality, and splices these monologues with images of people he loves as well as his long career in film.

The result is a work that's brave and intimate, but also hard to watch.
