site_title: What's up at the World Cup so far
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

What's up at the World Cup so far

Published

Fri, Jun 27, 2014 · 10:00 PM

WE are at the halfway mark of a quite enthralling World Cup in Brazil. All 48 group games have been completed, and the tournament is now in the crucial knockout stage. For the 16 nations still standing, there is no more room for error. The deal is simple - lose, and you're on the next plane home. There will not be any draws as all matches must produce a winner, be it in extra time or via the lottery of the dreaded penalty shoot-out.

It wasn't an easy task, but we've picked out the standout performers and talking points of the 2014 Fifa World Cup so far. This list will invariably change by the end of the tournament on July 13, but it's safe to say that these teams and players have left an indelible mark - good or bad - on The Beautiful Game.

Best team - The Netherlands

This was a tough choice, but the Dutch have certainly done enough to impress in Brazil, winning all three games in the so-called Group of Death in ruthless fashion. After a stunning 5-1 demolition of the 2010 champions Spain, Louis van Gaal's men kept up the momentum by netting another five goals past Australia and Chile.

Holland have certainly come a long way since their disgraceful show at the final in South Africa four years ago. This time, with Robin van Persie and Arjen Robben forming an irresistible partnership, the Oranje will fancy themselves to go one step further and win their first-ever World Cup trophy.

Biggest surprise - Costa Rica

If anyone had said before the tournament that tiny Costa Rica would have topped a group that included three former world champions, I would have packed them off to the nearest mental hospital right away.

The Latin Americans first shocked Uruguay 3-1, silenced Italy 1-0, and then drew with England to finish undefeated. It's an amazing achievement, and now only fellow overachiever Greece stand between them and a place in the quarter-finals.

Biggest flops - Spain

There were quite a few contenders for this dubious honour, but the nod has to go to the Spaniards. After sitting pretty at the top of international football for the last six years, they came crashing down to earth at this World Cup.

Vicente del Bosque's men never fully recovered from that humbling loss to Holland, and were outplayed for long periods against Chile. A comfortable 3-0 win over Australia in a meaningless final match only served to cover the cracks in this ageing team temporarily.

Many of the veterans will have played their last game in the famous red jersey. It's not the end of a dynasty just yet, of course, with the team looking to defend its European Championship crown in 2016.

Biggest letdown - Luis Suarez

Goodness me, where do you start with this fellow? He misses Uruguay's opening defeat to Costa Rica because of injury, comes back to score two mesmerising goals to send England out of the World Cup, and then completely loses his marbles by biting - yes, biting - the shoulder of an Italian player.

A defiant Suarez got his comeuppance. He's now banned from world football for four months. Some say he's gotten off lightly for a repeat offender. Will he ever come good and let his boots do the talking, instead of his teeth? Whichever way you look at it, this man never seems to learn.

Best goal - Tim Cahill

When Robin van Persie scored with an absurd diving header against Spain on day two of the tournament, that goal was hailed as a near-certainty to bag the goal of the tournament award.

A week later, Australia's Tim Cahill laid claim to that prize. Against the Dutch, the 34-year-old midfielder let fly with a sumptuous volley - on his weaker left foot, no less - that rattled the bar before bulging the back of the net.

Even when Cahill is 90 years old, he will still have people knocking on his door asking him to relive that moment in Porto Alegre. That audacious strike will be talked about for decades to come.

Most thrilling match - USA 2 Portugal 2

This World Cup has had its fair share of five-star matches, the likes of Germany's 2-2 draw with Ghana and France's 5-2 thumping of Switzerland immediately come to mind. But it is the United States' dramatic 2-2 draw against Portugal that is top of the pile here.

The Americans were 30 seconds away from escaping a difficult group, but Cristiano Ronaldo delivered one of the greatest crosses of the tournament for Silvestre Varela to level the scores in the 95th minute. Pure agony for the US, and an intense finish to a riveting match for everyone watching in the stands and at home.

site_title: Bombardier CSeries woes grow as engine failure halts test
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Bombardier CSeries woes grow as engine failure halts test

This is latest setback for model already plagued by delays and rising costs

Published

Sun, Jun 1, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[MONTREAL] With the debut of its newest, biggest jet already running late, the last thing Bombardier Inc needed was another problem.

One arrived anyway after an engine on the CSeries caught fire during ground tests, adding to the setbacks for a model already plagued by delays and rising development costs.

The plane, Bombardier's Flight Test Vehicle 1, also suffered damage on May 29 at the company's facility in Mirabel, Quebec, said Marc Duchesne, a spokesman.

Canada's Transportation Safety Board is gathering evidence and will decide by June 2 whether to conduct a full investigation, according to Julie Leroux, a spokeswoman.

Any time lost in flight trials would extend the struggles for a plane that Bombardier envisions producing as much as US$8 billion in annual revenue later this decade.

Orders for the plane haven't met Bombardier's target, and few major airlines have embraced a jet that the company bills as a challenger to Boeing Co and Airbus Group NV aircraft.

"This news is unlikely to help sentiment in the CSeries," Robert Stallard, an analyst at RBC Capital Markets in New York, wrote to clients on Friday.

Mr Stallard also said the incident may raise questions about the plane's new engines, the geared turbofan model from United Technologies Corp's Pratt & Whitney unit.

"We hope the investigation will proceed quickly so that we can resume flight tests as soon as possible," Mr Duchesne said.

Bombardier is being assisted in investigating the incident by Pratt & Whitney. More than 4,000 hours of engine testing have been conducted since trials began in September 2010, according to Bombardier's website.

The company has said the CSeries will cost about 15 per cent less to operate and produce less noise.

Bombardier's biggest customer for the CSeries, Republic Airways Holdings Inc, said earlier last month that it's considering whether to take the planes after a change in airline strategy.

"The whole point of 'testing' an aircraft is to find out if everything works perfectly - and then fix it before it enters service," Mr Stallard noted. "We've seen other testing issues in the past, but ultimately the issues have been addressed and the aircraft has entered operation. We expect this to be the case with the GTF," he added.

While rare, damaging engine failures during flight operations and ground trials do occur.

In August 2010, a Rolls-Royce Holdings plc Trent 1000 engine for the Boeing 787 Dreamliner suffered a blowout on a testbed in the United Kingdom. Three months later, a Trent 900 model exploded on an Airbus A380 flown by Qantas Airways Ltd.

In 2012, a Dreamliner doing high-speed taxi tests spewed debris from its General Electric Co engine, igniting a grass fire along a runway at the Charleston, South Carolina, airport near Boeing's new factory.

Bombardier is planning 2,400 hours of test flights for the CSeries.

As of May 1, the company had logged about 280 hours of flight tests, or about 12 per cent of the planned total. The FTV1 was the first CSeries prototype to fly, debuting on Sept 16.

"It is unlikely in our view that the investigation period would create another delay for the CSeries programme," said Benoit Poirier, an analyst at Desjardins Securities.

The CSeries is now targeted for a commercial debut in the second half of 2015, following Bombardier's Jan 16 announcement that more time was needed to complete flight tests. The plane is designed to seat 108 to 160 people. - Bloomberg

site_title: Digital Realty bullish about Asia-Pac
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Digital Realty bullish about Asia-Pac

It says Singapore is an important centre and the company will continue to invest here in coming years. By AMIT ROY CHOUDHURY

Published

Sun, Jun 1, 2014 · 10:00 PM

DIGITAL Realty, the world's largest provider of data centre (DC) real estate services, is benefiting from the ubiquitous growth of cloud computing in the Asia-Pacific region. Last year, Asia-Pacific's share of the company's global revenue grew to 4 per cent, up from one per cent in 2012, which was a very meaningful shift. In the first quarter of this year, more than 30 per cent of the company's incremental revenue came from Asia-Pacific.

Digital Realty doesn't compete in the area of software or hardware that make up a DC. Instead, it provides the physical infrastructure, including cooling, power and connectivity for DCs. A typical Digital Realty facility could have several DCs co-located on the premises.

A William Stein, Digital Realty's interim CEO and CFO, is bullish about the region. He told BizIT: "This is an exciting region in its nascent (growth) period now, and it has continued to evolve very rapidly. Technology shifts in the region also ensure that there are more years of growth to come in future."

A recent report by Frost & Sullivan noted that the Singapore DC market is expected to more than double from US$223 million in 2010 to US$550 million in 2017, at a compound annual growth rate of 13.8 per cent.

'Prominent pivot'

Singapore is an important centre and Mr Stein is quite definite that the company will continue to invest here in coming years. "It's been a great market for us and we continue to look at it as a prominent pivot in our global geography."

In Singapore, the company has invested more than US$300 million to date, Mr Stein noted. "We will continue to make these investments as demand increases. We are near capacity with our very large data centre in Jurong, and as we reach full capacity in the near future, we will continue to invest and develop the data centre capacity in this market."

Mr Stein noted that besides Singapore, the company also sees Australia and Hong Kong as key markets. "We are also in Japan, with a site in Osaka, where we will have a fully finished data centre next year and we will continue to move into other cities in Japan, such as Tokyo. We see phenomenal growth prospects in this market. In addition to that, we're observing emerging markets in Asia-Pacific, which we will enter when the time is right and when market conditions make sense for us."

In September last year, the company announced that it had completed the acquisition of a 15,000-square-metre site in Osaka for US$10.5 million.

Commenting on the notion that Singapore could become a DC hub for the region, Mr Stein noted that the DC investment level is already very high in the country.

He, however, added that it's quite unlikely that any one country will become the DC hub for Asia-Pacific given that there is growth across the region. "Oftentimes, you could create bottlenecks in your own traffic and data transmission if you try to get everything consolidated in one part of the region. So by the nature of data proliferation and businesses thriving in different geographies, we will start to see decentralisation in parts of Asia-Pacific, and not so much a hub and spoke DC model in the region."

In terms of investment, there are many business models and ways of building DCs. Mr Stein said his company has, over the past 10 to 12 years, "perfected" how it develops DCs having created the third generation of its POD Architecture.

Regional realities

"Our DCs are built in a very energy-efficient manner, and in sizes that suit our customers' requirements. This won't change dramatically going forward. We may have to tweak the way we put our products in place, but that varies region by region. For example, Singapore, being constrained by real estate, will have more vertical builds where we will maximise the amount of land we use for building our DCs. However, we're still more driven by the power requirements and the IT load, than we are by physical floor space."

Mr Stein said DCs are starting to become ubiquitous in the way they are being located geography by geography. There will come a time where we will not notice them as they will become commonplace as the switching exchange of the future. We also see this powerhouse of data being very meaningful to businesses. Companies leveraging on the advantages of data technology will be winners in the years ahead, he added.

"For Digital Realty, the next five years present a huge opportunity. We've evolved substantially over the past 10 years and grown more than 10-fold. In Asia-Pacific, we've grown quite substantially."

"We have more than 80 professionals across the region now. We expect to see that continue. At the same time, we will need to be smarter about how we meet our customer's needs in how we help them drive their growth and profitability across the region and the world," said Mr Stein.

site_title: World Cup leaves traders on the bench
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

World Cup leaves traders on the bench

SGX average daily volumes hit a 12-year low

Published

Fri, Jun 27, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

IF you have been trading the market this World Cup, you might be somewhat lonely.

Trading volumes for the benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) have fallen by a record proportion not seen since 2002, an analysis by The Business Times for the past five World Cups shows.

"Football fever has definitely caught on a little more in Singapore," Kevin Foy, director of equity sales trading at brokerage Maybank Kim Eng, told BT.

Average STI volumes from the beginning of the World Cup on June 12 through June 24 amounted to just 140 million shares daily - 36 per cent below the 219 million average for the year so far.

The 2010 World Cup held in South Africa saw only a 15 per cent decline, by contrast. And the 2006 World Cup in Germany saw just a 7.5 per cent fall.

One would have to go all the way back to 2002 to find a worse return during the World Cup period. That year, STI shares traded fell a whopping 45 per cent in volume compared to the year's average.

But that was no surprise; the 2002 World Cup was held in Japan and South Korea - countries with time zones similar to Singapore's.

Given that World Cup matches are typically held from afternoon all the way into the night, the 2002 World Cup was a fantastic excuse to take the month off.

And while match timings this year are in the wee hours, that has not deterred fans from catching the games.

A lot of people are taking vacations in this summertime period and travelling to London or the USA, where the timings for the games are better, said Mr Foy.

"We are seeing a lot of empty desks," he said, noting that his office was around 30 per cent emptier than usual.

The USA fan, who missed his team's loss to Germany yesterday morning, added that he would probably stay up and catch the round of 16 match with Belgium next week.

So should traders sell in May and go away to watch the World Cup in June?

This may prove to be a wise choice, if you examine returns during the 2002 World Cup and this year's World Cup so far.

The 2002 World Cup period coincided with a precipitous market downturn.

Global stocks, represented by the MSCI World Index, fell 6 per cent during the World Cup period. Considering how global stocks fell 20 per cent the entire year - or roughly 2 per cent a month - the 2002 World Cup period was a bad time to stay long on the market.

Similarly this year, the STI is down about one per cent so far in this World Cup, compared to a 4 per cent gain year-to-date.

But STI traders who took a vacation during the World Cups of 2006 and 2010 missed out.

Despite a 15 per cent fall in volume that year during the tournament, STI stocks gained 4.3 per cent during that period, compared to 13.3 per cent for the entire year.

In short, traders could have made a third of the year's return in just one month in 2010.

In 2006, stocks also did better on average during the World Cup month, though less significantly so. They returned 4.6 per cent during the tournament, compared to 30 per cent for the year. So traders who went back to work were rewarded.

Fundamentally, however, the World Cup is not likely to play much of a difference on a mid- to long-term basis as performance still depends on the stocks, said Terence Wong, DMG & Partners head of research.

OCBC head of investment research Carmen Lee also noted that the June period usually sees a decline in trading activity, even without the World Cup, as it coincides with the mid-year school holidays.

While Singapore traders may like staying away from the market during the June-July World Cup season, those trading the MSCI World Index are more indifferent.

People trade the index whether there is a World Cup going on or not, and volumes do not necessarily fall during the summer season.

And for those who trade the index, returns are generally better during the World Cup month compared to an average month in that year.

As much as World Cup organiser Fifa expects record television audiences around the world - an average of 188.4 million per match was recorded in 2010 - not everybody in the world cares about the World Cup.

The Economist magazine noted in an article earlier in June that football is not a big preoccupation in the world's largest nations. The US has its own version of "football", on top of basketball, baseball and ice hockey among its top-watched sports. India is obsessed with cricket. And can you name a famous Chinese football team? Is Yao Ming a footballer?

So if you are more globally inclined and like the MSCI World Index, buy before the World Cup starts and go on a holiday; sell when you come back. For four of the last five World Cups, except for 2002, you would have beaten the monthly averages.

site_title: Business as usual in the Land of Smiles?
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Business as usual in the Land of Smiles?

What has been the impact, if any, of the protracted Thai political crisis on your business? How does your organisation handle political risks?

Published

Sun, Jun 1, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Pinaki Rath

Managing Director

Gold Matrix Resources Pte Ltd

DESPITE the political uncertainties in Thailand in the recent past, we at Gold Matrix have continued to invest there. By doing so, we have created immense goodwill which can only help our business in the long term. Admittedly, we have faced some problems but nothing that can break our resolve. Rather, it has been business as usual. There are smaller issues around commuting during the political demonstrations. Also, the province where our factory is located is a stronghold of the ''yellow-shirts'' brigade, which means that we have to live with absenteeism during the days when there had been demonstrations. That aside, we have faced no problems in dealing with the government machinery despite the political stalemate and the subsequent military coup. The wisest thing is to take insurance cover to mitigate the political risks but we are deterred by the prohibitive costs from doing so for Thailand. As a foreign investor, we tend to keep a low profile as we all well know the perils of collateral damage. Case in point is how the Taiwanese companies were mistakenly targeted for Chinese companies by miscreants in Vietnam during the recent riots there.

Lim Soon Hock

Managing Director

PLAN-B ICAG Pte Ltd

A COMPANY which I am involved in as a board member and senior adviser has been working on a project with the Thai government for some time now. It was at an advanced stage of negotiation and the contract would have been signed - had it not been for the removal of Prime Minister Yingluck and the ensuing military coup.

This is an example of how businesses can be negatively impacted when a country is plunged into political turmoil. There will always be an impact on business whenever there is political upheaval; it is a question of the degree and the industry the business is in. Countries doing business in Asean must pay particular attention to political and country risks.

Thailand has had a chequered political history. Businesses and the people are used to coups, of which there had been 12 since 1932 - an average of one in seven years. Although the frequency is high, the Thais have always been able to survive the coups. There will be short-term disruptions and hiccups to businesses, especially in the tourism sector, but the Thais have shown time and again that they have the resilience to ride out crises. The latest coup is probably the only effective and proven way for Thailand to resolve the impasse between the two opposing political parties.

I hope the well tested resilience of the Thais and their pragmatism will see them through this latest crisis. In this regard, Thailand is unique. Businesses would be in a worse-off situation if the stand-off continues. At least for now, businesses can take comfort in the fact that the National Council for Peace and Order is focused on returning the country to political stability, without which business cannot be properly conducted, especially for infrastructure projects.

The company which I am involved in did expect a coup to take place - we just did not expect it to happen so soon. We tried to expedite the negotiation, but the coup beat us to it. We have also adjusted our resources in line with the situation. That said, I believe it is a temporary setback; when the situation normalises, we can expect to resume negotiation, as the country must move on and move forward.

Florence Ng

Managing Director, Founder

Straits Talent Pte Ltd

IN our organisation, one thing is clear - no contract or business deal, regardless of its size and potential, is worth a human life. Never send any member of the staff anywhere that I myself am not prepared to be. Whether it is a military coup, potential war or terrorist zone, Sars, Mers or haze-infected area ... so long as there is a real threat to personal safety, then it is best to pull the plug on travel plans and let things calm down.

This is fundamental business-continuity planning and risk management. Yet sadly, many business leaders seem to think they and their teams are invincible. Thankfully, our business has negligible exposure to Thailand and, therefore, has not been impacted by the recent spate of heated political unrest.

That said, I personally spent an anxious four days keeping vigil as my husband had arrived in Bangkok the very day the military took over and imposed martial law. My ordeal did not end until he returned safely at the end of the week. During those four agonising days, a military coup was declared and various prominent political leaders detained. I thank the divine powers above for my husband's safe return.

While business might have been ''as usual'', it is not without a lot of anxiety. If one really has to be in the heat of the meltdown, then extreme caution is key, as is regular communication.

Christophe Duchatellier

CEO

Adecco Asia

THE recent crises in Thailand have prompted some concern in the country - but, for Adecco, it's business as usual with companies still operating and looking to identifying the best talent. On how our organisation handles political risks, our Thailand office has built a structured internal process where the senior team remains engaged with employers and employees regarding the changes taking place in Bangkok. Regular and timely updates are communicated to everyone, branch managers are empowered to make decisions such as early closing. The top priority for us in times like this is employee safety and security.

Natalie Shuman

Senior Vice-President, General Manager - EMEA & APAC

Kelly Services

OUR business in Thailand has thrived through several episodes of political turmoil, economic crisis and natural disasters since 1995. Any impact on the business so far has been short-term, lasting one or two quarters. Our business grew 48 per cent in 2006, the year the last military intervention occurred.

Thailand is essentially a consistently growing economy, a regional and global manufacturing/export base for a wide variety of goods. Political turmoil has not capped natural growth momentums for long, it seems. The resilience of the Thai people is another key factor lessening the negative impact on business.

In the current scenario where the country has experienced more than six months of political instability, the majority of our clients continue to hire, albeit more conservatively. Some opt for alternative hiring solutions to serve their needs better during the crisis. Kelly offers a wide range of services and solutions to ensure that clients' talent supply chain is appropriately managed under different circumstances.

Through all the crises, it is fortunate that none of our employees have been adversely affected. We anticipate a slowdown over the next few months as the country awaits clarity from the new military administration. A gradual rebound is expected from the fourth quarter. Our business outlook continues to be positive on Thailand.

Chris Comer

CEO

Castlewood Group

THE Royal Thai Army's decision to declare a coup was inevitable considering the political instability over the past six months. I feel this is precisely the right first step for what the country needs to initiate internal peace and unity and restore confidence among stakeholders. The declaration of a coup has attracted critics, but many locals have welcomed this move as they finally see a means to an end. Thailand is renowned for its history of political instability and it is well documented that this is how the Thais signal their desire for a change in political strategy.

From a business point of view, Castlewood Group has two projects in the region - our recently opened beach club, Nikki Beach Phuket, and our soon-to-be- opened Nikki Beach Hotel & Spa Phuket, which is in the final stages of construction. Contrary to reports of damage to tourism, our beach club is still in demand and construction of the hotel is going full steam ahead. Of course, since the volatility started six months ago, there has been a detrimental impact on tourism in parts of Thailand; however, Phuket has, in some ways, indirectly benefited from the upheaval, as the core unrest has been mainly in Bangkok.

From an economic standpoint we must try to keep things in perspective - Thailand is South-east Asia's second biggest economy, and the last time the country experienced a military coup in 2006, the economy retracted by 1.4 per cent as a knee-jerk reaction, but then bounced back to grow 4.5 per cent from its pre-coup level. Right now, with the relaxation of curfews less than a week after they were imposed, there's a sense that calm has been restored, which proves that the military made the right decision. Tourism is the backbone of Thailand's economy, so both the locals and the military understand the importance of restoring balance.

With our operations in Thailand we are fortunate to have a team on the ground and the feedback has been positive; indeed, keeping in the theme of the Thai military leader, ''it is definitely business as usual''. Overall, there has been no direct impact on our businesses, but we make sure that we are well equipped to keep abreast of any developments and ensure that all of Castlewood's investors remain well informed. In situations like this, communication is key.

Philippe Huinck

Regional Managing Director, South and South East Asia

International SOS

INTERNATIONAL SOS is advising some 22,000 members currently in Thailand or due to travel there in the next week. Most of the information requests seek our assessment of the situation and advice relevant to an organisation's specific locations and nature of operations, among other factors. We are also handling several cases relating to contingency planning and potential security and medical operational support.

Through our online membership Travel Security Online site, International SOS produces daily reporting on the issue, which contains timely validated information, our assessment and objective advice, such as:

Organisations with local offices in Bangkok should review their business continuity and crisis management plans and ensure they are able to locate and communicate with their staff in the country. For companies which have not thought about preparing their business travellers and do not have programmes in place to do so, we strongly advise them to do so now.

Joshua Yim

CEO

Achieve Group

BESIDES Singapore, we have operations in Malaysia and Hong Kong but not Thailand so the Thai political crisis has not had an impact on our business so far.

Companies that want to venture overseas should always conduct feasibility studies first. It is important to understand the lay of the land, and how stable the country is in terms of political and other factors. From there, weigh the potential risks that may occur further down the road. Having said that, business owners should note that all countries will have their own risks, even Singapore. As much as we can conduct feasibility studies and put in place certain contingencies, it is true that some risks may be unforeseen.

Thus, I would advocate that businesses spread their eggs in several baskets. For example, a manufacturing firm may want to consider having production facilities in two or three geographical locations so that in case one area is struck by an upheaval, there would be another facility that can continue to support the production requirements.

At Achieve Group, the nature of our recruitment and human resource consulting business is much more people-centric and we obviously operate in more mature cities. In the event that our business might be affected by a political upheaval like in Thailand, our modus operandi would be safety first for our people. We would need to lie low and instruct our people to stay away from work if need be.

Apart from people, the other most important element in our business is our database and confidential information of our clients so it is imperative that such information is always kept safe. These are the things we can do in our trade to mitigate such risks.

Mike Muller

President, Asia Pacific

Avaya

THE situation in Thailand clearly reinforces the need for businesses of all sizes to have flexibility in how they work as well as comprehensive recovery plans in place to ensure business continuity.

In an ever more mobile-centric world, employees need simple, secure access to essential collaboration tools regardless of their location or the device they are using. That means workers can be as productive on the road, at home, or at a customer's premises as they can be in the office. Video collaboration tools that people can access from any device to communicate with their team members, partners or customers as if they were face to face form an increasingly important element of this.

Mobile video has certainly helped the Avaya team in Thailand to stay active, productive and drive our business forward even when people are unable to get to the office. This flexibility helps not only in times of crisis. It helps many employees to work smarter and manage their professional and personal lives more effectively - whether they are parents juggling the demands of work and their kids, international business travellers or home office workers.

And the advantages are not limited to individuals. For example, when it is not possible for workers to reach a large customer service centre with hundreds or thousands of agents helping customers resolve important queries around the clock, the ability to have those agents connect from home and still deliver that essential service, or to have a back-up facility in a secondary location, allows the business to keep functioning effectively.

Political and environmental risks abound, across Asia Pacific and around the world - and many are completely unpredictable. Ensuring you have the right collaboration systems and back-up plans in place can make the difference between seamless business continuity and a complete suspension of operations.

Dora Hoan

Co-Chairman / Group CEO

Best World International Ltd

THE protracted crisis has severely affected consumer sentiments; they have developed a tendency to hold on to their cash. Therefore, demand for our lifestyle products, such as health supplements and skincare products, has been dampened. Fortunately, as our group's businesses are spread over many countries in Asia, we have spread our risks and avoided over-reliance on any one country. While we are sure that Thailand will bounce back from this crisis, we are adopting a wait-and-see attitude towards the market. We are also actively managing our sales to prevent losses from currency fluctuations.

site_title: Cloud can transform your business
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Cloud can transform your business

Published

Sun, Jun 1, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE disruptive force of cloud computing has vastly transformed the business landscape. The ubiquitous access of cloud infrastructure at a pay-as-you-use model has resulted in a level playing field for anyone with a great idea to experiment and start their business easily. Many young start-ups have re-defined business models with innovative solutions, created new business opportunities, and transformed the industry as they offer their solutions as a service to millions of users worldwide.

Companies that were start-ups a few years ago such as Dropbox, Pinterest, Spotify, Airbnb, Foursquare and Reddit, are now global businesses. All these start-ups have one common trait; they built their business using cloud computing services and have gone global.

Successful start-ups are growing user base in minutes and monetising services at a phenomenal pace, while disrupting traditional enterprise business models. This is a wake-up call for enterprises to re-evaluate their status quo and assumptions.

Enterprises need to seek new ways of using technology such as cloud computing to drive business growth. An increasing number of CIOs (chief information officers) are moving away from the traditional tasks of keeping the lights on for on-premises data centres or negotiating long-term contracts. The forward-looking CIOs are now taking the lead in embracing cloud computing and challenging their IT teams to think differently.

As we look at the strategies undertaken by CIOs around the world, there are seven broad IT approaches in cloud adoption:

Enterprises are moving their development and test environments into the cloud to reduce deployment time and cost. One example is Galata Chemicals, a global producer of polyvinyl chloride (PVC) additives that run their disaster recovery (DR) systems on the cloud. Unlike the traditional DR systems that often have a risk window during the testing phase, Galata is able to test DR procedures on demand in the cloud without the need to rebuild the DR environment after completing tests. By running DR solution on the cloud, Galata has reduced operational cost by about 70 per cent.

Enterprises can accelerate cloud adoption by starting new projects on the cloud. For example, Qantas wanted to develop an in-flight application that would aggregate and present passenger information to cabin crew to improve customer recognition captured on board the flight. Qantas started working on the application using cloud services in 2012 and was able to roll out the pilot programme to 20 people within 12 weeks.

The application is now used by nearly 1,000 cabin crew supervisors to capture incidents where a customer is not completely happy with the service they receive. The airline can then refer these situations to its customer care team to resolve proactively before the customer contacts them.

Another approach is supplementing existing applications running in data centres with cloud resources. BookMyShow, an entertainment ticketing company, uses cloud data warehouse service for fast query and analytics on huge amounts of usage data. The processed content is then integrated back to their on-premises application called Tableau for visualisation.

BookMyShow has saved tens of thousands of dollars by avoiding expensive data warehouse hardware and delivered quicker recommendations for their customers.

This is the reverse of the previous strategy, where applications built on the cloud reaches back to on-premises applications for resources. Samsung's Visual Display Unit adopted this method to develop and run their Smart Hub TV application.

When new customers subscribe to Smart Hub TV content, the financial transaction processing occurs on their on-premises systems and upon completion, content is delivered seamlessly from the cloud to their customers.

In this strategy companies have to decide which workloads to move to the cloud first and in subsequent phases. For example, Jollibee Foods Corporation migrated mission critical enterprise applications to the cloud.

Using cloud computing has streamlined its supply chain, reduced deployment time from several months to within minutes to meet all kinds of workloads and user demands.

Enterprises are beginning to consolidate their DCs. For example, News Corp is in the process of consolidating 40 DCs worldwide, consisting of thousands of servers, into six DCs.

They expect to save tens of millions of dollars in on-premises infrastructure costs by moving its ERP (enterprise resource planning) system to the cloud.

This strategy requires foresight and commitment from C-level executives to move their entire IT infrastructure to the cloud, and re-focus resources on what truly matters to their business. With the top executive support to embrace cloud computing, the entire organisation becomes aligned in one single vision to accelerate business transformation.

The above strategies have helped organisations transform their business. To stay competitive in this dynamic world, it is imperative that enterprises embark on their journey to adopt cloud computing quickly.

The writer is Asia-Pacific managing director of Amazon Web Services

site_title: Meaty Italian
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Meaty Italian

Buttero refers to the horse-riding shepherds in Tuscany who have been herding cattle for centuries. By JAIME EE

Published

Sun, Jun 1, 2014 · 10:00 PM

NEW RESTAURANT

Buttero

54 Tras Street

Tel: 6438-7737

Open for lunch and dinner Mon to Sat: 12pm to 3pm; 6pm to late (last order 10.30pm). Closed on Sun.

IT can't be easy coming up with restaurant concepts these days, when everything from Alpine cows to New Orleans revelry have been mined to add gloss and gimmickry to garden-variety European or American cuisine.

The latest in mutton-dressed-as-continental-lamb attempts to cross our dining path is Buttero - Tras Street's tribute to the Tuscan cowboy. No, don't rack your brains trying to remember the last time you saw an Italian gunslinger in a Clint Eastwood spaghetti western - or whether cowboys ever boiled pasta at camp in-between fighting Mexican banditos. Buttero refers to horse-riding shepherds in Tuscany, who have been herding cattle and looking after livestock for centuries, and there are still some around today.

In this context, however, it's just a fancy name for an Italian restaurant which can't decide whether it's a pasta joint, grill or American diner and settles for all three. And to make sure there are no territorial disputes over the menu's origins, an Australian chef is at the helm to maintain culinary diplomacy.

What ensues is a mishmash menu with no clear theme, although its anything-goes stance seems well-matched with its gritty-chic surroundings by Australian designer Barry Polson. Not quite cowboy, not quite Italian but tastefully funky, it stands out for its impressive wood-panelled open kitchen, quirky wall features and bathroom fixtures, and the large mural of an evil-faced pig-tailed girl by street artist Caratoes on the wall in front.

Whether intentional or not, the menu looks like a cheap diner menu in big font and loud colours, divided simply into sweets, pastas, entrees (appetisers), large plates (namely the grill items) and sides.

The starters, though, are sadly middling. A simple caprese salad ($21) promises a pop of Mediterranean flavour with heirloom tomatoes, buffalo mozzarella and basil but is instead muddled with the addition of hard chunks of fried cornbread with a vague porkiness that distract from the already bland tomato and cheese combo. An intriguing-sounding raw black kingfish soldiers ($20) seems too much like an uneasy Japanese-Middle Eastern coupling, with sashimi slices marinated in olive oil and sliced chilli that you wrap in a stodgy chickpea blini. Even the pleasant sweet pickled fennel cannot strike a flavourful deal between the two.

Faring a little better is the crumbed veal taco ($19) - a crunchy patty of shredded (slightly mushy) veal packed into a soft taco shell, offering a satisfying mouthful of corn pancake, crunchy meat patty and sweet acidity of cabbage apple slaw to counter the richness.

As for the pastas, the pappardelle spanner crab ($25) is what happens when a Tuscan cowboy starts whipping up his famous noodles with tomato sauce and forgets that, being in the livestock business, he has no crab. So good luck trying to find any in this so-so melange of wide pasta strips tossed in basic tomato sauce. A "black and white" pasta ($24) of squid ink and regular noodles in clam sauce also falls short. And unless you've had some dental work done, skip the mush balls posing as house-made gnocchi ($21) and just eat the nicely grilled Brussels sprouts bathed in a citrus honey dressing.

That said, Buttero fares best when it sticks to what its name represents. Chef Logan Campbell (incidentally one of the most well-mannered chefs we've come across) shows a stronger affinity with meats, especially from the grill. He does a pretty good porchetta ($32) using rolled pork loin with skin that falls a little short of crispy but is nonetheless meaty and tender with a good whiff of its herb rub. Braised beans round off this hearty main.

The dirty steak is probably the best item on the menu ($34) - a flatiron steak is done rare between its charred exterior but yields tender, flavourful meat. Zesty salsa verde with yoghurt and a brown sauce make for a tangy trio and proves there's potential for this place. That and the waffle fries, which are not to be missed.

We also like most of the desserts. Not so much the sandy textured cannoli filled with powdery cream, but the light vanilla panna cotta ($12) with super sweet nutty meringue cookie, strawberries and passion fruit, and the sticky chewy chocolate pot ($12) topped with vanilla foam scented with rosemary and served with a delicate crisp puff pastry stick on the side.

Besides a refining of menu, Buttero could also use a bit of a kick in the service side, which is haphazard although well-meaning, and an inhouse soundtrack with more than one solitary song that loops repeatedly as if they don't expect anyone to notice.

It's hard to tell on a packed Tuesday which is half-price wine night, but like cowboys who know when a calf is missing from their herd, little things can make a difference.

Overall rating:

6

site_title: Board evaluation - more can be done
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Board evaluation - more can be done

The main challenge is the perceived difficulty of having a rigorous process. By YVONNE GOH

Published

Sun, Jun 1, 2014 · 10:00 PM

IN the corporate world, it has long been the norm to have procedures for regular appraisal or evaluation of both staff and departments at various levels throughout the organisation.

It is only logical that the board of directors - being the highest governing body of a company which controls major resources, both financial and human - should also be subjected to a regular evaluation process.

The Singapore Code of Corporate Governance states that: "There should be a formal annual assessment of the effectiveness of the board as a whole and its board committees and the contribution by each director to the effectiveness of the board."

It is also recommended that a write-up of the board evaluation process be included in the company's annual report.

The process

Board evaluations are typically based around directors rating themselves, the other directors and the collective board, as well as the three principal committees (Audit, Nomination and Remuneration). This rating is done on a series of questions related to their responsibilities and functions as a board.

The results of this rating are then compiled and analysed and a report delivered to the Nominating Committee or the board.

There are two basic areas to look at in board evaluation: people factors and process factors. People factors tend to be by far the more important of the two in achieving an effective board.

On the people front, questions that should be asked include: How do the directors work as a team; what are their interpersonal skills; and is there a dominant chairman or CEO.

Process factors deal with things such as whether appropriate, timely and unbiased information, of the right length and quality, is provided to the board; whether there are sufficient board and committee meetings; and if they are conducted in a manner that ensures open communication, meaningful participation and timely resolution of issues.

Over-arching the people and process questions are those which are broader and more strategic. Questions such as:

Ensuring effectiveness

For the exercise to be of value, there should be a firm commitment and belief that formal annual evaluations and follow through of findings would go a long way to helping the board improve its own performance.

Therefore, serious thought and adequate time should be put into answering the questionnaires. Honesty is also important. To that end, directors are encouraged to articulate their views to support or justify the ratings they provide.

Well conducted evaluations have the potential to achieve various benefits, among other things, helping the board to:

Based on the results of the evaluation, a work programme incorporating recommendations that are to be undertaken, specifying who are responsible for which recommendations and the deadline for the recommendations to be implemented should be developed.

This provides a formal accountability and project plan for the board, which is more likely to result in the recommendations being put into action.

In practice

In Singapore, board evaluation is typically done on the board as a whole. Self and peer evaluations are avoided, probably because of our Asian culture which treasures politeness, humility and avoidance of conflict.

What is also not usually done is an evaluation of each director by the board chairman and of the board chairman by the directors. This, in my view, should be undertaken as boards mature.

The engagement of external facilitators and professional consultants to gather and analyse the findings can help to instill greater discipline and improve objectivity in the process. However, this is not normally done due primarily to cost considerations.

The most recent SID-SGX Board of Directors Survey 2013, which polled listed companies in Singapore, showed that there has been a shift from results-oriented emphasis of performance criteria towards more process-oriented factors when appraising boards.

The main challenge faced by boards in executing board assessment is the perceived challenge of having a rigorous process to pursue substance over form.

To further raise the level of corporate governance, transparency and accountability in Singapore, it is time to enhance the rigours of board evaluation by introducing some of these steps.

The writer is the second vice-chairman of the Singapore Institute of Directors

SUBSCRIBERS

How big data can improve life in 'smart cities'

Yi Shyan tells mayors S'pore experience at World Cities Summit

Anita Gabriel

Published

Sun, Jun 1, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Singapore will leverage big data to enhance the quality of life of its people as part of its efforts in urban transformation, says Senior Minister of State for National Development Lee Yi Shyan.

The information revolution and big data can be used in many areas such as transport, healthcare, education and hospitality in developing "intelligent or smart cities", said Mr Lee in his opening remarks at the World Cities Summit Mayors Forum (WCSMF) 2014 here yesterday.

One example is Singapore's homegrown Grab- Taxi, a taxi booking app that aims to revolutionise the industry by channelling passengers to taxi drivers.

"Commuters can benefit as they are able to book taxis from not just one but all companies, and enjoy a higher probability of booking," said Mr Lee, who is also the forum's chairman.

At the summit themed Liveable and Sustainable Cities: Common Challenges, Shared Solutions, which drew some 130 mayors and city leaders from all over the world, Mr Lee shared Singapore's journey in becoming a global and vibrant city from a "fledgling nation struggling with urban slums and poor infrastructure" in the 1950s and '60s.

Given its size and limited resources, Singapore is mindful of protecting its environment such as in the area of water and waste management. "Singapore's approach towards development has never been one that says 'development first and clean up later'," he said, citing the clean-up of the Singapore River, which has allowed for a reservoir in the heart of the city.

The development of Singapore as a "City in a Garden" also reflects its focus on environmental management and promotion of greenery.

Promoting a competitive economy by wooing investments and providing jobs for the people to achieve economic security and to be self-sustaining is a priority. Mr Lee added that efforts to promote multiracial harmony and assimilate new citizens with the mainstream of society also need to continue as society evolves and becomes more diverse.

He shared the Singapore story to highlight the need for mayors and city leaders to share the different approaches in overcoming challenges faced by cities, especially rapidly emerging cities in Asia.

At the forum's fifth edition, the participants discussed the importance of good governance and community engagement, and how smart technologies will contribute to urban development, said a statement issued by the World Cities Summit.

"Passion and people involvement are key . . . unless the people feel connected and proud, it's not much use," said Damon Thomas, lord mayor of the city of Hobart, Australia.

site_title: Fix software front-end from back: Forrester
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Fix software front-end from back: Forrester

It says people are realising getting mobile right is a back-end challenge, not a front-end one, reports VICTORIA HO

Published

Sun, Jun 15, 2014 · 10:00 PM

COMPANIES looking to spruce up their software front-ends should first examine their back-end IT architecture, says Forrester vice-president John McCarthy.

Mr McCarthy, who is the research firm's principal analyst working with CIOs (chief information officers), told BizIT that there has been a fundamental shift in mindsets among IT chiefs over the last nine months. They have realised that putting up a good digital "storefront" requires rethinking the underlying software on the server side.

Before, most efforts to redesign customer-facing software would have focused on facelifting the front interface. Now, companies are investing more resources in getting their software to work on more devices, from browsers on desktops to mobile devices.

For e-commerce, especially, this is crucial, given the rising transaction volumes performed over mobile phones and tablets, he said.

According to a study conducted by Nielsen in September 2013, South-east Asians spend an average of more than three hours per day on smartphones.

And nearly 530 million smartphones were sold across the Asia-Pacific in 2013, said research firm IDC. This made up 52 per cent of the total global shipping volume. "People are realising that getting mobile right is a back-end challenge, not a front-end one," he said.

Customers are expecting mobile sites and apps to be as robust as desktop versions because they are getting accustomed to transacting fully on the mobile.

To allow mobile software to retrieve data and work with back-end payment systems smoothly, the back-end software needs to be more modular, Mr McCarthy explained.

Older software and databases tended to organise information into unmovable blocks. Newer databases and systems are not structured so rigidly; by allowing data and processes to be organised in modules, a transaction can be "handed over" easily from the front-end ordering system, to payment, to the warehouse for delivery.

This is where natively digital firms, such as dotcom e-commerce players, are giving larger, traditional firms a run for their money, he pointed out.

Singapore cosmetics e-tailer Luxola, for example, has a system that tracks what users buy. For items that are purchased on a regular basis, it will push reminders and recommended items, to raise the potential final basket size and keep users coming back. These online players are showing end-users the power of crunching data; traditional firms are left hamstrung because they sunk costs into older systems that cannot be ripped out and replaced, he said.

To compound the effect, dotcoms that are already built on modular architectures can release software upgrades by the hundreds per year. Older firms are accustomed to upgrading their back-end systems several times a decade, in contrast, said Mr McCarthy.

"Customers are evolving faster than companies can catch up with. That's why firms are writing huge cheques for digital transformations, because they have so many legacy systems," he added.

And, it is not just digital retailers that need to consider their customer software strategies. Banks and airlines, for example, rely increasingly on customer-facing websites and mobile apps to serve customers.

"You have a few minutes to engage. If you turn a customer off, you'll have a hell of a time getting them back," Mr McCarthy says.

The leaders in the space are trying their best to cut the number of clicks that a user has to do. He pointed to taxi-calling app Uber, saying that the entire transaction from identifying your location to getting the cab can be accomplished within five clicks.

For banks and firms offering a large spread of services, they can start stripping down their sites by breaking down the range of services offered into smaller standalone apps.

This allows customers to be funnelled into light, express versions of their frequently used services, reducing the friction of transacting with the main "heavy" site, he said.

These mobile apps are generating about five to 10 times the traffic that the larger website does, because of that convenience, he said. He pointed to the example of traditional railway companies which display train timetables on the site. For the average customer, an information-laden site with timetables is not ideal.

"The customer just wants to go home, or go to work. If the back-end can figure out what 'home' means to the individual and display travel times from start to end, the site is a lot more useful and simple," he said.

According to Forrester figures, building these new systems will represent US$1 trillion in IT spending by 2017. Based on his experience of working with large firms, he estimates that just 10 per cent to 15 per cent of companies are doing well in providing good software. About 30 per cent are doing a decent job."The rest - the 50 per cent - are holding on for dear life," he said.

content:

Around Town

Published

Thu, Jun 12, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Pick of the Week

>Balik Pulau:

Many Singaporeans are not aware that Singapore was part of an archipelago, and one of 70 islands. Balik Pulau, the latest exhibition by the National Heritage Board seeks to change that by offering Singaporeans a look into the earlier days of those islands and the people who lived on them. The exhibition allows viewers to experience island life as it was - through video interviews with past inhabitants, uncommon archival pictures and artefacts such as boats, marine life specimens and personal keepsakes. It also chronicles the transformation the islands went through in tandem with Singapore's modernisation.

Balik Pulau runs till August 10, at the National Museum of Singapore.

The exhibition is open from 10am to 6pm daily. Admission is free.

Go to

www.nationalmuseum.sg

>Outings

Le Noir:

The exhilarating sensation Le Noir is back, with several new acts to keep the audience in anticipation. A theatrical experience with the aim of engaging audiences, Le Noir brings to the stage thrilling acts by the best cirque performers from around the world. One of the new acts added is The Wheel of Death, which will involve two acrobats performing high-risk feats on top and inside a pair of spinning wheels high above the stage.

Le Noir will be on till June 29 at the MasterCard Theatre, Marina Bay Sands. It will be held at 7.30pm on Tuesdays to Fridays; 3pm and 7.30pm on Saturdays; and 1pm and 5.30pm on Sundays. Tickets from S$70 to $395 and can be purchased from

sistic.com.sg

>Extant Phantoms:

Widely acclaimed American artist Gary Simmons unveils his first solo presentation in Singapore, Extant Phantoms. The exhibition will feature his early works such as his first chalk drawings done on blackboards, which hasn't been on display since its appearance in the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden in 1994. Simmons's earlier "erasure" drawings accentuate televised media's role in sustaining racial stereotypes, taking inspiration from vintage cartoons and mass culture.

Extant Phantoms runs till June 28 at Ikkan Art. The exhibition is open from 12pm to 7pm, from Tuesdays to Saturdays. Admission is free. Go to

www.ikkan-art.com

>A Little Talk:

A solo exhibition by up-and-coming Korean artist Jieun Park, A Little Talk is a collection of works of cityscapes, including the iconic skylines of Singapore, Paris and more. The works represent the feelings and moments Jieun experienced during her visits to these cities. Done using calligraphic brush strokes, acrylic paint and Korean paper canvas, Jieun uses the contrast of her materials to represent the contrast of isolation and intricacy in each city.

A Little Talk runs till June 29 at REDSEA Gallery. The exhibition is open from 9.30am to 9pm daily. Go to

www.redseagallery.com

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Brazil hopes for smooth opener as tournament finally kicks off

Clashes reported hours before opening game

Published

Thu, Jun 12, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SAO PAULO] After years of construction delays and budget overruns, the World Cup was set to kick off in Brazil this morning under a cloud of discontent at home even as happy foreign fans pour in for the tournament.

Brazil's national team were to host Croatia in the opening match at a newly built stadium in Sao Paulo whose cost and late delivery came to embody the troubled World Cup preparations.

Brazil is seen by many fans around the world as the spiritual home of soccer and hundreds of thousands will descend on the country for the month-long tournament, but until now the enthusiasm among Brazilians has been muted.

Many are angry over the US$11.3 billion spent on hosting the World Cup when basic social services are poorly financed.

Brazilian police and protesters clashed hours before the opening game with police firing noise bombs to disperse a crowd of about 200 demonstrators angry about government overspending.

The protesters were trying to cut off a key avenue leading to the Arena Corinthians where the match was to be played on the eastern edge of Sao Paulo.

Brazilians say the country will rally as soon as the action starts, especially if their team justifies its billing as favourite to win the tournament for a record sixth time.

"Just wait until Brazil starts winning. Then you'll see people in the streets," said Rogerio Souza, a fan in Sao Paulo, although he warned failure would cause more discontent.

"Brazilians only count titles. No one cares about second place. If they don't win the Cup at home, you'll see the criticism rain down".

President Dilma Rousseff dismisses complaints about the heavy spending and delays in preparing stadiums and airports, and is betting Brazil will put on a show on and off the field.

"What I'm seeing more and more is the welcome given to the teams and the happiness of the Brazilian people with our team," she said in a speech on Wednesday.

Yet the list of possible problems is long. In fact, hosting a successful World Cup may ultimately prove harder for Brazil than winning it.

The main risk, for both fans and the government, appears to be violent street demonstrations.

Protests and labour strikes are planned in the 12 host cities, including a 24-hour slowdown by some airport workers in Rio de Janeiro although the threat of a long subway strike in Sao Paulo has eased.

Some businesses in Rio, the venue for seven Cup games including the final, had boarded up windows and doors by late on Wednesday in case protests erupted.

Officials privately expressed fears that protests and traffic problems meant that some fans would still be stuck outside the Arena Corinthians in Sao Paulo when the opening match started.

The government had decreed a partial holiday yesterday to help ease congestion. Still, a long list of VIPs including 10 heads of state and senior officials from world soccer body Fifa meant traffic was still likely to be complicated.

The stadium itself has been a source of anxiety.

Not only was it delivered six months late at a cost of US$525 million, about US$150 million over budget, but because of the delays the opening game this morning was to be the facility's first at full capacity.

That's a big no-no in the field of logistics and a violation of Fifa's normal protocol for World Cup games.

"I'm praying that nothing goes wrong," said Lizbeth Silva, a clerical worker at a Sao Paulo school. "You hear about all these problems, but you still want to root for Brazil."

The stakes for Brazil go well beyond the World Cup itself.

Ms Rousseff is running for re-election in October, and a rough tournament would likely cause her popularity, already under duress, to fall further.

Polls show she currently holds a lead of about 10 percentage points over her likely rival if the vote goes to a second round, as most expect.

Any major logistical problems and unrest could also further dent Brazil's reputation among investors, which has suffered since a decade-long economic boom fizzled under Ms Rousseff.

Brazil's team, led by its exciting 22-year-old star striker Neymar, were heavily favoured to beat Croatia.

As the tournament progresses, the fervour of foreign fans, hordes of whom have already descended upon host cities, could also help ease any tension among Brazilians themselves.

Outside Rio's Maracana stadium on Wednesday, Brazilians cheered and whistled as an SUV with a Colombian flag draped atop it stopped at a red light.

"We wouldn't miss this for the world," said the driver, adding that he and his three passengers left Colombia by road nearly three weeks ago. - Reuters

IF employers needed any proof that the manpower shortage in Singapore is becoming more acute, last Friday's labour market report provided some.

Job vacancies rose to an eight-year high in the first quarter, continuing to outnumber job seekers. The 60,500 vacancies in March also made up 3 per cent of total labour demand, up from 2.6 per cent a year ago.

There is some consolation in the fact that there are now more job seekers chasing jobs. The unemployment rate rose to 2 per cent in March, and stood at a higher 2.9 per cent for residents. In the Ministry of Manpower's (MOM) view, this reflects how more residents (particularly less educated ones) have been encouraged by the greater availability of jobs and higher wages to get back into the labour market.

site_title: Deutsche Asset & Wealth joins physical ETF trend
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Deutsche Asset & Wealth joins physical ETF trend

Industry shift a sign of higher concerns over risks after financial crisis

Published

Thu, Jun 5, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE shift towards replicating exchange-traded funds (ETFs) with physical assets continues apace, with Deutsche Asset and Wealth Management announcing that it will no longer use swaps and derivatives to replicate 12 Singapore-listed funds.

The db x-trackers ETFs for the MSCI Japan, MSCI Pacific ex-Japan, MSCI Brazil, FTSE China 25, MSCI Korea, MSCI China, S&P/ASX 200, MSCI Taiwan, MSCI Philippines IM, MSCI Thailand, MSCI Malaysia and MSCI Singapore indices will be converted from synthetic to physical replication, Deutsche said yesterday.

This follows Deutsche's move in the first quarter to convert 18 European-listed ETFs.

Deutsche is not the only ETF provider moving in that direction. As early as December 2012, Lyxor began to switch some physical and swap-replicated European bond ETFs to a physical-only mechanism.

The industry shift reflects higher concerns about risks from investors after the global financial crisis. Because synthetic ETFs' returns hinge on derivative or swap agreements, ETF investors are exposed to the risk that whoever provided those swaps or derivative contracts may not be able to pay up.

In fact, the International Organization of Securities Commissions (Iosco) in 2013 recommended that regulators address counterparty risks of ETFs.

Physical replication, in which the fund holds the actual assets being tracked by its underlying index, does not face such counterparty risk.

But the use of physical replication tended to be restricted to simple indices whose assets could be easily traded. For benchmarks such as global or emerging indices, however, synthetic replication gained a stronger foothold because it allowed ETF providers to more efficiently track indices that are not as liquid or harder to access. For such cases, tracking error, or the ability of the index to accurately depict the performing of the underlying index, was better and costs were often lower as well.

Online trade journal ETFtrends.com noted that when Deutsche switched its Euro Stoxx 50 ETF to physical replication, the fund's expense ratio increased to 0.09 per cent from zero.

Deutsche said on Friday that the conversion will not affect the total expense ratios for the Singapore-listed ETFs.

Dell's latest products lift the bar on specs

Published

Sun, Jun 15, 2014 · 10:00 PM

LAST week, Dell unveiled a new range of end-user devices which included rugged laptops, AIO (all-in-one) desktops, mobile workstations and ultra-high 4K resolution displays.

Harjeet Singh Rekhi, general manager of Dell's End-User Computing business in South Asia, noted that with constantly evolving and dynamic workforces, consumers and companies alike demand computing power anytime and anywhere to achieve greater productivity.

"With our devices, Dell is committed to making a difference in our customers' lives by providing them with the best possible experience, through purposeful design and complementary solutions."

Prakash Mallya, chipmaker Intel's Malaysia and Singapore country manager for sales and marketing, added that owners of personal computing devices more than four years old in Singapore will benefit greatly from switching their PCs to the latest devices based on Intel architecture. "Since the very first desktop, personal devices have evolved into a wide variety of form factors to meet our every need ... From tablets to 2-in-1 devices, desktop to AIO PCs, we are experiencing a level of innovation never seen before."

He added that this year is going to be exciting for consumers. "Intel has and will continue to drive the evolution of the PC with our partners to provide low-power, high-performance devices."

Among the more interesting devices launched by Dell are a pair of ruggedised machines, the Latitude 14 Rugged Extreme notebook and the Latitude 12 Rugged Extreme convertible notebook. Both are powerful machines built to function in the harshest of conditions.

Constructed with robust materials, including impact-resistant ultra-polymers and sturdy magnesium alloy, these systems are built to withstand hazards such as dust, moisture, drops, vibration, extreme temperatures and other conditions faced by users in military, public safety, manufacturing or industrial settings. However, they do not come cheap. The Latitude 12 Rugged Extreme has a starting price of $5,580 while the Latitude 14 Rugged Extreme starts from $4,600.

For those who require computing power to run graphic and data-intensive workloads on the move, Dell has introduced the new 15" Dell Precision M2800 mobile workstation that, it claims, breaks cost barriers with workstation-class performance. Prices start from $2,018 excluding GST.

Dell also introduced two ultrasharp 4K monitors, the 32-inch UP3214Q and the 24-inch UP2414Q. The UP3214Q costs $4,949 while its smaller sibling UP2414Q costs $1,599.

The company also announced the availability of the OptiPlex9030 and OptiPlex3030 AIOs. Interestingly, more than 10 per cent of the device's chassis comprises recycled technological products, making it a leading product in the green effort.

site_title: MediShield Life a welcome addition
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

MediShield Life a welcome addition

Published

Thu, Jun 12, 2014 · 10:00 PM

CONSUMER surveys have time and again highlighted Singaporeans' deep anxiety over rising healthcare costs. In this context, MediShield Life has emerged as a welcome addition to Singapore's healthcare financing framework. Based on the recommendations of a review committee, the scheme will result in higher payouts and, consequently, lower out-of-pocket expenses for CPF members. This is thanks to bigger claim limits for a number of benefits such as ward costs, surgical procedures and outpatient cancer therapy. The removal of the age limit of 90 also enables the plan to offer life-long coverage, a boon at a time when people are living longer. Significantly, it steps into the breach to cover those with pre-existing illnesses, who today may suffer huge premium loadings or may be rejected by insurers outright.

Premiums are yet to be announced but already, there are assurances that they will be affordable. It is most likely that premiums can be funded by Medisave contributions. CPF members will have to take stock of their healthcare coverage. They are likely to question if they still need a private Integrated Shield plan. Premiums of private Shield plans were raised significantly last year. But those thinking of cancelling their plans should think twice. MediShield Life is structured as a catastrophic plan, unlike private Shield plans where benefits are paid on an "as charged" basis. Based on illustrations, MediShield Life could potentially cover as much as half of a large hospital bill. But the examples feature heavily subsidised B2 wards. Members should calibrate their expectations of benefits such as the choice of a private hospital or a Class A ward, alongside their insurance cover. A mismatch can be extremely costly.

Meanwhile, it is worth contemplating a portable medical scheme, as advocated by NTUC. At the moment, much duplication exists. Companies provide group cover for their staff, who in turn continue to pay for MediShield and private Shield plans that they are unlikely to claim on while they are employed. There exist a number of schemes where employers can make an additional contribution to employees' Medisave accounts, or pay the premiums of a Shield plan on employees' behalf. As the take-up of the schemes is reportedly poor, a tax incentive as suggested by NTUC may help. Certainly, small and medium enterprises in particular may benefit, as their company size and budget may limit their choice of a group plan.

To be sure, Singaporeans have good reasons to fret about healthcare costs. An ageing population means that medical expenses are likely to rise exponentially along with chronic illnesses. Many households do not qualify for heavily subsidised wards. Estimates of medical inflation of between 5 and 10 per cent are significantly higher than goods inflation, and costs at private hospitals are expected to rise at an even more rapid clip. Insurance is a must as a means to hedge this risk, but there is also the risk - as private Shield policyholders have recently seen - that premiums could rise to unaffordable levels. One way to ease this spiral is to encourage healthy living. Insurers can do their bit by offering no-claims discounts, for instance, similar to motor insurance. The responsibility for healthcare ultimately lies with individuals but every bit of help goes a long way.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Get chauffeured in a luxury marque

Tay Suan Chiang

Published

Fri, Jun 27, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Uber

www.uber.com/cities/singapore

App is available from Apple App Store and Google Play

IT is 9am on a rainy Tuesday morning, and you are running late for an event. The cab booking line is constantly engaged, and there are no taxis in sight anywhere. You begin to fret.

Getting a car from Uber could have saved you that morning anguish. Think of Uber as a private driver service - all it takes is one button on the app to get a car to get you from point A to point B. The service started in San Francisco four years ago and is now available in about 140 cities worldwide.

Here's how it works: Download the app, and register your particulars, including your credit card details, and select the pick-up location. The app shows how long a wait for a car will be. The wait for a car tends to be shorter in the CBD area where there are more cars available, whereas in the heartlands, the wait can be 15 minutes long.

Customers have two choices when it comes to the type of car they want. The UberExec which has a more premium range of cars, such as Porsche Panamera, BMW 5-Series and Mercedes Benz E-Class. The base fare for a trip is $7, plus $0.45/min and $1.95/km.

Then, there is the lower-priced option, UberX, which uses cars such as Toyota Corolla, Nissan Sunny and Mitsubishi Lancer. The base fare for a trip is $3.50, plus $0.40/min and $0.70/km.

Within minutes of booking a car, the driver calls to confirm your pick-up location, and turns up during the said time. You can also track the car's movement through the app. Hop into the car, get to point B, and head straight out to your event. There is no need to fumble for small change, as the fare is charged to the customer's credit card. A receipt is later emailed to the customer.

Michael Brown, Uber's regional manager says that Uber offers convenience. "Usually, it is only a five-minute wait for a car in the CBD, and you don't have to worry about parking. And there is no need to book in advance, either."

Regardless of the time of day, Mr Brown says that customers don't have to fret about not being able to get a car. During peak hours, as demand for cars start to increase, Uber's surge pricing kicks in. Fares will go up, based on an algorithm. Customers have the ability to use the app's fare quote option which will show how much more they will have to pay compared to a non-peak hour ride.

Customers have the option of choosing to wait, or to pay more, "and they will be guaranteed a car", says Mr Brown. Price surge ends when the demand has been met, and customers pay the original rate.

Mr Brown says that apart from convenience, customers are assured accountability and safety whenever they take a ride with Uber. Drivers are given a rating by customers, and errant drivers are known to have been removed from Uber's list.

And while Uber cars appear like private ones, "it won't be someone who is driving your grandmother's car that is coming to pick you up," he says.

Mr Brown says all Uber cars are commercially registered with the Land Transport Authority, and drivers are either employees or owners of limousine companies. He declined to disclose how many Uber drivers there are in Singapore, and would only say, "we have many hundreds".

He adds that while the price of a ride is about 1.5 to 2.5 times more than a regular cab, the Uber service is popular with those who have more disposable income and who want the convenience of a private driver.
